As the grass begins to turn green again after winter has passed, these tiny flowers dot up here and there. Now just look out your window at a patch of grass somewhere and think what a nice idea it would be to have your name spelled out in flowers once as a sort of early harbinger of spring. 	 	 	Grass grows in earlier than flowers. 	 	On-Yomi: ソウ   Kun-Yomi: くさ、くさ-、-ぐさ  	Examples: 草 (くさ)"
suffering	"suffering 	 	苦   	   	Lesson: 10   Frame: 239   Strokes: 8   —   Jouyou Grade: 3   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: suffering, flowers, old, tombstone, gravestone, church, ten, needle, mouth 	 	The picture of suffering we are given here is that of a flower that has grown old. When a flower ages, it pales and dries up, and probably even suffers. If you think that plants are incapable of such feelings, then ask yourself why so many people believe that talking to their flowers helps them bloom better. 	 	 	Flowers for the old man suffering in the hospital. 	 	On-Yomi: ク   Kun-Yomi: くる.しい、-ぐる.しい、くる.しむ、くる.しめる、にが.い、にが.る  	Examples: 苦しい (くる.しい), 苦しむ (くる.しむ), 苦しめる (くる.しめる), 苦い (にが.い), 苦る (にが.る)"
tolerant	"tolerant 	 	寛   	   	Lesson: 10   Frame: 241   Strokes: 13   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: tolerant, house, flowers, look, see, telescope, eye, human legs 	 	The house of flowers or ""hothouse"" has become a metaphor for a narrow-minded, biased, and intolerant attitude distrustful of change. Tolerance, in contrast, is open-minded and welcomes novelty. The way to encourage tolerance in those who lack it is first to have them see through their own hothouse attitudes, which is the very counsel we are given in this kanji. 	 	 	A tolerant person will ignore SEEing GRASS (marijuana) in the HOUSE of a friend. 	 	On-Yomi: カン   Kun-Yomi: くつろ.ぐ、ひろ.い、ゆる.やか"
dilute	"dilute 	 	薄   	   	Lesson: 10   Frame: 242   Strokes: 16   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: dilute, flowers, water, water droplets, water pistol, acupuncturist, specialty, drop, ten, needle, rice field, brains, glue 	 	Take a good look at this kanji: the ""strong"" element here is really the flower, not the water as you might have thought on first glance. To the right is the acupuncturist from frame 48. Taking the key word to connote diluting the vital humors of the body, we can imagine our acupuncturist performing his task with flowers in place of needles, and using their hollow stems to pipe water into the body of the patient. 	 	 	A Dr. missing his needle can only use dilute flower water for medicine. 	 	On-Yomi: ハク   Kun-Yomi: うす.い、うす-、-うす、うす.める、うす.まる、うす.らぐ、うす.ら-、うす.れる、すすき  	Examples: 薄い (うす.い), 薄まる (うす.まる), 薄める (うす.める), 薄らく (うす.らく), 薄れる (うす.れる)"
leaf	"leaf 	 	葉   	   	Lesson: 10   Frame: 243   Strokes: 12   —   Jouyou Grade: 3   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: leaf, flowers, Tarzan, generation, tree, wood 	 	Three elements are given here: flower . . . generation . . . tree. The first and last seem logical enough, since it is the leaf that feeds the flowers on a tree. The element for generation interposed between the two suggests that the movement of a tree from one generation to the next is like its ""turning over a new leaf."" 	 	 	On top of the leaves a flower appears, promising new generations for the old tree below. 	 	On-Yomi: ヨウ   Kun-Yomi: は  	Examples: 葉 (は)"
imitation	"imitation 	 	模   	   	Lesson: 10   Frame: 244   Strokes: 14   —   Jouyou Grade: 6   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: imitation, tree, wood, graveyard, flowers, sun, day, large, St. Bernard 	 	Ah, but haven't modern graveyards become a parody of their ancestors! The flowers are plastic, the writing on the stones is unimaginative and cold, and the whole thing looks more like a marble orchard than a right and proper graveyard. This kanji continues with the modernization trend by picturing imitation trees in the graveyard. But of course, how convenient! They don't need pruning or fertilizing, their leaves don't fall, and they remain the same color all year long. 	 	 	If I find out this furniture you´re selling me is made of imitation wood, I´ll put you in the graveyard. 	 	On-Yomi: モ、ボ   Kun-Yomi:   	Examples: 模範 (もはん), 模型 (もけい), 模倣 (もほう)"
vague	"vague 	 	漠   	   	Lesson: 10   Frame: 245   Strokes: 13   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: vague, water, water droplets, water pistol, graveyard, flowers, sun, day, large, St. Bernard 	 	Think of the key word as having to do with something viewed through a haze, or in the twilight and from a distance, so that only its outlines are vaguely discernible. Now we are back again to the essence of the true graveyard. The water may be taken as the sound of waves dashing up against the rocks or the dripping of moisture on cold rock - anything that helps you associate vagueness with the graveyard and keep it distinct from the imitation we met in the last frame. 	 	 	The precise locations of sailors who meet a WATERY GRAVE are vague. 	 	On-Yomi: バク   Kun-Yomi:"
grave	"grave 	 	墓   	   	Lesson: 10   Frame: 246   Strokes: 13   —   Jouyou Grade: 5   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: grave, graveyard, flowers, sun, day, large, St. Bernard, soil, dirt, ground 	 	The mounds of soil with crude wooden crosses set at their head suggests those boot-hill graves we all know from cowboy lore. The only odd thing about this kanji is that the soil comes UNDER the graveyard, rather than to its left, where we might expect. Just think of the bodies as ""lying under boot-hill"" if you have any trouble. By the way, this is not the first time, nor will it be the last, that we learn a kanji whose key word is the same, or almost the same, as a primitive element based on it, but whose shape differs somewhat. There is no cause to worry. By using the primitive in a variety of other characters, as we have done here, the confusion will be averted as a matter of course. In most cases, as here, the primitive element is taken from a part of the fuller kanji. 	 	 	The soil under a graveyard is full of graves. 	 	On-Yomi: ボ   Kun-Yomi: はか  	Examples: 墓 (はか)"
livelihood	"livelihood 	 	暮   	   	Lesson: 10   Frame: 247   Strokes: 14   —   Jouyou Grade: 6   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: livelihood, graveyard, flowers, sun, day, large, St. Bernard, sun2, day2 	 	Imagine that you have chosen the occupation of the keeper of a graveyard and spend your days tending to other's dead hood in order to make your means of livelihood. 	 	 	He made a livelihood out of robbing GRAVEYARDS in broad DAYlight. 	 	On-Yomi: ボ   Kun-Yomi: く.れる、く.らす  	Examples: 暮らす (く.らす), 暮れる (く.れる)"
membrane	"membrane 	 	膜   	   	Lesson: 10   Frame: 248   Strokes: 14   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: membrane, moon, month, flesh, part of the body, graveyard, flowers, sun, day, large, St. Bernard 	 	The part of the body first affected by a stroll through a haunted graveyard is the skin, which gets goose bumps. But we save the word ""skin"" for another kanji, and use the odd word ""membrane"" here. Think of being so scared through and through that the goose flesh moves from the outside in, giving you goose membranes. 	 	 	In the moonlight of the graveyard I hear a zombie say, MMMMM..EMM...BRANEsssss. 	 	On-Yomi: マク   Kun-Yomi:"
seedling	"seedling 	 	苗   	   	Lesson: 10   Frame: 249   Strokes: 8   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: seedling, flowers, rice field, brains 	 	To avoid confusion with the image of rice seedlings to appear later, we shall take these seedlings out of their agricultural setting in the rice fields and into the frame of Brave New World surgery, where ""ideas"" or ""values"" are being implanted into brains like seedlings to insure a harmonious society. Then you need only imagine them taking root and breaking out into flower right through the tops of the skulls of people walking around on the streets. 	 	 	If you plant seedlings in a FIELD eventually they will FLOWER. 	 	On-Yomi: ビョウ、ミョウ   Kun-Yomi: なえ、なわ-  	Examples: 苗 (なえ)"
portent	"portent 	 	兆   	   	Lesson: 11   Frame: 250   Strokes: 6   —   Jouyou Grade: 4   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: portent, turtle, portent 	 	Here we have a pictograph of the back of a turtle, the two sloping vertical strokes representing the central ridge and the four short strokes the pattern. Think of reading turtle shells as a way to foretell the future, and in particular things that portend coming evils. 	  * When this character is used as a primitive in its full form, we keep the key-word sense of a portent. When it appears to the left in its abbreviated form (namely, the left half only), we shall give it the pictographic sense of a turtle. 	 	When your wife´s LEGs get huge hairs on them it is surely a bad portent for things to come. 	 	On-Yomi: チョウ   Kun-Yomi: きざ.す、きざ.し  	Examples: 兆し (きざ.し), 兆す (きざ.す)"
peach tree	"peach tree 	 	桃   	   	Lesson: 11   Frame: 251   Strokes: 10   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: peach tree, tree, wood, portent, turtle 	 	To associate the peach tree with the primitive for a portent, recall the famous Japanese legend of Momotarō, the Peach Boy. It begins once upon a time with a fisherman and his wife who wanted badly to have a child, but none was born to them. Then one day the old man caught a giant peach, out of which jumped a healthy young lad whom they named Peach Boy. Though the boy was destined to perform heroic deeds, his birth also portended great misfortune (how else could he become a hero?). Thus the tree that is associated with a portent of coming evil comes to be the peach tree. 	 	 	The pits of a peach tree look like turtles. 	 	On-Yomi: トウ   Kun-Yomi: もも  	Examples: 桃 (もも)"
stare	"stare 	 	眺   	   	Lesson: 11   Frame: 252   Strokes: 11   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: stare, eye, portent, turtle 	 	To give someone the ""evil eye"" is to stare at them, wishing them evil. The roots of the superstition are old and almost universal throughout the cultures of the world. In this kanji, too, being stared at is depicted as an eye that portends evil. 	 	 	Sauron´s One fiery eye stare at Frodo and it is a sign of portent. Evil will become whomever the eye is staring upon. 	 	On-Yomi: チョウ   Kun-Yomi: なが.める  	Examples: 眺める (なが.める)"
dog	"dog 	 	犬   	   	Lesson: 11   Frame: 253   Strokes: 4   —   Jouyou Grade: 1   JLPT: 4   	Constituents: dog, large, St. Bernard, drop 	 	We know that the character for large takes on the meaning of the St. Bernard dog when used as a primitive. In this frame we finally see why. The drop added as a fourth and final stroke means that we have to do with a normal-sized dog, which compared to the St. Bernard is no more than a drop in the kennel. 	  * As a primitive this character can take two meanings. In the form given here it will mean a very small dog (which we shall refer to as a chihuahua for convenience sake). When it takes the form 犭 to the left of a character, we shall give it the meaning of a pack of wild dogs. 	 	A large dog, dripping drool. 	 	On-Yomi: ケン   Kun-Yomi: いぬ、いぬ-  	Examples: 犬 (いぬ)"
status quo	"status quo 	 	状   	   	Lesson: 11   Frame: 254   Strokes: 7   —   Jouyou Grade: 5   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: status quo, turtle, chihuahua, dog, large, drop 	 	Did you ever hear of the turtle who fell madly in love with a chihuahua but could not have her because their two families did not like the idea of their children intermarrying? Like all classic stories of ill-fated love, this one shows how the young upset the status quo with an emotion older and more powerful than anything their elders have devised to counter it: blind love. 	 	 	It was left to the turtle to make right with the dog and thus maintain the status quo.. 	 	On-Yomi: ジョウ   Kun-Yomi:"
silence	"silence 	 	黙   	   	Lesson: 11   Frame: 255   Strokes: 15   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: silence, black, computer, chihuahua, dog, large, drop, oven-fire, barbecue 	 	Oddly enough, the character for silence shows us a black chihuahua. Actually, the cute little critter's name is Darkness, as I am sure you remember from the famous song about silence that begins, ""Hello, Darkness, my old friend...."" Note how the four dots reach all the way across the bottom of the character. 	 	 	The computer won´t stop beeping, which is making the chihauhua bark, and it´s driving this guy insane. The only solution he can come up with is to throw them both on the fire and finally enjoy the silence. 	 	On-Yomi: モク、ボク   Kun-Yomi: だま.る、もだ.す  	Examples: 黙る (だま.る)"
sort of thing	"sort of thing 	 	然   	   	Lesson: 11   Frame: 256   Strokes: 12   —   Jouyou Grade: 4   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: sort of thing, moon, crescent moon, month, flesh, part of the body, chihuahua, dog, large, drop, oven-fire, barbecue 	 	The key word in this frame refers to a suffix that gives the word before it an adjectival quality; hence we refer to it as ""sort of thing."" Reverting to the time when dog was more widely eaten than it is today (See frame 127), we see here a large cauldron boiling over an oven flame with the flesh of a chihuahua being thrown into the whole concoction to make it into a ""hot-diggity, dog-diggity"" sort of thing. 	 	 	Flesh of a dog over a cooking fire = ""hotdog"". There are all sorts of things in hot dogs. Believe me, you don´t want to know what sort of things . Visualize the hotdog curling as it cooks, to remember the unusual way the flesh primitive curves in this kanji. (tweaked version of ziggr´s. Thanks!). 	 	On-Yomi: ゼン、ネン   Kun-Yomi: しか、しか.り、しか.し、さ  	Examples: 当然 (とうぜん), 自然 (しぜん), 必然 (ひつぜん)"
reed	"reed 	 	荻   	   	Lesson: 11   Frame: 257   Strokes: 10   —   Jouyou Grade: Names   JLPT:    	Constituents: reed, flowers, pack of wild dogs, fire 	 	You've no doubt seen cattails, those swamp reeds with a furry flower to them like the tail of a cat. This might just turn out to be a good way to get rid of a troublesome pack of wild dogs: lure them into a swamp of these reeds with the cattail flowers and then set fire to the swamp. Take care to focus on the flower rather than the ""cattail"" to avoid confusion with frame 259 below. 	 	 	REEDS are the only FLOWERS that WILD DOGS like to FIRE up and smoke while they are playing poker. 	 	On-Yomi: テキ   Kun-Yomi: おぎ"
hunt	"hunt 	 	狩   	   	Lesson: 11   Frame: 258   Strokes: 9   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: hunt, pack of wild dogs, guard, house, glue 	 	One of the worst problems you have to face when you go hunting is to guard your take from the wild dogs. If you imagine yourself failing at the task, you will probably have a stronger image than if you try to picture yourself succeeding. 	 	 	Actually when hunting it may be a good idea to use a pack of dogs as your personal guard. 	 	On-Yomi: シュ   Kun-Yomi: か.る、か.り、-が.り  	Examples: 狩り (か.り), 狩る (か.る)"
cat	"cat 	 	猫   	   	Lesson: 11   Frame: 259   Strokes: 11   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: cat, pack of wild dogs, seedlings, flowers, rice field, brains 	 	Knowing how much dogs love to chase cats, picture a pack of wild dogs planting ""cat-seedlings,"" watering them, and fertilizing them until they can be harvested as a crop of cats for them to chase and torment. If you begin from the key word and think of a ""crop of cats,"" you will not confuse this story with the apparently similar story of two frames ago. 	 	 	The cat hid in the FLOWERS of the FIELD from the WILD DOGs. 	 	On-Yomi: ビョウ   Kun-Yomi: ねこ  	Examples: 猫 (ねこ)"
cow	"cow 	 	牛   	   	Lesson: 11   Frame: 260   Strokes: 4   —   Jouyou Grade: 2   JLPT: 4   	Constituents: cow 	 	Can you the ""doodle"" of a cow that has just been run over by a steamroller? The small dot in the first stroke shows its head turned to one side, and the next two strokes, the four legs. 	  * As a primitive, the same sense of cow is kept. Note only that when it is placed OVER another element, its tail is cut off. In this case, and when the element appears on the left, the stroke order is changed. 	 	A cow tried to climb up a vermilion tree, but in doing so, it broke its two bottom branches off. 	 	On-Yomi: ギュウ   Kun-Yomi: うし  	Examples: 牛 (うし)"
special	"special 	 	特   	   	Lesson: 11   Frame: 261   Strokes: 10   —   Jouyou Grade: 4   JLPT: 4   	Constituents: special, cow, Buddhist temple, soil, dirt, ground, glue 	 	Despite the strong phonetic similarity, there will be no problem keeping the key word special distinct from the character we met earlier for specialty (Frame 47), since the latter has immediate connotations lacking in this kanji. Anyway, we shall let the key word of this frame refer to something in a special class all its own - like the sacred cows of India that wander freely without fear of being butchered and ground into hamburger. Even though the practice is originally a Hindu one, and in any case no longer followed among the majority of Japanese Buddhist monks, the Buddha's refusal to take the life of any sentient being makes it only fitting that the cows should be placed on the sacred grounds of a Buddhist temple in this kanji. 	 	 	Think of not special people, but special animals. The sacred Hindu cows are special - they can wander around the temple without fear of becoming roast beef. 	 	On-Yomi: トク   Kun-Yomi:"
revelation	"revelation 	 	告   	   	Lesson: 11   Frame: 262   Strokes: 7   —   Jouyou Grade: 4   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: revelation, cow, mouth 	 	Folklore throughout the world tells us of talking animals who show a wisdom superior to that of human beings, and that same tradition has found its way into television shows and cartoons right into our own century. This character depicts revelation through the mouth of a cow, suggesting oracular utterances about truths hidden to human intelligence. 	 	 	The revelation makes the cow´s mouth drop down, ""Hamburgers are made of what?!"". 	 	On-Yomi: コク   Kun-Yomi: つ.げる  	Examples: 告げる (つ.げる)"
before	"before 	 	先   	   	Lesson: 11   Frame: 263   Strokes: 6   —   Jouyou Grade: 1   JLPT: 5   	Constituents: before, cow, human legs 	 	Take this key word in its physical, not its temporal, sense (even though it refers to both). If you have a cow with human legs, as the elements show us here, it can only be because you have two people in a cow-suit. I always thought I'd prefer to be the one standing before, rather than the one that holds up the rear and becomes the ""butt"" of everyone's laughter. 	 	 	I´ve never seen a cow with human legs before! 	 	On-Yomi: セン   Kun-Yomi: さき、ま.ず  	Examples: 先 (さき)"
wash	"wash 	 	洗   	   	Lesson: 11   Frame: 264   Strokes: 9   —   Jouyou Grade: 6   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: wash, water, water droplets, water pistol, before, cow, human legs 	 	This character is so logical that one is tempted to let the elements speak for themselves: water . . . before. But we have already decided we will not allow such rationalism to creep into our stories. Not even this once. Instead, let us change the character from the Peanuts comic strip called ""Pigpen,"" who is always preceded by a little cloud of dust and grime, and rename him ""Wash-Out."" Everywhere he walks, a spray of water goes before him to sanitize everything he touches. 	 	 	In Japan, you always wash with water from the shower before you enter the bathtub. 	 	On-Yomi: セン   Kun-Yomi: あら.う  	Examples: 洗う (あら.う)"
jammed in	"jammed in 	 	介   	   	Lesson: 12   Frame: 265   Strokes: 4   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: jammed in, umbrella, stick, walking cane 	 	The idea of something getting jammed into something else is depicted here by having a walking stick get jammed into an umbrella frame by someone shoving it into an already occupied slot in the umbrella stand at the door. First notice the vertical strokes: on the left is the curved umbrella handle, and on the right the straight walking stick. Now try to imagine the two parties tugging at their respective properties like two kids on a wishbone, creating a scene at the entrance of an elegant restaurant. 	 	 	The two strokes at the bottom look like a J and I, which stands for ""jammed in."". 	 	On-Yomi: カイ   Kun-Yomi:"
world	"world 	 	界   	   	Lesson: 12   Frame: 266   Strokes: 9   —   Jouyou Grade: 3   JLPT: 4   	Constituents: world, rice field, brains, jammed in, umbrella, stick, cane 	 	As the world gets jammed with more and more people, there is less and less space. Imagine yourself taking an air flight over a world so densely populated that every bit of it is sectioned off like a gigantic checkerboard (the rice fields). If you look closely at the character, you should be able to see a kind of movement taking place as still more is being jammed into that already narrow space. 	 	 	One Japanese farmer I know is so small minded that he thinks the entire world is JAMMED IN the borders of his little RICE FIELD. 	 	On-Yomi: カイ   Kun-Yomi:"
tea	"tea 	 	茶   	   	Lesson: 12   Frame: 267   Strokes: 9   —   Jouyou Grade: 2   JLPT: 4   	Constituents: tea, flowers, umbrella, wooden pole 	 	As everyone knows, tea is made from tea leaves. But the tea plant itself has its own flowers, which can be quite beautiful and add a special flavor to the tea, as the Chinese found out already over 4,598 years ago. With the image of a terrace of flowering tea bushes in mind, picture a number of brightly painted and very l-o-n-g wooden poles (Frame 207) placed here and there in their midst, with a tiny umbrella at the top to shade the delicate-tasting tea flowers. 	 	 	Some people think drinking tea is boring and quaint. That´s why I spice mine up by adding a cocktail umbrella, which of course is made from a wood-en toothpick supporting a paper umbrella with flowers printed on top. 	 	On-Yomi: チャ、サ   Kun-Yomi:   	Examples: 茶色 (ちゃいろ), 茶番劇 (ちゃばんげき), 番茶 (ばんちゃ)"
fit	"fit 	 	合   	   	Lesson: 12   Frame: 269   Strokes: 6   —   Jouyou Grade: 2   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: fit, meeting, umbrella, one, mouth 	 	The kanji for fit reads literally, top to bottom, as a meeting of mouths - which is a rather descriptive way of speaking of a romantic kiss. We all know what happens when there is no meeting of minds and when people's ideas don't fit with one another. But this kanji invites us to imagine what would happened to the romance of a certain unfortunate couple whose mouths didn't fit. 	 	 	I wouldn´t mind a meeting of mouths with her, she´s really fit ! 	 	On-Yomi: ゴウ、ガッ、カッ   Kun-Yomi: あ.う、-あ.う、あ.い、あい-、-あ.い、-あい、あ.わす、あ.わせる、-あ.わせる  	Examples: 合同 (ごうどう), 合計 (ごうけい), 結合 (けつごう), 合併 (がっぺい), 合宿 (がっしゅく), 合点 (がてん), 合う (あ.う), 合わす (あ.わす), 合わせる (あ.わせる)"
pagoda	"pagoda 	 	塔   	   	Lesson: 12   Frame: 270   Strokes: 12   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: pagoda, soil, dirt, ground, flowers, fit, meeting, umbrella, one, mouth 	 	On the left we see a mound of dirt, and to the right flowers made to fit together. The two sides combine to create a great pagoda made of dirt, with flowers by the tens of thousands fitted together for the roofing of each of the layers. Be sure to put yourself in the scene and fit a few of the flowers in place yourself so that the image works its way into memory with full force. 	 	 	In order to build a pagoda in this small Japanese garden everything has to fit: the soil to the left and the flowers in the upper right corner. 	 	On-Yomi: トウ   Kun-Yomi:"
king	"king 	 	王   	   	Lesson: 12   Frame: 271   Strokes: 4   —   Jouyou Grade: 1   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: king, jewel, ball 	 	See what you can do to come up with a pictograph of a king's scepter here that suits your own idea of what it should look like. You might even begin with the basic element for I beam and then try to fit the remaining third stroke in. 	  * As a primitive, this can mean either king or scepter, but it will usually be taken to mean ball, as an abbreviation of the character in the next frame. 	 	To be king you have to be a real crafty one ! 	 	On-Yomi: オウ、ノウ   Kun-Yomi:"
jewel	"jewel 	 	玉   	   	Lesson: 12   Frame: 272   Strokes: 5   —   Jouyou Grade: 1   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: jewel, king, jewel, ball, earring, drop 	 	Note the drop here in the king's scepter, which is exactly what you would expect it to be: a precious jewel handed down from of old as a symbol of his wealth and power. 	  * As a primitive, we can use this to mean either jewel or ball. When it appears anywhere other than on the left side of a kanji, it takes the same shape as here. On the left, it will be lacking the final stroke, making it the same as the character in the previous frame. 	 	The king is said to have only one family jewel below the belt... 	 	On-Yomi: ギョク   Kun-Yomi: たま、たま-、-だま  	Examples: 玉 (たま)"
treasure	"treasure 	 	宝   	   	Lesson: 12   Frame: 273   Strokes: 8   —   Jouyou Grade: 6   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: treasure, house, king, jewel, ball, earring, drop 	 	Every house has its treasure, as every thief knows only too well. While the things we treasure most are usually of sentimental value, we take the original sense of the term treasure here and make it refer to jewels kept in one's house. 	 	 	On treasure island is a single house - where all the jewels are stored. 	 	On-Yomi: ホウ   Kun-Yomi: たから  	Examples: 宝 (たから)"
pearl	"pearl 	 	珠   	   	Lesson: 12   Frame: 274   Strokes: 10   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: pearl, king, jewel, ball, vermillion, drop, not yet, one, tree, wood 	 	Take care to keep the meaning of this kanji distinct from that for jewel. Think of the most enormous pearl you have ever seen, a great vermilion-colored ball sitting on your ring and making it extremely difficult to move without falling over from the weight of the thing. 	 	 	The king of the Oysters produces special Vermillion pearls! 	 	On-Yomi: シュ   Kun-Yomi: たま"
present	"present 	 	現   	   	Lesson: 12   Frame: 275   Strokes: 11   —   Jouyou Grade: 5   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: present, king, jewel, ball, see, telescope, eye, human legs 	 	Do not think of a ""gift"" here, but of the present moment, as distinct from the future and the past. The kanji gives us a ball in which we see the present - obviously a crystal ball that enables us to see things going on at the present in faraway places. 	 	 	The KING ... can SEE clearly the PRESENT state of affairs in the land. (maybe he hees them in the crystal ball on the left?). 	 	On-Yomi: ゲン   Kun-Yomi: あらわ.れる、あらわ.す、うつつ、うつ.つ  	Examples: 現す (あらわ.す), 現れる (あらわ.れる)"
lunatic	"lunatic 	 	狂   	   	Lesson: 12   Frame: 277   Strokes: 7   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: lunatic, pack of wild dogs, king, jewel, ball 	 	A lunatic is literally one driven mad by the light of the moon, and the most famous of the ""looneys"" are the legendary lycanthropes or ""wolfmen."" Sometimes the transformation is only a temporary phenomenon, sometimes it is permanent. In the latter case, the poor chap takes off on all fours to live with the beasts. To remember this kanji, imagine one of these lycanthropes going looney and setting himself up as king of a pack of wild dogs that roams about and terrorizes innocent suburban communities. 	 	 	Oh no ! A pack of dogs has bitten the king. He has turned into a rabid lunatic ! 	 	On-Yomi: キョウ   Kun-Yomi: くる.う、くる.おしい、くるお.しい  	Examples: 狂う (くる.う), 狂おしい (くる.おしい)"
emperor	"emperor 	 	皇   	   	Lesson: 12   Frame: 279   Strokes: 9   —   Jouyou Grade: 6   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: emperor, white, dove, king, jewel, ball 	 	An emperor, as we all know, is a ruler - something like a king but higher in status. The white bird perched above the king, elevating him to imperial heights, is the messenger he sends back and forth to the gods to request advice and special favors, something that white birds have long done in folklore throughout the world. 	 	 	Ancient Rome had Emperors instead of Kings, and they wore white robes. Thus an emperor is a king in white. (make sure you picture a roman emperor not a japanese one and you´ll be ok). 	 	On-Yomi: コウ、オウ   Kun-Yomi:   	Examples: 皇帝 (こうてい), 皇室 (こうしつ), 皇后 (こうごう)"
display	"display 	 	呈   	   	Lesson: 12   Frame: 280   Strokes: 7   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: display, mouth, king, jewel, ball 	 	The trick to remembering this character lies in associating the key word with the line from the nursery rhyme about 4 and 20 blackbirds baked in a pie: ""Wasn't this a dainty dish to set before the king?"" If we think of display in terms of that famous line, and the king with his head thrown back and his mouth wide open as 4 and 20 blackbirds fly in one after the other, we shall have satisfied both the elements and their position. 	 	 	The mouth of the king is displaying his bling. 	 	On-Yomi: テイ   Kun-Yomi:"
whole	"whole 	 	全   	   	Lesson: 12   Frame: 281   Strokes: 6   —   Jouyou Grade: 3   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: whole, umbrella, king, jewel, ball 	 	Wholeness suggests physical and spiritual health, ""having your act together."" The kanji-image for wholeness depicts being ""king under your own umbrella,"" that is, giving order to your own life. I know it sounds terribly abstract, but what could be more abstract than the word whole? 	 	 	The fat king hogs the whole space under his umbrella. (tweaked version of radical tyro´s story. ""fat"" makes a more vivid image for me.). 	 	On-Yomi: ゼン   Kun-Yomi: まった.く、すべ.て  	Examples: 全く (まった.く)"
plug	"plug 	 	栓   	   	Lesson: 12   Frame: 282   Strokes: 10   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: plug, tree, wood, whole, umbrella, king, jewel, ball 	 	Here we think of plug in the sense of a cork or stopper used to seal the mouth of a bottle, water faucet, or something with liquid running out of it. Forgetting the abstract picture of the former frame, let us work with all the primitive units: tree . . . umbrella . . . ball. Imagine a tree with a faucet in the side out of which tennis balls are flowing, bouncing all over the ground by the hundreds. You fight your way up to it and shove your giant beach umbrella into the tree to plug it up. 	 	 	The fat king under his umbrella offers useless advice to the workers. ""You´ll need the whole tree to plug that gap"". Imagine a grossly fat, incompetent king under a parasol giving annoying advice to sweating workers who know what they´re doing. (I always have trouble bringing up the ""whole"" primitive. This story reminds me how to build that part. ). 	 	On-Yomi: セン   Kun-Yomi:"
logic	"logic 	 	理   	   	Lesson: 12   Frame: 283   Strokes: 11   —   Jouyou Grade: 2   JLPT: 4   	Constituents: logic, king, jewel, ball, computer 	 	We first referred to this character back in frame 185, to which you might want to return to have a peek. The image of logic we are given is something like a central jewel in a computer, like the jewels in old clocks that keep them running smoothly. Try to picture yourself making your way through all the rams and roms and approaching this shining jewel, a chorus of voice sand a blast of trumpets in the background heralding the great seat of all-knowing logic. 	 	 	The king of LOGIC is the computer. 	 	On-Yomi: リ   Kun-Yomi: ことわり"
lord	"lord 	 	主   	   	Lesson: 12   Frame: 284   Strokes: 5   —   Jouyou Grade: 3   JLPT: 4   	Constituents: lord, drop, king, jewel, ball 	 	A man's home is his castle, goes the proverb from an age where it was the male who was lord of the household. Fundamentally, it means only that every one of us is a bit (or drop) of a king in our own environment. As for the positioning of the elements, if you take care to ""read off"" the primitives in this way, you won't end up putting the drop down below, where it turns the kanji into a jewel. 	  * As a primitive element, we set the key word aside entirely and take it as a pictograph of a solid brass candlestick (with the drop representing the flame at the top). 	 	A lord is a little drop down from King in hierarchy. 	 	On-Yomi: シュ、ス、シュウ   Kun-Yomi: ぬし、おも、あるじ  	Examples: 主人 (しゅじん), 主権 (しゅけん), 施主 (せしゅ), 主 (おも), 主 (ぬし)"
pour	"pour 	 	注   	   	Lesson: 12   Frame: 285   Strokes: 8   —   Jouyou Grade: 3   JLPT: 4   	Constituents: pour, water, water droplets, water pistol, candlestick, lord, drop, king, jewel, ball 	 	Picture pouring water from a lighted candlestick. What could be more ridiculous, or simpler, as a way to recall this kanji? 	 	 	Visualize an idiot trying to figure out how to extinguish a candle. He sees a glass of WATER and decides to pour it onto the CANDLESTICK to put it out. Water spills everywhere. 	 	On-Yomi: チュウ   Kun-Yomi: そそ.ぐ、さ.す、つ.ぐ  	Examples: 注ぐ (そそ.ぐ)"
pillar	"pillar 	 	柱   	   	Lesson: 12   Frame: 286   Strokes: 9   —   Jouyou Grade: 3   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: pillar, tree, wood, candlestick, lord, drop, king, jewel, ball 	 	The pillar referred to here is the wooden beam that stands at the entrance to a traditional Japanese house. Carve it in imagination into the shape of a gigantic candlestick and your work is done. 	 	 	The main pillar in a house should be made of the biggest and strongest tree - the lord of the trees. 	 	On-Yomi: チュウ   Kun-Yomi: はしら  	Examples: 柱 (はしら)"
gold	"gold 	 	金   	   	Lesson: 12   Frame: 287   Strokes: 8   —   Jouyou Grade: 1   JLPT: 5   	Constituents: gold, metal, gold, umbrella, drop, king, jewel, ball, drop2 	 	If this were not one of the most common characters you will ever have to write, I would apologize for having to give the explanation that follows. Anyway, we want to depict bars of gold bullion with an umbrella overhead to shade them from the heat (and perhaps to hide them as well). The bullion is made by melting down all the scepters of the kingdom, drop by drop, and shaping them into bars. 	  * As a primitive, it means not only gold but any metal at all. 	 	The fat king taking up the whole space under the umbrella actually isn´t fat - he just has two big gold bars hidden under his clothes. 	 	On-Yomi: キン、コン、ゴン   Kun-Yomi: かね、かな-、-がね  	Examples: 金属 (きんぞく), 金銭 (きんせん), 純金 (じゅんきん), 金 (かね)"
pig iron	"pig iron 	 	銑   	   	Lesson: 12   Frame: 288   Strokes: 14   —   Jouyou Grade: Names   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: pig-iron, metal, gold, before, cow, human legs 	 	Pig iron refers to iron in the crude form in which it emerges from the smelting furnaces. Of all the various forms metal can take, this one shows us metal before it has been refined. Imagine two photographs labeled ""before"" and ""after"" to show the process. 	 	 	Pig iron is basic/crude metal, that is, before it has been processed. 	 	On-Yomi: セン   Kun-Yomi:"
bowl	"bowl 	 	鉢   	   	Lesson: 12   Frame: 289   Strokes: 13   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: bowl, metal, gold, origin, book, tree, wood, one 	 	Let bowl suggest a large and heavy golden bowl into which you are throwing all the books you own to mash them into pulp, for some outrageous reason you will have to think up yourself. 	 	 	This is the BOWL of an alchemist: see how he mixes metals in his bowl, as he follows the instructions from his book? 	 	On-Yomi: ハチ、ハツ   Kun-Yomi:   	Examples: 鉢 (はち), 植木鉢 (うえきばち)"
copper	"copper 	 	銅   	   	Lesson: 12   Frame: 290   Strokes: 14   —   Jouyou Grade: 5   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: copper, metal, gold, same, monks, hood, one, mouth 	 	Picture an order of monks serving as chaplains for the police force. Their special habit, made of protective metal, is distinguished by a row of copper buttons just like the ""cops"" they serve. 	 	 	I can´t believe no one has used this one yet: Copper is metal which looks almost the same as gold. Really, look it up on Wikipedia, it´s yellow and it´s shiny (atleast in some compounds)! 	 	On-Yomi: ドウ   Kun-Yomi: あかがね"
angling	"angling 	 	釣   	   	Lesson: 12   Frame: 291   Strokes: 11   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: angling, metal, gold, ladle, bound up, drop 	 	The character we learned for fishing (Frame 184) refers to the professional, net-casting industry, while the angling of this character refers to the sport. The odd thing is that your angling rod is a golden ladle which you are using to scoop goldfish out of a river. 	 	 	All the people that go to the Japanese festivals to catch fish part time are suckers. Me? I´m a pro. I bring a big-ass golden ladle. I´m a true ANGLING professional. 	 	On-Yomi: チョウ   Kun-Yomi: つ.る、つ.り、つ.り-  	Examples: 釣る (つ.る)"
needle	"needle 	 	針   	   	Lesson: 12   Frame: 292   Strokes: 10   —   Jouyou Grade: 6   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: needle, metal, gold, ten, needle 	 	In frame 10 we referred ahead to this full character from which the primitive for needle (on the right) derives. Since we already expect that needles are made of metal, let us picture a set of solid gold darning needles to complete the kanji. 	 	 	Remember the story of the needle in the haystack. Why would someone even look for a needle if it wasn´t a GOLD NEEDLE? 	 	On-Yomi: シン   Kun-Yomi: はり  	Examples: 針 (はり)"
inscription	"inscription 	 	銘   	   	Lesson: 12   Frame: 293   Strokes: 14   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: inscription, metal, gold, name, evening, mouth 	 	Take inscription in the sense of the name you ask the jeweler to carve on a gold bracelet or inside a gold ring to identify its owner or communicate some sentimental message. It will help if you can recall the first time you had this done and the feelings you had at the time. 	 	 	A piece of metal with a name on it. Well, this is basically the definition of inscription. 	 	On-Yomi: メイ   Kun-Yomi:"
tranquillize	"tranquillize 	 	鎮   	   	Lesson: 12   Frame: 294   Strokes: 18   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: tranquilize, metal, gold, true, truth, ten, needle, eye, tool, animal legs, eight 	 	The first lie-detector machines of the twentieth century worked by wiring pieces of metal to the body to measure the amount of sweat produced when questions were asked. It was discovered that nervousness produced more sweat, indicating subconscious reactions when the truth was getting too close for comfort. Nowadays, people can take drugs that tranquillize them in such a way as to neutralize the effect of the device, which is why other means have had to be developed. 	 	 	Tranquilize - using a metal syringe to get the truth. 	 	On-Yomi: チン   Kun-Yomi: しず.める、しず.まる、おさえ  	Examples: 鎮まる (しず.まる), 鎮める (しず.める)"
road-way	"road-way 	 	道   	   	Lesson: 13   Frame: 295   Strokes: 12   —   Jouyou Grade: 2   JLPT: 4   	Constituents: road-way, neck, horns, drop, eye, road 	 	The key word carries both the sense of a road for transit and a way or method of doing something, but the former is better for forming an image. The primitives read: the neck of a road. Think of a crowded road-way where traffic has come to a standstill - what we commonly refer to as a ""bottleneck."" 	 	 	When we go out on the ROAD-WAY, we often risk our own necks (that´s why I take the train! ). 	 	On-Yomi: ドウ、トウ   Kun-Yomi: みち  	Examples: 道路 (どうろ), 道徳 (どうとく), 報道 (ほうどう), 道 (みち)"
guidance	"guidance 	 	導   	   	Lesson: 13   Frame: 296   Strokes: 15   —   Jouyou Grade: 5   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: guidance, neck, horns, drop, eye, road, glue 	 	When we accept someone's guidance, we permit ourselves to be glued to a certain road or way of doing something, and try to ""stick"" to it. 	 	 	For guidance on the road-way, glue a GPS unit to your car. 	 	On-Yomi: ドウ   Kun-Yomi: みちび.く  	Examples: 導く (みちび.く)"
crossing	"crossing 	 	辻   	   	Lesson: 13   Frame: 297   Strokes: 5   —   Jouyou Grade: Names   JLPT:    	Constituents: crossing, cross, ten, needle, road 	 	Take the first two strokes in the sense we gave them back in frame 10, as the pictograph of a cross, and set it on a road to create a ""crossing."" 	 	 	Cross-road. 	 	On-Yomi:    Kun-Yomi: つじ"
swift	"swift 	 	迅   	   	Lesson: 13   Frame: 298   Strokes: 6   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: swift, fishhook, cross, ten, needle, road 	 	Here we see a crossing in the form of a barbed fishhook, suggesting a swifter alternate not only to the roundabouts used in Europe but also to the ""cloverleaf"" design used on superhighways in the United States. 	 	 	The car went too swiftly through the crossing and was hooked by the cops. 	 	On-Yomi: ジン   Kun-Yomi:"
create	"create 	 	造   	   	Lesson: 13   Frame: 299   Strokes: 10   —   Jouyou Grade: 5   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: create, revelation, cow, mouth, road 	 	Think of creating as making something out of nothing. Then recall how the way of revelation laid out in the Bible begins with the story of how God created the world out of a dark and chaotic nothingness. 	 	 	A cow creates a road by eating all the grass on its path. 	 	On-Yomi: ゾウ   Kun-Yomi: つく.る、つく.り、-づく.り  	Examples: 造る (つく.る)"
urge	"urge 	 	迫   	   	Lesson: 13   Frame: 300   Strokes: 8   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: urge, white, dove, road 	 	To urge someone to do something, you make the way as appealing as possible, perhaps even whitewashing it a bit. 	 	 	When you have the URGE to go to White Castle, you know it´s time to hit the road. 	 	On-Yomi: ハク   Kun-Yomi: せま.る  	Examples: 迫る (せま.る)"
escape	"escape 	 	逃   	   	Lesson: 13   Frame: 301   Strokes: 9   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: escape, turtle, portent, road 	 	When escaping from something or someone, one always feels as if one is not going fast enough, like a turtle on an expressway. (Since the turtle is on the road and not on the left, it can keep its full kanji shape as given in frame 250.) 	 	 	I used my pants to make a rope, which I then used to escape from prison; hence the naked, hairy legs running along the road! 	 	On-Yomi: トウ   Kun-Yomi: に.げる、に.がす、のが.す、のが.れる  	Examples: 逃がす (に.がす), 逃げる (に.げる), 逃す (のが.す), 逃れる (のが.れる)"
environs	"environs 	 	辺   	   	Lesson: 13   Frame: 302   Strokes: 5   —   Jouyou Grade: 4   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: environs, dagger, sword, road 	 	To keep the environs clean and safe, you could cement daggers in the road, blades pointed upwards, so that no polluting traffic could pass by. You could, if you were an ecologically-minded terrorist. 	 	 	Caution: this kanji doesn´t mean environment; it means ""environs; boundary; border; vicinity"". To separate the environs, create the border by placing daggers on the road. 	 	On-Yomi: ヘン   Kun-Yomi: あた.り、ほと.り、-べ  	Examples: 辺境 (へんきょう), 周辺 (しゅうへん), その辺 (そのへん), 辺り (あた.り), 辺 (べ)"
patrol	"patrol 	 	巡   	   	Lesson: 13   Frame: 303   Strokes: 6   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: patrol, deluge, stream, flood, road 	 	A virtual flood of motorcycle police washing down a road is this kanji's image for a patrol. 	 	 	The cops don´t PATROL anymore - they just flood the road. 	 	On-Yomi: ジュン   Kun-Yomi: めぐ.る、めぐ.り  	Examples: 巡る (めぐ.る)"
car	"car 	 	車   	   	Lesson: 13   Frame: 304   Strokes: 7   —   Jouyou Grade: 1   JLPT: 5   	Constituents: car, sun, ten, needle 	 	You may keep the whole range of connotations for this keyword, car, provided it does not interfere with the pictograph. Look for the front and back wheels (the first and last horizontal strokes) and the seat in the carriage in the middle. As an exercise, try to isolate the primitives on your own and make a story out of them. 	  * Car, cart, wagon, and vehicle may all be used as primitive meanings. 	 	My car is so fast it can go through ten rice fields in ten minutes. 	 	On-Yomi: シャ   Kun-Yomi: くるま  	Examples: 車 (くるま)"
take along	"take along 	 	連   	   	Lesson: 13   Frame: 305   Strokes: 10   —   Jouyou Grade: 4   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: take along, car, road 	 	What you are meant to take along in this kanji are not things but people. The image of the car on the road should ground your image for picking up your friends to take them along to wherever you are going. 	 	 	When you put your car on the road you should always take along a few friends. Don´t confuse with carry (#303). 	 	On-Yomi: レン   Kun-Yomi: つら.なる、つら.ねる、つ.れる、-づ.れ  	Examples: 連れる (つ.れる), 連なる (つら.なる), 連ねる (つら.ねる)"
rut	"rut 	 	軌   	   	Lesson: 13   Frame: 306   Strokes: 9   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: rut, car, nine, baseball 	 	Combine the primary and secondary meanings of this keyword to form your story. Begin with the car whose tires get caught in a rut and spin without going anywhere. Then go onto the baseball team who can't win a game because it has fallen into a rut of losing. 	 	 	My car got so stuck in a rut it required nine people pushing to get it out again. 	 	On-Yomi: キ   Kun-Yomi:"
transport	"transport 	 	輸   	   	Lesson: 13   Frame: 307   Strokes: 16   —   Jouyou Grade: 5   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: transport, car, meeting of butchers, umbrella, one, moon, month, flesh, part of the body, sword, sabre, saber 	 	On the left we see a vehicle used for transport. On the right, we see a new tangle of elements that need sorting out. The first three strokes, you will remember, are the primitive for meeting. Below it we see the elements for flesh and saber, which combine to create a compound element for a butcher and his trade. Together they give us the image of a ""trucker's convoy."" 	 	 	The car is a cattle-car, used to transport animals for the butcher´s meeting - a convention on new butchering techniques. Hear the screams of the animals as it pulls up in front of the convention hall, where the butchers are waiting with their knives out front. 	 	On-Yomi: ユ、シュ   Kun-Yomi:"
in front	"in front 	 	前   	   	Lesson: 13   Frame: 309   Strokes: 9   —   Jouyou Grade: 2   JLPT: 5   	Constituents: in front, horns, butcher, moon, month, flesh, part of the body, sword, sabre, saber 	 	We waited to introduce this character until now, even though the pieces have been available for some time, because it helps to reinforce the odd kanji of the last frame. Picture the butcher hacking away with his knife at a slab of meat on his table with a pair of ram's horns placed in front of him (or on his head, if you prefer). There is no need to worry about confusing this kanji with that for before (Frame 263), since it will not appear as a primitive in any other character used in this book. 	 	 	When I get horny my flesh sword sticks out in front of me. 	 	On-Yomi: ゼン   Kun-Yomi: まえ、-まえ  	Examples: 前 (まえ)"
each	"each 	 	各   	   	Lesson: 13   Frame: 311   Strokes: 6   —   Jouyou Grade: 4   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: each, walking legs, mouth 	 	""Suum cuique"" goes the popular Latin proverb. A certain disease of the English language makes it almost impossible to translate the phrase without gender bias. In any event, here we see someone walking with his/her mouth between his/her walking legs, giving us an image of ""To each his/her own."" 	  * The sense of the proverb should help when using this kanji as a primitive; otherwise, reduce it to its original elements. But do not associate it in any way with the word ""every,"" which we shall meet later in another context. 	 	Son, I´ve never told you this but each woman has a second mouth between their fiiiiiine walking legs. 	 	On-Yomi: カク   Kun-Yomi: おのおの  	Examples: 各 (おのおの)"
status	"status 	 	格   	   	Lesson: 13   Frame: 312   Strokes: 10   —   Jouyou Grade: 5   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: status, tree, wood, each, walking legs, mouth 	 	If you can imagine trees as status symbols (as they might well be for those living in Japan's congested cities, where greenery has become something of a luxury item), then each might be aiming to have his/her own tree, just to keep up with the Suzukis. 	 	 	Ranger! I want you to go check the status of each tree. ""Errr, Each tree sir?"" replies the ranger looking out over the vast forest. ""That´s Right, I want the status of each tree! Move out!"". 	 	On-Yomi: カク、コウ、キャク、ゴウ   Kun-Yomi:   	Examples: 格式 (かくしき), 規格 (きかく), 性格 (せいかく)"
abbreviation	"abbreviation 	 	略   	   	Lesson: 13   Frame: 314   Strokes: 11   —   Jouyou Grade: 5   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: abbreviation, rice field, brains, each, walking legs, mouth 	 	Each field has its own abbreviations (chemistry, philosophy, sports, etc.). Needless to say, the ""stronger"" primitive - thatis to say, the simpler and more often used one - takes the dominant position on the left, even though the story would read them off the other way around. 	 	 	There are so many abbreviations and acronyms nowadays that no brain can remember each of them. Mnemonic: ab-brain-each-ation. 	 	On-Yomi: リャク   Kun-Yomi: ほぼ、おか.す、おさ.める、はかりごと、はか.る、はぶ.く、りゃく.す、りゃく.する"
guest	"guest 	 	客   	   	Lesson: 13   Frame: 315   Strokes: 9   —   Jouyou Grade: 3   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: guest, house, each, walking legs, mouth 	 	When you are a guest in a courteous town, each household has its own way of welcoming you, and each house becomes your home. 	 	 	Each person under my roof is treated as a guest. 	 	On-Yomi: キャク、カク   Kun-Yomi:   	Examples: 客間 (きゃくま), 客車 (きゃくしゃ), 乗客 (じょうきゃく)"
forehead	"forehead 	 	額   	   	Lesson: 13   Frame: 316   Strokes: 18   —   Jouyou Grade: 5   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: forehead, guest, house, each, walking legs, mouth, head, page, one, ceiling, drop, shellfish, clam, oyster, eye, animal legs, eight 	 	As Miss Manners will be the first to tell you, out of respect, one does not look straight into the eyes of one's guests, but focus on the top button of their collar. Here, however, you are told to look above the eyes to the forehead of your guest. 	 	 	Sign the guestbook page with your forehead. (Picture a guestbook full of forehead prints like thumbprints). 	 	On-Yomi: ガク   Kun-Yomi: ひたい  	Examples: 額 (ひたい)"
summer	"summer 	 	夏   	   	Lesson: 13   Frame: 317   Strokes: 10   —   Jouyou Grade: 2   JLPT: 4   	Constituents: summer, one, ceiling, drop, eye, walking legs 	 	In the summer, fatigued by the heat, your head hangs down nearly as far as your walking legs, or rather, your ""dragging legs."" Note how the walking legs (instead of ""animal legs"") are the only thing that distinguishes this character from that for page (Frame 64). 	 	 	In SUMMER you are hot from the top of your head down to your walking legs. 	 	On-Yomi: カ、ガ、ゲ   Kun-Yomi: なつ  	Examples: 夏季 (かき), 初夏 (しょか), 盛夏 (せいか), 夏 (なつ)"
dispose	"dispose 	 	処   	   	Lesson: 13   Frame: 318   Strokes: 5   —   Jouyou Grade: 6   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: dispose, walking legs, wind 	 	Both the stretching out of the walking legs and the little bit of wind tucked in on the right suggest using one's legs to kick something out of the way, or dispose of it. 	 	 	The best way to dispose of a nasty bit of wind is to let it go and use those walking legs to dissapear. Nobody will ever know it was you. 	 	On-Yomi: ショ   Kun-Yomi: ところ、-こ、お.る"
twig	"twig 	 	条   	   	Lesson: 13   Frame: 319   Strokes: 7   —   Jouyou Grade: 5   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: twig, walking legs, tree, wood 	 	Geppetto made walking legs for his little Pinocchio from two twigs of a tree, giving him a set of ""twiggy"" shanks. 	 	 	They all say they have a TREE between their WALKING LEGS but most only have a TWIG. 	 	On-Yomi: ジョウ、チョウ、デキ   Kun-Yomi: えだ、すじ"
fall	"fall 	 	落   	   	Lesson: 13   Frame: 320   Strokes: 12   —   Jouyou Grade: 3   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: fall, flowers, water, water droplets, water pistol, each, walking legs, mouth 	 	When water falls, it splats and splashes; when flower petals fall, they float gently in the breeze. To each thing its own way of falling. 	 	 	Water each flower or the petals will wither and fall. 	 	On-Yomi: ラク   Kun-Yomi: お.ちる、お.ち、お.とす  	Examples: 落ちる (お.ちる), 落とす (お.とす)"
superfluous	"superfluous 	 	冗   	   	Lesson: 14   Frame: 321   Strokes: 4   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: superfluous, crown, weathercock, wind 	 	Picture a weather vane beneath a regal crown, spinning round and round. It is not only superfluous but makes a perfect ass out of the one who wears it. 	 	 	The king´s crown was blown off by the wind. ""Oh well,"" he said, ""it´s just a superfluous symbol."". 	 	On-Yomi: ジョウ   Kun-Yomi:"
army	"army 	 	軍   	   	Lesson: 14   Frame: 323   Strokes: 9   —   Jouyou Grade: 4   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: army, chariot, crown, vehicle, car 	 	The crowned vehicle depicted here is a ""chariot,"" symbol of an army. 	  * Used as a primitive this kanji means only chariot. 	 	British army cars are at the service of the crown. 	 	On-Yomi: グン   Kun-Yomi:"
radiance	"radiance 	 	輝   	   	Lesson: 14   Frame: 324   Strokes: 15   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: radiance, ray, small, little, human legs, army, chariot, crown, vehicle, car 	 	Take advantage of the first syllable of the key word to think of the ray of light to the left. Now add the glittering chariot that is emitting those rays and you have radiance. 	 	 	Rays of light emitted from Apollo´s chariot = radiance. Don´t put the sun into this kanji. The rays are coming from the chariot directly! 	 	On-Yomi: キ   Kun-Yomi: かがや.く  	Examples: 輝く (かがや.く)"
carry	"carry 	 	運   	   	Lesson: 14   Frame: 325   Strokes: 12   —   Jouyou Grade: 3   JLPT: 4   	Constituents: carry, army, chariot, crown, vehicle, car, road 	 	A long string of ""sweet"" chariots ""swinging low"" to our roads is a sure sign that the Lord is ""comin' for to carry"" someone home. 	 	 	Don’t confuse it with “take along” (287). In that one, there was a car so you could take along your friends once you found them on the road. In this one, there is an army chariot just to carry military supplies (sorry no room for you). 	 	On-Yomi: ウン   Kun-Yomi: はこ.ぶ  	Examples: 運ぶ (はこ.ぶ)"
crown	"crown 	 	冠   	   	Lesson: 14   Frame: 326   Strokes: 9   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: crown, beginning, two, human legs, glue 	 	By having the crown pass from one age to the next, a people keeps itself glued to its beginnings. 	 	 	Remember the SUPERFLUOUS CROWN that flew away in the WIND? Well now the king is saying ""i should have had the thing GLUED to my head from the BEGINNING"". 	 	On-Yomi: カン   Kun-Yomi: かんむり  	Examples: 冠 (かんむり)"
dream	"dream 	 	夢   	   	Lesson: 14   Frame: 327   Strokes: 13   —   Jouyou Grade: 5   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: dream, flowers, eye, cross-eyed, net, crown, evening 	 	To have a dream after going to bed is really the crown to a perfect evening. The flower petals over the eyes (instead of the ""sand"" that Westerners are used to finding there when they awake in the morning) only confirms the image of a pleasant dream suggested by the rest of this rather complex kanji. 	 	 	Last night´s date with Miss Sweden was like a dream. She even laid flowers over my eyes to crown the perfect evening. 	 	On-Yomi: ム、ボウ   Kun-Yomi: ゆめ、ゆめ.みる、くら.い  	Examples: 夢 (ゆめ)"
pit	"pit 	 	坑   	   	Lesson: 14   Frame: 328   Strokes: 7   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: pit, soil, dirt, ground, whirlwind, top hat, wind 	 	A whirlwind begins to dig its way into the soil like a drill until it makes a deep pit. 	 	 	A whirlwind digs a hole in the ground throwing out lots of dirt until it ends up with a giant pit. 	 	On-Yomi: コウ   Kun-Yomi:"
tall	"tall 	 	高   	   	Lesson: 14   Frame: 329   Strokes: 10   —   Jouyou Grade: 2   JLPT: 5   	Constituents: tall, top hat, mouth, alien, hood, mouth, mouth2 	 	Recalling an image from frame 195, first see the mouth under the extraterrestrial's glass hood, and then the mouth under the top hat of one of his mates who has tried on the strange earthling's headgear only to find that it makes him look much, much taller than everyone else. 	  * As a primitive, this character keeps its sense of tall and its position at the top of other primitives, but its writing is abbreviated to the first 5 strokes. 	 	Two little aliens in a trenchcoat and top hat, trying to look TALL. The bottom one, in the glass helmet, is under the coat. The top one has his top hat pulled down in disguise, so all you can see is his mouth. 	 	On-Yomi: コウ   Kun-Yomi: たか.い、たか、-だか、たか.まる、たか.める  	Examples: 高 (たか), 高い (たか.い), 高まる (たか.まる), 高める (たか.める)"
receive	"receive 	 	享   	   	Lesson: 14   Frame: 330   Strokes: 8   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: receive, tall, top hat, mouth, children 	 	Tall children receive more attention. Tall children grow up to make better wide receivers. Take your pick, depending on whether you prefer child psychology or American football. At any rate, be sure you have some particular tall child in mind, someone who really was outstanding and always attracting attention, because he or she will come in handy in the next two frames. 	 	 	In basketball however, tall children receive all the attention. 	 	On-Yomi: キョウ、コウ   Kun-Yomi: う.ける"
cram school	"cram school 	 	塾   	   	Lesson: 14   Frame: 331   Strokes: 14   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: cram school, receive, tall, top hat, mouth, child, children, round, nine, baseball, drop, soil, dirt, ground 	 	Cram schools are after-hours educational institutions where kids can do concentrated preparing for their coming entrance examinations or drill what they missed during regular class hours. The exception are the tall children who are out on the school grounds practicing sports, and the fat ones who are out there burning off calories. So this character depicts those who do NOT go to the cram schools, rather than those who do. 	 	 	Welcome to our cram school: you will receive a rounded education on our grounds. 	 	On-Yomi: ジュク   Kun-Yomi:"
mellow	"mellow 	 	熟   	   	Lesson: 14   Frame: 332   Strokes: 15   —   Jouyou Grade: 6   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: mellow, receive, tall, top hat, mouth, child, children, round, nine, baseball, drop, oven-fire, barbecue 	 	The tall and fat children from the last frame are here cast into a cauldron over an oven flame until they have sufficiently mellowed that they can return to the normal life of a student. 	 	 	Imagine tall children sitting round the fire toasting marsh-mellows. 	 	On-Yomi: ジュク   Kun-Yomi: う.れる  	Examples: 熟れる (う.れる)"
pavilion	"pavilion 	 	亭   	   	Lesson: 14   Frame: 333   Strokes: 9   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: pavilion, tall, top hat, mouth, crown, street, nail, spike 	 	Think of all the pavilions at County Fairs or World Expos you have wandered into or seen advertised in the media, and you will no doubt see rising up among them the towering tall crowned nail (the crown being a revolving restaurant) - that architectural monstrosity that has become a symbol of science and technology at such events. 	 	 	The Pavillion on crown street is the tallest I have ever seen. 	 	On-Yomi: テイ、チン   Kun-Yomi:"
capital	"capital 	 	京   	   	Lesson: 14   Frame: 334   Strokes: 8   —   Jouyou Grade: 2   JLPT: 4   	Constituents: capital, tall, top hat, mouth, small, little 	 	When we think of a capital city today we think of tall skyscrapers dwarfing the endless swarms of little folk scurrying here and there about their business. 	 	 	Tokyo, capital of Japan: tall buildings, small people (compared to the buildings). 	 	On-Yomi: キョウ、ケイ、キン   Kun-Yomi: みやこ"
refreshing	"refreshing 	 	涼   	   	Lesson: 14   Frame: 335   Strokes: 11   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: refreshing, water droplets, water pistol capital, tall, top hat, mouth, small, little 	 	Since few things are as refreshing on a warm day as a cool shower (the water), here we picture an entire capital city treating itself to one, and in full view of everyone. 	 	 	When you´re a tourist in the capital during the heat of summer, finding a water fountain is oh, so refreshing. 	 	On-Yomi: リョウ   Kun-Yomi: すず.しい、すず.む、すず.やか、うす.い、ひや.す、まことに  	Examples: 涼しい (すず.しい), 涼む (すず.む)"
scenery	"scenery 	 	景   	   	Lesson: 14   Frame: 336   Strokes: 12   —   Jouyou Grade: 4   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: scenery, sun, day, capital, tall, top hat, mouth, small, little 	 	Scenery is depicted as a sun rising over a capital city, which is a bit of natural scenery the city dwellers themselves rarely get to see! 	 	 	Imaging the sun rising over the capital--classic postcard scenery. 	 	On-Yomi: ケイ   Kun-Yomi:"
whale	"whale 	 	鯨   	   	Lesson: 14   Frame: 337   Strokes: 19   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: whale, fish, bound up, rice field, brains, oven-fire, barbecue, capital, tall, top hat, mouth, small, little 	 	The whale swallows a whole school of fish, who turn their new abode into a proper little fish-capital. 	 	 	If fish were cities, the whale would surely be the capital. 	 	On-Yomi: ゲイ   Kun-Yomi: くじら  	Examples: 鯨 (くじら)"
cottage	"cottage 	 	舎   	   	Lesson: 14   Frame: 338   Strokes: 8   —   Jouyou Grade: 5   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: cottage, umbrella, earthenware jar, lidded crock, soil, dirt, ground, mouth 	 	A lidded crock with an umbrella overhead gives us a mixture of the modern and the nostalgic in this design for a cottage. 	 	 	The cottage is so small - it has an umbrella for the roof; soil for the floor and room for only one mouth. 	 	On-Yomi: シャ、セキ   Kun-Yomi: やど.る"
circumference	"circumference 	 	周   	   	Lesson: 14   Frame: 339   Strokes: 8   —   Jouyou Grade: 4   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: circumference, glass hood, earthenware jar, lidded crock, soil, dirt, ground, mouth 	 	Look more closely at your lidded crock and you will see little ruler marks along its bottom edge. This is so you can use it to calculate the circumference of your motorcycle helmet: just begin at a fixed point and turn the lidded crock around and around, keeping it flush against the side of the helmet, until you come back to your starting point. If you kept track of how many turns and part-turns your lidded crock made, you now know the circumference. 	  * As a primitive, this character can take the added significance of a lap. 	 	If my LIDDED CROCK has the same CIRCUMFERENCE as my head, I like to use it as a HELMET. 	 	On-Yomi: シュウ   Kun-Yomi: まわ.り  	Examples: 周り (まわ.り)"
week	"week 	 	週   	   	Lesson: 14   Frame: 340   Strokes: 11   —   Jouyou Grade: 2   JLPT: 4   	Constituents: week, circumference, running track, earthenware jar, lidded crock, soil, dirt, ground, mouth, road 	 	Picture a circular road with 7 markers on it, one for each day of the week. When you have walked one complete lap on this road, you shall have completed one week. 	 	 	Imagine a road built so well that it takes only a week to travel the circumference of the earth. 	 	On-Yomi: シュウ   Kun-Yomi:"
gentleman	"gentleman 	 	士   	   	Lesson: 14   Frame: 341   Strokes: 3   —   Jouyou Grade: 4   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: gentleman, gentleman, samurai 	 	The shape of this kanji, slightly differing from that for soil by virtue of its shorter final stroke, hints at a broad-shouldered, slender-waisted warrior standing at attention. When feudalism collapsed, these warriors became Japan's gentlemen. 	  * The primitive meaning reverts to the more colorful image of the samurai, Japan's warrior class. 	 	What a handsome gentleman. Standing up so straight, and broad shoulders too!! He´s like a modern samurai! 	 	On-Yomi: シ   Kun-Yomi:"
good luck	"good luck 	 	吉   	   	Lesson: 14   Frame: 342   Strokes: 6   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: good luck, samurai, mouth 	 	Here we see a samurai standing on a street with an open mouth, which people walk up to and look down deep inside of for good luck. 	  * As a primitive, we shall take this shape to mean an aerosol can, from the mouth and the very tightly-fitting lid (note how it differs here from the lidded crock). 	 	The samurai´s wife gives him a (uhum) before battle for good luck. 	 	On-Yomi: キチ、キツ   Kun-Yomi: よし  	Examples: 吉日 (きちじつ), 吉例 (きちれい), 大吉 (だいきち)"
robust	"robust 	 	壮   	   	Lesson: 14   Frame: 343   Strokes: 6   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: robust, turtle, samurai 	 	Robust is seen as a turtle turned samurai. 	 	 	Half of a turtle shell as a shield makes a samurai more robust. 	 	On-Yomi: ソウ   Kun-Yomi: さかん"
villa	"villa 	 	荘   	   	Lesson: 14   Frame: 344   Strokes: 9   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: villa, flowers, robust, turtle, samurai 	 	The villa pictured here is filled with exotic flowers at every turn, and has a pair of turtle-samurai standing before its gates. 	 	 	A villa is fancier (decorated with flowers) and more robust than the average. 	 	On-Yomi: ソウ、ショウ、チャン   Kun-Yomi: ほうき、おごそ.か"
sell	"sell 	 	売   	   	Lesson: 14   Frame: 345   Strokes: 7   —   Jouyou Grade: 2   JLPT: 4   	Constituents: sell, samurai, paper punch, Miss World, crown, human legs 	 	A samurai, out of a job, is going door-to-door selling little windup crowns with human legs that run around on the floor looking like headless monarchs. 	 	 	The samurai happened to find an extra large crown that he wore as a belt on his waist, just above his legs. I wonder if he will sell it to me? 	 	On-Yomi: バイ   Kun-Yomi: う.る、う.れる  	Examples: 売る (う.る), 売れる (う.れる)"
study	"study 	 	学   	   	Lesson: 15   Frame: 346   Strokes: 8   —   Jouyou Grade: 1   JLPT: 5   	Constituents: study, schoolhouse, owl, crown, child 	 	The child in the little red schoolhouse is there for one reason only: to study. Anyone who has gone through the schooling system knows well enough that study is one thing and learning quite another again. In the kanji, too, the character for learning (Frame 616) has nothing to do with the schoolhouse. 	 	 	In the school house there are kids always studying. (BTW, atomiton, this is NOT 字). 	 	On-Yomi: ガク   Kun-Yomi: まな.ぶ  	Examples: 学ぶ (まな.ぶ)"
memorize	"memorize 	 	覚   	   	Lesson: 15   Frame: 347   Strokes: 12   —   Jouyou Grade: 4   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: memorize, schoolhouse, owl, crown, see, telescope, eye, human legs 	 	The idea of memorizing things is easily related to the schoolhouse; and since we have been at it for more than a hundred pages in this book, the idea that memorizing involves seeing things that are not really there should make it easy to put the two elements together. 	 	 	In a schoolhouse in class: 1) you see something on the blackboard, then 2) you memorize it. 	 	On-Yomi: カク   Kun-Yomi: おぼ.える、さ.ます、さ.める、さと.る  	Examples: 覚える (おぼ.える), 覚ます (さ.ます), 覚める (さ.める)"
flourish	"flourish 	 	栄   	   	Lesson: 15   Frame: 348   Strokes: 9   —   Jouyou Grade: 4   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: flourish, schoolhouse, owl, crown, tree, wood 	 	The botanical connotations of the word flourish (to bud and burst into bloom, much as a tree does) are part of the ideal of the schoolhouse as well. 	 	 	The TREES FLOURISH in the CLASSROOM, a little too much perhaps, there´s no room for the students any more. 	 	On-Yomi: エイ、ヨウ   Kun-Yomi: さか.える、は.え、-ば.え、は.える、え  	Examples: 栄える (さか.える), 栄え (は.え), 栄える (は.える)"
write	"write 	 	書   	   	Lesson: 15   Frame: 349   Strokes: 10   —   Jouyou Grade: 2   JLPT: 5   	Constituents: write, brush, tongue wagging, sun, day 	 	The sage talks rapidly with his tongue wagging in his mouth, while the brush of the scribe runs apace to write down the master 'swords. 	 	 	Make sure you practice writing kanji with a brush every day before the sun goes down. 	 	On-Yomi: ショ   Kun-Yomi: か.く、-が.き、-がき  	Examples: 書く (か.く)"
haven	"haven 	 	津   	   	Lesson: 15   Frame: 350   Strokes: 9   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: haven, water, water droplets, water pistol, brush 	 	Seeing the tiny boats of poor mortals tossed about in a stormy sea like so many corks, the All-Merciful took its brush and drew little inlets of water where the hapless creatures might seek shelter. And so it is that we have havens. 	 	 	A brush laying in dirty water is a haven for bacteria. 	 	On-Yomi: シン   Kun-Yomi: つ  	Examples: 津 (つ)"
breed	"breed 	 	牧   	   	Lesson: 15   Frame: 351   Strokes: 8   —   Jouyou Grade: 4   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: breed, cow, taskmaster 	 	When it is time to breed new cattle, the bull is usually willing but the cow is often not. Thus the taskmaster to the right forces the cow into a compromising position, so to speak, so that she and her mate can breed. 	 	 	Imagine a taskmaster giving a cow the command to ""start breeding, and start doing it now!"", except that the cow takes his advice a bit too literally and starts chasing the taskmaster to carry out this command! instead of finding another cow to breed with. Hence, you see the taskmaster running to the right, trying to stay ahead of the cow. 	 	On-Yomi: ボク   Kun-Yomi: まき  	Examples: 牧 (まき)"
aggression	"aggression 	 	攻   	   	Lesson: 15   Frame: 352   Strokes: 7   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: aggression, craft, taskmaster 	 	The special craft of successful taskmasters is their ability to remain constantly on the aggressive, never allowing their underlings a moment to ponder a counter-aggression of their own. 	 	 	Aggression is the craft of a good dominatrix. 	 	On-Yomi: コウ   Kun-Yomi: せ.める  	Examples: 攻める (せ.める)"
failure	"failure 	 	敗   	   	Lesson: 15   Frame: 353   Strokes: 11   —   Jouyou Grade: 4   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: failure, shellfish, clam, oyster, eye, animal legs, eight, taskmaster 	 	The taskmaster is acknowledging the failure of a clam to make the grade in some marine school or other. 	 	 	If you end up in failure, you give money to the taskmaster to train you. 	 	On-Yomi: ハイ   Kun-Yomi: やぶ.れる  	Examples: 敗れる (やぶ.れる)"
a sheet of	"a sheet of 	 	枚   	   	Lesson: 15   Frame: 354   Strokes: 8   —   Jouyou Grade: 6   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: sheet of…, tree, wood, taskmaster 	 	English counts thin, flat objects, like bed linen and paper, in sheets. The kanji does this with a taskmaster whipping a tree into producing sheets against its will. 	 	 	The taskmaster is a strict bathroom monitor who hands out only one sheet of really rough, splintery toilet paper per person. You can see the wood fibers. 	 	On-Yomi: マイ、バイ   Kun-Yomi:"
happenstance	"happenstance 	 	故   	   	Lesson: 15   Frame: 355   Strokes: 9   —   Jouyou Grade: 5   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: happenstance, old, tombstone, gravestone, church, ten, needle, mouth, taskmaster 	 	Call it fate or providence or plain old Lady Luck, happenstance is the oldest taskmaster we know. It nearly always has its way. 	 	 	An OLD TASKMASTER is no happenstance (coincidence). The older you get the more rigid in your ways. 	 	On-Yomi: コ   Kun-Yomi: ゆえ、ふる.い、もと  	Examples: 故 (ゆえ)"
awe	"awe 	 	敬   	   	Lesson: 15   Frame: 356   Strokes: 12   —   Jouyou Grade: 6   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: awe, flowers, phrase, bound up, mouth, taskmaster 	 	Standing in awe of someone, you get self-conscious and may try to speak in flowery phrases out of veneration or fear. The taskmaster at the right is drilling you in the practice of your ""honorifics."" 	 	 	The flowery phrases of the schoolmaster held the students in awe. 	 	On-Yomi: ケイ、キョウ   Kun-Yomi: うやま.う  	Examples: 敬う (うやま.う)"
say	"say 	 	言   	   	Lesson: 15   Frame: 357   Strokes: 7   —   Jouyou Grade: 2   JLPT: 4   	Constituents: say, words, keitai, mouth 	 	Of all the things we can do with our mouths, speech is the one that requires the greatest distinctness and clarity. Hence the kanji for say has four little sound-waves, indicating the complexity of the achievement. 	  * This kanji, which appears often as a primitive, can mean saying, speech, or words, depending on which is most useful. 	 	A pictogram of someone saying a four letter word from their mouth after the censors have gotten a hold of it. 	 	On-Yomi: ゲン、ゴン   Kun-Yomi: い.う、こと  	Examples: 言行 (げんこう), 言論 (げんろん), 宣言 (せんげん), 言う (い.う), 言 (こと)"
admonish	"admonish 	 	警   	   	Lesson: 15   Frame: 358   Strokes: 19   —   Jouyou Grade: 6   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: admonish, awe, flowers, phrase, bound up, mouth, taskmaster, say, words, keitai, mouth, mouth2 	 	Here you have a perfect example of how an apparently impossible snarl of strokes becomes a snap to learn once you know its elements. The idea of being admonished for something already sets up a superior-inferior relationship between you and the person you are supposed to stand in awe of. While you are restricted to answering in honorifics, the superior can use straightforward and ordinary words. 	 	 	To admonish is to enforce awe by means of words. 	 	On-Yomi: ケイ   Kun-Yomi: いまし.める"
plot	"plot 	 	計   	   	Lesson: 15   Frame: 359   Strokes: 9   —   Jouyou Grade: 2   JLPT: 4   	Constituents: plot, say, words, keitai, mouth, ten, needle 	 	Words and a meter's needle combine to form the sense of plot: to talk over plans and to calculate a course of action. 	 	 	A plot is a summary of a book that can be given in ten words. 	 	On-Yomi: ケイ   Kun-Yomi: はか.る、はか.らう  	Examples: 計らう (はか.らう), 計る (はか.る)"
prison	"prison 	 	獄   	   	Lesson: 15   Frame: 361   Strokes: 14   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: prison, pack of wild dogs, say, words, keitai, mouth, chihuahua, dog, large, drop 	 	Although we did not make note of it at the time, the kanji for dog is also a low-grade term for a spy. And later (Frame 1517) we will meet another association of criminals with dogs. The prison here depicts a pack of wild dogs (the long-timers and hardened criminals) into which the poor little chihuahua (first offender) has been cast. The only thing he has to protect himself against the pack are his shrill and frightened words. 	 	 	The wild dog family visits their cousin in prison. They exchange words over the interphone at the visiting booth. 	 	On-Yomi: ゴク   Kun-Yomi:"
revise	"revise 	 	訂   	   	Lesson: 15   Frame: 362   Strokes: 9   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: revise, say, words, keitai, mouth, street, nail, spike 	 	After completing the first draft, you revise it by nailing down your words and ""hammering"" them into shape. 	 	 	Revise, revise and revise until you have all the words nailed down. 	 	On-Yomi: テイ   Kun-Yomi:"
chastise	"chastise 	 	討   	   	Lesson: 15   Frame: 364   Strokes: 10   —   Jouyou Grade: 6   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: chastise, say, words, keitai, mouth, glue 	 	Words spoken to chastise us stick to us like glue in a way no other words can. 	 	 	I said some bad words, and my mother chastised me by washing my mouth out with glue instead of soap! 	 	On-Yomi: トウ   Kun-Yomi: う.つ  	Examples: 討つ (う.つ)"
instruction	"instruction 	 	訓   	   	Lesson: 15   Frame: 365   Strokes: 10   —   Jouyou Grade: 4   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: instruction, say, words, keitai, mouth, stream, flood 	 	The personalism connoted by the word instruction, as opposed to ""teaching"" or ""discipline,"" suits the picture here of words guiding one's progress like the gentle flowing of a stream. Even the etymology of the word instruction suggests the sense of ""pouring into"". 	 	 	The best type of Japanese INSTRUCTION is full immersion, which consists of going to Japan and swimming in the stream of words that surrounds you every day. 	 	On-Yomi: クン、キン   Kun-Yomi: おし.える、よ.む、くん.ずる"
imperial edict	"imperial edict 	 	詔   	   	Lesson: 15   Frame: 366   Strokes: 12   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: imperial edict, say, words, keitai, mouth, summon, seduce, sword, dagger, mouth, mouth2 	 	The imperial edict, spoken with the force of unquestionable law, is made up of words intended to seduce the masses - be it through fear or respect - to follow obediently. 	 	 	The mnemonic ""words to seduce the masses"" was just too vague and I kept forgetting it. So now instead I picture a seductive female reading aloud the imperial edict to the masses, thus ""seducing"" the masses. 	 	On-Yomi: ショウ   Kun-Yomi: みことのり  	Examples: 詔 (みことのり)"
packed	"packed 	 	詰   	   	Lesson: 15   Frame: 367   Strokes: 13   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: packed, say, words, keitai, mouth, aerosol, good luck, samurai, mouth, mouth2 	 	A piece of writing that is pregnant with meaning and needs to be reread several times to be understood we refer to colloquially as ""packed."" The character sees the words as sealed tightly inside an aerosol can. 	 	 	WORDS of GOOD LUCK are PACKED into fortune cookies. 	 	On-Yomi: キツ、キチ   Kun-Yomi: つ.める、つ.め、-づ.め、つ.まる、つ.む  	Examples: 詰まる (つ.まる), 詰む (つ.む), 詰める (つ.める)"
tale	"tale 	 	話   	   	Lesson: 15   Frame: 368   Strokes: 13   —   Jouyou Grade: 2   JLPT: 5   	Constituents: tale, say, words, keitai, mouth, tongue, thousand, mouth, mouth2 	 	That the words of the tongue should come to mean a tale is clear from the etymology: a tale is something ""talked,"" not something read from a book. 	 	 	Tales are always spoken, not written, and because of this, words fly out of your tongue, rather than your pen. 	 	On-Yomi: ワ   Kun-Yomi: はな.す、はなし  	Examples: 話す (はな.す), 話 (はなし)"
recitation	"recitation 	 	詠   	   	Lesson: 15   Frame: 369   Strokes: 12   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: recitation, say, words, keitai, mouth, eternity, drop, water 	 	Listening to the words of poets reciting their poetry is like being transported for a moment into eternity where the rules of everyday life have been suspended. 	 	 	Listening to the words in a recitation of Vogon poetry is worse than spending an eternity in hell. [Note: I assume those 2 reports are to warn against possible confusion with poem (#346) but how can you confuse Vogon poetry with an actual poem? Anyway, it´s the next frame, so it should be easy to keep them straight... Or maybe there´s a kanji for Vogon in RTK3?]. 	 	On-Yomi: エイ   Kun-Yomi: よ.む、うた.う  	Examples: 詠む (よ.む)"
poem	"poem 	 	詩   	   	Lesson: 15   Frame: 370   Strokes: 13   —   Jouyou Grade: 3   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: poem, say, words, keitai, mouth, Buddhist temple, soil, dirt, ground, glue 	 	Since silence is treasured so highly at a Buddhist temple the words spoken there must be well-chosen. Perhaps this is why the records of the monks often read to us like poems. Before going on, back up a frame and make sure you have kept poem and recitation distinct in your mind. 	 	 	A poem is a temple of words. 	 	On-Yomi: シ   Kun-Yomi: うた"
word	"word 	 	語   	   	Lesson: 15   Frame: 371   Strokes: 14   —   Jouyou Grade: 2   JLPT: 5   	Constituents: word, say, words, keitai, mouth, I, five, mouth, mouth2 	 	Whereas the character for say focused on the actual talking, that for words stresses the fact that although it is I who say them, the words of a language are not my own. You can see the clear distinction between I and words just by looking at the kanji. 	 	 	The simplest word to say is I. 	 	On-Yomi: ゴ   Kun-Yomi: かた.る、かた.らう  	Examples: 語らう (かた.らう), 語る (かた.る)"
read	"read 	 	読   	   	Lesson: 15   Frame: 372   Strokes: 14   —   Jouyou Grade: 2   JLPT: 5   	Constituents: read, say, words, keitai, mouth, sell, sale, samurai, paper punch, Miss World, crown, human legs 	 	In the age of advertising, most words we read are out to sell some product or point of view. 	 	 	Read the WORDS used to SELL things. 	 	On-Yomi: ドク、トク、トウ   Kun-Yomi: よ.む、-よ.み  	Examples: 読書 (どくしょ), 音読 (おんどく), 購読 (こうどく), 読本 (どくほん), 読む (よ.む)"
tune	"tune 	 	調   	   	Lesson: 15   Frame: 373   Strokes: 15   —   Jouyou Grade: 3   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: tune, say, words, keitai, mouth, circumference, running track, soil, dirt, ground, mouth, mouth2 	 	A complete tune is composed not only of a succession of notes but also of one lap of the words that go with it. 	 	 	To tune an old-fashioned radio, you turn the dial the full range of the circumference, until you can clearly hear what´s being said. 	 	On-Yomi: チョウ   Kun-Yomi: しら.べる、しら.べ、ととの.う、ととの.える  	Examples: 調べる (しら.べる), 調う (ととの.う), 調える (ととの.える)"
discuss	"discuss 	 	談   	   	Lesson: 15   Frame: 374   Strokes: 15   —   Jouyou Grade: 3   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: discuss, say, words, keitai, mouth, inflammation, fire, fire2 	 	In almost every attempt to discuss an issue, the fervor of one's convictions comes to the surface and creates an inflammation of words (if you will, the ""cuss"" in discuss). 	 	 	Think of an online discussion group where misunderstanding someone´s words leads to flaming. An angry discussion = inflamed words. 	 	On-Yomi: ダン   Kun-Yomi:"
consent	"consent 	 	諾   	   	Lesson: 15   Frame: 375   Strokes: 15   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: consent, say, words, keitai, mouth, young, flowers, by one’s side, mouth, mouth2 	 	The words of the young do not have legal validity unless backed up by ""parental consent."" 	 	 	The words of the very young are useless without CONSENT from their elders. 	 	On-Yomi: ダク   Kun-Yomi:"
