rebuke	"rebuke 	 	諭   	   	Lesson: 15   Frame: 376   Strokes: 16   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: rebuke, say, words, keitai, mouth, meeting of butchers, moon, month, flesh, part of the body, sword, sabre, saber 	 	The stern tone of a rebuke is seen here in the image of words spoken at a meeting of butchers (See frame 307) waving their choppers at one another and ""cutting one another down"" as only butchers can. 	 	 	A PETA activist speaks at a meeting of butchers to rebuke them. 	 	On-Yomi: ユ   Kun-Yomi: さと.す  	Examples: 諭す (さと.す)"
style	"style 	 	式   	   	Lesson: 16   Frame: 377   Strokes: 6   —   Jouyou Grade: 3   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: style, arrow, craft 	 	Take style in its sense of some fashion design or model. Then let the element arrow and craft stand for the well-known style of shirts known as ""Arrow shirts"" because of the little arrow sewn on each one. 	 	 	Each Indian tribe crafts their arrows in a certain style.. 	 	On-Yomi: シキ   Kun-Yomi:"
test	"test 	 	試   	   	Lesson: 16   Frame: 378   Strokes: 13   —   Jouyou Grade: 4   JLPT: 4   	Constituents: test, say, words, keitai, mouth, style, arrow, craft 	 	When a manufacturer produces a new style for the market, the first thing that is done is to run a test on consumers, asking them to speak their opinions frankly about the product. Never mind the anachronism (the kanji was there well before our capitalistic market system) if it helps you remember. 	 	 	In an essay test, you are judged on both your choice of words and your writing style. 	 	On-Yomi: シ   Kun-Yomi: こころ.みる、ため.す  	Examples: 試みる (こころ.みる), 試す (ため.す)"
II (two)	"II (two) 	 	弐   	   	Lesson: 16   Frame: 379   Strokes: 6   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: II, two, arrows, quiver 	 	We use the Roman numeral II here to stress that this kanji is an older form of the kanji for two. Think of two arrows in a quiver, standing up like the numeral II. 	 	 	II (older form of writing 2). After shooting one arrow (the dash top left), I have 2 arrows left in my quiver (bottom left). 	 	On-Yomi: ニ、ジ   Kun-Yomi: ふた.つ、そえ"
range	"range 	 	域   	   	Lesson: 16   Frame: 380   Strokes: 11   —   Jouyou Grade: 6   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: range, soil, dirt, ground, pope, fiesta, mouth, one, floor 	 	From its original meaning of a defined area or zone, a range has also come to mean a grazing land where cowboys roam and do whatever it is they do with cows. When the herds have all been driven to market, there is a great homecoming fiesta like that pictured here. As soon as the cowboys come home, home on the range, the first thing they do is kiss the ground (the mouth on the floor), and then get on with the fiesta. 	 	 	An astronaut lands back at the launch range, kisses the earth beneath him with his mouth, then heads off to a fiesta to celebrate a safe flight. 	 	On-Yomi: イキ   Kun-Yomi:"
burglar	"burglar 	 	賊   	   	Lesson: 16   Frame: 381   Strokes: 13   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: burglar, shellfish, clam, oyster, eye, animal legs, eight, ten, needle, fiesta 	 	From a burglar's point of view, a fiesta is an occasion to takeout the old lock picking needle and break into the unattended safe filled with the family shells (the old form of money, as we saw in frames 84 and 206). 	 	 	Burglars... those guys!!! Burglars only want money (clams) so that they can get needles (drugs) and party (fiesta)! 	 	On-Yomi: ゾク   Kun-Yomi:"
plantation	"plantation 	 	栽   	   	Lesson: 16   Frame: 382   Strokes: 10   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: plantation, Thanksgiving, harvest festival, ten, needle, fiesta, tree, wood 	 	On a fruit plantation it is the trees that one is particularly grateful for at the time of Thanksgiving. Imagine yourself inviting a few representative trees from the fields and orchards to join you around the table to give thanks. 	 	 	The plantation is where we get our Christmas trees. We pick them out at Thanksgiving to be sure we get a good one. 	 	On-Yomi: サイ   Kun-Yomi:"
load	"load 	 	載   	   	Lesson: 16   Frame: 383   Strokes: 13   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: load, Thanksgiving, harvest festival, ten, needle, fiesta, car, vehicle 	 	One loads bales on a wagon or cart in preparation for the great Hay Ride that follows the Thanksgiving dinner each year. 	 	 	After eating a big Thanksgiving dinner, you have to be careful in the car ride home not to drop a load in your pants. 	 	On-Yomi: サイ   Kun-Yomi: の.せる、の.る  	Examples: 載せる (の.せる), 載る (の.る)"
overgrown	"overgrown 	 	茂   	   	Lesson: 16   Frame: 384   Strokes: 8   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: overgrown, flowers, parade 	 	The sense of the key word overgrown is of something growing luxuriously, though not necessarily in excess - in this case a whole parade of weeds (outcast flowers). By way of exception, the flowers take their normal place over the enclosure. 	 	 	The gay parade looks astonishing, as if overgrown with flowers. 	 	On-Yomi: モ   Kun-Yomi: しげ.る  	Examples: 茂る (しげ.る)"
turn into	"turn into 	 	成   	   	Lesson: 16   Frame: 386   Strokes: 6   —   Jouyou Grade: 4   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: turn into, parade, sword, dagger 	 	Let the phrase ""turn into"" suggest some sort of a magical change. What happens here is that the parade marching down main street turns into a dagger-throwing bout between competing bands. Note how only one stroke has to be added to make the change. 	 	 	It only takes a single stroke of a dagger for a parade to TURN INTO a bloodbath. 	 	On-Yomi: セイ、ジョウ   Kun-Yomi: な.る、な.す、-な.す  	Examples: 成功 (せいこう), 完成 (かんせい), 賛成 (さんせい), 成す (な.す), 成る (な.る)"
castle	"castle 	 	城   	   	Lesson: 16   Frame: 387   Strokes: 9   —   Jouyou Grade: 6   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: castle, soil, dirt, ground, turn into, parade, sword, dagger 	 	In this frame, we see a mound of dirt that is being turned into a castle (the way you may have done as a child playing on the beach). 	 	 	The sand castle is just the soil (#150) that turns into a castle. 	 	On-Yomi: ジョウ   Kun-Yomi: しろ  	Examples: 城 (しろ)"
sincerity	"sincerity 	 	誠   	   	Lesson: 16   Frame: 388   Strokes: 13   —   Jouyou Grade: 6   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: sincerity, say, words, keitai, mouth, turn into, sword, dagger, parade 	 	The sure sign of sincerity is that one's mere words are turned into deeds. 	 	 	Sincerity happens when what you say actually turns into something. 	 	On-Yomi: セイ   Kun-Yomi: まこと  	Examples: 誠 (まこと)"
intimidate	"intimidate 	 	威   	   	Lesson: 16   Frame: 389   Strokes: 9   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: intimidate, march, women, woman 	 	Here we see a march of women demonstrating on behalf of equal rights, something extremely intimidating to the male chauvinist population. 	 	 	The march of women - against intimidation in the workplace - is pretty intimidating in itself! 	 	On-Yomi: イ   Kun-Yomi: おど.す、おど.し、おど.かす"
destroy	"destroy 	 	滅   	   	Lesson: 16   Frame: 390   Strokes: 13   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: destroy, water, water droplets, water pistol, march, fire 	 	Picture a march of flames demonstrating against the Fire Department for their right to destroy, but being doused with water by the police riot squads. 	 	 	Water flows down to destroy the march of fire. 	 	On-Yomi: メツ   Kun-Yomi: ほろ.びる、ほろ.ぶ、ほろ.ぼす  	Examples: 滅びる (ほろ.びる), 滅ぼす (ほろ.ぼす)"
dwindle	"dwindle 	 	減   	   	Lesson: 16   Frame: 391   Strokes: 12   —   Jouyou Grade: 5   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: dwindle, water, water droplets, water pistol, march, mouth 	 	A group of unquenchable mouths sets out on a march across the country, drinking water wherever they find it until the water supply has dwindled to a trickle, triggering a national disaster. 	 	 	When WATER was tossed on the PROTESTORS (a march of mouths), the numbers began to DWINDLE. 	 	On-Yomi: ゲン   Kun-Yomi: へ.る、へ.らす  	Examples: 減らす (へ.らす), 減る (へ.る)"
scaffold	"scaffold 	 	桟   	   	Lesson: 16   Frame: 393   Strokes: 10   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: scaffold, tree, wood, float, fiesta 	 	Prior to the use of metal, trees were once cut down and bound together for use as scaffolding material. In the case of this kanji, what is being constructed is not a skyscraper but a simple float. 	 	 	Japanese festival floats are often so tall they need wood scaffolds to be completed. (http://www.japan-guide.com/e/e5909.html). 	 	On-Yomi: サン、セン   Kun-Yomi: かけはし"
coin	"coin 	 	銭   	   	Lesson: 16   Frame: 394   Strokes: 14   —   Jouyou Grade: 5   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: coin, metal, gold, float, fiesta 	 	Those special gold-colored tokens minted each year for the Mardi Gras and thrown into the crowds from people on the floats give us the kanji for coins. 	 	 	Political hopefuls in Rome threw gold COINS from floats when they were campaigning for office. 	 	On-Yomi: セン、ゼン   Kun-Yomi: ぜに、すき  	Examples: 銭 (ぜに)"
shallow	"shallow 	 	浅   	   	Lesson: 16   Frame: 395   Strokes: 9   —   Jouyou Grade: 4   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: shallow, water, water droplets, water pistol, float, fiesta 	 	An entourage of floats going from one town to the next must always seek a shallow place to cross the water. Try to picture what happens if they don't. 	 	 	The water can´t be too SHALLOW if you expect to float. 	 	On-Yomi: セン   Kun-Yomi: あさ.い  	Examples: 浅い (あさ.い)"
stop	"stop 	 	止   	   	Lesson: 17   Frame: 396   Strokes: 4   —   Jouyou Grade: 2   JLPT: 4   	Constituents: stop, footprint 	 	The character for stop is easiest to learn as a pictograph, though you have to take a moment to see it. Take it as a rather crude drawing of a footprint: the first 3 strokes represent the front of the foot and the last the heel. The big toe (stroke 2 sticking out to the right) on the right indicates that this is a left foot. 	  * Although the meaning of stop will be retained, we will return often to the pictographic meaning of footprint. 	 	If you find in the ground a walking stick with a magic wand, STOP! Maybe it´s some kind of macumba/black magic/voodoo bad thing. 	 	On-Yomi: シ   Kun-Yomi: と.まる、-ど.まり、と.める、-と.める、-ど.め、とど.める、とど.め、とど.まる、や.める、や.む、-や.む、よ.す、-さ.す、-さ.し  	Examples: 止まる (と.まる), 止める (と.める)"
walk	"walk 	 	歩   	   	Lesson: 17   Frame: 397   Strokes: 8   —   Jouyou Grade: 2   JLPT: 4   	Constituents: walk, stop, footprint, few 	 	Footprints that follow one another a few at a time indicate walking. 	 	 	When walking your pet, you must stop a few times along the way when nature calls. 	 	On-Yomi: ホ、ブ、フ   Kun-Yomi: ある.く、あゆ.む  	Examples: 歩道 (ほどう), 徒歩 (とほ), 進歩 (しんぽ), 歩合 (ぶあい), 日歩 (ひぶ), 歩む (あゆ.む), 歩く (ある.く)"
ford	"ford 	 	渉   	   	Lesson: 17   Frame: 398   Strokes: 11   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: ford, water, water droplets, water pistol, walk, stop, footprint, few 	 	To ford a body of water means to walk across it. 	 	 	The new Ford Jesus. It can do everything except WALK on WATER. 	 	On-Yomi: ショウ   Kun-Yomi: わた.る"
repeatedly	"repeatedly 	 	頻   	   	Lesson: 17   Frame: 399   Strokes: 17   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: repeatedly, walk, stop, footprint, few, head, page, one, ceiling, drop, shellfish, clam, oyster, eye, animal legs, eight 	 	The image of something occurring repeatedly, over and over again, is of having one's head walked on. 	 	 	I repeatedly walk around hoping this kanji will come into my head. I repeatedly walk around hoping this kanji will come into my head. I repeatedly walk around hoping this kanji will come into my head. I repeatedly walk around hoping this kanji will come into my head. I repeatedly walk around hoping this kanji will come into my head. 	 	On-Yomi: ヒン   Kun-Yomi: しき.りに"
agreement	"agreement 	 	肯   	   	Lesson: 17   Frame: 400   Strokes: 8   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: agreement, stop, footprint, moon, month, flesh, part of the body 	 	Seeing footprints on someone's flesh indicates a rather brutal way of having secured that person's agreement. 	 	 	A secret agreement between a covert gov´t agency and aliens states that we will not step foot on the moon again in return for alien technology. 	 	On-Yomi: コウ   Kun-Yomi: がえんじ.る"
undertake	"undertake 	 	企   	   	Lesson: 17   Frame: 401   Strokes: 6   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: undertake, umbrella, stop, footprint 	 	To undertake a project is to take some idea floating in the air and stop it so that it can be brought down to earth and become a reality. Here we see some undertaking made to stop under a beach umbrella. 	 	 	Mary Poppins floated down with her umbrella to undertake the job of stopping the children´s misbehaving. 	 	On-Yomi: キ   Kun-Yomi: くわだ.てる、たくら.む  	Examples: 企てる (くわだ.てる)"
curriculum	"curriculum 	 	歴   	   	Lesson: 17   Frame: 402   Strokes: 14   —   Jouyou Grade: 4   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: curriculum, cliff, grove, tree, wood, stop, footprint, tree2, wood2 	 	That same grove of trees we met in frame 226 shows up here in the character for curriculum (in the sense of a record of one's life or academic achievements, the curriculum vitae). Instead of the grove making its way slowly through the surface of the cliff as before, here we see it stopped, much the same as a curriculum vitae calls a halt to the calendar and talks only about the past. 	 	 	A CURRICULUM is a calendar that replaces days with reasons to stop having fun. 	 	On-Yomi: レキ、レッキ   Kun-Yomi:"
warrior	"warrior 	 	武   	   	Lesson: 17   Frame: 403   Strokes: 8   —   Jouyou Grade: 5   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: warrior, one, arrow, stop, footprint 	 	With a quiver of arrows set on one's back, the goal of the warrior depicted here is not to attack but merely to stop the attack of others: the oldest excuse in history! 	 	 	ONE-ARROW can STOP a warrior. 	 	On-Yomi: ブ、ム   Kun-Yomi: たけ.し  	Examples: 武力 (ぶりょく), 武士 (ぶし), 文武 (ぶんぶ)"
levy	"levy 	 	賦   	   	Lesson: 17   Frame: 404   Strokes: 15   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: levy, shellfish, clam, oyster, eye, animal legs, eight, warrior, one, stop, footprint, arrow 	 	A certain portion of shells (money) is collected by the warrior from the local villages as he passes through to defray the costs of keeping the land safe, and this is called a levy. 	 	 	A warrior stands guard at a bridge collecting shells as a levy for any who want to pass. 	 	On-Yomi: フ、ブ   Kun-Yomi:"
correct	"correct 	 	正   	   	Lesson: 17   Frame: 405   Strokes: 5   —   Jouyou Grade: 1   JLPT: 4   	Constituents: correct, one, ceiling, stop, footprint 	 	""A journey of a thousand miles begins with a single step,"" says the Chinese proverb. Here we see one footprint, complementing that proverb with the sound advice that if the first step is not made correctly, the whole point of the journey will be forfeited. This is the ideal that teachers are supposed to have in correcting their students, and parents in correcting their children. 	 	 	If you do it correct on the first attempt you can stop. 	 	On-Yomi: セイ、ショウ   Kun-Yomi: ただ.しい、ただ.す、まさ、まさ.に  	Examples: 正義 (せいぎ), 正誤 (せいご), 訂正 (ていせい), 正しい (ただ.しい), 正す (ただ.す), 正 (まさ)"
evidence	"evidence 	 	証   	   	Lesson: 17   Frame: 406   Strokes: 12   —   Jouyou Grade: 5   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: evidence, say, words, keitai, mouth, correct, one, ceiling, stop, footprint 	 	Words that testify to the correctness of some fact are classified as evidence. (Here we see a good example of how the more common primitive element takes the ""strong"" position to the left, even though it has more strokes.) 	 	 	Your words must be absolutely correct if you plan to use them as evidence. 	 	On-Yomi: ショウ   Kun-Yomi: あかし  	Examples: 証 (あかし)"
politics	"politics 	 	政   	   	Lesson: 17   Frame: 407   Strokes: 9   —   Jouyou Grade: 5   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: politics, correct, one, ceiling, stop, footprint, taskmaster 	 	To the many definitions for politics that already exist, this character offers yet another: correct taskmastering. Think about what the primitives tell us. On the one hand, we see the pessimistic wisdom that politics has to do with taskmastering, maneuvering people with or without their will. And on the other, we see the campaign assurances that this duty can be performed correctly if only the right candidate is given a chance. 	 	 	Those involved in politics are always trying to elect the correct taskmaster. 	 	On-Yomi: セイ、ショウ   Kun-Yomi: まつりごと、まん  	Examples: 政治 (せいじ), 行政 (ぎょうせい), 家政 (かせい), 政 (まつりごと)"
determine	"determine 	 	定   	   	Lesson: 17   Frame: 408   Strokes: 8   —   Jouyou Grade: 3   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: determine, house, mend 	 	Determination, in the sense of settling on a certain course of action, is likened here to mending one's house. 	 	 	In The Karate Kid, the boy must prove his determination by MENDING his teacher´s HOUSE in various ways. 	 	On-Yomi: テイ、ジョウ   Kun-Yomi: さだ.める、さだ.まる、さだ.か  	Examples: 定価 (ていか), 安定 (あんてい), 決定 (けってい), 定か (さだ.か), 定まる (さだ.まる), 定める (さだ.める)"
lock	"lock 	 	錠   	   	Lesson: 17   Frame: 409   Strokes: 16   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: lock, metal, gold, determine, determined, house, mend 	 	Metal of itself doesn't lock. It needs to be so determined by a locksmith. Now make a concrete image of that. 	 	 	Even if you lock up your GOLD, a DETERMINED thief will get it in the end. 	 	On-Yomi: ジョウ   Kun-Yomi:"
run	"run 	 	走   	   	Lesson: 17   Frame: 410   Strokes: 7   —   Jouyou Grade: 2   JLPT: 4   	Constituents: run, soil, dirt, ground, mend 	 	Running, we are told here, mends the soil. Observe in the following frames how this kanji can embrace other elements from below, much the same way as the element for road does; and how, in order to do this, the final stroke needs to be lengthened. 	 	 	Hint: This kanji is NOT soil on top of mend, as Heisig claims - that would duplicate one of the strokes. Instead, it is 10 on top of mend. So my story is: If you run 10 miles, you will need to mend your socks! 	 	On-Yomi: ソウ   Kun-Yomi: はし.る  	Examples: 走る (はし.る)"
transcend	"transcend 	 	超   	   	Lesson: 17   Frame: 411   Strokes: 12   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: transcend, run, soil, dirt, ground, mend, summon, seduce, sword, dagger, mouth 	 	When one is running after something, the goal that seduces one is said to transcend the seeker. 	 	 	A successful marathon runner needs to be able to transcend seductions, such as the possibility of rest, shelter from the rain, or a cold beer. 	 	On-Yomi: チョウ   Kun-Yomi: こ.える、こ.す  	Examples: 超える (こ.える), 超す (こ.す)"
proceed	"proceed 	 	赴   	   	Lesson: 17   Frame: 412   Strokes: 9   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: proceed, run, soil, dirt, ground, mend, magic wand, augury 	 	In proceeding to a new city or a new job, something in you runs ahead with excitement, and something else holds you back, like a divining rod built into your psyche warning you to check things out carefully before rushing in too wildly. 	 	 	Don´t run into trouble, Dumbledore tells Harry. ""Proceed with caution with your wand out."". 	 	On-Yomi: フ   Kun-Yomi: おもむ.く  	Examples: 赴く (おもむ.く)"
surpass	"surpass 	 	越   	   	Lesson: 17   Frame: 413   Strokes: 12   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: surpass, run, soil, dirt, ground, mend, parade 	 	Here we see two parades in competition, each trying to surpass the other by running at high speed from one town to the next. Note the little ""hook"" at the end of the first stroke of the element for parade. This is the ONLY time it appears like this in the kanji treated in this book. 	 	 	The person in charge of running the parade surpassed all our expectations (by just a extra drop...). 	 	On-Yomi: エツ、オツ   Kun-Yomi: こ.す、-こ.す、-ご.し、こ.える、-ご.え  	Examples: 越える (こ.える), 越す (こ.す)"
just so	"just so 	 	是   	   	Lesson: 17   Frame: 414   Strokes: 9   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: just so, sun, day, mend 	 	In this kanji we are shown someone spending an entire day at mending one stocking, because they want the job done ""just so."" Be sure to make a clear image of a finicky old fusspot to make the abstract idea as concrete as possible. 	 	 	´Sun´ ´Mend´ - It just so happens that sunshine can mend your gloomy spirits. 	 	On-Yomi: ゼ、シ   Kun-Yomi: これ、この、ここ"
topic	"topic 	 	題   	   	Lesson: 17   Frame: 415   Strokes: 18   —   Jouyou Grade: 3   JLPT: 4   	Constituents: topic, just so, sun, day, mend, head, page, one, ceiling, drop, shellfish, clam, oyster, eye, animal legs, eight 	 	In many kinds of research, one can find information on a given topic only if the headings are prepared just so. 	 	 	The ""TOPIC"" of the day´s newspaper must be placed JUST SO at the top of the PAGE to attract attention. 	 	On-Yomi: ダイ   Kun-Yomi:"
dike	"dike 	 	堤   	   	Lesson: 17   Frame: 416   Strokes: 12   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: dike, soil, dirt, ground, just so, sun, day, mend 	 	A dike is a successful bit of engineering only if the amount of earth piled up is measured just so for the height and pressure of the water it is meant to contain. 	 	 	Making a dike is all about arranging the soil just so.... 	 	On-Yomi: テイ   Kun-Yomi: つつみ  	Examples: 堤 (つつみ)"
build	"build 	 	建   	   	Lesson: 17   Frame: 417   Strokes: 9   —   Jouyou Grade: 4   JLPT: 4   	Constituents: build, brush, stretch 	 	To construct a building, you first draw a set of plans (the writing brush) and then s-t-r-e-t-c-h your drawing out to scale in reality. 	 	 	Build is easy to remember if you can remember that archtiechts have two steps in building. 1. Take a brush and brush out the blueprints. 2. Get a visual image of the blueprints all rolled up like they usually are. The second step is easy, it´s just the architecht stretching out the blueprints and showing it to his clients. 	 	On-Yomi: ケン、コン   Kun-Yomi: た.てる、た.て、-だ.て、た.つ  	Examples: 建築 (けんちく), 建議 (けんぎ), 封建的 (ほうけんてき), 建つ (た.つ), 建てる (た.てる)"
prolong	"prolong 	 	延   	   	Lesson: 17   Frame: 419   Strokes: 8   —   Jouyou Grade: 6   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: prolong, drop, stop, footprint, stretch 	 	This character is a kind of pictographic image of how prolonging is a clever way of stopping things by trying to stretch them out a little bit at a time (the extra drop at the top of stop). Be sure to get a concrete image of this process, by imagining yourself prolonging something you can really, physically, stretch. 	 	 	Stretching correctly prolongs life. Even the top part of 正 is stretching... 	 	On-Yomi: エン   Kun-Yomi: の.びる、の.べる、の.べ、の.ばす  	Examples: 延ばす (の.ばす), 延びる (の.びる), 延べる (の.べる)"
nativity	"nativity 	 	誕   	   	Lesson: 17   Frame: 420   Strokes: 15   —   Jouyou Grade: 6   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: nativity, say, words, keitai, mouth, prolonged, drop, stop, footprint, stretch 	 	The key word of course calls to mind the feast of Christmas. As the famous poem at the start of St. John's gospel tells us, the nativity we celebrate at Christmas had its origins at the very start of time and governs all of human history: it represents the prolongation of the eternal Word in time and space. 	 	 	Nativity = born, being born. Think of birth as a painful and prolonged event. And of course, all the words and curses being yelled at the soon-to-be father for doing this to her! 	 	On-Yomi: タン   Kun-Yomi:"
cornerstone	"cornerstone 	 	礎   	   	Lesson: 17   Frame: 421   Strokes: 18   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: cornerstone, stone, rock, grove, tree, wood, zoo, critters, tree2, wood2 	 	This character depicts a cornerstone as a stone set at the end of a wildlife preserve (the ""zoo in the grove""). 	 	 	Features like stones and groves of trees are the cornerstones of a happy zoo. 	 	On-Yomi: ソ   Kun-Yomi: いしずえ  	Examples: 礎 (いしずえ)"
bridegroom	"bridegroom 	 	婿   	   	Lesson: 17   Frame: 422   Strokes: 12   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: bridegroom, woman, zoo, critters, moon, month, flesh, part of the body 	 	What makes a man a bridegroom is obviously a woman and her dowry, here presented as a small zoo (animals were often used for this purpose in earlier societies) and a month away from it all (the ""honeymoon""). 	 	 	The virgin bridegroom tries to understand the new, mysterious part of his woman´s body - but with little success. It´s a zoo down there! (primitives placement: the part of the body is ´down there´ - the woman is ´left´ unsatisfied). 	 	On-Yomi: セイ   Kun-Yomi: むこ  	Examples: 婿 (むこ)"
garment	"garment 	 	衣   	   	Lesson: 18   Frame: 423   Strokes: 6   —   Jouyou Grade: 4   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: garment, top hat, scarf, cloth, clothes, clothing, garment 	 	At the top we see the top hat, and at the bottom a pictographic representation of the folds of a garment. If you break the ""4-fold"" fold into 2 sets of 2 strokes, you will find it easier to remember. 	  * Used as a primitive, the additional meanings of cloak or scarf will come in handy. What has to be noted particularly are the changes in shape the kanji can undergo when it becomes an element in other kanji. In fact, it is the most volatile of all the kanji we shall treat, and for that reason deserves special attention here. When it appears to the left, it looks like a hiragana ne (ネ) with an extra drop on the right, and we shall take it to mean cloak. At the bottom, when attached to the stroke immediately above it, the first two strokes (the top hat) are omitted, which we shall take to mean a scarf. On rare occasions, the element can be torn right across the middle, with the first 2 strokes appearing at the top and the last 4 at the bottom of another primitive or cluster of primitive, in which cases we shall speak of a top hat and scarf. And finally, of course, it can keep its original kanji shape, along with its original meaning of garment in general. Note that when any of the above forms have something beneath them (as in frame 429), the third from final stroke is ""unhooked."" 	 	The only garments allowed in this club are top hat and scarf. 	 	On-Yomi: イ、エ   Kun-Yomi: ころも、きぬ、-ぎ  	Examples: 衣 (ころも)"
tailor	"tailor 	 	裁   	   	Lesson: 18   Frame: 424   Strokes: 12   —   Jouyou Grade: 6   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: tailor, Thanksgiving, harvest festival, ten, needle, fiesta, top hat, scarf, cloth, clothes, clothing, garment 	 	You might think here of garment that have been specially tailored for Thanksgiving celebrations to look like traditional Pilgrim garb. 	 	 	The tailor was hard at work making sure all the pilgrims were dressed in their best garments for thanksgiving. 	 	On-Yomi: サイ   Kun-Yomi: た.つ、さば.く  	Examples: 裁く (さば.く), 裁つ (た.つ)"
attire	"attire 	 	装   	   	Lesson: 18   Frame: 425   Strokes: 12   —   Jouyou Grade: 6   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: attire, turtle, samurai, top hat, scarf, cloth, clothes, clothing, garment 	 	The character for attire can be remembered as a picture of what we may call a ""turtle-samurai"" sweater. At the top we see the turtle-samurai and at the bottom the element for garment. 	 	 	The TURTLE SAMURAI needs special GARMENTs for his ATTIRE since his body is much more ROBUST than others. 	 	On-Yomi: ソウ、ショウ   Kun-Yomi: よそお.う、よそお.い  	Examples: 装置 (そうち), 服装 (ふくそう), 変装 (へんそう), 装う (よそお.う)"
back	"back 	 	裏   	   	Lesson: 18   Frame: 426   Strokes: 13   —   Jouyou Grade: 6   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: back, top hat, scarf, computer 	 	An innocent looking top hat and scarf lying there in front of you, turned over, reveal a hidden computer sewn into the back of each - obviously the tools of a master spy. Such experiences teach one always to have a look at the back side of things. 	 	 	The computer had carefully dressed up in clothes to look human. It was n´t until I looked at the back and saw the cables and stuff that I realized what it was. 	 	On-Yomi: リ   Kun-Yomi: うら  	Examples: 裏 (うら)"
demolition	"demolition 	 	壊   	   	Lesson: 18   Frame: 427   Strokes: 16   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: demolition, soil, dirt, ground, poltergeist, BernaE, ten, needle, eye, cross-eyed, net, top hat, scarf, cloth, clothes, clothing, garment 	 	The right half of this character shows a garment woven so fine that it can pass through the eye of a needle, fittingly draped around the slithering, ethereal form of a poltergeist. In this frame, our eerie visitor brushes its robes against a nearby block of apartments and completely demolishes them, razing them to the ground. 	 	 	If you stand too close to a DEMOLITION site, the dust might sting you like NEEDLES in your EYE and get your GARMENTs all dirty. 	 	On-Yomi: カイ、エ   Kun-Yomi: こわ.す、こわ.れる、やぶ.る  	Examples: 壊す (こわ.す), 壊れる (こわ.れる)"
pathetic	"pathetic 	 	哀   	   	Lesson: 18   Frame: 428   Strokes: 9   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: pathetic, top hat, scarf, mouth 	 	A drunken sod in a tattered top hat and soiled silk scarf with a giant mouth guzzling something or other gives us a pathetic character role in which W. C. Fields might find himself right at home. 	 	 	One of my friends with a crazy sense of fashion loves to wear a tophat and a scarf so that you can´t see his whole face but only his mouth. He thinks it´s cool. I think it´s pathetic. 	 	On-Yomi: アイ   Kun-Yomi: あわ.れ、あわ.れむ、かな.しい  	Examples: 哀れ (あわ.れ), 哀れむ (あわ.れむ)"
distant	"distant 	 	遠   	   	Lesson: 18   Frame: 429   Strokes: 13   —   Jouyou Grade: 2   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: distant, earthenware jar, lidded crock, soil, dirt, ground, mouth, scarf, road 	 	A distant figure on the road is such a blur it looks like a lidded crock wearing a silk scarf. 	 	 	Keep distant from a lidded crock on the road wrapped in a scarf. It might be a bomb. 	 	On-Yomi: エン、オン   Kun-Yomi: とお.い  	Examples: 遠近 (えんきん), 永遠 (えいえん), 敬遠 (けいえん), 遠い (とお.い)"
monkey	"monkey 	 	猿   	   	Lesson: 18   Frame: 430   Strokes: 13   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: monkey, pack of wild dogs, earthenware jar, lidded crock, soil, dirt, ground, mouth, scarf 	 	This clever little monkey has captured an entire pack of wild dogs, locked them inside a lidded crock, and wrapped the whole thing up in a silk scarf to present to the dogcatcher. 	 	 	The MONKEY likes to play hide and seek with the PACK of WILD DOGS by hiding in the LIDDED CROCK. But he is easy to see because the SCARF he always wears is at the base of the LIDDED CROCK. 	 	On-Yomi: エン   Kun-Yomi: さる  	Examples: 猿 (さる)"
first time	"first time 	 	初   	   	Lesson: 18   Frame: 431   Strokes: 7   —   Jouyou Grade: 4   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: first time, cloak, sword, dagger 	 	The primitives here take care of themselves: cloak and dagger .What I leave to you is to decide on an appropriate connotation for ""first time"" to take advantage of them. 	 	 	This is the first time we´ve been out of the Shire, Mr. Frodo! Says Sam, covering himself with his cloak and clutching his dagger. 	 	On-Yomi: ショ   Kun-Yomi: はじ.め、はじ.めて、はつ、はつ-、うい-、-そ.める、-ぞ.め  	Examples: 初 (うい), 初める (そ.める), 初め (はじ.め), 初めて (はじ.めて), 初 (はつ)"
linen	"linen 	 	布   	   	Lesson: 18   Frame: 433   Strokes: 5   —   Jouyou Grade: 5   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: linen, by one’s side, towel 	 	The maid, towels by her side, distributes the linen. 	 	 	A matador holding his red linen by his side. 	 	On-Yomi: フ   Kun-Yomi: ぬの  	Examples: 布 (ぬの)"
sail	"sail 	 	帆   	   	Lesson: 18   Frame: 434   Strokes: 6   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: sail, towel, mediocre, drop, wind 	 	A sail made of a towel makes a mediocre vessel. 	 	 	When stranded at sea, we needed a Sail. The best we had was a TOWEL, which was MEDICORE, only catching a DROP of WIND. 	 	On-Yomi: ハン   Kun-Yomi: ほ  	Examples: 帆 (ほ)"
hanging scroll	"hanging scroll 	 	幅   	   	Lesson: 18   Frame: 435   Strokes: 12   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: hanging scroll, towel, wealth, one, ceiling, mouth, rice field, brains 	 	A towel owned by the wealthiest tycoon in the world is made into a hanging scroll after his death and auctioned off to the highest bidder. 	 	 	In the west, the rich use $100 bills to light their cigars... In Japan, after showering, when the wealthy don´t have any clean towels, they simply grab a hanging scroll off the wall and use it to dry off! 	 	On-Yomi: フク   Kun-Yomi: はば  	Examples: 幅 (はば)"
cap	"cap 	 	帽   	   	Lesson: 18   Frame: 436   Strokes: 12   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: cap, towel, risk, sun, day, eye 	 	Because of the risk involved (of getting the sun in one's eyes),one puts together a makeshift cap out of a dirty old towel. 	 	 	If you wear a towel as a cap, you are at risk of being seized and searched in U.S. airports. 	 	On-Yomi: ボウ、モウ   Kun-Yomi: ずきん、おお.う"
curtain	"curtain 	 	幕   	   	Lesson: 18   Frame: 437   Strokes: 13   —   Jouyou Grade: 6   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: curtain, graveyard, flowers, sun, day, large, St. Bernard, towel 	 	A dirty towel draped over the entrance to the old graveyard is painted to look like the curtain of death that leads to the otherworld. 	 	 	There is a graveyard outside my house that scares me, so I put a huge towel over the window to serve as a curtain so I can get a good nights sleep. 	 	On-Yomi: マク、バク   Kun-Yomi: とばり  	Examples: 幕切れ (まくぎれ), 天幕 (てんまく), 暗幕 (あんまく)"
canopy	"canopy 	 	幌   	   	Lesson: 18   Frame: 438   Strokes: 13   —   Jouyou Grade: Names   JLPT:    	Constituents: canopy, towel, limpid, sun, day, ray, small, little, human legs 	 	A large towel stretched overhead with only a few of the sun's rays breaking through represents a canopy over one's bed. 	 	 	A canopy is a towel to block the suns rays. 	 	On-Yomi: コウ   Kun-Yomi: ほろ、とばり"
brocade	"brocade 	 	錦   	   	Lesson: 18   Frame: 439   Strokes: 16   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: brocade, metal, gold, napkin, white, dove, towel 	 	A strip of white towel and some scraps of metal have the makings of a primitive kind of brocade. 	 	 	Brocade is the art of sewing gold on a white towel. 	 	On-Yomi: キン   Kun-Yomi: にしき  	Examples: 錦 (にしき)"
market	"market 	 	市   	   	Lesson: 18   Frame: 440   Strokes: 5   —   Jouyou Grade: 2   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: market, top hat, towel 	 	Dressed in nothing but a bath towel and top hat, one sets off to the marketplace in search of a bargain or two. 	 	 	My recurring nightmare: Walking through the market, and suddenly realizing that I´m wearing only a top hat...and a towel. 	 	On-Yomi: シ   Kun-Yomi: いち  	Examples: 市 (いち)"
elder sister	"elder sister 	 	姉   	   	Lesson: 18   Frame: 442   Strokes: 8   —   Jouyou Grade: 2   JLPT: 4   	Constituents: elder sister, woman, market, top hat, towel 	 	Of all the women of the family, it is the elder sister who has the duty to go to market to do the shopping. 	 	 	Unlike the younger sister (妹), who is not yet old enough to date... the elder sister is on the market! 	 	On-Yomi: シ   Kun-Yomi: あね、はは  	Examples: 姉 (あね)"
lungs	"lungs 	 	肺   	   	Lesson: 18   Frame: 443   Strokes: 9   —   Jouyou Grade: 6   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: lungs, moon, month, flesh, part of the body, market, top hat, towel 	 	One is surprised, strolling through the market, to find among the meats hung out for sale a slab marked: lungs. 	 	 	LUNGS are a PART of the BODY that can be found at any meat MARKET or black MARKET. 	 	On-Yomi: ハイ   Kun-Yomi:"
sash	"sash 	 	帯   	   	Lesson: 18   Frame: 444   Strokes: 10   —   Jouyou Grade: 4   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: sash, buckle, apron, crown, towel 	 	The part of the apron where one finds the buckle (represented pictorially by the first 5 strokes) is on the sash. 	 	 	First, note that the top half of the kanji consists of one and mountain. Of course, the ""number 1"" mountain in Japan is Mt. Fuji. The bottom half, under Mt. Fuji, consists of crown and towel. Now for the story. Archaeologists digging under Mt. Fuji (Japan´s #1 mountain) in an ancient royal tomb (they know it´s royal because of the crown) discover what looks like a towel, but after they clean it up, they see it is actually a splendid royal sash for the king´s kimono. 	 	On-Yomi: タイ   Kun-Yomi: お.びる、おび  	Examples: 帯びる (お.びる), 帯 (おび)"
stagnate	"stagnate 	 	滞   	   	Lesson: 18   Frame: 445   Strokes: 13   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: stagnate, water, water droplets, water pistol, sash, buckle, apron, crown, towel 	 	People that have been ""sashed"" to something (whether their mother's apron strings or a particular job) for too long become like water that has stopped moving: they start to stagnate. 	 	 	History of the first karate blackbelts: In those days, it was often difficult to find fresh, clean water, so samurai usually had to wash their sashes in stagnant puddles. The longer one had been studying martial arts, the older the sash on one´s karate uniform and, therefore, the darker the color. So why weren´t their karate uniforms black too? Never seen a ninja???? 	 	On-Yomi: タイ、テイ   Kun-Yomi: とどこお.る  	Examples: 滞る (とどこお.る)"
thorn	"thorn 	 	刺   	   	Lesson: 18   Frame: 446   Strokes: 8   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: thorn, tree, wood, belt, sword, sabre, saber 	 	Thorns grow on a bush here that has wrapped itself around a tree like a belt, cutting into the poor tree like little sabers. 	 	 	A TREE with a BELT wrapped around the middle. If you tighten the BELT, hundreds of tiny SABERS pop out of the tree in all directions, looking like THORNS. 	 	On-Yomi: シ   Kun-Yomi: さ.す、さ.さる、さ.し、さし、とげ  	Examples: 刺さる (さ.さる), 刺す (さ.す)"
system	"system 	 	制   	   	Lesson: 18   Frame: 447   Strokes: 8   —   Jouyou Grade: 5   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: system, cow, belt, sword, sabre, saber 	 	This kanji show a unique system for leading cows to the slaughterer's saber: one ties a belt about their waist and fixes that belt to an overhead cable, pulling the cow up into the air where it hangs suspended, helpless against the fate that awaits it. 	 	 	The system for making leather belts involves slicing up a cow with a sword. 	 	On-Yomi: セイ   Kun-Yomi:"
made in...	"made in... 	 	製   	   	Lesson: 18   Frame: 448   Strokes: 14   —   Jouyou Grade: 5   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: made in…, system, cow, belt, sword, sabre, saber, hat, scarf, cloth, clothes, clothing, garment 	 	A label indicating that a garment was made in U.S.A. or Taiwan or Japan is itself a symbol for the systematization of the garment industry. 	 	 	Made in china - a system of exploitation . making garments for nothing. 	 	On-Yomi: セイ   Kun-Yomi:"
revolve	"revolve 	 	転   	   	Lesson: 18   Frame: 449   Strokes: 11   —   Jouyou Grade: 3   JLPT: 4   	Constituents: revolve, car, rising cloud, two, elbow, wall 	 	As the wheels of the car revolve, they kick up small rising clouds of dust and debris behind them. 	 	 	The REVOLVING wheels of the car (with REVOLVER blaring on the stereo) kicked up RISING CLOUDS of dust. 	 	On-Yomi: テン   Kun-Yomi: ころ.がる、ころ.げる、ころ.がす、ころ.ぶ、まろ.ぶ、うたた、うつ.る、くる.めく  	Examples: 転がす (ころ.がす), 転がる (ころ.がる), 転げる (ころ.げる), 転ぶ (ころ.ぶ)"
technique	"technique 	 	芸   	   	Lesson: 18   Frame: 450   Strokes: 7   —   Jouyou Grade: 4   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: technique, flowers, rising cloud, two, elbow, wall 	 	The secret technique of making a rising cloud of smoke turn into a bouquet of flowers is shown here. 	 	 	Imagine an old Kung-fu movie: ""Try my rising cloud flower technique!!!"" smash pow crack!! . 	 	On-Yomi: ゲイ、ウン   Kun-Yomi: う.える、のり、わざ"
rain	"rain 	 	雨   	   	Lesson: 18   Frame: 451   Strokes: 8   —   Jouyou Grade: 1   JLPT: 5   	Constituents: rain, rain, weather 	 	This kanji, also a primitive, is one of the clearest instances we have of a complex pictograph. The top line is the sky, the next 3 strokes a pair of clouds, and the final 4 dots the rain collected there and waiting to fall. 	  * As a primitive it can mean either rain or weather in general. Because it takes so much space, it usually has to be contracted into a crown by shortening the second and third strokes into a crown. 	 	From the ceiling hangs a towel dripping four drops like RAIN. 	 	On-Yomi: ウ   Kun-Yomi: あめ、あま-、-さめ  	Examples: 雨 (あま), 雨 (あめ)"
cloud	"cloud 	 	雲   	   	Lesson: 18   Frame: 452   Strokes: 12   —   Jouyou Grade: 2   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: cloud, rain, weather, rising cloud, two, elbow, wall 	 	Here is the full character for cloud from which the primitive for a rising cloud derives. Clouds begin with vapors rising up in small clouds from the surface of the earth, and then gathering to make clouds that eventually dump their rain back on the earth. 	 	 	Every rising cloud is a potential rain cloud. (Thanks astridtops). 	 	On-Yomi: ウン   Kun-Yomi: くも、-ぐも  	Examples: 雲 (くも)"
cloudy weather	"cloudy weather 	 	曇   	   	Lesson: 18   Frame: 453   Strokes: 16   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: cloudy weather, sun, day, cloud, rain, weather, rising cloud, two, elbow, wall 	 	We refer to days when the sun is covered by the clouds as cloudy weather. 	 	 	Cloudy weather is when a cloud blocks the sun (up above). 	 	On-Yomi: ドン   Kun-Yomi: くも.る  	Examples: 曇る (くも.る)"
thunder	"thunder 	 	雷   	   	Lesson: 18   Frame: 454   Strokes: 13   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: thunder, rain, weather, rice field, brains 	 	The full rumble and roar and terror of thunder is best felt not with your head tucked under your pillow safe in bed, but out in an open rice field where you can get the real feel of the weather. 	 	 	If it´s raining and you´re standing in the middle of a rice field, you´re sure to soon become acquainted with the thunder up close and personal. 	 	On-Yomi: ライ   Kun-Yomi: かみなり  	Examples: 雷 (かみなり)"
frost	"frost 	 	霜   	   	Lesson: 18   Frame: 455   Strokes: 17   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: frost, rain, weather, inter, Inter Milan, tree, wood, eye 	 	Think of frost as a cooperative venture, an inter-action of the malevolent forces of weather that sit around a conference table and finally decide to allow a very light amount of moisture to fall just before a short and sudden freeze. 	 	 	FROST is kind of an inter-weather, phenomenon, something between rain, snow and freezing temp’s. 	 	On-Yomi: ソウ   Kun-Yomi: しも  	Examples: 霜 (しも)"
winter	"winter 	 	冬   	   	Lesson: 18   Frame: 456   Strokes: 5   —   Jouyou Grade: 2   JLPT: 4   	Constituents: winter, walking legs, ice 	 	Walking legs slipping on the ice are a sure sign of winter. 	 	 	Don´t slip off your legs in winter, strap two skis to your feet. 	 	On-Yomi: トウ   Kun-Yomi: ふゆ  	Examples: 冬 (ふゆ)"
heavens	"heavens 	 	天   	   	Lesson: 18   Frame: 457   Strokes: 4   —   Jouyou Grade: 1   JLPT: 5   	Constituents: heavens, heavens, one, ceiling, large 	 	This character is meant to be a pictograph of a great man, said to represent the Lord of the Heavens. (You may, of course, use the elements ceiling and St. Bernard instead.) 	  * The primitive can mean either the heaven of eternal bliss or the general term for sky, the heavens. Pay special attention to the fact that in its primitive form the first stroke is written right to left, rather like the first stroke of thousand (Frame 40), rather than left to right. From the next character, we shall give it the primitive meaning of a witch. 	 	If you think of the sky as a ceiling above our heads, here you have the heavens as the largest ceiling you could ever imagine. As Heisig pointed out, nothing comes above the ceiling primitive thus the order of primitives is taken care of. 	 	On-Yomi: テン   Kun-Yomi: あまつ、あめ、あま-  	Examples: 天 (あめ)"
bridge	"bridge 	 	橋   	   	Lesson: 18   Frame: 460   Strokes: 16   —   Jouyou Grade: 3   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: bridge, tree, wood, angel, heavens, mouth, hood, mouth, mouth2 	 	The bridge shown here is made of trees in their natural form, except that the trunks have been carved into the forms of angels, a sort of ""Ponte degli Angeli."" 	 	 	The nicest bridge is not in Hollywood or Los Angeles, but in San Francisco. 	 	On-Yomi: キョウ   Kun-Yomi: はし  	Examples: 橋 (はし)"
attractive	"attractive 	 	嬌   	   	Lesson: 18   Frame: 461   Strokes: 15   —   Jouyou Grade:    JLPT:    	Constituents: attractive, woman, angel, heavens, mouth, hood, mouth, mouth2 	 	Associating a particularly attractive woman you know with an angel should be no problem. 	 	 	The most attractive woman in the world is obviously Angelina Jolie. 	 	On-Yomi: キョウ   Kun-Yomi: なまめか.しい"
stand up	"stand up 	 	立   	   	Lesson: 18   Frame: 462   Strokes: 5   —   Jouyou Grade: 1   JLPT: 4   	Constituents: stand up, vase, stand up 	 	This picture of a vase standing up has its meaning extended to represent the general posture of anything standing up. 	  * Used as a primitive, it can also mean vase. Using its kanji meaning, think of something standing up that is normally lying down, or something standing up in an unusual way. 	 	A vase that can´t stand up won´t be a vase for long. 	 	On-Yomi: リツ、リュウ、リットル   Kun-Yomi: た.つ、-た.つ、た.ち-、た.てる、-た.てる、た.て-、たて-、-た.て、-だ.て、-だ.てる  	Examples: 立案 (りつあん), 起立 (きりつ), 独立 (どくりつ), 立つ (た.つ), 立てる (た.てる)"
cry	"cry 	 	泣   	   	Lesson: 18   Frame: 463   Strokes: 8   —   Jouyou Grade: 4   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: cry, water, water droplets, water pistol, vase, stand up 	 	One cries and cries until one is standing up knee-deep in water (or until one has a vase-full of water). 	 	 	Guys have two ways of watering when they are standing, the less common one is crying. 	 	On-Yomi: キュウ   Kun-Yomi: な.く  	Examples: 泣く (な.く)"
badge	"badge 	 	章   	   	Lesson: 18   Frame: 464   Strokes: 11   —   Jouyou Grade: 3   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: badge, vase, stand up, sunflower, early, sun, day, ten, needle 	 	Try to imagine a club badge pinned to your lapel in the form of a mammoth sunflower protruding from a wee little vase. 	 	 	In the military, badges are given out early in the day, with everyone standing at attention. 	 	On-Yomi: ショウ   Kun-Yomi:"
vie	"vie 	 	競   	   	Lesson: 18   Frame: 465   Strokes: 20   —   Jouyou Grade: 4   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: vie, vase, stand up, elder brother, teenager, mouth, human legs, vase2, stand up2, elder brother2, teenager2, mouth2, human legs2 	 	Two teenagers are seen here standing up to one another, vying for the attention of their peers. 	 	 	TWO twin BROTHERS are competing (VYING) for the title of who is the older BROTHER. The game is that they must balance a VASE on their head and the one who drops his looses and becomes the younger BROTHER! 	 	On-Yomi: キョウ、ケイ   Kun-Yomi: きそ.う、せ.る  	Examples: 競争 (きょうそう), 競技 (きょうぎ), 競泳 (きょうえい), 競う (きそ.う), 競る (せ.る)"
sovereign	"sovereign 	 	帝   	   	Lesson: 18   Frame: 466   Strokes: 9   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: sovereign, vase, stand up, apron, crown, towel 	 	An uncommon, but not altogether unlikely picture of a reigning sovereign has him standing up in his apron, presumably at the behest of HIS sovereign (she who is to be obeyed), who needs help with washing the dishes. 	 	 	The crazy sovereign stands up from his throne, wearing nothing but a crown and a towel. That´s why they try to keep him locked up in the castle away from the public. 	 	On-Yomi: テイ   Kun-Yomi: みかど"
juvenile	"juvenile 	 	童   	   	Lesson: 18   Frame: 468   Strokes: 12   —   Jouyou Grade: 3   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: juvenile, vase, stand up, computer 	 	This frame shows up the image of a juvenile hacker standing on top of a computer, or rather jumping up and down on it, because it refused to come up with the right answer. 	 	 	The juvenile stood on top of his computer and broke it. Noob. 	 	On-Yomi: ドウ   Kun-Yomi: わらべ  	Examples: 童 (わらべ)"
pupil	"pupil 	 	瞳   	   	Lesson: 18   Frame: 469   Strokes: 17   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: pupil, eye, juvenile, vase, stand up, computer 	 	Begin with the double meaning of the key word pupil: ""student"" and the ""the apple of one's eye."" Now all you have to do is dwell on the phrase ""juvenile of one's eye"" (the meaning here) until it provides you with an image. 	 	 	In Japanese comics, the eye´s of juvenilles all have enormouse pupils. 	 	On-Yomi: ドウ、トウ   Kun-Yomi: ひとみ  	Examples: 瞳 (ひとみ)"
bell	"bell 	 	鐘   	   	Lesson: 18   Frame: 470   Strokes: 20   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: bell, metal, gold, juvenile, vase, stand up, computer 	 	This bell is made of cheap metal, and so badly made that when you ring it, it lets out a noise like the ""bellowing"" of juveniles who aren't getting their own way. 	 	 	The METAL bell rings to call the JUVENILES to class. 	 	On-Yomi: ショウ   Kun-Yomi: かね  	Examples: 鐘 (かね)"
make a deal	"make a deal 	 	商   	   	Lesson: 18   Frame: 471   Strokes: 11   —   Jouyou Grade: 3   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: make a deal, vase, stand up, alien, hood, human legs, mouth 	 	See the peddlar standing atop his motorcycle helmet as if it were a soapbox, hawking his wares to passersby. The legs and mouth represent the tools of the trade of making a deal any way you can. 	 	 	I use what I think is the real etymology for this kanji which is so shocking it sticks. The STANDING member at the top is a certain part of the body that all men have and it is approaching the HOLE between TWO LEGS (the HOOD) with extra marks to show they are FLESHY - ie a womans legs. So this shows the oldest DEAL of all time - prostitution. 	 	On-Yomi: ショウ   Kun-Yomi: あきな.う  	Examples: 商う (あきな.う)"
legitimate wife	"legitimate wife 	 	嫡   	   	Lesson: 18   Frame: 472   Strokes: 14   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: legitimate wife, woman, antique, vase, stand up, hood, old, tombstone, gravestone, church, ten, needle, mouth 	 	The phrase legitimate wife would have no meaning if there were not such things as ""illegitimate wives,"" taken because one's legal woman has turned into an antique. The very offense of the idea should help you remember the kanji. 	 	 	Legitmate wifes tend to be women who are antiques in contrast to the young bit of illigitmate fluff on the side. 	 	On-Yomi: チャク、テキ   Kun-Yomi:"
suitable	"suitable 	 	適   	   	Lesson: 18   Frame: 473   Strokes: 14   —   Jouyou Grade: 5   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: suitable, antique, vase, stand up, hood, old, tombstone, gravestone, church, ten, needle, mouth, road 	 	Can you imagine anything less suitable to do with one's precious antiques than to display them in the middle of a crowded road-way? 	 	 	Think of the term from televison ""suitable for all audiences"" to get the sense of the word. What program could be more suitable for the whole family than the ""antiques road(show)"". 	 	On-Yomi: テキ   Kun-Yomi: かな.う"
drip	"drip 	 	滴   	   	Lesson: 18   Frame: 474   Strokes: 14   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: drip, water, water droplets, water pistol, antique, vase, stand up, hood, old, tombstone, gravestone, church, ten, needle, mouth 	 	Picture water dripping on what you thought were precious antiques, only to find that the artificial aging painted on them is running! 	 	 	DRIPS of WATER were collected in ANTIQUE VASES since the museum had a leaky roof. 	 	On-Yomi: テキ   Kun-Yomi: しずく、したた.る  	Examples: 滴 (しずく), 滴る (したた.る)"
enemy	"enemy 	 	敵   	   	Lesson: 18   Frame: 475   Strokes: 15   —   Jouyou Grade: 5   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: enemy, antique, vase, stand up, hood, old, tombstone, gravestone, church, ten, needle, mouth, taskmaster 	 	Picture your most precious antique (it doesn't matter how old it really is, so long as it is the oldest thing YOU own) being knocked over by your most unlikeable taskmaster, and you have a good picture of how people make themselves enemies for life. 	 	 	The taskmaster became my enemy for life when he smashed the antique vase holding my wife´s ashes. 	 	On-Yomi: テキ   Kun-Yomi: かたき、あだ、かな.う  	Examples: 敵 (かたき)"
spoon	"spoon 	 	匕   	   	Lesson: 18   Frame: 476   Strokes: 2   —   Jouyou Grade:    JLPT:    	Constituents: spoon, sitting on the ground 	 	This character, a pictograph of a spoon, is easy enough to remember, provided you keep it distinct from that for seven, where the first stroke is written left to right (the opposite of here) and cuts noticeably across the second. 	  * As a primitive, this kanji can take on the additional meaning of someone sitting on the ground, of which it can also be considered a pictograph. In general, the second stroke does not cut through the first - or if it does in some fonts, only slightly. 	 	To remember the primitive meaning, picture someone sitting on the ground performing Seppuku...with a spoon. http://tinyurl.com/co48k. 	 	On-Yomi: ヒ   Kun-Yomi: さじ、さじのひ"
north	"north 	 	北   	   	Lesson: 18   Frame: 480   Strokes: 5   —   Jouyou Grade: 2   JLPT: 5   	Constituents: north, spoon, sitting on the ground 	 	The cold air from the north is so strong that we see two people sitting on the ground back to back, their arms interlocked so they don't blow away. (Pay special attention to the drawing of the first 3 strokes.) 	 	 	Warning: The left part is NOT the primitive turtle! The stroke order is different. Sometimes it will look exactly the same but not always depending on the font / style used to draw this character. Be sure to study the difference! 	 	On-Yomi: ホク   Kun-Yomi: きた  	Examples: 北 (きた)"
stature	"stature 	 	背   	   	Lesson: 18   Frame: 481   Strokes: 9   —   Jouyou Grade: 6   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: stature, north, spoon, sitting on the ground, moon, month, flesh, part of the body 	 	One's stature is measured according to the ""northern-most"" part of the body. 	 	 	While japanese people are generally small, people in the northern contryes have taller stature because of all the flesh they eat! 	 	On-Yomi: ハイ   Kun-Yomi: せ、せい、そむ.く、そむ.ける  	Examples: 背 (せ), 背 (せい), 背く (そむ.く), 背ける (そむ.ける)"
compare	"compare 	 	比   	   	Lesson: 18   Frame: 482   Strokes: 4   —   Jouyou Grade: 5   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: compare, spoon, sitting on the ground, spoon2, sitting on the ground2 	 	With two spoons, one in each hand, you are comparing your mother's cooking with your mother-in-law's. 	 	 	A gay couple about to turn around to compare which role is better... 	 	On-Yomi: ヒ   Kun-Yomi: くら.べる  	Examples: 比べる (くら.べる)"
descendants	"descendants 	 	昆   	   	Lesson: 18   Frame: 483   Strokes: 8   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: descendants, sun, day, compare, spoon, sitting on the ground, spoon2, sitting on the ground2 	 	By comparing apes with anthropoids, we not only discover the latter have descended from those progenitors educated in the higher branches, but that the very idea of seeing everything descended from everything else, one way or another, means that there is ""nothing new UNDER the sun."" 	 	 	Grandparent spends all DAY COMPARING photos of their DESCENDANTS. 	 	On-Yomi: コン   Kun-Yomi:"
all	"all 	 	皆   	   	Lesson: 18   Frame: 484   Strokes: 9   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: all, compare, spoon, sitting on the ground, white, dove, spoon2, sitting on the ground2 	 	Think of the housewives in TV commercials ""comparing the whiteness"" of their laundry across the fence, a typical advertisement for the popular detergent known as All. (If you don't know the brand, surely you've heard the phrases ""all-purpose detergent"" or ""all-temperature detergent."") 	 	 	If you compare colors, you will find that white is produced from the mix of all the others. 	 	On-Yomi: カイ   Kun-Yomi: みな、みんな  	Examples: 皆 (みな)"
mix	"mix 	 	混   	   	Lesson: 18   Frame: 487   Strokes: 11   —   Jouyou Grade: 5   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: mix, water, water droplets, water pistol, descendants, sun, day, compare, spoon, sitting on the ground, spoon2, sitting on the ground2 	 	Mixed marriages, this character suggests, water down the quality of one's descendants - the oldest racial nonsense in the world! 	 	 	People have to mix their fluids (have sex), in order to create descendants. 	 	On-Yomi: コン   Kun-Yomi: ま.じる、-ま.じり、ま.ざる、ま.ぜる、こ.む  	Examples: 混ざる (ま.ざる), 混じる (ま.じる), 混ぜる (ま.ぜる)"
thirst	"thirst 	 	渇   	   	Lesson: 18   Frame: 488   Strokes: 11   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: thirst, water, water droplets, water pistol, mexican bandit, muchacho, siesta, sun, day, aroma, bound up, spoon, sitting on the ground 	 	As you pass by the muchacho taking the siesta, he cries out that he is thirsty and asks for something to drink. So you turn the water hose on him. 	 	 	You awaken from your siesta because you feel extremely thirsty so you go looking for some water. 	 	On-Yomi: カツ   Kun-Yomi: かわ.く  	Examples: 渇く (かわ.く)"
audience	"audience 	 	謁   	   	Lesson: 18   Frame: 489   Strokes: 15   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: audience, say, words, keitai, mouth, mexican bandit, muchacho, siesta, sun, day, aroma, bound up, spoon, sitting on the ground 	 	Imagine an audience with the emperor or the pope in which all those in attendance are sitting down, leaning against the wall, sleeping like our muchacho on siesta as the honorable host delivers his speech. 	 	 	The talk was so boring the audience took a siesta. 	 	On-Yomi: エツ   Kun-Yomi:"
brown	"brown 	 	褐   	   	Lesson: 18   Frame: 490   Strokes: 13   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: brown, cloak, mexican bandit, muchacho, siesta, sun, day, aroma, bound up, spoon, sitting on the ground 	 	The color of the serape or cloak of our muchacho on siesta is a dull brown, the color this kanji indicates. 	 	 	Why is my package late? Imagine a UPS driver dressed in BROWN garments taking a siesta. What can BROWN do for you? 	 	On-Yomi: カツ   Kun-Yomi:"
hoarse	"hoarse 	 	喝   	   	Lesson: 18   Frame: 491   Strokes: 11   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: hoarse, mouth, mexican bandit, muchacho, siesta, sun, day, aroma, bound up, spoon, sitting on the ground 	 	When the muchacho on siesta looks up at you and opens his mouth to talk, his voice is so hoarse that you cannot understand him. 	 	 	If you have a siesta with your mouthopen, you will wake up with a hoarse voice. 	 	On-Yomi: カツ   Kun-Yomi:"
delicious	"delicious 	 	旨   	   	Lesson: 18   Frame: 493   Strokes: 6   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: delicious, spoon, sitting on the ground, sun, day 	 	Something is so downright delicious that one spends the entire day with a spoon in hand gobbling it up. 	 	 	Use a spoon to eat a DELICIOUS hot fudge sundae. Duh.. 	 	On-Yomi: シ   Kun-Yomi: むね、うま.い  	Examples: 旨 (むね)"
fat	"fat 	 	脂   	   	Lesson: 18   Frame: 494   Strokes: 10   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: fat, moon, month, flesh, part of the body, delicious, spoon, sun, day 	 	This kanji tells us that if you feed the flesh with too many delicious things, it soon picks up a thick layer of fat. 	 	 	Every chef will tell you, fat is what make the meat taste delicious. 	 	On-Yomi: シ   Kun-Yomi: あぶら  	Examples: 脂 (あぶら)"
I (one)	"I (one) 	 	壱   	   	Lesson: 18   Frame: 496   Strokes: 7   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: 1 (one), samurai, crown, spoon, sitting on the ground 	 	The Roman numeral I - like that for II we met earlier in frame 379 - is only rarely used now. In the midst of all the samurai, we notice one in particular sitting on the ground with a crown on his head, indicating that he is ""number I"" in the current rankings. 	 	 	I am ´the one´ , says the samurai with the crown around his waist and a spoon up his a***. 	 	On-Yomi: イチ、イツ   Kun-Yomi: ひとつ"
every	"every 	 	毎   	   	Lesson: 18   Frame: 497   Strokes: 6   —   Jouyou Grade: 2   JLPT: 5   	Constituents: every, reclining, lying down, mother 	 	""Behind every successful person lies a woman...,"" who usually turns out to be one's mama! 	 	 	Freud believed every man wants to lie down with his mother. 	 	On-Yomi: マイ   Kun-Yomi: ごと、-ごと.に"
cleverness	"cleverness 	 	敏   	   	Lesson: 18   Frame: 498   Strokes: 10   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: cleverness, every, reclining, lying down, mother, breasts, taskmaster 	 	Behind every successful taskmaster, the cleverness of a fox to outwit his charges. 	 	 	Every master(or taskmaster) must have some degree of cleverness. 	 	On-Yomi: ビン   Kun-Yomi: さとい"
plum	"plum 	 	梅   	   	Lesson: 18   Frame: 499   Strokes: 10   —   Jouyou Grade: 4   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: plum, tree, wood, every, reclining, lying down, mother, breasts 	 	Behind every Jack Horner's pie maker, a tree full of plums. 	 	 	Plums actually grow on every single tree. What, you didn´t know that? They do. Orange trees, apple trees, cantaloupe trees. Plums are simply mutant fruits that have been installed in the root software of every single tree. I hear that some plum-loving scientists are working on a way to hack every tree´s genetic code so that every tree will bear nothing _but_ plums. 	 	On-Yomi: バイ   Kun-Yomi: うめ  	Examples: 梅 (うめ)"
sea	"sea 	 	海   	   	Lesson: 18   Frame: 500   Strokes: 9   —   Jouyou Grade: 2   JLPT: 4   	Constituents: sea, water, water droplets, water pistol, every, reclining, lying down, mother, breasts 	 	Behind every drop of water, a sea from which it originated. 	 	 	Every drop of water will eventually return to the sea. 	 	On-Yomi: カイ   Kun-Yomi: うみ  	Examples: 海 (うみ)"
beg	"beg 	 	乞   	   	Lesson: 18   Frame: 501   Strokes: 3   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT:    	Constituents: beg, reclining, lying down, fishhook 	 	See someone lying down in a public place with a hook in place of a hand, begging a morsel of rice or a few pence. 	 	 	Lying down, Captain Hook is begging to be spared from the ticking crocodile. 	 	On-Yomi: コツ、キツ、キ、キケ、コチ   Kun-Yomi: こ.う  	Examples: 乞う (こ.う)"
drought	"drought 	 	乾   	   	Lesson: 18   Frame: 502   Strokes: 11   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: drought, mist, ten, needle, early, sun, day, beg, reclining, lying down, fishhook, ten2, needle2 	 	In times of drought anything at all will do. Here we see the victims begging for just a little mist for relief. 	 	 	During a drought, everything begs for even a mist for relief. 	 	On-Yomi: カン、ケン   Kun-Yomi: かわ.く、かわ.かす、ほ.す、ひ.る、いぬい  	Examples: 乾かす (かわ.かす), 乾く (かわ.く)"
abdomen	"abdomen 	 	腹   	   	Lesson: 18   Frame: 503   Strokes: 13   —   Jouyou Grade: 6   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: abdomen, moon, month, flesh, part of the body, fold back, double back, reclining, lying down, sun, day, walking legs 	 	If you double back (fold over) most animals - or people, for that matter - in the middle, the part of the body where the crease comes is the abdomen. 	 	 	The only body part that doubles over. 	 	On-Yomi: フク   Kun-Yomi: はら  	Examples: 腹 (はら)"
duplicate	"duplicate 	 	複   	   	Lesson: 18   Frame: 504   Strokes: 14   —   Jouyou Grade: 5   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: duplicate, cloak, fold back, double back, reclining, lying down, sun, day, walking legs 	 	In its original and etymologically transparent sense, to duplicate something means to double it back with a fold, like the fold of a cloak. 	 	 	My girlfiend saw someone wearing the exact same (duplicate) outfit at a party, so she doubled back to change! 	 	On-Yomi: フク   Kun-Yomi:"
lack	"lack 	 	欠   	   	Lesson: 18   Frame: 505   Strokes: 4   —   Jouyou Grade: 4   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: lack, yawn 	 	The pictograph hidden in this character is of someone yawning. The first stroke shows the head thrown back; the second, the arm bent at the elbow as the hand reaches up to cover the mouth; and the last two, the legs. Since yawning shows a lack of something (psychologically, interest; physiologically, sleep), the connection is plain to see. 	  * As a primitive, it can mean either yawn or lack. 	 	To me, this kanji looks like a person with two arms and two legs, but who lacks a head. 	 	On-Yomi: ケツ、ケン   Kun-Yomi: か.ける、か.く、あくび  	Examples: 欠く (か.く), 欠ける (か.ける)"
blow	"blow 	 	吹   	   	Lesson: 18   Frame: 506   Strokes: 7   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: blow, mouth, lack, yawn 	 	To blow is really no more than a deliberate effort to make one's mouth lack all the air that is in it. 	 	 	This is clearly a BLOWJOB, we can see the MOUTH and the LACK OF condom. (I am sorry for the image, but it sticks forever in your mind). 	 	On-Yomi: スイ   Kun-Yomi: ふ.く  	Examples: 吹く (ふ.く)"
cook	"cook 	 	炊   	   	Lesson: 18   Frame: 507   Strokes: 8   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: cook, fire, lack, yawn 	 	Better to picture what happens when you do not pay attention to your work in the kitchen. Here we see a blazing fire and an inattentive, yawning cook who let things get out of control. 	 	 	Japanese cooking sometimes lacks fire, e.g., sashimi. 	 	On-Yomi: スイ   Kun-Yomi: た.く、-だ.き  	Examples: 炊く (た.く)"
song	"song 	 	歌   	   	Lesson: 18   Frame: 508   Strokes: 14   —   Jouyou Grade: 2   JLPT: 4   	Constituents: song, cancan, can, mouth, street, nail, spike, lack, yawn, can2, mouth2, street2, nail2, spike2 	 	The song in this kanji is being sung by a chorus line of can-can girls. Why it should be eliciting nothing but yawning from the audience, I leave to you to decide. 	 	 	Can-Can-ers lack the ability to sing a song, so they just dance. 	 	On-Yomi: カ   Kun-Yomi: うた、うた.う  	Examples: 歌 (うた), 歌う (うた.う)"
soft	"soft 	 	軟   	   	Lesson: 18   Frame: 509   Strokes: 11   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: soft, car, lack, yawn 	 	If the cushions of one's car are too soft, one may begin yawning at the wheel. 	 	 	Cars are rough steel things, lacking softness. 	 	On-Yomi: ナン   Kun-Yomi: やわ.らか、やわ.らかい  	Examples: 軟らか (やわ.らか), 軟らかい (やわ.らかい)"
next	"next 	 	次   	   	Lesson: 18   Frame: 510   Strokes: 6   —   Jouyou Grade: 3   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: next, ice, lack, yawn 	 	This key word connotes the ""next in line"" of a succession of people or things. Let there be a lack of ice on the hottest day of summer, and you stand impatiently in line waiting for the distributor to call out ""Next!"" 	  * As a primitive, this character can either retain its key word meaning of next or the related meaning of second. 	 	Is this store lacking ice? Let´s try the next one, then. 	 	On-Yomi: ジ、シ   Kun-Yomi: つ.ぐ、つぎ  	Examples: 次回 (じかい), 次元 (じげん), 目次 (もくじ), 次ぐ (つ.ぐ), 次 (つぎ)"
briar	"briar 	 	茨   	   	Lesson: 18   Frame: 511   Strokes: 9   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT:    	Constituents: briar, flowers, next, ice, lack, yawn 	 	Earlier we made mention of the story of Briar Rose (or ""Sleeping Beauty,"" as we called her in frame 165) and drew attention to the briar hedge that grew up all about her castle. But in the second part of the story, these briars blossomed into flowers. Hence her name, Briar Rose. Be careful not to confuse this character with that for thorn (Frame 446). 	 	 	To prevent animals from eating the beautiful flowers in your garden, the best thing to do is to plant briar bushes immediately next to them. 	 	On-Yomi: シ、ジ   Kun-Yomi: いばら、かや、くさぶき  	Examples: 茨 (いばら)"
assets	"assets 	 	資   	   	Lesson: 18   Frame: 512   Strokes: 13   —   Jouyou Grade: 5   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: assets, next, ice, lack, yawn, shellfish, clam, oyster, eye, animal legs, eight 	 	The first shells (money) you earn, you use to pay your debts. From then on, the next shells you accumulate become your assets. 	 	 	Assets are the next best thing to money. 	 	On-Yomi: シ   Kun-Yomi:"
figure	"figure 	 	姿   	   	Lesson: 18   Frame: 513   Strokes: 9   —   Jouyou Grade: 6   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: figure, next, ice, lack, yawn, woman 	 	This kanji depicts a woman's figure as a sort of second self. 	 	 	The next woman always has a better figure! Thinking like that, you´ll end up alone in an old folks home longing for the good old days! 	 	On-Yomi: シ   Kun-Yomi: すがた  	Examples: 姿 (すがた)"
consult with	"consult with 	 	諮   	   	Lesson: 18   Frame: 514   Strokes: 16   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: consult with, say, words, keitai, mouth, next, ice, lack, yawn, mouth, mouth2 	 	To seek the words of a second mouth is to consult with someone about something. 	 	 	Having a word with the next mouth over, like a neighbor, is usually a good way to consult with somebody for cheap. Because, you know, actual consultants charge huge sums. 	 	On-Yomi: シ   Kun-Yomi: はか.る  	Examples: 諮る (はか.る)"
compensation	"compensation 	 	賠   	   	Lesson: 19   Frame: 515   Strokes: 15   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: compensation, shellfish, clam, oyster, eye, animal legs, eight, muzzle, vase, stand up, mouth 	 	Picture a clam used as a muzzle to quiet the complaints of a fisherman's widow asking compensation for her husband lost at sea. 	 	 	Compensation is money you give to someone to shut them up (i.e. muzzle their mouth). 	 	On-Yomi: バイ   Kun-Yomi:"
cultivate	"cultivate 	 	培   	   	Lesson: 19   Frame: 516   Strokes: 11   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: cultivate, soil, dirt, ground, muzzle, vase, stand up, mouth 	 	The barrel hoops used by many Japanese farmers to stretch clear plastic over row of vegetables in a garden patch in the hopes of cultivating bigger and bigger vegetables is a way of muzzling the soil. 	 	 	To cultivate the land is to tame it, control it. In short, you muzzle it´s unruly, chaotic nature. 	 	On-Yomi: バイ   Kun-Yomi: つちか.う  	Examples: 培う (つちか.う)"
divide	"divide 	 	剖   	   	Lesson: 19   Frame: 517   Strokes: 10   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: divide, muzzle, vase, stand up, mouth, sword, sabre, saber 	 	To ""divide and conquer"" you use a saber and a muzzle. 	 	 	When you DIVIDE someone, there is sure to be a lot of screaming. That´s why you should use a MUZZLE before using the SABER. 	 	On-Yomi: ボウ   Kun-Yomi:"
sound	"sound 	 	音   	   	Lesson: 19   Frame: 518   Strokes: 9   —   Jouyou Grade: 1   JLPT: 4   	Constituents: sound, vase, stand up, sun, day, tongue wagging 	 	The kanji for sound depicts something standing in the air over a tongue wagging in a mouth, much the same as a sound does for the briefest of moments before disappearing. 	  * The primitive from this kanji also means simply a sound. 	 	If you were standing on the sun, believe me, you´d be making sound. 	 	On-Yomi: オン、イン、ノン   Kun-Yomi: おと、ね  	Examples: 音楽 (おんがく), 発音 (はつおん), 騒音 (そうおん), 音 (おと), 音 (ね)"
