Boss yells, ""Who damaged the Xerox machine?!"" fingers of employees point at one another. 	 	On-Yomi: ソン   Kun-Yomi: そこ.なう、そこな.う、-そこ.なう、そこ.ねる、-そこ.ねる  	Examples: 損なう (そこ.なう), 損ねる (そこ.ねる)"
pick up	"pick up 	 	拾   	   	Lesson: 23   Frame: 720   Strokes: 9   —   Jouyou Grade: 3   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: pick up, finger, fingers, fit, meeting, umbrella, one, mouth 	 	Fingers . . . fit together. Compare frame 698. 	 	 	I tried to PICK UP the bowling ball...but my FINGERS didn´t FIT in the holes. 	 	On-Yomi: シュウ、ジュウ   Kun-Yomi: ひろ.う  	Examples: 拾得 (しゅうとく), 収拾 (しゅうしゅう), 拾う (ひろ.う)"
shouldering	"shouldering 	 	担   	   	Lesson: 23   Frame: 721   Strokes: 8   —   Jouyou Grade: 6   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: shouldering, finger, fingers, nightbreak, sun, day, one, floor 	 	The key word of this frame refers to shouldering a burden of some sort. Its elements are: fingers . . . nightbreak. 	 	 	One of Hercules´ labors was to hold the world in his fingers for Atlas and not move until nightbreak, shouldering the considerable burden. 	 	On-Yomi: タン   Kun-Yomi: かつ.ぐ、にな.う  	Examples: 担ぐ (かつ.ぐ), 担う (にな.う)"
foothold	"foothold 	 	拠   	   	Lesson: 23   Frame: 722   Strokes: 8   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: foothold, finger, fingers, dispose, walking legs, wind 	 	Fingers . . . dispose. 	 	 	When rockclimbing, when your weight disposes of the valuble foothold, all that´s left is your fingers keeping you from death. Meanwhile, your walking legs are left dangling in the wind. 	 	On-Yomi: キョ、コ   Kun-Yomi: よ.る  	Examples: 拠点 (きょてん), 占拠 (せんきょ), 根拠 (こんきょ)"
sketch	"sketch 	 	描   	   	Lesson: 23   Frame: 723   Strokes: 11   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: sketch, finger, fingers, seedlings, flowers, rice field, brains 	 	Fingers . . . seedling. 	 	 	A sketch is a seedling (#234) of things to come. Before the assault, the sergeant draws a sketch of the attack with his fingers in the sand. 	 	On-Yomi: ビョウ   Kun-Yomi: えが.く、か.く  	Examples: 描く (えが.く)"
maneuver	"maneuver 	 	操   	   	Lesson: 23   Frame: 724   Strokes: 16   —   Jouyou Grade: 6   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: maneuver, finger, fingers, wooden goods, furniture, goods, mouth, tree, wood, mouth3 	 	Fingers . . . goods . . . tree. 	 	 	Tip: goods + wood/tree : This combination of primitives appears four times in Heisig, so it´s worthwhile giving it a name. I suggest ""furniture"" (a common type of wooden goods). REF: parch (#215) , maneuver (FRAME 671), winding (#1369), seaweed (#2035). Story: Using just a finger you are trying to maneuver your furniture round your room. 	 	On-Yomi: ソウ、サン   Kun-Yomi: みさお、あやつ.る  	Examples: 操る (あやつ.る), 操 (みさお)"
touch	"touch 	 	接   	   	Lesson: 23   Frame: 725   Strokes: 11   —   Jouyou Grade: 5   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: touch, finger, fingers, concubine, vase, stand up, woman 	 	Fingers . . . vase . . . woman. 	 	 	A pervert meets a woman. The pervert tries to touch the women with his lustful fingers. The woman takes a vase, lifts it over her head and smashes it on the pervert´s head... 	 	On-Yomi: セツ、ショウ   Kun-Yomi: つ.ぐ  	Examples: 接ぐ (つ.ぐ)"
put up a notice	"put up a notice 	 	掲   	   	Lesson: 23   Frame: 726   Strokes: 11   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: put up (a notice), finger, fingers, mexican bandit, muchacho, siesta, sun, day, aroma, bound up, spoon, sitting on the ground 	 	Fingers . . . siesta. 	 	 	A muchacho puts up a notice that says “NO FINGER SNAPPING ALLOWED. MUCHACHOS ON SIESTA”. The muchachos are sleeping soundly, completely oblivious to the sound of dogs barking, guitar playing and even gun shots. Now imagine one tourist passing by and snapping his fingers and waking up all the muchachos at once. 	 	On-Yomi: ケイ   Kun-Yomi: かか.げる  	Examples: 掲げる (かか.げる)"
hang	"hang 	 	掛   	   	Lesson: 23   Frame: 727   Strokes: 11   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: hang, finger, fingers, ivy, square jewel, soil, dirt, ground, magic wand, augury, soil2, dirt2, ground2 	 	Fingers . . . ivy . . . magic wand. 	 	 	Think RPG. The wizard points his finger to the guard and the ivy he has just animated with his magic wand climbs down the wall to hang the poor guy, opening the way for the adventurers into the dungeon. 	 	On-Yomi: カイ、ケイ   Kun-Yomi: か.ける、-か.ける、か.け、-か.け、-が.け、か.かる、-か.かる、-が.かる、か.かり、-が.かり、かかり、-がかり  	Examples: 掛かる (か.かる), 掛ける (か.ける), 掛 (かかり)"
polish	"polish 	 	研   	   	Lesson: 23   Frame: 729   Strokes: 9   —   Jouyou Grade: 3   JLPT: 4   	Constituents: polish, stone, rock, two hands 	 	Stone . . . two hands. 	 	 	My stones are so huge that it takes two hands to polish them! 	 	On-Yomi: ケン   Kun-Yomi: と.ぐ  	Examples: 研ぐ (と.ぐ)"
commandment	"commandment 	 	戒   	   	Lesson: 23   Frame: 730   Strokes: 7   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: commandment, two hands, fiesta 	 	Two hands . . . fiesta. 	 	 	Two hands, fiesta.....when moses received the ten commandments with two hands, he went back down the mountain and threw a fiesta with the jews, celebrating the arrival of the commandments. 	 	On-Yomi: カイ   Kun-Yomi: いまし.める  	Examples: 戒める (いまし.める)"
contraption	"contraption 	 	械   	   	Lesson: 23   Frame: 732   Strokes: 11   —   Jouyou Grade: 4   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: contraption, tree, wood, commandments, two hands, fiesta 	 	Tree . . . commandment. 	 	 	The ten commandments were heavy. So to help carry them, Moses made a wooden contraption; the ark of the covenant. 	 	On-Yomi: カイ   Kun-Yomi: かせ"
nose	"nose 	 	鼻   	   	Lesson: 23   Frame: 733   Strokes: 14   —   Jouyou Grade: 3   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: nose, drop, eye, rice field, brains, two hands 	 	Let me share a rather grotesque image to help with this kanji. Imagine taking your two hands and reaching up into someone's nostrils. Once inside you grab hold of the brain and yank it out. At the end, you would have a picture something like that of this character, the full kanji for nose. 	 	 	An Egyptian embalmer reaching both hands into the dead pharaoh´s nose and yanking out handfuls of brain. 	 	On-Yomi: ビ   Kun-Yomi: はな  	Examples: 鼻 (はな)"
punish	"punish 	 	刑   	   	Lesson: 23   Frame: 734   Strokes: 6   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: punish, two hands, sword, sabre, saber 	 	Two hands . . . saber. 	 	 	This kanji is for severe punishment. A man has his shackled hands placed on a wood block and they´re chopped off with a saber. No more stealing bread in the Middle East... 	 	On-Yomi: ケイ   Kun-Yomi:"
mould	"mould 	 	型   	   	Lesson: 23   Frame: 735   Strokes: 9   —   Jouyou Grade: 4   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: mould, punish, two hands, sword, sabre, saber, soil, dirt, ground 	 	Punish . . . soil. In cases like this, you might find it easier to break the character up into its more basic elements, like this: two hands . . . saber . . . soil. 	 	 	A famous ninja once pressed his two hands and saber into the soil of his temple, before going onto a mission from which he never came back. Think of some sort of signature that he left behind him. The mould of his two hands and saber has since become a popular attraction in the area. 	 	On-Yomi: ケイ   Kun-Yomi: かた、-がた  	Examples: 型 (かた)"
genius	"genius 	 	才   	   	Lesson: 23   Frame: 736   Strokes: 3   —   Jouyou Grade: 2   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: genius, genius, genie 	 	Whatever one is particularly adept at - one's special ""genius"" - one can do very easily, ""with one finger"" as the phrase goes. This kanji is a pictograph of that one finger. Note how its distinctive form is created by writing the final stroke of the element for fingers backwards. 	  * The primitive meaning, genie, derives from the roots of the word genius. Use the genie out in the open when the primitive appears to the right of or below its relative primitive; in that case it also keeps its same form. At the left, the form is altered, and the meaning becomes a genie in the bottle. 	 	Spinal tap: ""Every other band´s amps go to ten. But you see my extra stroke of genius - these go to eleven."". 	 	On-Yomi: サイ   Kun-Yomi:"
property	"property 	 	財   	   	Lesson: 23   Frame: 737   Strokes: 10   —   Jouyou Grade: 5   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: property, shellfish, clam, oyster, eye, animal legs, eight, genie 	 	Clam . . . genie. 	 	 	If you´re a money genius, you can afford a lot of property. 	 	On-Yomi: ザイ、サイ、ゾク   Kun-Yomi: たから  	Examples: 財産 (ざいさん), 私財 (しざい), 文化財 (ぶんかざい)"
lumber	"lumber 	 	材   	   	Lesson: 23   Frame: 738   Strokes: 7   —   Jouyou Grade: 4   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: lumber, tree, wood, genie 	 	Tree . . . genie. 	 	 	A TREE GENIUS is a LUMBER jack. Duh. 	 	On-Yomi: ザイ   Kun-Yomi:"
suppose	"suppose 	 	存   	   	Lesson: 23   Frame: 739   Strokes: 6   —   Jouyou Grade: 6   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: suppose, genie, child 	 	Genie in the bottle . . . a child. Hint: focus on the key word's connotation of ""make believe"". 	 	 	How do you suppose they manage to cram a genie inside a bottle? Well, I suppose they put him in there while he´s still a little child... 	 	On-Yomi: ソン、ゾン   Kun-Yomi:   	Examples: 存在 (そんざい), 存続 (そんぞく), 既存 (きぞん)"
exist	"exist 	 	在   	   	Lesson: 23   Frame: 740   Strokes: 6   —   Jouyou Grade: 5   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: exist, genie, soil, dirt, ground 	 	Genie in the bottle . . . soil. 	 	 	Genie in the bottle does exist but you need to dig deep into the soil to find one. 	 	On-Yomi: ザイ   Kun-Yomi: あ.る  	Examples: 在る (あ.る)"
from	"from 	 	乃   	   	Lesson: 23   Frame: 741   Strokes: 2   —   Jouyou Grade: Names   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: from, fist, from 	 	This pictograph of a clenched fist is another of the ""hand primitives."" Take note of its rather peculiar drawing. Try to think of drawing a fist (the primitive meaning) ""from"" this character to give yourself a connotation for the otherwise abstract key word. 	  * The primitive meaning is taken from the pictograph: a fist. 	 	FROM a pictograph of a thumbs up. That´s how it also gets the primitive meaning of fist. 	 	On-Yomi: ナイ、ダイ、ノ、アイ   Kun-Yomi: の、すなわ.ち、なんじ"
portable	"portable 	 	携   	   	Lesson: 23   Frame: 742   Strokes: 13   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: portable, finger, fingers, turkey, fist, from 	 	Fingers . . . turkey . . . fist. 	 	 	This character is the ""kei"" in ""keitai"" (cell phone), a word you will no doubt hear often in Japan, since everyone has one. Imagine you´ve just arrived in Japan, but don´t have a cell phone yet, so instead you´re carrying around a portable turkey you can hold in your fist. To dial a number, just poke it with your fingers. 	 	On-Yomi: ケイ   Kun-Yomi: たずさ.える、たずさ.わる  	Examples: 携える (たずさ.える), 携わる (たずさ.わる)"
reach out	"reach out 	 	及   	   	Lesson: 23   Frame: 743   Strokes: 3   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: reach out, fist, from, drop 	 	The addition of a final stroke transforms this character from the primitive for a clenched fist into the kanji for reaching out, much as a stroke of kindness can often turn anger into acceptance. 	  * As a primitive, this shall stand for outstretched hands. Only take care not to confuse it with that for beg (Frame 501) 	 	I like to think of this as a fist with with brass knuckles because of the extra line. An old school thug reaches out to help you up but then with his other hand ( with the brass knuckles) punches you. 	 	On-Yomi: キュウ   Kun-Yomi: およ.ぶ、およ.び、および、およ.ぼす  	Examples: 及び (およ.び), 及ぶ (およ.ぶ), 及ぼす (およ.ぼす)"
suck	"suck 	 	吸   	   	Lesson: 23   Frame: 744   Strokes: 6   —   Jouyou Grade: 6   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: suck, mouth, reach out 	 	Mouth . . . outstretched hands. Hint: use the image of a nursing baby. 	 	 	Imagine a baby reaching out and holding mom´s breast as if it were bottle, and sucking on it to get some milk. 	 	On-Yomi: キュウ   Kun-Yomi: す.う  	Examples: 吸う (す.う)"
handle	"handle 	 	扱   	   	Lesson: 23   Frame: 745   Strokes: 6   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: handle, finger, fingers, reach out 	 	Finger . . . outstretched hands. 	 	 	See suck (#689): if it´s too big to handle, just use your fingers instead... 	 	On-Yomi: ソウ、キュウ   Kun-Yomi: あつか.い、あつか.う、あつか.る、こ.く  	Examples: 扱う (あつか.う)"
length	"length 	 	丈   	   	Lesson: 23   Frame: 746   Strokes: 3   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT:    	Constituents: length, stick, tucked under the arm 	 	The length whose measure this kanji depicts extends from the tip of one hand to the tip of the other with arms at full length. Notice the final stroke, which cuts across the vertical second stroke to distinguish it from large (Frame 112). 	 	 	Both a meter and a yard are about one arm-length. 	 	On-Yomi: ジョウ   Kun-Yomi: たけ、だけ  	Examples: 丈 (たけ)"
history	"history 	 	史   	   	Lesson: 23   Frame: 747   Strokes: 5   —   Jouyou Grade: 4   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: history, mouth, tucked under the arm 	 	A mouth . . . tucked under the arm. 	 	 	I sleep in history class with my mouth tucked under my arm. 	 	On-Yomi: シ   Kun-Yomi:"
officer	"officer 	 	吏   	   	Lesson: 23   Frame: 748   Strokes: 6   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: officer, history, length, stick, one, mouth, tucked under the arm 	 	One . . . mouth . . . tucked under the arm. 	 	 	One officer can change the course of history. 	 	On-Yomi: リ   Kun-Yomi:"
grow late	"grow late 	 	更   	   	Lesson: 23   Frame: 749   Strokes: 7   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: grow late, Ameratasu, one, ceiling, sun, tucked under the arm 	 	The implication behind the meaning of grow late is that things are changing in the same way that the day turns into night. The elements: ceiling . . . sun . . . tucked under the arm. 	 	 	At nightbreak (#30) the sun rises above the floor, so it is logical that when it is growing late, the sun would rise to the ceiling. Time to pack up your things and take your belongings under your arm. 	 	On-Yomi: コウ   Kun-Yomi: さら、さら.に、ふ.ける、ふ.かす  	Examples: 更 (さら), 更かす (ふ.かす), 更ける (ふ.ける)"
stiff	"stiff 	 	硬   	   	Lesson: 23   Frame: 750   Strokes: 12   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: stiff, stone, rock, grow late, Ameratasu, one, ceiling, sun, tucked under the arm 	 	Rocks . . . grow late. 	 	 	A stiff drink on the ROCKs after it GROWS LATE is a way to unwind after a long day... 	 	On-Yomi: コウ   Kun-Yomi: かた.い  	Examples: 硬い (かた.い)"
or again	"or again 	 	又   	   	Lesson: 23   Frame: 752   Strokes: 2   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: or again, crotch 	 	Like the several abbreviations in Roman script to indicate ""and"" (+, &, etc.), this short two-stroke kanji is used for the similar meaning of or again. 	  * As a primitive, it will mean crotch, as in the crotch of the arm. Or whatever. 	 	After her boyfriend´s crotch has been satisfied, a woman might suggest they cuddle. The boyfriend, on the other hand, might say, ""Or again, we could fool around . . . "". 	 	On-Yomi: ユウ   Kun-Yomi: また、また-、また.の-  	Examples: 又 (また)"
pair	"pair 	 	双   	   	Lesson: 23   Frame: 753   Strokes: 4   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: pair, crotch, crotch2 	 	The crotch reduplicated gives us a pair. 	 	 	Crotch to crotch is how many pairs spend their private time together. . . 	 	On-Yomi: ソウ   Kun-Yomi: ふた、たぐい、ならぶ、ふたつ  	Examples: 双 (ふた)"
mulberry	"mulberry 	 	桑   	   	Lesson: 23   Frame: 754   Strokes: 10   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: mulberry, crotch, tree, wood, crotch3 	 	Crotches, crotches everywhere . . . tree. Hint: think of a group of children playing an original version of ""Here We Go 'Round the Mulberry Bush."" 	 	 	Children going around the mulberry tree singing ""This is the way we wash our crotch, wash our crotch, wash our crotch..."". 	 	On-Yomi: ソウ   Kun-Yomi: くわ  	Examples: 桑 (くわ)"
vessels	"vessels 	 	隻   	   	Lesson: 23   Frame: 755   Strokes: 10   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: vessels, turkey, crotch 	 	The key word indicates the Japanese generic term for counting ships. Its elements: turkey . . . crotch. 	 	 	On Vessels that travel long distances, sailors often get quite lonely. They keep TURKEYS on the VESSELS, but not for use as food. The lonely sailors take turns enjoying the turkey´s CROTCH. 	 	On-Yomi: セキ   Kun-Yomi:"
safeguard	"safeguard 	 	護   	   	Lesson: 23   Frame: 756   Strokes: 20   —   Jouyou Grade: 5   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: safeguard, say, words, keitai, mouth, radio caroline, flowers, vessels, turkey, crotch 	 	Words . . . flowers . . . vessels. 	 	 	Think of the flower-vessels as a the Greenpeace vessel “Arctic Sunrise”, only instead of a rainbow there is a big flower painted on the hull (this will come back in seize (#701) and harvest (#908)). Think of “flower-power” and of the “peace” in “Greenpeace” and it will make some sense hopefully. -- In this kanji, we see an inauguration speech being given before the Greenpeace vessel is set afloat and sent to safeguard our planet. 	 	On-Yomi: ゴ   Kun-Yomi: まも.る"
seize	"seize 	 	獲   	   	Lesson: 23   Frame: 757   Strokes: 16   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: seize, pack of wild dogs, radio caroline, flowers, vessels, turkey, crotch 	 	A pack of wild dogs . . . flowers . . . vessels. Do not confuse this with the character for arrest (Frame 706). 	 	 	A pack of genetically-modified wild dogs is seized by a group of Greenpeace activists and taken onboard the Greenpeace vessel (the flower vessel, see safeguard (#700)). 	 	On-Yomi: カク   Kun-Yomi: え.る  	Examples: 獲る (え.る)"
guy	"guy 	 	奴   	   	Lesson: 23   Frame: 758   Strokes: 5   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: guy, woman, crotch 	 	Woman . . . crotch. 	 	 	That GUY stole my WOMAN so I kicked him in the CROTCH. (This story helps keep the word ""GUY"" as someone you hold in contempt). 	 	On-Yomi: ド   Kun-Yomi: やつ、やっこ"
angry	"angry 	 	怒   	   	Lesson: 23   Frame: 759   Strokes: 9   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: angry, guy, woman, crotch, heart 	 	Guy . . . heart. 	 	 	This woman is angry because of the guys in the previous frame who pay more attention to her crotch than her heart. I prefer to decompose the kanji in three elements here because it is easier to read like a mnemonic. 	 	On-Yomi: ド、ヌ   Kun-Yomi: いか.る、おこ.る  	Examples: 怒る (いか.る), 怒る (おこ.る)"
friend	"friend 	 	友   	   	Lesson: 23   Frame: 760   Strokes: 4   —   Jouyou Grade: 2   JLPT: 5   	Constituents: friend, by one’s side, crotch 	 	By one's side . . . crotch. 	 	 	A good friend is always at your side. ---- I teach at a Japanese High School, and I often see chummy male students grabbing each other´s crotches in a joking manner. It´s still weird to me, but apparently reaching to your side and grabbing you neighbor´s crotch is a great way to express friendship. 	 	On-Yomi: ユウ   Kun-Yomi: とも  	Examples: 友 (とも)"
slip out	"slip out 	 	抜   	   	Lesson: 23   Frame: 761   Strokes: 7   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: slip out, finger, fingers, friend, woman, crotch 	 	Fingers . . . friend. 	 	 	Don´t let good friends slip out between your fingers. 	 	On-Yomi: バツ、ハツ、ハイ   Kun-Yomi: ぬ.く、-ぬ.く、ぬ.き、ぬ.ける、ぬ.かす、ぬ.かる  	Examples: 抜かす (ぬ.かす), 抜かる (ぬ.かる), 抜く (ぬ.く), 抜ける (ぬ.ける)"
throw	"throw 	 	投   	   	Lesson: 23   Frame: 762   Strokes: 7   —   Jouyou Grade: 3   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: throw, finger, fingers, cruise missile, missile, wind, crotch 	 	Fingers . . . missile. 	 	 	Well, you usually use your fingers to throw objects used as missile weapons. Easy. By the way, for those of you looking for a less anachronistic image for the missile primitive as a modern rocket, try a slingshot. it´s a crotch (originally a tree branch) that sends missile projectiles flying into/like the wind. And for this present kanji, it is something you naturally use with your fingers... 	 	On-Yomi: トウ   Kun-Yomi: な.げる、-な.げ  	Examples: 投げる (な.げる)"
drown	"drown 	 	没   	   	Lesson: 23   Frame: 763   Strokes: 7   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: drown, water, water droplets, water pistol, cruise missile, missile, wind, crotch 	 	Water . . . missile. 	 	 	(Note: this kanji is more collapse/cave-in/sink (#1888) than humans drowning) A water missile? A torpedo! And when it hits it´s target? The ship collapses then sinks and everyone drowns! 	 	On-Yomi: ボツ、モツ   Kun-Yomi: おぼ.れる、しず.む、ない"
establishment	"establishment 	 	設   	   	Lesson: 23   Frame: 765   Strokes: 11   —   Jouyou Grade: 5   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: establishment, say, words, keitai, mouth, cruise missile, missile, wind, crotch 	 	Words . . . missile. 	 	 	Establishment can be attacked by words or by missiles. Writers will use words, whereas militars will use missiles. 	 	On-Yomi: セツ   Kun-Yomi: もう.ける  	Examples: 設ける (もう.ける)"
beat	"beat 	 	撃   	   	Lesson: 23   Frame: 766   Strokes: 15   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: beat, tank, car, cruise missile, missile, wind, crotch, hand 	 	Car . . . missile . . . hand. 	 	 	Your car has missles?! That beats mine, hands down. 	 	On-Yomi: ゲキ   Kun-Yomi: う.つ  	Examples: 撃つ (う.つ)"
husk	"husk 	 	殻   	   	Lesson: 23   Frame: 767   Strokes: 11   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: husk, samurai, superfluous, crown, wind, cruise missile, missile, wind, crotch, wind2 	 	Samurai . . . superfluous . . . missile. 	 	 	Samurai´s husk/shell/armour is superflous to missile attacks 甲殻　卵殻　貝殻. 	 	On-Yomi: カク、コク、バイ   Kun-Yomi: から、がら  	Examples: 殻 (から)"
branch	"branch 	 	支   	   	Lesson: 23   Frame: 768   Strokes: 4   —   Jouyou Grade: 5   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: branch, ten, needle, crotch 	 	Needle . . . crotch. 	 	 	Picture sliding down the branch of a tree (in this case a pine tree or any tree with needles) and getting a bunch of needles stuck in your crotch--ouch!! 	 	On-Yomi: シ   Kun-Yomi: ささ.える、つか.える、か.う、しんよう、じゅうまた  	Examples: 支える (ささ.える)"
skill	"skill 	 	技   	   	Lesson: 23   Frame: 769   Strokes: 7   —   Jouyou Grade: 5   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: skill, finger, fingers, branch, ten, needle, crotch 	 	Fingers . . . branch. 	 	 	(Adapted from darg_sama´s) Balancing a branch on your finger is the prototypical example of a skill that is nothing more than a skill (i.e., it is completely useless). 	 	On-Yomi: ギ   Kun-Yomi: わざ  	Examples: 技 (わざ)"
bough	"bough 	 	枝   	   	Lesson: 23   Frame: 770   Strokes: 8   —   Jouyou Grade: 5   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: bough, tree, wood, branch, ten, needle, crotch 	 	Tree . . . branch. Take a moment to focus on the differences between a bough, a branch, and a twig (Frame 319). 	 	 	The tree´s primary branch is known as the bough. 	 	On-Yomi: シ   Kun-Yomi: えだ  	Examples: 枝 (えだ)"
limb	"limb 	 	肢   	   	Lesson: 23   Frame: 771   Strokes: 8   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: limb, moon, month, flesh, part of the body, branch, ten, needle, crotch 	 	Part of the body . . . branch. 	 	 	The limbs that this kanji represents are parts of the body that are connected to the trunk, like the main branches to a tree (“arms and legs” is the second meaning of this kanji). In other words, limbs are ""flesh branches"". 	 	On-Yomi: シ   Kun-Yomi:"
stalk	"stalk 	 	茎   	   	Lesson: 23   Frame: 772   Strokes: 8   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: stalk, flowers, spool, clod, toilet paper, crotch, soil, dirt, ground 	 	Flower . . . spool. 	 	 	Suggestion: Replace ""spool"" with ""toilet paper/roll"". Reasons: (1) Toilet paper/roll usually comes on a spool. (2) Toilet paper is used to clean the soil off your crotch. Story: Just get a flower and carefully wrap some toilet paper around its stalk. Spool also appears in suspicious (#716), lightly (#717), diameter (#882), sutra (#1360). 	 	On-Yomi: ケイ、キョウ   Kun-Yomi: くき  	Examples: 茎 (くき)"
suspicious	"suspicious 	 	怪   	   	Lesson: 23   Frame: 773   Strokes: 8   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: suspicious, Freud, state of mind, spool, clod, toilet paper, crotch, soil, dirt, ground 	 	State of mind . . . spool. 	 	 	When you´re suspicious, your state of mind twists round and round like a spool of thread. 	 	On-Yomi: カイ、ケ   Kun-Yomi: あや.しい、あや.しむ  	Examples: 怪しい (あや.しい), 怪しむ (あや.しむ)"
lightly	"lightly 	 	軽   	   	Lesson: 23   Frame: 774   Strokes: 12   —   Jouyou Grade: 3   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: lightly, car, spool, clod, toilet paper, crotch, soil, dirt, ground 	 	Car . . . spool. 	 	 	Fact: this kanji is used to denote a certain class of vehicles in Japan whose engines are under a certain size (less than 750cc I think) and are called light vehicles here. Imagine a so-called light vehicle or a light-truck with a load of spools driving down a road ever so lightly, careful not to let any of the spools roll out onto the street. 	 	On-Yomi: ケイ   Kun-Yomi: かる.い、かろ.やか、かろ.んじる  	Examples: 軽い (かる.い), 軽やか (かろ.やか)"

Oh come on people - say what we´ve all been thinking: the uncle is that creepy guy towering above a little one´s crotch. 	 	On-Yomi: シュク   Kun-Yomi:"

anti-	"anti- 	 	反   	   	Lesson: 23   Frame: 779   Strokes: 4   —   Jouyou Grade: 3   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: anti-, demonstation, cliff, crotch 	 	Cliff . . . crotch. 	 	 	I think of an anti-hero (Dirty Harry etc.) for this primitive, whose trademark for disposing of villians is not an honorable fight, but a kick in the crotch and then a shove off a cliff (perhaps whilst the villain´s back is turned). 	 	On-Yomi: ハン、ホン、タン、ホ   Kun-Yomi: そ.る、そ.らす、かえ.す、かえ.る、-かえ.る  	Examples: 反映 (はんえい), 反対 (はんたい), 違反 (いはん), 謀反 (むほん), 反らす (そ.らす), 反る (そ.る)"

claw	"claw 	 	爪   	   	Lesson: 23   Frame: 784   Strokes: 4   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT:    	Constituents: claw, vulture 	 	This character is a pictograph of a bird's claw, and from there comes to mean animal claws in general (including human fingernails). 	  * As a primitive, we shall use the graphic image of a vulture, a bird known for its powerful claws. It generally appears above another primitive, in which case it gets squeezed into the form ⺥. 	 	A pictograph of Wolverine´s adamantium claws. 	 	On-Yomi: ソウ   Kun-Yomi: つめ、つま-  	Examples: 爪 (つめつま)"

Overly gentle women are vultures who want to marry you and steal your money - not true but an easy mnemonic! 	 	On-Yomi: ダ   Kun-Yomi:"
milk	"milk 	 	乳   	   	Lesson: 23   Frame: 786   Strokes: 8   —   Jouyou Grade: 6   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: milk, fledgling, claw, vulture, child, fishhook 	 	Fledglings . . . hook. 	 	 	A fledgling is being nursed at a zoo, it is fed milk through a small tube that is bent in the shape of a hook (so that it fits inside its beak). The fledgling soon becomes addicted to milk, giving us this very catchy mnemonic: “fledgling hooked on milk”. 	 	On-Yomi: ニュウ   Kun-Yomi: ちち、ち  	Examples: 乳 (ち), 乳 (ちち)"

method	"method 	 	法   	   	Lesson: 23   Frame: 813   Strokes: 8   —   Jouyou Grade: 4   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: method, water, water droplets, water pistol, gone, soil, dirt, ground, elbow 	 	Water . . . gone. 	 	 	This kanji shows up in a lot of words related to the legal process. Try this image: using a very outdated judicial method, the people of Salem dunked accused witches in the water until they were all gone. meeting	"meeting 	 	会   	   	Lesson: 23   Frame: 814   Strokes: 6   —   Jouyou Grade: 2   JLPT: 4   	Constituents: meeting, meeting, one, wall, umbrella, rising cloud, two, elbow, wall 	 	Meeting . . . wall. This is the full character for meeting, from which the abbreviated primitive that we met back in lesson 12 gets its name. 	 	 	At the local company they have a very gory way of getting rid of incompetent personnel : they arrange a business meeting in a very special room where the walls are ... meeting. Not surprisingly the boss is never present at these meetings, he´s the one who pushes the button that sets the walls in motion. 	 	On-Yomi: カイ、エ   Kun-Yomi: あ.う、あ.わせる、あつ.まる  	Examples: 会話 (かいわ), 会計 (かいけい), 社会 (しゃかい), 会う (あ.う)"

The key word allows for the full variety of connotations: to peak, to arrive at the end, and the like. 	 	 	Sexual climaxes don´t always happen on the bed; they sometimes happen against a wall or on the ground! 	 	On-Yomi: シ   Kun-Yomi: いた.る  	Examples: 至る (いた.る)"

abandon	"abandon 	 	棄   	   	Lesson: 23   Frame: 820   Strokes: 13   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: abandon, infant, toddler, top hat, elbow, buckle, tree, wood 	 	Infant . . . buckle (See frame 444) . . . tree. 	 	 	Think of a really loud and annoying baby, you want to abandon it but it keeps coming back...so you take of your belt by the buckle, and buckle the baby to a tree! 	 	On-Yomi: キ   Kun-Yomi: す.てる"
bring up	"bring up 	 	育   	   	Lesson: 23   Frame: 821   Strokes: 8   —   Jouyou Grade: 3   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: bring up, infant, toddler, top hat, elbow, moon, month, flesh, part of the body 	 	Since the key word has to do with raising children to be strong both in mind and body, it is easy to coordinate the primitive elements: infant . . . meat. 	 	 	Bringing up your offspring means raising them from infant until they are meat ready to be harvested. What, cannibalism is in poor taste? Forget I ever brought it up. But bring up will forver be infant meat to me. I want my baby back baby back baby back ribs! 	 	On-Yomi: イク   Kun-Yomi: そだ.つ、そだ.ち、そだ.てる、はぐく.む  	Examples: 育つ (そだ.つ), 育てる (そだ.てる)"
remove	"remove 	 	撤   	   	Lesson: 23   Frame: 822   Strokes: 15   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: remove, finger, fingers, borstal, bring up, infant, toddler, top hat, elbow, moon, month, flesh, part of the body, taskmaster 	 	Fingers . . . bring up . . . taskmaster. 	 	 	Don´t lay a finger on him, a concerned mother says as the state REMOVES her child away for upbringing by a taskmaster foster home. 	 	On-Yomi: テツ   Kun-Yomi:"
allot	"allot 	 	充   	   	Lesson: 23   Frame: 823   Strokes: 6   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: allot, infant, toddler, top hat, elbow, human legs 	 	Infant . . . human legs. 	 	 	Scene at the baby factory: Manager: ""Good news! Your infant has been allotted human legs"". Parent to be: ""Thanks a lot!"". 	 	On-Yomi: ジュウ   Kun-Yomi: あ.てる、み.たす  	Examples: 充てる (あ.てる)"
gun	"gun 	 	銃   	   	Lesson: 23   Frame: 824   Strokes: 14   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: gun, metal, gold, allot, infant, toddler, top hat, elbow, human legs 	 	Metal . . . allot. 	 	 	Everyone is allotted a metal gun (US constitution according to the NRA). 	 	On-Yomi: ジュウ   Kun-Yomi: つつ"
sulfur	"sulfur 	 	硫   	   	Lesson: 23   Frame: 825   Strokes: 12   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: sulphur, stone, rock, lifebelt, infant, toddler, top hat, elbow, stream, flood 	 	Rock . . . infant . . . flood. 	 	 	Sulphur is like a rock, but it can stink like a stream of infant doodie. 	 	On-Yomi: リュウ   Kun-Yomi:"
current	"current 	 	流   	   	Lesson: 23   Frame: 826   Strokes: 10   —   Jouyou Grade: 3   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: current, water, water droplets, water pistol, lifebelt, infant, toddler, top hat, elbow, stream, flood 	 	Water . . . infant . . . flood. Be sure to distinguish the two water primitives from one another in making your story. 	 	 	INFANT Moses placed in the WATER and sent down the current of the STREAM. 	 	On-Yomi: リュウ、ル   Kun-Yomi: なが.れる、なが.れ、なが.す、-なが.す  	Examples: 流行 (りゅうこう), 流動 (りゅうどう), 電流 (でんりゅう), 流す (なが.す), 流れる (なが.れる)"
license	"license 	 	允   	   	Lesson: 23   Frame: 827   Strokes: 4   —   Jouyou Grade: Names   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: license, elbow, human legs 	 	Elbow . . . human legs. 	 	 	In some Asian kung-fu version of James Bond, the main protagonist has a “License To Kill” with his deadly elbows and human legs. His suit is always stained of red blood at the elbows and lower legs (this to help create an image that distinguish the two elements). 	 	On-Yomi: イン   Kun-Yomi: じょう、まこと.に、ゆるす"
tempt	"tempt 	 	唆   	   	Lesson: 23   Frame: 828   Strokes: 10   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: tempt, mouth, streetwalker, Ministry of silly walks, John Cleese, license, elbow, human legs, walking legs 	 	Mouth . . . license . . . walking legs. 	 	 	I named the right part legal prostitute has it represents a walker [walking legs] with the license. It´s easy to imagine a legal prostitute tempting a man with her mouth. 	 	On-Yomi: サ   Kun-Yomi: そそのか.す  	Examples: 唆す (そそのか.す)"
exit	"exit 	 	出   	   	Lesson: 24   Frame: 829   Strokes: 5   —   Jouyou Grade: 1   JLPT: 5   	Constituents: exit 	 	The kanji for exit pictures a series of mountain peaks coming out of the earth. Learn it together with the following frame. 	 	 	Suddenly, a cactus comes out of the ground with a sign that reads: exit. Now you can leave the desert! (Note: giving this primitive the meaning ´cactus´ can be useful later). 	 	On-Yomi: シュツ、スイ   Kun-Yomi: で.る、-で、だ.す、-だ.す、い.でる、い.だす  	Examples: 出入 (しゅつにゅう), 出現 (しゅつげん), 提出 (ていしゅつ), 出す (だ.す), 出る (で.る)"
mountain	"mountain 	 	山   	   	Lesson: 24   Frame: 830   Strokes: 3   —   Jouyou Grade: 1   JLPT: 5   	Constituents: mountain 	 	Note the clearer outline of a triangular mountain here. 	 	 	Pictograph, see book. * As a primitive this element appears equally as well at the top or bottom of the kanjis (besides appearing to the left). Since a mountain often brings to mind towering peaks, I will consider it implied that the element is placed at the top of the kanji. When this primitive appears at the bottom, I will arrange my story in a way that other elements are said to be at the very top of the mountain (see FRAME 775 for an example). 	 	On-Yomi: サン、セン   Kun-Yomi: やま  	Examples: 山 (やま)"
bungling	"bungling 	 	拙   	   	Lesson: 24   Frame: 831   Strokes: 8   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: bungling, finger, fingers, exit 	 	Fingers . . . exit. 	 	 	With fingers fumbling around trying to get the key in the door so he could exit, the bungling husband woke his wife as he tried to leave for a rendezvous with his mistress. 	 	On-Yomi: セツ   Kun-Yomi: つたな.い"
boulder	"boulder 	 	岩   	   	Lesson: 24   Frame: 832   Strokes: 8   —   Jouyou Grade: 2   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: boulder, mountain, stone, rock 	 	Mountain . . . rock. 	 	 	A mountain-sized stone is known as a boulder. 	 	On-Yomi: ガン   Kun-Yomi: いわ  	Examples: 岩 (いわ)"
charcoal	"charcoal 	 	炭   	   	Lesson: 24   Frame: 833   Strokes: 9   —   Jouyou Grade: 3   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: charcoal, mountain, ashes, cliff, fire 	 	Mountain . . . ashes. 	 	 	Burn enough charcoal and you´ll have a mountain of ash. 	 	On-Yomi: タン   Kun-Yomi: すみ  	Examples: 炭 (すみ)"
branch off	"branch off 	 	岐   	   	Lesson: 24   Frame: 834   Strokes: 7   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: branch off, mountain, branch, ten, needle, crotch 	 	Mountains . . . branch. 	 	 	On the left, there are three mountains. The road branches off to each of them. (Note: This kanji is mostly used for branches in the road). 	 	On-Yomi: キ、ギ   Kun-Yomi:"
mountain pass	"mountain pass 	 	峠   	   	Lesson: 24   Frame: 835   Strokes: 9   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: mountain peak, mountain, above, below 	 	Mountain . . . above . . . below. 	 	 	Heisig mentions at kanjiclinic.com that he wishes he´d chosen mountain pass for this keyword as it´s closer to what the word means. If we do this, the kanji makes complete sense because a mountain pass is just below the mountain top. 	 	On-Yomi:    Kun-Yomi: とうげ  	Examples: 峠 (とうげ)"
crumble	"crumble 	 	崩   	   	Lesson: 24   Frame: 836   Strokes: 11   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: crumble, mountain, companion, moon, month, flesh, part of the body, moon2, month2, flesh2, part of the body2 	 	Mountain . . . companion. 	 	 	Sam and Frodo were steadfast companions even as Mount Doom crumbled above them. 	 	On-Yomi: ホウ   Kun-Yomi: くず.れる、-くず.れ、くず.す  	Examples: 崩す (くず.す), 崩れる (くず.れる)"
secrecy	"secrecy 	 	密   	   	Lesson: 24   Frame: 837   Strokes: 11   —   Jouyou Grade: 6   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: secrecy, house, invariably, heart, mountain 	 	House . . . invariably . . . mountain. 	 	 	To maintain secrecy, secret societies invariably have to house themselves in the moutains. 	 	On-Yomi: ミツ   Kun-Yomi: ひそ.か"
honey	"honey 	 	蜜   	   	Lesson: 24   Frame: 838   Strokes: 12   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT:    	Constituents: honey, house, invariably, heart, insect 	 	House . . . invariably . . . insect. 	 	 	When I think of honey, I think of a bee hive, which is a HOUSE that INVARIABLY has INSECTS. 	 	On-Yomi: ミツ、ビツ   Kun-Yomi:"
storm	"storm 	 	嵐   	   	Lesson: 24   Frame: 839   Strokes: 12   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: storm, mountain, wind, gnats, drop, insect 	 	Mountain . . . winds. 	 	 	Storm is a full-blown wind that rips the mountains off the ground (you see one flying here). 	 	On-Yomi: ラン   Kun-Yomi: あらし  	Examples: 嵐 (あらし)"
promontory	"promontory 	 	崎   	   	Lesson: 24   Frame: 840   Strokes: 11   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: promontory, mountain, strange, large, St. Bernard, can, street, nail, spike, mouth 	 	Mountain . . . strange. Hint: you might save yourself the trouble of a story here simply by recalling the kanji for cape (Frame 164) and toying around with the differing images suggested by the key words promontory and cape. 	 	 	This is “Cape Strange” from FRAME 153, only with mountain in place of soil. Interestingly, there is also 碕 which is made of the primitives stone and strange. The three kanjis 碕, 埼 and 崎 all have the same meanings and pronunciations. They have very little uses other than names, for which promontory is the clear winner with over 2300 uses in place and people names, while the other two kanjis account for less than 200 names. 	 	On-Yomi: キ   Kun-Yomi: さき、さい、みさき  	Examples: 崎 (さき)"
enter	"enter 	 	入   	   	Lesson: 24   Frame: 842   Strokes: 2   —   Jouyou Grade: 1   JLPT: 5   	Constituents: enter 	 	This character is meant to be a picture of someone walking leftwards, putting one leg forward in order to enter someplace. Since the ""in"" side of a character is the left, it should be easy to remember the writing of this character. 	  * As a primitive, the meaning of the key word is expanded to include: to go in, to put in, to come in, and the like. It generally appears atop its relative primitive, where, unlike the element for umbrella, the two strokes do not touch each other, making it virtually the same as the kanji for eight. When it appears in any other position, however, it retains its original form. 	 	Pictograph, see book. * As a primitive, using the image of going through a door, even one that stands alone with the frame and no wall around, helps flesh out the primitive “enter”. 	 	On-Yomi: ニュウ、ジュ   Kun-Yomi: い.る、-い.る、-い.り、い.れる、-い.れ、はい.る  	Examples: 入る (い.る), 入れる (い.れる), 入る (はい.る)"
crowded	"crowded 	 	込   	   	Lesson: 24   Frame: 843   Strokes: 5   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: crowded, enter, road 	 	Enter . . . road. 	 	 	During a traffic jam it is impossible to get your car to enter the roadway as it is crowded with cars. Think of a grid lock so bad cars are litterally scraping up against each other like people on a Japanese train during rush hour. 	 	On-Yomi:    Kun-Yomi: こ.み、 -こ.み、 -こ.む、 こ.む、 こ.める  	Examples: 込む (こ.む), 込める (こ.める)"
part	"part 	 	分   	   	Lesson: 24   Frame: 844   Strokes: 4   —   Jouyou Grade: 2   JLPT:    	Constituents: part, eight, sword, dagger 	 	Go in . . . dagger. 	 	 	When something is entered by a dagger, it ends up being cut in several parts. 	 	On-Yomi: ブン、フン、ブ   Kun-Yomi: わ.ける、わ.け、わ.かれる、わ.かる、わ.かつ  	Examples: 分解 (ぶんかい), 自分 (じぶん), 水分 (すいぶん), 分別 (ふんべつ), 分銅 (ふんどう), 三十分 (さんじゅうふん), 分かつ (わ.かつ), 分かる (わ.かる), 分かれる (わ.かれる), 分ける (わ.ける)"
poverty	"poverty 	 	貧   	   	Lesson: 24   Frame: 845   Strokes: 11   —   Jouyou Grade: 5   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: poverty, part, eight, sword, dagger, shellfish, clam, oyster, eye, animal legs, eight 	 	Part . . . shells/money. 	 	 	In the case of true poverty, not having money is only part of the problem. There are other components as well, like lack of education, class structuring, etc., but that doesn´t really matter. Just remember that the money is only part of it, not the whole. 	 	On-Yomi: ヒン、ビン   Kun-Yomi: まず.しい  	Examples: 貧富 (ひんぷ), 貧弱 (ひんじゃく), 清貧 (せいひん), 貧しい (まず.しい)"
partition	"partition 	 	頒   	   	Lesson: 24   Frame: 846   Strokes: 13   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: partition, part, eight, sword, dagger, head, page, one, ceiling, drop, shellfish, clam, oyster, eye, animal legs, eight 	 	Part . . . head. 	 	 	The PART of my HEAD where I remember the KANJI is in the kanji PARTITION. 	 	On-Yomi: ハン   Kun-Yomi: わか.つ"
public	"public 	 	公   	   	Lesson: 24   Frame: 847   Strokes: 4   —   Jouyou Grade: 2   JLPT: 4   	Constituents: public, eight, elbow 	 	Come in . . . elbows. Use the key word in its adjectival sense, not as a noun. 	 	 	I always open the doors to the public restrooms with my elbows because I don´t want to touch the door with my hands. 	 	On-Yomi: コウ、ク   Kun-Yomi: おおやけ  	Examples: 公 (おおやけ)"
pine tree	"pine tree 	 	松   	   	Lesson: 24   Frame: 848   Strokes: 8   —   Jouyou Grade: 4   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: pine tree, tree, wood, public, eight, elbows 	 	Tree . . . public. 	 	 	Following up with the ""entering public restrooms"" story for the right-hand primitive: public restrooms always reek of pine tree scented disinfectant. 	 	On-Yomi: ショウ   Kun-Yomi: まつ  	Examples: 松 (まつ)"
venerable old man	"venerable old man 	 	翁   	   	Lesson: 24   Frame: 849   Strokes: 10   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: venerable old man, public, eight, elbows, feathers, wings 	 	Public . . . feathers. 	 	 	The venerable old man is the public figure head of the Native American Village, answering all questions and solving all problems. The higher in rank you get in this tribe, the more feathers decorate you. Imagine this old man covered in beautiful feathers. 	 	On-Yomi: オウ   Kun-Yomi: おきな"
sue	"sue 	 	訟   	   	Lesson: 24   Frame: 850   Strokes: 11   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: sue, say, words, keitai, mouth, public, eight, elbows 	 	Words . . . public. 	 	 	Take care what words you say in public lest you be sued. 	 	On-Yomi: ショウ   Kun-Yomi:"
valley	"valley 	 	谷   	   	Lesson: 24   Frame: 851   Strokes: 7   —   Jouyou Grade: 2   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: valley, eight, umbrella, mouth 	 	Go in . . . an umbrella . . . a mouth. Because of space restrictions, the element for go in is shortened in this character. If you stand on your head and look at this kanji, the image of a valley stands out more clearly: the mouth of the river whose water flows down at the intersection of the two mountains, with the final two strokes adding the element of perspective. Now get back on your feet again and see if the image still remains clear. If not, then return to the primitives and make a story in the usual way. 	 	 	This could be seen as a very accurate pictograph of another type of valley: a valley mouth open under the umbrella of inner labia, with the outer labia parted above. There are even more connections to be made among the primitive keywords and the visuals, but i will enter no further... 	 	On-Yomi: コク   Kun-Yomi: たに、きわ.まる  	Examples: 谷 (たに)"
bathe	"bathe 	 	浴   	   	Lesson: 24   Frame: 852   Strokes: 10   —   Jouyou Grade: 4   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: bathe, water, water droplets, water pistol, valley, eight, umbrella, mouth 	 	Water . . . valley. 	 	 	This story is quite lascivious, sorry... Now, imagine you are at a 混浴　（こんよく） [two kanjis we now know] Onsen (温泉), and you are watching a woman bathe. Just picture the water dripping down her cleavage (that valley in between her breasts). Note: cleavage in Japanese is 谷間. 	 	On-Yomi: ヨク   Kun-Yomi: あ.びる、あ.びせる  	Examples: 浴びせる (あ.びせる), 浴びる (あ.びる)"
contain	"contain 	 	容   	   	Lesson: 24   Frame: 853   Strokes: 10   —   Jouyou Grade: 5   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: contain, house, valley, eight, umbrella, mouth 	 	This character depicts a house so large that it can contain an entire valley. 	 	 	Imagine a house big enough to contain an entire valley. might want to live there. And now imagine cleaning it. . . . Maybe not . . . 	 	On-Yomi: ヨウ   Kun-Yomi: い.れる"
melt	"melt 	 	溶   	   	Lesson: 24   Frame: 854   Strokes: 13   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: melt, water, water droplets, water pistol, contents, contain, house, valley, animal legs, eight, umbrella, mouth 	 	Water . . . contain. 	 	 	Think of what happens when the snow on top of the mountains melts: it turns into water and flows down onto the rooftops of all the houses in the valley below. 	 	On-Yomi: ヨウ   Kun-Yomi: と.ける、と.かす、と.く  	Examples: 溶かす (と.かす), 溶く (と.く), 溶ける (と.ける)"
longing	"longing 	 	欲   	   	Lesson: 24   Frame: 855   Strokes: 11   —   Jouyou Grade: 6   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: longing, valley, eight, umbrella, mouth, lack, yawn 	 	Valley . . . yawn. Be sure to keep the key word distinct from pining (Frame 683). 	 	 	Guess what? Japanese has dirty words too! (In fact, a lot of them) A sexual story is NOT inappropriate here, as this kanji is very sexual, such as in 性欲; lust. As for a story: the lack of contact with a woman´s valley will leave a man LONGING for love. 	 	On-Yomi: ヨク   Kun-Yomi: ほっ.する、ほ.しい  	Examples: 欲しい (ほ.しい), 欲する (ほっ.する)"
abundant	"abundant 	 	裕   	   	Lesson: 24   Frame: 856   Strokes: 12   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: abundant, cloak, valley, eight, umbrella, mouth 	 	This character shows the typical cloak of valley folk, which, unlike the tailor-made, high-fashion overcoats of city folk, is loose-fitting and free-form. Hence the key word's meaning of abundant. 	 	 	Again using the fact that cleavage in Japanese is called ""valley of the chest"": a woman with abundant cleavage tightly wraps up her bosom in a form-fitting cloak, but leaving her valley exposed. Another unforgettable image (thank you, thank you, I´ll be here all week). 	 	On-Yomi: ユウ   Kun-Yomi:"
lead (metal)	"lead (metal) 	 	鉛   	   	Lesson: 24   Frame: 857   Strokes: 13   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: lead, metal, gold, gully, eight, mouth 	 	Metal . . . gully. 	 	 	Picture the molten lead (the heavy metal) being discreetly drained out of the factory into a gully behind. 	 	On-Yomi: エン   Kun-Yomi: なまり  	Examples: 鉛 (なまり)"
run alongside	"run alongside 	 	沿   	   	Lesson: 24   Frame: 858   Strokes: 8   —   Jouyou Grade: 6   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: run alongside, water, water droplets, water pistol, gully, eight, mouth 	 	Water . . . gully. The key word is meant to refer to things like rivers and railway tracks that run alongside something else. 	 	 	Water in a gully runs alongside the path. 	 	On-Yomi: エン   Kun-Yomi: そ.う、-ぞ.い  	Examples: 沿う (そ.う)"
prize	"prize 	 	賞   	   	Lesson: 25   Frame: 859   Strokes: 15   —   Jouyou Grade: 4   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: prize, outhouse, small, little, crown, mouth, shellfish, clam, oyster, eye, animal legs, eight 	 	Outhouse . . . shellfish. 	 	 	This is a bit silly.. or maybe not only a bit, but.. You know some foodstuffs (cereals come to mind) sometimes have prizes mixed in them? Well, in this case, the prize was a shell (money, remember) and you only notice in the outhouse... (see also secret (#904)). 	 	On-Yomi: ショウ   Kun-Yomi: ほ.める"
party	"party 	 	党   	   	Lesson: 25   Frame: 860   Strokes: 10   —   Jouyou Grade: 6   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: party, outhouse, small, little, crown, mouth, human legs 	 	Think of this key word as referring to a political party, not a gala affair. Its elements: human legs . . . sticking out of an outhouse window. 	 	 	Every major political party, if personified, would look like a giant outhouse walking around with human legs spewing out a constant stream of bullshit. 	 	On-Yomi: トウ   Kun-Yomi: なかま、むら"
hall	"hall 	 	堂   	   	Lesson: 25   Frame: 861   Strokes: 11   —   Jouyou Grade: 4   JLPT: 4   	Constituents: public chamber, outhouse, small, little, crown, mouth, soil, dirt, ground 	 	Outhouse . . . land. 	 	 	There is a secret hall buried in the soil underneath the outhouse. 	 	On-Yomi: ドウ   Kun-Yomi:"
usual	"usual 	 	常   	   	Lesson: 25   Frame: 862   Strokes: 11   —   Jouyou Grade: 5   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: usual, outhouse, small, little, crown, mouth, towel 	 	Outhouse . . . towel. 	 	 	It´s usual to take your towel with you when you go to the outhouse at the onsen (hot springs bath in Japan) so everybody doesn´t see your stuff. 	 	On-Yomi: ジョウ   Kun-Yomi: つね、とこ-  	Examples: 常 (つね), 常 (とこ)"
skirt	"skirt 	 	裳   	   	Lesson: 25   Frame: 863   Strokes: 14   —   Jouyou Grade: Names   JLPT:    	Constituents: skirt, outhouse, small, little, crown, mouth, cloth, clothes, clothing, garment 	 	The key word refers to an ancient skirt once used as part of a woman's costume. The primitives you have to work with are: outhouse . . . garment. 	 	 	Compared to pants, a SKIRT is the GARMENT to be wearing when you want to use one of those Japanese toilets. It makes it so much easier: you just walk in the OUTHOUSE hike it up, and do your business. 	 	On-Yomi: ショウ   Kun-Yomi: も、もすそ"
manipulate	"manipulate 	 	掌   	   	Lesson: 25   Frame: 864   Strokes: 12   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: manipulate, outhouse, small, little, crown, mouth, hand 	 	Outhouse . . . hand. 	 	 	If you´re going to manipulate your body with your hand, then go do it in an outhouse, at least! 	 	On-Yomi: ショウ   Kun-Yomi: てのひら、たなごころ"
pelt	"pelt 	 	皮   	   	Lesson: 25   Frame: 865   Strokes: 5   —   Jouyou Grade: 3   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: pelt, branch, ten, needle, crotch, hook 	 	The simplest way to remember this character is to see it as built up from that for branch. The first stroke can then stand for something ""hanging"" down from the branch, namely its bark or pelt. The barb at the end of the second stroke is the only other change. Merely by concentrating on this as you write the following small cluster of characters should be enough to fix the form in your mind. By way of exception, you might doodle around with the kanji's form to see what you can come up with. 	 	 	A pelt is hooked on a branch. A small tent is made with a pelt and a branch planted in the ground. The mnemonic hints at the first stroke (the hanging pelt) and the hook at the end of the second stroke. This is chinese radical #107 meaning “skin”. 	 	On-Yomi: ヒ   Kun-Yomi: かわ、けがわ  	Examples: 皮 (かわ)"
waves	"waves 	 	波   	   	Lesson: 25   Frame: 866   Strokes: 8   —   Jouyou Grade: 3   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: waves, water, water droplets, water pistol, pelt, branch, ten, needle, crotch, hook 	 	Water's . . . pelt. 	 	 	Waves are the ocean´s pelt (skin). 	 	On-Yomi: ハ   Kun-Yomi: なみ  	Examples: 波 (なみ)"
old woman	"old woman 	 	婆   	   	Lesson: 25   Frame: 867   Strokes: 11   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: old woman, wave, water, water droplets, water pistol, pelt, branch, ten, needle, crotch, hook, woman 	 	Waves . . . woman. 	 	 	An old woman is seen here as a woman with waves (i.e. wrinkles, creases). 	 	On-Yomi: バ   Kun-Yomi: ばば、ばあ"
expose	"expose 	 	披   	   	Lesson: 25   Frame: 868   Strokes: 8   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: expose, finger, fingers, pelt, branch, ten, needle, crotch, hook 	 	Fingers . . . pelt. 	 	 	You expose holes in a pelt by passing your fingers through them and wiggling them on the other side. The sense of the kanji here is to reveal something that was hidden, to make known, to open your heart (thus revealing it, exposing it to others), express your opinion, etc. 	 	On-Yomi: ヒ   Kun-Yomi:"
rend	"rend 	 	破   	   	Lesson: 25   Frame: 869   Strokes: 10   —   Jouyou Grade: 5   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: rend, stone, rock, pelt, branch, ten, needle, crotch, hook 	 	Rock . . . pelt. 	 	 	Before the invention of scissors or knives, sharp STONES were used to REND PELTs, so that caveman designers could complete new styles for the upcoming year. 	 	On-Yomi: ハ   Kun-Yomi: やぶ.る、やぶ.れる  	Examples: 破る (やぶ.る), 破れる (やぶ.れる)"
incur	"incur 	 	被   	   	Lesson: 25   Frame: 870   Strokes: 10   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: incur, cloak, pelt, branch, ten, needle, crotch, hook 	 	Cloak . . . pelt. 	 	 	If you wear a coat of fur (pelt) you are sure to incur the wrath of animal rights extremists. 	 	On-Yomi: ヒ   Kun-Yomi: こうむ.る、おお.う、かぶ.る、かぶ.せる  	Examples: 被る (こうむ.る)"
remainder	"remainder 	 	残   	   	Lesson: 25   Frame: 871   Strokes: 10   —   Jouyou Grade: 4   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: remainder, bones, one, ceiling, evening, float 	 	Bones . . . (parade) float. 	 	 	The remainder of the bones have been thrown from the float (for the dogs maybe, at the end of the parade). 	 	On-Yomi: ザン、サン   Kun-Yomi: のこ.る、のこ.す、そこな.う、のこ.り  	Examples: 残す (のこ.す), 残る (のこ.る)"
martyrdom	"martyrdom 	 	殉   	   	Lesson: 25   Frame: 872   Strokes: 10   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: martyrdom, bones, one, ceiling, evening, decameron, bound up, sun, day 	 	Bones . . . decameron. 	 	 	Think of the early Christian martyrs who suffered martyrdom because of their faith. See them held in cells for 10 days (a decameron) before being fed to the lions. They appear before the chanting Roman crowds as bones to be devoured. Think of what was leftover after the lions finished them off....nothing, not even a pile of bones to bury. 	 	On-Yomi: ジュン   Kun-Yomi:"
particularly	"particularly 	 	殊   	   	Lesson: 25   Frame: 873   Strokes: 10   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: particularly, bones, one, ceiling, evening, vermilion, drop, not yet, one, tree, wood 	 	Bones . . . vermilion. 	 	 	A t-bone steak is vermilion - particularly if served rare. 	 	On-Yomi: シュ   Kun-Yomi: こと  	Examples: 殊 (こと)"
augment	"augment 	 	殖   	   	Lesson: 25   Frame: 874   Strokes: 12   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: augment, bones, one, ceiling, evening, straightaway, ten, needle, eye, fishhook 	 	Bones . . . straightaway. 	 	 	Advertisement for Breast Implants -- Tired of nights all alone? Want to get boned straightaway? AUGMENT your breasts and all your troubles will be solved! 	 	On-Yomi: ショク   Kun-Yomi: ふ.える、ふ.やす  	Examples: 殖える (ふ.える), 殖やす (ふ.やす)"

The sense of the key word is of people or things lined up in a row. 	 	 	A line of skeletal warriors, all armed with sabers. 	 	On-Yomi: レツ、レ   Kun-Yomi:"
split	"split 	 	裂   	   	Lesson: 25   Frame: 876   Strokes: 12   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: split, file, bones, one, ceiling, evening, sword, sabre, saber, cloth, clothes, clothing, garment 	 	File . . . garment. 	 	 	They tried issuing the skeleton warriors with proper garments to wear, but they kept getting split by the sharp bones or by their sabres. In the end, it was decided they look scarier naked anyway. 	 	On-Yomi: レツ   Kun-Yomi: さ.く、さ.ける、-ぎ.れ  	Examples: 裂く (さ.く), 裂ける (さ.ける)"
ardent	"ardent 	 	烈   	   	Lesson: 25   Frame: 877   Strokes: 10   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: ardent, file, bones, one, ceiling, evening, sword, sabre, saber, oven-fire, barbecue 	 	File . . . oven fire. 	 	 	The nazis were ardent believers in the master arian race, see them marching everyone else into the oven fires, single file. 	 	On-Yomi: レツ   Kun-Yomi: はげ.しい"
death	"death 	 	死   	   	Lesson: 25   Frame: 878   Strokes: 6   —   Jouyou Grade: 3   JLPT: 4   	Constituents: death, bones, one, ceiling, evening, spoon, sitting on the ground 	 	Bones . . . spoon. Note how the first stroke is extended to the right, forming a sort of ""roof"" overhead. 	 	 	Ok, this is where knowing some Eastern culture comes in handy! In Japanese society, when someone dies they creamate the body and pick out the remaining bones with special chopsticks. In this case, they´re out of chopsticks so they decide to use (gasp!) a spoon instead. 	 	On-Yomi: シ   Kun-Yomi: し.ぬ、し.に-  	Examples: 死ぬ (し.ぬ)"
interment	"interment 	 	葬   	   	Lesson: 25   Frame: 879   Strokes: 12   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: interment, flowers, death, bones, one, ceiling, evening, spoon, sitting on the ground, two hands 	 	Flowers . . . death . . . two hands. Do not confuse with bury (Frame 191). 	 	 	I imagine an interment as a funeral. At this funeral it´s an open casket, and the dead body (death) is holding flowers with both of its hands. 	 	On-Yomi: ソウ   Kun-Yomi: ほうむ.る  	Examples: 葬る (ほうむ.る)"
wink	"wink 	 	瞬   	   	Lesson: 25   Frame: 880   Strokes: 18   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: wink, eye, Rose of Sharon, birdhouse, birdcage, claw, vulture, crown, sunglasses, dancing legs, ballerina, evening 	 	Eye . . . birdhouse . . . sunglasses. 	 	 	Imagine Snoopy winking with his big eyes (and a happy smile) standing next to Woodstocks Birdhouse, woodstock being so cool that he wears little sunglasses. 	 	On-Yomi: シュン   Kun-Yomi: またた.く、まじろ.ぐ  	Examples: 瞬く (またた.く)"
ear	"ear 	 	耳   	   	Lesson: 25   Frame: 881   Strokes: 6   —   Jouyou Grade: 1   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: ear 	 	The pictograph for the ear looks much like that for eye, but note how the stroke order gives it a different look. 	 	 	Your ear is like the eye on the side of your head for seeing things, but there is hair around it that creates jagged lines. 	 	On-Yomi: ジ   Kun-Yomi: みみ  	Examples: 耳 (みみ)"
take	"take 	 	取   	   	Lesson: 25   Frame: 882   Strokes: 8   —   Jouyou Grade: 3   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: take, ear, crotch 	 	Ear . . . crotch. 	 	 	You put your ear next to a womans crotch...and somehow, from it, you hear the words ""Take me...."". 	 	On-Yomi: シュ   Kun-Yomi: と.る、と.り、と.り-、とり、-ど.り  	Examples: 取る (と.る)"
gist	"gist 	 	趣   	   	Lesson: 25   Frame: 883   Strokes: 15   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: gist, run, soil, dirt, ground, mend, take, ear, crotch 	 	Run . . . take. 	 	 	The gist of it is this: We take the money and run! 	 	On-Yomi: シュ   Kun-Yomi: おもむき、おもむ.く  	Examples: 趣 (おもむき)"
utmost	"utmost 	 	最   	   	Lesson: 25   Frame: 884   Strokes: 12   —   Jouyou Grade: 4   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: utmost, sun, day, take, ear, crotch 	 	Sun . . . take. 	 	 	TAKE the UTMOST care when you SUN bath all DAY, or you´ll get burned from your EARS to your CROTCH. 	 	On-Yomi: サイ、シュ   Kun-Yomi: もっと.も、つま  	Examples: 最も (もっと.も)"
snapshot	"snapshot 	 	撮   	   	Lesson: 25   Frame: 885   Strokes: 15   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: snapshot, finger, fingers, utmost, sun, day, take, ear, crotch 	 	Finger . . . utmost. This character is used for taking photographs. Note how, conveniently, the element for ""take"" is included in it. 	 	 	Take the utmost care that you don´t have your finger in the way when you take a snapshot. 	 	On-Yomi: サツ   Kun-Yomi: と.る、つま.む、-ど.り  	Examples: 撮る (と.る)"
shame	"shame 	 	恥   	   	Lesson: 25   Frame: 886   Strokes: 10   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: shame, ear, heart 	 	Ear . . . heart. It is most rare to have the heart at the right, rather than at the bottom. Take advantage of this fact when you compose your story. 	 	 	Amelia Ear-Heart (sic) brought shame to those who said women couldn´t fly. 	 	On-Yomi: チ   Kun-Yomi: は.じる、はじ、は.じらう、は.ずかしい  	Examples: 恥じらう (は.じらう), 恥じる (は.じる), 恥ずかしい (は.ずかしい), 恥 (はじ)"
post	"post 	 	職   	   	Lesson: 25   Frame: 887   Strokes: 18   —   Jouyou Grade: 5   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: post, ear, kazoo, sound, vase, stand up, sun, day, fiesta 	 	The key word refers to one's occupation, or position of employment. Its elements: ear . . . kazoo. 	 	 	Worst post in history: quality checker at the kazoo factory. Imagine the toll on your ears! 	 	On-Yomi: ショク、ソク   Kun-Yomi:"
holy	"holy 	 	聖   	   	Lesson: 25   Frame: 888   Strokes: 13   —   Jouyou Grade: 6   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: holy, ear, mouth, king, jewel, ball 	 	Ear . . . mouth . . . king. 	 	 	The trick for me is to remember that the 耳 is to the left of the 口. However, this is easy because a true holy man uses his ear to listen (i.e., to God or his supplicant) before he opens his mouth to speak, unlike a charlatan who just makes something up. Of course, kings are often true holy men and prophets (e.g., King David in the bible). 	 	On-Yomi: セイ、ショウ   Kun-Yomi: ひじり"
daring	"daring 	 	敢   	   	Lesson: 25   Frame: 889   Strokes: 12   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: daring, street, nail, spike, ear, taskmaster 	 	Spike . . . ear . . . taskmaster. 	 	 	Only a truly daring Japanese student would wear a spike in his ear under the gaze of the Japanese teacher taskmasters! 	 	On-Yomi: カン   Kun-Yomi: あ.えて、あ.えない、あ.えず"
listen	"listen 	 	聴   	   	Lesson: 25   Frame: 890   Strokes: 17   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: listen, ear, stethoscope, camel, ten, needle, eye, cross-eyed, net, heart 	 	Ear . . . needle . . . eye . . . heart. Compare frame 427 for this and the following kanji, and then once again when you get to frame 950. 	 	 	I promise to use my ear to do nothing but listen ... stick a needle in my eye, cross my heart and hope to die! (Intentionally said backwards to get the order of the primitives correct). 	 	On-Yomi: チョウ、テイ   Kun-Yomi: き.く、ゆる.す  	Examples: 聴く (き.く)"
pocket	"pocket 	 	懐   	   	Lesson: 25   Frame: 891   Strokes: 16   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: pocket, Freud, state of mind, poltergeist, BernaE, ten, needle, eye, cross-eyed, net, top hat, scarf, cloth, clothes, clothing, garment 	 	State of mind . . . needle . . . eyes . . . garment. 	 	 	(re: taijuando) When you are in New York City you have to be alert, i.e. in the ""New York State of Mind"": you need ten eyes to make sure no one will go through your garments and pick your pockets. 	 	On-Yomi: カイ、エ   Kun-Yomi: ふところ、なつ.かしい、なつ.かしむ、なつ.く、なつ.ける、なず.ける、いだ.く、おも.う  	Examples: 懐かしい (なつ.かしい), 懐かしむ (なつ.かしむ), 懐く (なつ.く), 懐ける (なつ.ける), 懐 (ふところ)"
ridicule	"ridicule 	 	慢   	   	Lesson: 25   Frame: 892   Strokes: 14   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: ridicule, Freud, state of mind, mandala, sun, day, eye, cross-eyed, net, crotch 	 	State of mind . . . mandala. 	 	 	I´ll focus on the mandala primitive here. I guess Heisig chose this keyword for phonetic reasons and as a character it´s the ""man"" in mandara/mandala (曼荼羅). A mandala is a graphic representation of the universe, here split in 3 planes of existance, the sun representing the cosmos, the eye represents the human observer, the crotch represents the animal instincts. 	 	On-Yomi: マン   Kun-Yomi:"
loose	"loose 	 	漫   	   	Lesson: 25   Frame: 893   Strokes: 14   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: loose, water, water droplets, water pistol, mandala, sun, day, eye, cross-eyed, net, crotch 	 	Water . . . mandala. 	 	 	One obscure Tibetan sect-- the Otaku cult-- has an unusually loose interpretation of mandala drawing practice. Instead of traditional mandalas they draw mangas (漫画). They then pour water on the image to wash it away, and begin anew. 	 	On-Yomi: マン   Kun-Yomi: みがりに"
buy	"buy 	 	買   	   	Lesson: 25   Frame: 894   Strokes: 12   —   Jouyou Grade: 2   JLPT: 4   	Constituents: buy, eye, cross-eyed, net, shellfish, clam, oyster, eye, animal legs, eight 	 	Eye . . . shellfish. 	 	 	When something catches my eye, I take out a few clams and buy before anybody else does. 	 	On-Yomi: バイ   Kun-Yomi: か.う  	Examples: 買う (か.う)"
placement	"placement 	 	置   	   	Lesson: 25   Frame: 895   Strokes: 13   —   Jouyou Grade: 4   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: placement, eye, cross-eyed, net, straightaway, ten, needle, eye, fishhook 	 	Eye . . . straightaway. 	 	 	On the JET Programme, many people have their eye on a placement in Tokyo, Osaka or another big city, and write it on their application form. They are usually sent to the countryside straightaway. 	 	On-Yomi: チ   Kun-Yomi: お.く、-お.き  	Examples: 置く (お.く)"
penalty	"penalty 	 	罰   	   	Lesson: 25   Frame: 896   Strokes: 14   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: penalty, eye, cross-eyed, net, say, words, keitai, mouth, sword, sabre, saber 	 	Eye . . . words . . . saber. 	 	 	For Japanese, when the mind´s eye (the sideways eye) feels guilty for something bad that the body has done, there are two penaltys to choose from. One, you can say I´m sorry. Two, you can commit suicide by sabre. Why, oh why, do so many Japanese executives commit suicide at the first sign of scandal when all the have to do is say I´m sorry to get off the hook. (on yomi: バチ, バツ). 	 	On-Yomi: バツ、バチ、ハツ   Kun-Yomi: ばっ.する  	Examples: 罰金 (ばっきん), 処罰 (しょばつ), 天罰 (てんばつ)"
rather	"rather 	 	寧   	   	Lesson: 25   Frame: 897   Strokes: 14   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: rather, house, heart, eye, cross-eyed, net, street, nail, spike 	 	House . . . heart . . . eye . . . spike. 	 	 	A pretty tough kanji. Think of elegant old housewives with English accents dining together at a HOUSE party. The hostess brings out a dish of hors d´oeuvres: a SPIKE of metal with an EYEBALL and a HEART skewered on it. Upon being offered this treat, one of the housewives says in her English accent, ""I´d RATHER not."". 	 	On-Yomi: ネイ   Kun-Yomi: むし.ろ"
voiced	"voiced 	 	濁   	   	Lesson: 25   Frame: 898   Strokes: 16   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: voiced, water, water droplets, water pistol, spider, eye, cross-eyed, net, bound up, insect 	 	The key word for this kanji connotes the ""muddying"" effect on a soft consonant brought about by vibrating the vocal chords. For example, in English a ""j"" is voiced while a ""sh"" is unvoiced. In Japanese, the し is changed to じ when it is voiced. The primitives are: water . . . eye . . . bound up . . . insect. 	 	 	The fly is wrapped in a spiderweb voicing ""Help me, Help Me"" under the watchful eye of the spider who´s venom is dripping like water from her fangs. 	 	On-Yomi: ダク、ジョク   Kun-Yomi: にご.る、にご.す  	Examples: 濁す (にご.す), 濁る (にご.る)"
ring	"ring 	 	環   	   	Lesson: 25   Frame: 899   Strokes: 17   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: ring, king, jewel, ball, trampoline, eye, cross-eyed, net, one, ceiling, mouth, scarf 	 	Jewel . . . eye . . . ceiling . . . mouth . . . scarf. The number of elements is large here, so take extra care. Learn it in conjunction with the next frame, since these are the only two cases in this book where the combination of elements to the right appears. 	 	 	Together with the next kanji, the keywords spell “send back the ring”. First we have a jewel. Next we have the great eye of Sauron searching for the fellowship hiding under the many ceilings during their journey. The fourth and fifth primitives are the mouth of Gollum always mumbling “My preciousss”; and Pippin´s scarf! Placement: the eye appears at the top similarly to how the Great Eye of Sauron is perched atop the Dark Tower. 	 	On-Yomi: カン   Kun-Yomi: わ"
send back	"send back 	 	還   	   	Lesson: 25   Frame: 900   Strokes: 16   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: send back, trampoline, eye, cross-eyed, net, one, ceiling, mouth, scarf, road 	 	Road . . . eye . . . ceiling . . . mouth . . . scarf. 	 	 	You´ve probably guessed it by now, this is the road that Sam and Frodo take to send back the ring to Mount Doom! (see previous frame, the jewel is replaced by the road). 	 	On-Yomi: カン   Kun-Yomi: かえ.る"
husband	"husband 	 	夫   	   	Lesson: 25   Frame: 901   Strokes: 4   —   Jouyou Grade: 4   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: husband, husband, one, large 	 	The kanji for a husband or ""head of the family"" is based on the kanji for large and an extra line near the top for the ""head."" Recall the kanji for heavens already learned back in frame 457, and be sure to keep your story for this kanji different. 	 	 	Even though it is argued size is not important, I´m sure most women would like their husband to have a big one. 	 	On-Yomi: フ、フウ、ブ   Kun-Yomi: おっと、そ.れ  	Examples: 夫妻 (ふさい), 農夫 (のうふ), 凡夫 (ぼんおっと), 夫 (おっと)"
aid	"aid 	 	扶   	   	Lesson: 25   Frame: 902   Strokes: 7   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: aid, finger, fingers, husband 	 	Fingers . . . husband. 	 	 	Using his finger the husband sometimes is an erotic aid to his partner. 	 	On-Yomi: フ   Kun-Yomi: たす.ける"
mountain stream	"mountain stream 	 	渓   	   	Lesson: 25   Frame: 903   Strokes: 11   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: mountain stream, water, water droplets, water pistol, claw, vulture, husband 	 	Water . . . vulture . . . husband. 	 	 	The Simpsons are on vacation. Homer stops to take a leak in a mountain stream but gets snatched by an eagle. Hear his scream? 	 	On-Yomi: ケイ   Kun-Yomi: たに、たにがわ"

In the male-dominated world of yesterday, the husband´s way of seeing things was considered the standard point of view. Women who dared to disagree were frowned upon. 	 	On-Yomi: キ   Kun-Yomi:"
exchange	"exchange 	 	替   	   	Lesson: 25   Frame: 905   Strokes: 12   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: exchange, husband, sun, day, tongue wagging, husband2 	 	Two husbands . . . day. 	 	 	A show like ""Trading Spouses"" called ""exchanging husbands"" where 2 husbands are exchanged for a day (thanks dingomick). 	 	On-Yomi: タイ   Kun-Yomi: か.える、か.え-、か.わる  	Examples: 替える (か.える), 替わる (か.わる)"
approve	"approve 	 	賛   	   	Lesson: 25   Frame: 906   Strokes: 15   —   Jouyou Grade: 5   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: approve, husband, shellfish, clam, oyster, eye, animal legs, eight, husband2 	 	Two husbands . . . shells. 	 	 	Out of two potential husbands, which would you approve of? Well, the one with shells (money) of course!!! 	 	On-Yomi: サン   Kun-Yomi: たす.ける、たた.える"
submerge	"submerge 	 	潜   	   	Lesson: 25   Frame: 907   Strokes: 15   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: submerge, water, water droplets, water pistol, exchange, husband, sun, day, tongue wagging, husband2 	 	Water . . . exchange. 	 	 	When a submarine or similar vessel SUBMERGES an EXCHANGE of air for WATER takes place in special compartments. 	 	On-Yomi: セン   Kun-Yomi: ひそ.む、もぐ.る、かく.れる、くぐ.る、ひそ.める  	Examples: 潜む (ひそ.む), 潜る (もぐ.る)"
lose	"lose 	 	失   	   	Lesson: 25   Frame: 908   Strokes: 5   —   Jouyou Grade: 4   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: lose, drop, husband 	 	""To lose"" here takes the sense of ""misplace,"" not the sense of defeat, whose kanji we learned in frame 67. It pictures a husband with something falling from his side as he is walking along, something he loses. 	  * As a primitive, this character can also mean to drop. 	 	The drop falling here is the husband´s toupee... he´s already lost his hair once, now he´s losing it again. Such is life, I suppose. 	 	On-Yomi: シツ   Kun-Yomi: うしな.う、う.せる  	Examples: 失う (うしな.う)"
iron	"iron 	 	鉄   	   	Lesson: 25   Frame: 909   Strokes: 13   —   Jouyou Grade: 3   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: iron, metal, gold, lose, drop, husband 	 	Metal . . . to drop. 	 	 	Iron is a metal that gradually becomes lost due to oxidation and rust. 	 	On-Yomi: テツ   Kun-Yomi: くろがね"
alternate	"alternate 	 	迭   	   	Lesson: 25   Frame: 910   Strokes: 8   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: transfer, alternate, lose, drop, husband, road 	 	To drop . . . road. 	 	 	When you get lost, you just take an alternate road to get back on track. 	 	On-Yomi: テツ   Kun-Yomi:"
retainer	"retainer 	 	臣   	   	Lesson: 25   Frame: 911   Strokes: 7   —   Jouyou Grade: 4   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: retainer, slave 	 	This kanji is actually a pictograph for an eye, distorted to make it appear that the pupil is protruding towards the right. This may not be an easy form to remember, but try this: Draw it once rather large, and notice how moving the two vertical lines on the right as far right as possible gives you the pictograph of the eye in its natural form. The ""pop-eye"" image belongs to an Emperor's retainer standing in awe before his ruler. 	  * As a primitive, the meaning of the key word becomes slave. 	 	Its a pictograph of a teeth with a retainer in the middle. 	 	On-Yomi: シン、ジン   Kun-Yomi:   	Examples: 臣下 (しんか), 君臣 (くんしん)"
princess	"princess 	 	姫   	   	Lesson: 25   Frame: 912   Strokes: 10   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: princess, woman, retainer, slave 	 	Woman . . . slave. 	 	 	Princess Leia becomes Jabba´s slave (“princess Leia is a woman slave”). 	 	On-Yomi: キ   Kun-Yomi: ひめ、ひめ-  	Examples: 姫 (ひめ)"
storehouse	"storehouse 	 	蔵   	   	Lesson: 25   Frame: 913   Strokes: 15   —   Jouyou Grade: 6   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: storehouse, flowers, parade, retainer, slave 	 	Flowers . . . parade . . . slaves. 	 	 	The storehouse is overgrown with slaves. The slaves are to be sold in the store, to differentiate from a warehouse, which doesn´t have the word ""store"" in it. 	 	On-Yomi: ゾウ、ソウ   Kun-Yomi: くら、おさ.める、かく.れる  	Examples: 蔵 (くら)"
entrails	"entrails 	 	臓   	   	Lesson: 25   Frame: 914   Strokes: 19   —   Jouyou Grade: 6   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: entrails, moon, month, flesh, part of the body, storehouse, flowers, parade, retainer, slave 	 	Part of the body . . . storehouse. 	 	 	You signed your organ donor card, right? So, when you die, your entrails and other body parts will be placed in a storehouse. 	 	On-Yomi: ゾウ   Kun-Yomi: はらわた"
intelligent	"intelligent 	 	賢   	   	Lesson: 25   Frame: 915   Strokes: 16   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: intelligent, loincloth, retainer, slave, crotch, shellfish, clam, oyster, eye, animal legs, eight 	 	Slave . . . crotch . . . shellfish. 	 	 	An intelligent man is neither slave to his crotch nor to money. But an intelligent slave will know how to use his/her crotch to make money. 	 	On-Yomi: ケン   Kun-Yomi: かしこ.い  	Examples: 賢い (かしこ.い)"
strict	"strict 	 	堅   	   	Lesson: 25   Frame: 917   Strokes: 12   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: strict, loincloth, retainer, slave, crotch, soil, dirt, ground 	 	Slave . . . crotch . . . soil. 	 	 	The strict parent thinks adolescent kids are ""slaves to their crotch"" (= can´t control their hormones), so he grounds them. Permanently! 	 	On-Yomi: ケン   Kun-Yomi: かた.い、-がた.い  	Examples: 堅い (かた.い)"
look to	"look to 	 	臨   	   	Lesson: 25   Frame: 918   Strokes: 18   —   Jouyou Grade: 6   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: look to, retainer, slave, reclining, lying down, goods, mouth, mouth3 	 	Slave . . . reclining . . . goods. The key word suggests both looking ahead to something and ""seeing to"" what is at hand. Consistent with everything we have learned about the role of the key word, this means that you must choose ONE meaning and stick to it. 	 	 	The slave is look to the future, ""One day"" he thinks ""I will be able to recline with all my goods, a tv, stereo and washing machine, and when that day comes I shall be truly happy"" he sighs. 	 	On-Yomi: リン   Kun-Yomi: のぞ.む  	Examples: 臨む (のぞ.む)"
perusal	"perusal 	 	覧   	   	Lesson: 25   Frame: 919   Strokes: 17   —   Jouyou Grade: 6   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: perusal, retainer, slave, reclining, lying down, one, floor, look, see, telescope, eye, human legs 	 	Slaves . . . reclining . . . floor . . . see. 	 	 	The slave reclines on the floor at night to watch the stars. Since that´s the only thing the slave is allowed to “read”, he does so very thoroughly and diligently, hence perusal. 	 	On-Yomi: ラン   Kun-Yomi: み.る"
gigantic	"gigantic 	 	巨   	   	Lesson: 25   Frame: 920   Strokes: 5   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: gigantic, Fafner 	 	This kanji depicts a gigantic ""pop-eye,"" which accounts for its shape. Be sure not to confuse it with the slave (retainer) we just learned. 	 	 	This is actually the top view of a porn star with a gigantic erect penis. The top and bottom are his arms and the middle is his penis. Imagine him making the pumping motion while he´s banging some chick. The arms move in, the penis moves out and vice versa. 	 	On-Yomi: キョ   Kun-Yomi:"
repel	"repel 	 	拒   	   	Lesson: 25   Frame: 921   Strokes: 8   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: repel, finger, fingers, gigantic, Fafner 	 	Fingers . . . gigantic. 	 	 	A woman might be REPELLED by a porn star´s GIGANTIC penis, so he kindly offers to use his FINGERS instead. 	 	On-Yomi: キョ、ゴ   Kun-Yomi: こば.む  	Examples: 拒む (こば.む)"
power	"power 	 	力   	   	Lesson: 25   Frame: 922   Strokes: 2   —   Jouyou Grade: 1   JLPT: 4   	Constituents: power, muscle, arnold 	 	With a little imagination, one can see a muscle in this simple, two-stroke character meaning power. 	  * As a primitive, either muscle or power can be used. 	 	I always refer to the power of the KATAKANA ""KA"". 	 	On-Yomi: リョク、リキ、リイ   Kun-Yomi: ちから  	Examples: 権力 (けんりょく), 努力 (どりょく), 能力 (のうりょく), 力 (ちから)"
man	"man 	 	男   	   	Lesson: 25   Frame: 923   Strokes: 7   —   Jouyou Grade: 1   JLPT: 5   	Constituents: male, rice field, brains, power, muscle, arnold 	 	Rice fields . . . power. This character is the gender-specific man, not the generic human person of frame 951. 	 	 	Male is seen here as muscles working in the field, in other words working in the rice fields is the work of the male who are usually stronger. This is more or less the meaning of the original Chinese character. 	 	On-Yomi: ダン、ナン   Kun-Yomi: おとこ、お  	Examples: 男子 (だんし), 男女 (だんじょ), 男性 (だんせい), 男 (おとこ)"

Those jocks who always tried to show their muscles in the schoolhouse are now the ones out there doing manual labor jobs while we sit here and learn Japanese. Ha! 	 	On-Yomi: ロウ   Kun-Yomi: ろう.する、いたわ.る、いた.ずき、ねぎら、つか.れる、ねぎら.う"

The necromancer hangs out at the local graveyard and uses his dark powers to recruit an army of undead. Emphasize the verb form to keep distinct from the noun cadet (#1173). This is the only case in which the primitive for muscle appears on the left; note should be taken of the fact in composing one's story. 	 	 	If you eat anymore, you will be adding more カロries. (katakana karo). 	 	On-Yomi: カ   Kun-Yomi: くわ.える、くわ.わる  	Examples: 加える (くわ.える), 加わる (くわ.わる)"
