erect	"erect 	 	架   	   	Lesson: 25   Frame: 934   Strokes: 9   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: erect, add, power, muscle, arnold, mouth, tree, wood 	 	Add . . . trees. Hint: if you ever played with an ""Erector Set"" or ""Tinker Toys"" as a child, don't pass up the opportunity to relate it to this kanji's key word and the element for trees. 	 	 	Instant wood. Just add Viagra. 	 	On-Yomi: カ   Kun-Yomi: か.ける、か.かる  	Examples: 架かる (か.かる), 架ける (か.ける)"
armpit	"armpit 	 	脇   	   	Lesson: 25   Frame: 935   Strokes: 10   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT:    	Constituents: armpit, moon, month, flesh, part of the body, triceps, power, muscle, arnold, power3, muscle3, arnold3 	 	Part of the body . . . muscles (three of which give us ""triceps"" or ""muscles on top of muscles""). You will want to keep the kanji distinct from the one that follows by paying attention to the positioning of the elements. 	 	 	What part of the body has a very, very, very powerful smell? The armpit, of course! 	 	On-Yomi: キョウ   Kun-Yomi: わき、わけ  	Examples: 脇 (わき)"
threaten	"threaten 	 	脅   	   	Lesson: 25   Frame: 936   Strokes: 10   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: threaten, triceps, power, muscle, arnold, moon, month, flesh, part of the body, power3, muscle3, arnold3 	 	Triceps . . . part of the body. 	 	 	Compare the primitive positions of armpit (#870) and threaten (#871). When your triceps rest alongside your body, they fit snugly against your armpit. When you hold them above your body, however, your posture becomes quite threatening. 	 	On-Yomi: キョウ   Kun-Yomi: おびや.かす、おど.す、おど.かす  	Examples: 脅かす (おど.かす), 脅す (おど.す), 脅かす (おびや.かす)"
co-	"co- 	 	協   	   	Lesson: 25   Frame: 937   Strokes: 8   —   Jouyou Grade: 4   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: co-, ten, needle, triceps, power, muscle, arnold, power3, muscle3, arnold3 	 	This prefix should be kept distinct from inter (Frame 222) and mutual (Frame 819). Its elements: needle . . . triceps. 	 	 	The nurse says : “If you co-operate, that needle (syringe) in your triceps won´t hurt”. Note: both co- and cooperate are meanings for this kanji. 	 	On-Yomi: キョウ   Kun-Yomi:"
going	"going 	 	行   	   	Lesson: 25   Frame: 938   Strokes: 6   —   Jouyou Grade: 2   JLPT: 5   	Constituents: going, boulevard, going 	 	By joining the top four strokes, you should get a picture of the front current of a river, the stream trailing behind. Hence the character for going. 	  * As a primitive, this character has two forms. Reduced to the left side only, it can mean a column, going, or a line of something or other. When the middle is opened up to make room for other elements, it means a boulevard. 	 	I use The Flash for for this primitive; a superhero who is always going very fast. 	 	On-Yomi: コウ、ギョウ、アン   Kun-Yomi: い.く、ゆ.く、-ゆ.き、-ゆき、-い.き、-いき、おこな.う、おこ.なう  	Examples: 行進 (こうしん), 行為 (こうい), 旅行 (りょこう), 行列 (ぎょうれつ), 行政 (ぎょうせい), 修行 (しゅぎょう), 行く (い.く), 行う (おこな.う), 行く (ゆ.く)"

The calligrapher´s brush is moving down a column of a script, in rhythm with his meditation. 	 	On-Yomi: リツ、リチ、レツ   Kun-Yomi:   	Examples: 律動 (りつどう), 規律 (きりつ), 法律 (ほうりつ)"

indications	"indications 	 	徴   	   	Lesson: 25   Frame: 952   Strokes: 14   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: indications, sherpa, Nelson, column, going, line, mountain, king, jewel, ball, taskmaster 	 	Line . . . mountain . . . king . . . taskmaster. penal	"penal 	 	懲   	   	Lesson: 25   Frame: 953   Strokes: 18   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: penal, indications, sherpa, Nelson, column, going, line, mountain, king, jewel, ball, taskmaster, heart 	 	Indications . . . heart. 	 	 	Penal servitude is served until indications show that one has had a change of heart (learned one´s lesson). Easily confused with punish (#679) and penalty (#833). Concentrate on the reasons behind the penal system (""changing people´s hearts"" here), instead of the penalty itself or the punishment (revenge) aspect. It may help to note that there´s no sword, but a heart :-) (Note: 懲りる = learn from one´s bad experiences). 	 	On-Yomi: チョウ   Kun-Yomi: こ.りる、こ.らす、こ.らしめる  	Examples: 懲らしめる (こ.らしめる), 懲らす (こ.らす), 懲りる (こ.りる)"
delicate	"delicate 	 	微   	   	Lesson: 25   Frame: 954   Strokes: 13   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: delicate, sherpa, Nelson, column, going, line, mountain, one, ceiling, human legs, taskmaster 	 	Line . . . mountain . . . ceiling . . . human legs . . . taskmaster. 	 	 	The Column of 300 spartans were in a delicate situation. They had travelled in one line (using only their legs) to the mountain pass to face the fierce Persian task master. 	 	On-Yomi: ビ   Kun-Yomi: かす.か"
boulevard	"boulevard 	 	街   	   	Lesson: 25   Frame: 955   Strokes: 12   —   Jouyou Grade: 4   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: boulevard, going, ivy, square jewel, soil, dirt, ground, soil2, dirt2, ground2 	 	This is the character from which the sense of boulevard mentioned in frame 938 derives. Its elements: boulevard . . . ivy. 	 	 	The boulevard of boulevards, the Champs Elysées, with the Arc de Triomphe covered in ivy to give the champions a heroes´ welcome. 	 	On-Yomi: ガイ、カイ   Kun-Yomi: まち  	Examples: 街頭 (がいとう), 市街 (しがい), 商店街 (しょうてんがい), 街 (まち)"

tax	"tax 	 	税   	   	Lesson: 26   Frame: 961   Strokes: 12   —   Jouyou Grade: 5   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: tax, wheat, cereal, devil, horns, elder brother, teenager, mouth, human legs 	 	Wheat . . . devil. 	 	 	Nobody likes the tax man, so here it is only fitting that the person who comes over to take some of your wheat is depicted here as a devil. Keep in mind that in feudal societies there was no kind of money to speak of, so taxes were paid by serfs in wheat to the devils who came over to keep them poor. 	 	On-Yomi: ゼイ   Kun-Yomi:"

Can also mean bacteria.....imagine the wheat pent in your fridge growing to the point where they resemble flowers.......I actually had something similar happen to onions...they grew footlong legs after about 2 or 3 years......OR just think of that Cowboy Bebop episode with the lobster in the fridge... :-). rice	"rice 	 	米   	   	Lesson: 26   Frame: 987   Strokes: 6   —   Jouyou Grade: 2   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: rice 	 	This kanji has a pictographic resemblance to a number of grains of rice lying on a plate in the shape of a star. 	  * As a primitive, it keeps its meaning of rice, and is meant to connote a very ordinary, commonplace grain, in contrast to the primitive for wheat that we just learned. (This meaning accords well with Japan, where the output of rice far exceeds that of wheat.) It occasionally takes a different shape when it stands on its own, or is joined to a line above. In this case, we shall have it refer specifically to grains of rice. This primitive is not to be confused with the similar-looking primitive for water. While the stroke orders are nearly alike, grains of rice has 5 strokes, while water only has 4 because it joins the second and third strokes into one. Finally, we may note that by itself the kanji for rice is an abbreviation used for the United States, which can then also serve as an alternate reading for the main primitive form, if you so wish. 	 	Stroke order: I like to think of the first two strokes as “chop sticks” with which one eats the rice. The rest then is the “tree” meaning “plant” in this contexct. also: USA. 	 	On-Yomi: ベイ、マイ、メエトル   Kun-Yomi: こめ、よね  	Examples: 米作 (べいさく), 米価 (べいか), 米食 (べいしょく), 米 (こめ)"

Parts of parts of parts of parts of rice... is flour. (Image: geishas patting their face with RICE flour to make it white. Not wheat flour...). 	 	On-Yomi: フン、デシメートル   Kun-Yomi: こ、こな  	Examples: 粉 (こ), 粉 (こな)"

core	"core 	 	奥   	   	Lesson: 26   Frame: 997   Strokes: 12   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: core, drop, pent in, rice, large, St. Bernard 	 	A drop . . . pent in . . . rice . . . St. Bernard dog. Notice that the horizontal line of the bottom primitive doubles up as the final stroke for pent in. 	 	 	In the core of a nuclear reactor, scientists have discovered a way to get power from rice, by penting it in under high pressure. It´s very dangerous, so they´ve trained a st. bernard dog to run things, he´s adding more drops of rice as necessary. 	 	On-Yomi: オウ、オク   Kun-Yomi: おく.まる、くま  	Examples: 奥 (おく)"

Young taskmaster is learning numbers by watching women haul sacks of rice past him. ""One... two... four! No, wrong! Go back, go back!"". watchtower	"watchtower 	 	楼   	   	Lesson: 26   Frame: 999   Strokes: 13   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: watchtower, tree, wood, rice, woman 	 	Tree . . . rice . . . woman. 	 	 	The young taskmaster (see number (#929)) uses a tree as a watchtower to get a better view of his rice-carrying women. ""I can seeeee you! One! Two! Three!"". 	 	On-Yomi: ロウ   Kun-Yomi: たかどの"
sort	"sort 	 	類   	   	Lesson: 26   Frame: 1000   Strokes: 18   —   Jouyou Grade: 4   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: sort, rice, large, St. Bernard, head, page, one, ceiling, drop, shellfish, clam, oyster, eye, animal legs, eight 	 	Rice . . . St. Bernard dog . . . head. 	 	 	Note this character means sort in the sense of what kind, I believe a better keyword would be ""variety"" and this character does appear in some dictionaries with the primary meaning as variety, my story: I´m in a Chinese restaurant and the waiter says ""What sort of rice would you like with your dog head?"". 	 	On-Yomi: ルイ   Kun-Yomi: たぐ.い"
lacquer	"lacquer 	 	漆   	   	Lesson: 26   Frame: 1001   Strokes: 14   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: lacquer, water, water droplets, water pistol, tree, wood, umbrella, grains of rice 	 	Water . . . tree . . . umbrella . . . grains of rice. 	 	 	LACQUER is a type of WATERY type of liquid used to protect items made from TREES, sort of an UMBRELLA of protection. So protective, you can carry around RICE in the LACQUERED, WOODEN product. 	 	On-Yomi: シツ   Kun-Yomi: うるし  	Examples: 漆 (うるし)"
Esq.	"Esq. 	 	様   	   	Lesson: 26   Frame: 1003   Strokes: 14   —   Jouyou Grade: 3   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: Esq., tree, wood, sheep, grains of rice 	 	The abbreviation Esq. will help associate this character with the honorific form of address to which it belongs. Its elements are: tree . . . sheep . . . grains of rice. Note that the final vertical stroke in the element for sheep is extended to form the first stroke for grains of rice. 	 	 	Here we have the requirements to be counted among the ranks of the noble Esq. You must posses a forested estate, herds of sheep, and granary full of grains of rice. 	 	On-Yomi: ヨウ、ショウ   Kun-Yomi: さま、さん  	Examples: 様 (さま)"
request	"request 	 	求   	   	Lesson: 26   Frame: 1004   Strokes: 7   —   Jouyou Grade: 4   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: request, arrow, grains of rice 	 	Let the drop in the upper right-hand corner of this character close the right angle off to make an arrowhead. Whenever we find the needle with that drop in an element that has no other special meaning, we will take advantage of this primitive meaning. At the bottom, we see the grains of rice, the vertical line doubling up for the two elements. Do not confuse with petition (Frame 143). 	 	 	Enemy: ""Any final requests?"" // MacGyver: ""Just an arrowhead and some grains of rice."" (MacGyver then throws the grains of rice at the enemy and uses the arrowhead to cut his hands free from the rope.). 	 	On-Yomi: キュウ、グ   Kun-Yomi: もと.める  	Examples: 求める (もと.める)"
ball	"ball 	 	球   	   	Lesson: 26   Frame: 1005   Strokes: 11   —   Jouyou Grade: 3   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: ball, king, jewel, ball, request, arrow, grains of rice 	 	Ball . . . request. 	 	 	Someone files a request to see the family jewels and, to their surprise, you show them your balls! 	 	On-Yomi: キュウ   Kun-Yomi: たま  	Examples: 球 (たま)"
salvation	"salvation 	 	救   	   	Lesson: 26   Frame: 1006   Strokes: 11   —   Jouyou Grade: 4   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: salvation, request, arrow, grains of rice, taskmaster 	 	Request . . . taskmaster. 	 	 	Like in the biblical sense, someone looks skyward and makes a request for salvation from this horrible taskmaster... 	 	On-Yomi: キュウ   Kun-Yomi: すく.う  	Examples: 救う (すく.う)"
bamboo	"bamboo 	 	竹   	   	Lesson: 26   Frame: 1007   Strokes: 6   —   Jouyou Grade: 1   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: bamboo 	 	Bamboo grows upwards, like a straight nail, and at each stage of its growth (which legend associates with the arrival of the new moon) there is a jointed rootstock (the first stroke). Two such bamboo stalks are pictured here. 	  * As a primitive, the meaning remains the same, but the vertical lines are severely abbreviated so that they can take their place at the top where, like flowers, they are always to be found. 	 	Pandas like to eat bamboo. I´m using panda as the primitive name when it fits the story. ^__^. 	 	On-Yomi: チク   Kun-Yomi: たけ  	Examples: 竹 (たけ)"
laugh	"laugh 	 	笑   	   	Lesson: 26   Frame: 1008   Strokes: 10   —   Jouyou Grade: 4   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: laugh, bamboo, heavens 	 	Bamboo . . . heavens. 	 	 	When the people tried to build a tower of bamboo to reach the heavens, the gods just laughed and laughed. 	 	On-Yomi: ショウ   Kun-Yomi: わら.う、え.む  	Examples: 笑む (え.む), 笑う (わら.う)"
bamboo hat	"bamboo hat 	 	笠   	   	Lesson: 26   Frame: 1009   Strokes: 11   —   Jouyou Grade: Names   JLPT:    	Constituents: bamboo hat, bamboo, vase, stand up 	 	Bamboo . . . vase. 	 	 	The bamboo vase was beautifully crafted, but the tourist didn´t know what it was and wore it as a little bamboo hat. 	 	On-Yomi: リュウ   Kun-Yomi: かさ"
bamboo grass	"bamboo grass 	 	笹   	   	Lesson: 26   Frame: 1010   Strokes: 11   —   Jouyou Grade: Names   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: bamboo grass, bamboo, generation 	 	Bamboo . . . generation. 	 	 	The bamboo generation smokes bamboo grass. 	 	On-Yomi:    Kun-Yomi: ささ"
muscle	"muscle 	 	筋   	   	Lesson: 26   Frame: 1012   Strokes: 12   —   Jouyou Grade: 6   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: muscle, bamboo, moon, month, flesh, part of the body, power, muscle, arnold 	 	Bamboo . . . part of the body . . . power. Here we see how the primitive meaning of muscle was derived from the kanji for power. 	 	 	Muscle is part of the body that gives strength, and can be both supple and tense like the bamboo. 	 	On-Yomi: キン   Kun-Yomi: すじ  	Examples: 筋 (すじ)"
box	"box 	 	箱   	   	Lesson: 26   Frame: 1013   Strokes: 15   —   Jouyou Grade: 3   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: box , bamboo, inter, Inter Milan, tree, wood, eye 	 	Bamboo . . . inter-. 	 	 	The best kind of BOX is made from BAMBOO sticks that are INTER-laced to make it air tight. Just picture such a box and you´ve mastered this kanji. 	 	On-Yomi: ソウ   Kun-Yomi: はこ  	Examples: 箱 (はこ)"
writing brush	"writing brush 	 	筆   	   	Lesson: 26   Frame: 1014   Strokes: 12   —   Jouyou Grade: 3   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: writing brush, bamboo, brush 	 	Bamboo . . . brush. 	 	 	Bamboo is the best material from which to make a brush if you want it to be a writing brush. 	 	On-Yomi: ヒツ   Kun-Yomi: ふで  	Examples: 筆 (ふで)"
cylinder	"cylinder 	 	筒   	   	Lesson: 26   Frame: 1015   Strokes: 12   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: cylinder, bamboo, same, monks, hood, one, mouth 	 	Bamboo . . . monk. 	 	 	Seriously, all BAMBOO sticks look the SAME, just long CYLINDERS. Should the story be more complicated? 	 	On-Yomi: トウ   Kun-Yomi: つつ  	Examples: 筒 (つつ)"
etc.	"etc. 	 	等   	   	Lesson: 26   Frame: 1016   Strokes: 12   —   Jouyou Grade: 3   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: etc., bamboo, Buddhist temple, soil, dirt, ground, glue 	 	Bamboo . . . Buddhist temple. 	 	 	The Bamboo Buddhist Temple has bamboo buddhas, bamboo buildings, bamboo benches, bamboo beds, bamboo bowls, etc. etc. etc. 	 	On-Yomi: トウ   Kun-Yomi: ひと.しい、など、-ら  	Examples: 等しい (ひと.しい)"
calculate	"calculate 	 	算   	   	Lesson: 26   Frame: 1017   Strokes: 14   —   Jouyou Grade: 2   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: calculate, bamboo, eye, two hands 	 	Bamboo . . . eyes . . . two hands. 	 	 	Before the time of digital calculators, people used old school calculators made of bamboo (abacus). It´s not as easy as a calculator, but you don´t need any batteries either. All you need are your eyes and your two hands. 	 	On-Yomi: サン   Kun-Yomi: そろ"
solution	"solution 	 	答   	   	Lesson: 26   Frame: 1018   Strokes: 12   —   Jouyou Grade: 2   JLPT: 4   	Constituents: solution, bamboo, fit, meeting, umbrella, one, mouth 	 	Bamboo . . . fit. 	 	 	The solution to this puzzle is, like the match stick game, to make the bamboo pieces fit together. 	 	On-Yomi: トウ   Kun-Yomi: こた.える、こた.え  	Examples: 答え (こた.え), 答える (こた.える)"
scheme	"scheme 	 	策   	   	Lesson: 26   Frame: 1019   Strokes: 12   —   Jouyou Grade: 6   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: scheme, bamboo, tree, wood, belt 	 	Bamboo . . . belted tree (See frame 446). 	 	 	(Elaboration of jameserb´s story:) A clever scheme from Wile E Coyote -- he ties one of those rubber belts to some trees and uses it to launch a bamboo spear at the roadrunner... 	 	On-Yomi: サク   Kun-Yomi:"
register	"register 	 	簿   	   	Lesson: 26   Frame: 1020   Strokes: 19   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: register, bamboo, water, water droplets, water pistol, acupuncturist, specialty, drop, ten, needle, rice field, brains, glue 	 	Bamboo . . . water . . . acupuncturist. 	 	 	Note : the keyword is not a verb, think of a record book. This acupuncturist who uses bamboo in place of flowers to dilute water into his patients (see frame 227), managed somehow to appear on the register of acupuncturists. Chances are, he won´t stay on the register for long. My image is close to that of gorgon´s story. 	 	On-Yomi: ボ   Kun-Yomi:"
fabricate	"fabricate 	 	築   	   	Lesson: 26   Frame: 1021   Strokes: 16   —   Jouyou Grade: 5   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: fabricate, bamboo, barge, craft, mediocre, wind, drop, tree, wood 	 	Bamboo . . . craft . . . mediocre . . . wood/tree. 	 	 	Bamboo crafting is a mediocre substitute for wood when you are building or fabricating a house. While it may look good and might attract a chick (ちく) or two, the kids´ll (きず) just tear it to pieces as its not sturdy enough. 	 	On-Yomi: チク   Kun-Yomi: きず.く  	Examples: 築く (きず.く)"
person	"person 	 	人   	   	Lesson: 27   Frame: 1023   Strokes: 2   —   Jouyou Grade: 1   JLPT: 5   	Constituents: person 	 	The character for enter (Frame 842) showed someone walking inwards (in terms of the direction of writing), the one for person, shown here, represents someone walking outwards. 	  * As a primitive, it can keep its kanji form except when it appears to the left (its normal position), where it is made to stand up in the form ⺅ (Similar to イ). The primitive meaning is another matter. The abstract notion of person so often has a relation to the meaning of the kanji that confusion readily sets in. So many of the previous stories have included people in them that simply to use person for a primitive meaning would be risky. We need to be more specific, to focus on one particular person. Try to choose someone who has not figured in the stories so far, perhaps a colorful member of the family or a friend whom you have known for a long time. That individual will appear again and again, so be sure to choose someone who excites your imagination. 	 	Behold Mister T (of ""A-Team"" fame)! I chose Mr.T because he´s sure to make amusing stories. He is a very versatile character since he´s both the big, tough guy and the “moralistic” person, telling kids not “to do drugs or alcohol”. He is easy to imagine, the heavy gold chains are probably the most prominent feature of the character. And last but not least you can always pepper your story with the famous line “I pity da foo!” * Fittingly, on the left side of the kanji, it looks like a “T”. 	 	On-Yomi: ジン、ニン   Kun-Yomi: ひと、-り、-と  	Examples: 人道 (じんどう), 人員 (じんいん), 成人 (せいじん), 人 (ひと)"
assistant	"assistant 	 	佐   	   	Lesson: 27   Frame: 1024   Strokes: 7   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: assistant, person, left, by one’s side, craft 	 	Person . . . left. 	 	 	Mr T´s assistant is on his left. Why? Because Mr T has this bad habit of suddenly extending his right arm (what with all the boxing that he did), and his assistant got inadvertently punched in the face more than once (ouch). So now his assistant is always to his left side, much safer - ""Stay on my left, foo!"". 	 	On-Yomi: サ   Kun-Yomi:"
however	"however 	 	但   	   	Lesson: 27   Frame: 1026   Strokes: 7   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: however, person, nightbreak, sun, day, one, floor 	 	Person . . . nightbreak. 	 	 	However drunk Mr T is when he comes back to his place, he always get up at nightbreak. “I pity da foo who gets up after nightbreak !”, says Mr. T. 	 	On-Yomi: タン   Kun-Yomi: ただ.し  	Examples: 但し (ただ.し)"
dwell	"dwell 	 	住   	   	Lesson: 27   Frame: 1027   Strokes: 7   —   Jouyou Grade: 3   JLPT: 4   	Constituents: dwell, person, candlestick, lord, drop, king, jewel, ball 	 	Person . . . candlestick. 	 	 	When Mr T shows people round his dwelling he takes a big candlestick (with a candle in it!) so that the light shows off his collection of bling bling jewellery. 	 	On-Yomi: ジュウ、ヂュウ、チュウ   Kun-Yomi: す.む、す.まう、-ず.まい  	Examples: 住まう (す.まう), 住む (す.む)"
rank	"rank 	 	位   	   	Lesson: 27   Frame: 1028   Strokes: 7   —   Jouyou Grade: 4   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: rank, person, vase, stand up 	 	Person . . . vase. 	 	 	Mr T ranks first position in the stand-up competition (doing knee flexions). Just picture him doing hundreds of these while the rest of the participants are already completely exhausted after a mere hundred. 	 	On-Yomi: イ   Kun-Yomi: くらい、ぐらい  	Examples: 位 (くらい)"
go-between	"go-between 	 	仲   	   	Lesson: 27   Frame: 1029   Strokes: 6   —   Jouyou Grade: 4   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: go-between, person, in, stick, mouth 	 	Person . . . in. 	 	 	When negotiating a hostage situation, Mr. T acted as the go-between, or person in the middle, for law enforcement and the terrorist. 	 	On-Yomi: チュウ   Kun-Yomi: なか  	Examples: 仲 (なか)"
body	"body 	 	体   	   	Lesson: 27   Frame: 1030   Strokes: 7   —   Jouyou Grade: 2   JLPT: 4   	Constituents: body, person, origin, book, tree, wood, one 	 	Person . . . book. 	 	 	Mister T works out his body (body-building), using two piles of books (i.e. an exercise that can be done at home with two chairs, similar to push-ups but working mostly the shoulders, trapezius and triceps). 	 	On-Yomi: タイ、テイ   Kun-Yomi: からだ、かたち  	Examples: 体格 (たいかく), 人体 (じんたい), 主体 (しゅたい), 体 (からだ)"
remote	"remote 	 	悠   	   	Lesson: 27   Frame: 1031   Strokes: 11   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: permanence, remote, person, stick, fred astaire, taskmaster, heart 	 	Person . . . walking stick . . . taskmaster . . . heart. 	 	 	Mr. T ventured out into a remote area to visit with his wise, old taskmaster who must use a walking stick to get around and originally gave Mr. T the heart to fight crime for the good of the community. 	 	On-Yomi: ユウ   Kun-Yomi:"
affair	"affair 	 	件   	   	Lesson: 27   Frame: 1032   Strokes: 6   —   Jouyou Grade: 5   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: affair, person, cow 	 	Person . . . cow. 	 	 	Note: this kanji refers to event or case. Current Affair headline: Mr. T has affair with cow. ""It´s only animal ´man´ enough for me"". 	 	On-Yomi: ケン   Kun-Yomi: くだん"

The key word means to wait on someone or serve them. 	 	 	Back in the day, a person who stands beside a samurai is usually attending to them or working for them. other	"other 	 	他   	   	Lesson: 27   Frame: 1034   Strokes: 5   —   Jouyou Grade: 3   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: other, person, scorpion 	 	Person . . . scorpion. 	 	 	Old latin saying: homo hominis scorpio (people are scorpions to other people). 	 	On-Yomi: タ   Kun-Yomi: ほか"
prostrated	"prostrated 	 	伏   	   	Lesson: 27   Frame: 1035   Strokes: 6   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: prostrated, person, chihuahua, dog, large, drop 	 	Person . . . chihuahua. 	 	 	Don´t need a silly story for this one: prostration is when a person puts themselves in a low position like a dog, as an extreme gesture of humility. 	 	On-Yomi: フク   Kun-Yomi: ふ.せる、ふ.す  	Examples: 伏す (ふ.す), 伏せる (ふ.せる)"
transmit	"transmit 	 	伝   	   	Lesson: 27   Frame: 1036   Strokes: 6   —   Jouyou Grade: 4   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: transmit, person, rising cloud, two, elbow, wall 	 	Person . . . rising cloud. Hint: the Amerindians' smoke signal scan help provide a good image for this kanji, whose key word is meant to include transmissions of all sorts. 	 	 	Mister T transmits a message with rising clouds (smoke) signals, to a nearby American Indian tribe. The smoke signals spell : ""I p-i-t-y y-o-u f-o-o !"". 	 	On-Yomi: デン、テン   Kun-Yomi: つた.わる、つた.える、つた.う、つだ.う、-づた.い、つて  	Examples: 伝う (つた.う), 伝える (つた.える), 伝わる (つた.わる)"

Be sure not to confuse with relax (Frame 202). 	 	 	Mr T resting by a tree. 	 	On-Yomi: キュウ   Kun-Yomi: やす.む、やす.まる、やす.める  	Examples: 休まる (やす.まる), 休む (やす.む), 休める (やす.める)"

(NB: I tried with the indian chief motif but kept adding feathers by mistake). 	 	On-Yomi: ハク   Kun-Yomi:"
vulgar	"vulgar 	 	俗   	   	Lesson: 27   Frame: 1042   Strokes: 9   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: vulgar, person, valley, eight, umbrella, mouth 	 	Person . . . valley. The key word should be taken in its older sense of ""popular"" or ""commonplace."" 	 	 	Mr. T says, ""Don´t be like them valley girls, always speaking vulgar language and acting all vulgar! They ain´t nothing but foos!"". 	 	On-Yomi: ゾク   Kun-Yomi:"

Mr. T has faith in the Word of God. (Image: Mr. T kneeling and prayering in front of a bible. ""Pity me, fool.""). 	 	On-Yomi: シン   Kun-Yomi:"
excellent	"excellent 	 	佳   	   	Lesson: 27   Frame: 1044   Strokes: 8   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: excellent, person, ivy, square jewel, soil, dirt, ground, soil2, dirt2, ground2 	 	Person . . . ivy. To distinguish from excel (Frame 980), eminent (Frame 52), esteem (Frame 196), and exquisite (Frame 130), give the key word its own unique connotation. 	 	 	Mr T wants to go to an excellent school, so he enrolls in Harvard, an ivy-league school. 	 	On-Yomi: カ   Kun-Yomi:"
reliant	"reliant 	 	依   	   	Lesson: 27   Frame: 1045   Strokes: 8   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: reliant, person, cloth, clothes, clothing, garment 	 	Person . . . garment. 	 	 	Mr T is reliant (depends on) on his garment (the gold chains). 	 	On-Yomi: イ、エ   Kun-Yomi: よ.る  	Examples: 依頼 (いらい), 依拠 (いきょ), 依然 (いぜん)"
example	"example 	 	例   	   	Lesson: 27   Frame: 1046   Strokes: 8   —   Jouyou Grade: 4   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: example, person, file, bones, one, ceiling, evening, sword, sabre, saber 	 	Person . . . file. 	 	 	Mr T shows the example to the kids, and stays in the file (at supermarket, ...). “I pity da foo who does not follow my example !”. 	 	On-Yomi: レイ   Kun-Yomi: たと.える  	Examples: 例える (たと.える)"
individual	"individual 	 	個   	   	Lesson: 27   Frame: 1047   Strokes: 10   —   Jouyou Grade: 5   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: individual, person, harden, pent in, old, tombstone, gravestone, church, ten, needle, mouth 	 	Person . . . harden. 	 	 	This keyword gave me trouble, I could write the kanji from memory but could not remember the keyword the other way around. In such case the dictionary definition can be helpful : ""Middle English, single, indivisible"". Here we have Mr. T. who is so hardened (all the body workout he´s had) that he became in-dividual, that is, in-divisible. ""I pity da foo who can be divided into smaller units."". 	 	On-Yomi: コ、カ   Kun-Yomi:"
healthy	"healthy 	 	健   	   	Lesson: 27   Frame: 1048   Strokes: 11   —   Jouyou Grade: 4   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: healthy, person, build, brush, stretch 	 	Person . . . build. 	 	 	Mr. T in a public service announcement yells, ""I´m healthy because every day I build a food pyramid, foo!"". 	 	On-Yomi: ケン   Kun-Yomi: すこ.やか  	Examples: 健やか (すこ.やか)"
side	"side 	 	側   	   	Lesson: 27   Frame: 1049   Strokes: 11   —   Jouyou Grade: 4   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: side, person, rule, shellfish, clam, oyster, eye, animal legs, eight, sword, sabre, saber 	 	Person . . . rule. See frame 92 for help. 	 	 	Mr. T rulezzz! I am on his side! 	 	On-Yomi: ソク   Kun-Yomi: かわ、がわ、そば  	Examples: 側 (かわ)"
waiter	"waiter 	 	侍   	   	Lesson: 27   Frame: 1050   Strokes: 8   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: waiter, person, Buddhist temple, soil, dirt, ground, glue 	 	Person . . . Buddhist temple. The key word is deceptively modern, but the kanji is actually another way of writing ""samurai."" Be careful not to confuse with attend (Frame 1033). 	 	 	Mr. T infiltrates the secret samurai Buddhist temple as a waiter with a tray of green tea. (Careful: attend (#960)). 	 	On-Yomi: ジ、シ   Kun-Yomi: さむらい、はべ.る  	Examples: 侍 (さむらい)"

Mr T downloads an emulator so that he can play his favorite game, Pokemon. reparation	"reparation 	 	償   	   	Lesson: 27   Frame: 1060   Strokes: 17   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: reparation, person, prize, outhouse, small, little, crown, mouth, shellfish, clam, oyster, eye, animal legs, eight 	 	Person . . . prize. 	 	 	Mr. T says, ""This ain´t no prize, foo! This is reparations for slavery!"". 	 	On-Yomi: ショウ   Kun-Yomi: つぐな.う  	Examples: 償う (つぐな.う)"
hermit	"hermit 	 	仙   	   	Lesson: 27   Frame: 1061   Strokes: 5   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: hermit, person, mountain 	 	Person . . . mountain. 	 	 	A HERMIT is a PERSON who lives in the MOUNTAINS. 	 	On-Yomi: セン、セント   Kun-Yomi:"
sponsor	"sponsor 	 	催   	   	Lesson: 27   Frame: 1062   Strokes: 13   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: sponsor, person, mountain, turkey 	 	Hermit . . . turkey. Note what has happened to the mountain in the element for hermit. In order to make room for the turkey, it was raised and condensed. 	 	 	And now a word from our sponsor. We see Mr. T, doing a sort of George Foreman thing, grilling Mountain Turkeys. ""I pity da foo who don´t have a Mr. T grill!"". 	 	On-Yomi: サイ   Kun-Yomi: もよう.す、もよお.す  	Examples: 催す (もよお.す)"
humanity	"humanity 	 	仁   	   	Lesson: 27   Frame: 1063   Strokes: 4   —   Jouyou Grade: 6   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: humanity, person, two 	 	To refer to the fullness of humanity that can only be achieved in dialogue with another (person . . . two), Confucius used this character. 	 	 	The beginning of humanity required at least TWO people. Mr. T and Mrs. T! 	 	On-Yomi: ジン、ニ、ニン   Kun-Yomi:   	Examples: 仁義 (じんぎ), 仁術 (ひとしじゅつ)"
scorn	"scorn 	 	侮   	   	Lesson: 27   Frame: 1064   Strokes: 8   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: scorn, person, every, reclining, lying down, mother, breasts 	 	Every . . . person. 	 	 	Mr. T has scorn for every fool. 	 	On-Yomi: ブ   Kun-Yomi: あなど.る、あなず.る  	Examples: 侮る (あなど.る)"
use	"use 	 	使   	   	Lesson: 27   Frame: 1065   Strokes: 8   —   Jouyou Grade: 3   JLPT: 4   	Constituents: use, person, history, length, stick, mouth, tucked under the arm 	 	Person . . . officer. 	 	 	Of course Mr. T will tell a police officer if he catches someone using drugs, foo! 	 	On-Yomi: シ   Kun-Yomi: つか.う、つか.い、-つか.い、-づか.い  	Examples: 使う (つか.う)"
convenience	"convenience 	 	便   	   	Lesson: 27   Frame: 1066   Strokes: 9   —   Jouyou Grade: 4   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: convenience, person, grow late, Ameratasu, one, ceiling, sun, tucked under the arm 	 	Person . . . grow late. Hint: this kanji also means that unmentionable material that one disposes of when one goes to the ""conveniences."" 	 	 	Mr. T loves the convenience of the new konbini. Not only does it stay open even if it grows late, they have brand new toilets, and a Post Office! 	 	On-Yomi: ベン、ビン   Kun-Yomi: たよ.り  	Examples: 便利 (べんり), 便法 (べんぽう), 簡便 (かんべん), 便り (たよ.り)"
double	"double 	 	倍   	   	Lesson: 27   Frame: 1067   Strokes: 10   —   Jouyou Grade: 3   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: double, person, muzzle, vase, stand up, mouth 	 	Person . . . muzzle. Do not confuse with the kanji for duplicate (Frame 504). 	 	 	Mr. T keeps his double muzzled ... he wants all the glory. 	 	On-Yomi: バイ   Kun-Yomi:"
tenderness	"tenderness 	 	優   	   	Lesson: 27   Frame: 1068   Strokes: 17   —   Jouyou Grade: 6   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: tenderness, person, melancholy, summer, head, page, crown, heart, walking legs 	 	Person . . . melancholy. 	 	 	The A-Team is on a mission to help Hamlet. With uncharacteristic tenderness, Mr. T consoles the melancholy Hamlet. ""No, I really DO pity the poor foo. There, there little guy...take my hanky"". (Careful: benevolence (#885). 	 	On-Yomi: ユウ、ウ   Kun-Yomi: やさ.しい、すぐ.れる、まさ.る  	Examples: 優れる (すぐ.れる), 優しい (やさ.しい)"
fell	"fell 	 	伐   	   	Lesson: 27   Frame: 1069   Strokes: 6   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: fell, person, fiesta 	 	Person . . . fiesta. Hint: recall the German legend of the English missionary, Saint Boniface, who felled the sacred oak tree dedicated to Thor at Geismar (in lower Hessia), occasioning a great fiesta for the Christians in the neighborhood to mark the defeat of their pagan competition. Be sure to fit your special person into the story if you use it. 	 	 	At a fiesta, Mr. T tries to knock down a large pinata, but in his overly enthusiastic swings to get ""the sucka,"" he actually FELLS the tree the piñata is hanging from, crushing some party goers. “I pity da fools who got crushed by my FELLED tree!”. 	 	On-Yomi: バツ、ハツ、カ、ボチ   Kun-Yomi: き.る、そむ.く、う.つ"
inn	"inn 	 	宿   	   	Lesson: 27   Frame: 1070   Strokes: 11   —   Jouyou Grade: 3   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: inn, house, person, hundred, one, ceiling, white, dove 	 	House . . . person . . . hundred. 	 	 	The Toyoko Inn can house 100 people or 1 Mr. T. 	 	On-Yomi: シュク   Kun-Yomi: やど、やど.る、やど.す  	Examples: 宿 (やど), 宿す (やど.す), 宿る (やど.る)"
wound	"wound 	 	傷   	   	Lesson: 27   Frame: 1071   Strokes: 13   —   Jouyou Grade: 6   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: wound, person, reclining, lying down, piggy bank, sun, day, piglets 	 	Person . . . reclining . . . piggy bank. 	 	 	If someone doesn't have a fat piggy bank to cover their medical costs and happen to get wounded somewhere, they'll be reclining there forever. 	 	On-Yomi: ショウ   Kun-Yomi: きず、いた.む、いた.める  	Examples: 傷む (いた.む), 傷める (いた.める), 傷 (きず)"
protect	"protect 	 	保   	   	Lesson: 27   Frame: 1072   Strokes: 9   —   Jouyou Grade: 5   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: protect, person, dumbfounded, mouth, tree, wood 	 	Person . . . mouth . . . tree. 	 	 	Mr. T opens his mouth from the top of the tree saying ""I pitty da foo who don´t protect the trees!"". 	 	On-Yomi: ホ、ホウ   Kun-Yomi: たも.つ  	Examples: 保つ (たも.つ)"
praise	"praise 	 	褒   	   	Lesson: 27   Frame: 1073   Strokes: 15   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: praise, top hat, protect, person, dumbfounded, mouth, tree, wood, scarf 	 	Top hat and scarf . . . protect. Note that the ""tree"" in protect becomes a wooden pole here. 	 	 	Mr. T is praised for his protecting of the trees by being given a top hat and scarf which he wears over his mohawk and chains, respectively. 	 	On-Yomi: ホウ   Kun-Yomi: ほ.める  	Examples: 褒める (ほ.める)"
greatness	"greatness 	 	傑   	   	Lesson: 27   Frame: 1074   Strokes: 13   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: greatness, person, sunglasses, dancing legs, ballerina, evening, tree, wood 	 	Person . . . sunglasses . . . tree. 	 	 	My wise person says greatness does not come from wearing shades (sunglasses) but from planting trees to shade everyone. 	 	On-Yomi: ケツ   Kun-Yomi: すぐ.れる"
adhere	"adhere 	 	付   	   	Lesson: 27   Frame: 1075   Strokes: 5   —   Jouyou Grade: 4   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: adhere, person, glue 	 	Person . . . glue. The few cases in which this character serves as a primitive should include some connotation of ""adhering to"" that distinguishes it from ""glued to."" Two examples follow. 	 	 	賀 TO EVERYONE WHO MADE IT TO 千 kanji!! Remember, after this, you´ll be 読ing japanese novels, the news, and the internet like a native. 吉 to ALL of you in your amazing japanese 往. :). 	 	On-Yomi: フ   Kun-Yomi: つ.ける、-つ.ける、-づ.ける、つ.け、つ.け-、-つ.け、-づ.け、-づけ、つ.く、-づ.く、つ.き、-つ.き、-つき、-づ.き、-づき  	Examples: 付く (つ.く), 付ける (つ.ける)"
token	"token 	 	符   	   	Lesson: 27   Frame: 1076   Strokes: 11   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: token, bamboo, adhere, sellotape, person, glue 	 	Bamboo . . . adhere. 	 	 	I dropped my token down the drain, so I used a piece of bamboo with chewing gum on the end to retrieve it. 	 	On-Yomi: フ   Kun-Yomi:"
municipality	"municipality 	 	府   	   	Lesson: 27   Frame: 1077   Strokes: 8   —   Jouyou Grade: 4   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: borough, municipality, cave, adhere, sellotape, person, glue 	 	Cave . . . adhere. 	 	 	A municipality, like any type of government, adheres to having caves for offices (see government office (#591)). 	 	On-Yomi: フ   Kun-Yomi:"
responsibility	"responsibility 	 	任   	   	Lesson: 27   Frame: 1078   Strokes: 6   —   Jouyou Grade: 5   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: responsibility, person, porter, drop, samurai 	 	Person . . . porter. 	 	 	It is always Mr. T´s responsibility to be the porter and carry around everyone´s luggage because he´s so strong. 	 	On-Yomi: ニン   Kun-Yomi: まか.せる、まか.す  	Examples: 任す (まか.す), 任せる (まか.せる)"
fare	"fare 	 	賃   	   	Lesson: 27   Frame: 1079   Strokes: 13   —   Jouyou Grade: 6   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: fare, responsibility, person, porter, drop, samurai, shellfish, clam, oyster, eye, animal legs, eight 	 	Responsibility . . . shells/money. 	 	 	It´s your own responsibility to pay the bus fare with the correct number of shells/money. 	 	On-Yomi: チン   Kun-Yomi:"
substitute	"substitute 	 	代   	   	Lesson: 27   Frame: 1080   Strokes: 5   —   Jouyou Grade: 3   JLPT: 4   	Constituents: substitute, person, arrow 	 	Person . . . arrow. 	 	 	Mister T substitutes an arrow for a toothpick -- The keyword meaning is to replace something with something else, to act for another, to represent. It´s best to stick to the first meaning, because the last two are very close to ""mediator"" which will come in frame 1761. The idea here is that the arrow is not a toothpick, neither it is changed into one, but it can substitute for one. 	 	On-Yomi: ダイ、タイ   Kun-Yomi: か.わる、かわ.る、かわ.り、-がわ.り、か.える、よ、しろ  	Examples: 代理 (だいり), 世代 (せだい), 現代 (げんだい), 代える (か.える), 代わる (か.わる), 代 (しろ), 代 (よ)"
sack	"sack 	 	袋   	   	Lesson: 27   Frame: 1081   Strokes: 11   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: sack, substitute, person, arrow, garment 	 	Substitute . . . garment. 	 	 	A sack is an easy substitute for a garment. 	 	On-Yomi: タイ、ダイ   Kun-Yomi: ふくろ  	Examples: 袋 (ふくろ)"
lend	"lend 	 	貸   	   	Lesson: 27   Frame: 1082   Strokes: 12   —   Jouyou Grade: 5   JLPT: 4   	Constituents: lend, substitute, person, arrow, shellfish, clam, oyster, eye, animal legs, eight 	 	Substitute . . . shells/money. 	 	 	In order for the bank to lend you money, you need to put up some sort of collateral as a substitute for the money. 	 	On-Yomi: タイ   Kun-Yomi: か.す、か.し-、かし-  	Examples: 貸す (か.す)"
change	"change 	 	化   	   	Lesson: 27   Frame: 1083   Strokes: 4   —   Jouyou Grade: 3   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: change, person, spoon, sitting on the ground 	 	Person . . . spoon. 	 	 	Referring to a scene in the movie ""The Matrix"" where a girl bends a spoon with the power of her mind alone, I imagine Mister T who changes a spoon into something else (maybe the waiter forgot to bring knives or forks). Note: as a primitive, it can help to use the image of ""spare change"", this can help you keep it distinct from other similar kanji such as ""shape"" or ""turn into"". 	 	On-Yomi: カ、ケ   Kun-Yomi: ば.ける、ば.かす、ふ.ける、け.する  	Examples: 化石 (かせき), 化学 (かがく), 文化 (ぶんか), 化かす (ば.かす), 化ける (ば.ける)"
flower	"flower 	 	花   	   	Lesson: 27   Frame: 1084   Strokes: 7   —   Jouyou Grade: 1   JLPT: 4   	Constituents: flowers, change, person, spoon, sitting on the ground 	 	Flower . . . change. 	 	 	The flowers change with the seasons. 	 	On-Yomi: カ、ケ   Kun-Yomi: はな  	Examples: 花 (はな)"
freight	"freight 	 	貨   	   	Lesson: 27   Frame: 1085   Strokes: 11   —   Jouyou Grade: 4   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: freight, change, person, spoon, sitting on the ground, shellfish, clam, oyster, eye, animal legs, eight 	 	Change . . . shells. 	 	 	Freight is the shells (money) paid to change the location of something big. Don´t confuse with the similar 賃 fare (#1004). 	 	On-Yomi: カ   Kun-Yomi: たから"
lean	"lean 	 	傾   	   	Lesson: 27   Frame: 1086   Strokes: 13   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: lean, change, person, about that time, spoon, sitting on the ground, head, page, one, ceiling, drop, shellfish, clam, oyster, eye, animal legs, eight 	 	Change . . . head. The key word has the sense of leaning on or toward someone or something. 	 	 	Mr. T gave a girl some change to lean over and give him head. 	 	On-Yomi: ケイ   Kun-Yomi: かたむ.く、かたむ.ける、かたぶ.く、かた.げる、かし.げる  	Examples: 傾く (かたむ.く), 傾ける (かたむ.ける)"

What can Mr T do? ´You mean: what can´t MR T do, you fool´. 	 	On-Yomi: カ   Kun-Yomi: なに、なん、なに-、なん-  	Examples: 何 (なに)"
baggage	"baggage 	 	荷   	   	Lesson: 27   Frame: 1088   Strokes: 10   —   Jouyou Grade: 3   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: baggage, flowers, what, person, can, mouth, street, nail, spike 	 	Flowers . . . what. 	 	 	TSA guard: What´s in the baggage?! It´s just flowers, I swear! 	 	On-Yomi: カ   Kun-Yomi: に  	Examples: 荷 (に)"
sagacious	"sagacious 	 	俊   	   	Lesson: 27   Frame: 1089   Strokes: 9   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: sagacious, person, streetwalker, Ministry of silly walks, John Cleese, license, elbow, human legs, walking legs 	 	Person . . . license . . . walking legs. 	 	 	The entire town wants to get rid of legal prostitutes, but the sagacious Mr T realizes that they are a benefit to the economy and society. So he lets the sa-geishas stay. 	 	On-Yomi: シュン   Kun-Yomi:"
bystander	"bystander 	 	傍   	   	Lesson: 27   Frame: 1090   Strokes: 12   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: bystander, person, traffic cop, fez, vase, stand up, crown, compass, direction 	 	Person . . . stand . . . crown . . . compass. 	 	 	In Japan, the emperor is a bystander - he stands on his crown but can´t really affect the direction of the country. (thx shimouma). 	 	On-Yomi: ボウ   Kun-Yomi: かたわ.ら、わき、おか-、はた、そば  	Examples: 傍ら (かたわ.ら)"
long time	"long time 	 	久   	   	Lesson: 27   Frame: 1092   Strokes: 3   —   Jouyou Grade: 5   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: long time, bound up, person, mummy 	 	This character uses the diagonal sweep of the second stroke to double up for bound up and a person. Think of a mummy, and the key word will not be far behind. 	 	 	Note: this is the ひさ in ひさしぶり . Long time no see mummy! (A bound up person). 	 	On-Yomi: キュウ、ク   Kun-Yomi: ひさ.しい  	Examples: 永久 (えいきゅう), 持久 (じきゅう), 耐久 (たいきゅう), 久しい (ひさ.しい)"
furrow	"furrow 	 	畝   	   	Lesson: 27   Frame: 1093   Strokes: 10   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: furrow, top hat, rice field, brains, long time, mummy, bound up, person 	 	Think of the three kinds of furrows shown here in this character - a top hat's rim, a rice field's ridges, and the wrinkles that show you've been around a long time. 	 	 	Using a TOP HAT to make FURROWS in the RICE FIELD takes a LONG TIME! 	 	On-Yomi: ボウ、ホ、モ、ム   Kun-Yomi: せ、うね  	Examples: 畝 (うね), 畝 (せ)"
captured	"captured 	 	囚   	   	Lesson: 27   Frame: 1094   Strokes: 5   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: captured, pent in, person 	 	Person . . . pent in. 	 	 	A person pent in is obviously captured. Imagine a man put inside a wooden box, his evil capturers waiting for ransom money. 	 	On-Yomi: シュウ   Kun-Yomi: とら.われる"
inside	"inside 	 	内   	   	Lesson: 27   Frame: 1095   Strokes: 4   —   Jouyou Grade: 2   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: inside, person, belt 	 	Person . . . belt. Note that we cannot use the primitive meaning of hood here because the person runs THROUGH the element, not under it. 	 	 	Mr. T´s new belt is huge! When he´s inside it, his feet no longer touch the ground! 	 	On-Yomi: ナイ、ダイ   Kun-Yomi: うち  	Examples: 内外 (ないがい), 内容 (ないよう), 家内 (かない), 内 (うち)"
third class	"third class 	 	丙   	   	Lesson: 27   Frame: 1096   Strokes: 5   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: third class, one, ceiling, inside, person, belt 	 	Those no-frills flights the airlines offer to attract customers should help create an image from ceiling . . . person . . . belt. The kanji meaning ""inside"" should not be used because of its proximity to the element for ""in."" 	 	 	In this third class flight, the seatbelts are so bad that with the slightest turbulence all the persons hit the ceiling. (it´s almost pictographic here!). 	 	On-Yomi: ヘイ   Kun-Yomi: ひのえ"
design	"design 	 	柄   	   	Lesson: 27   Frame: 1097   Strokes: 9   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: design, tree, wood, third class, one, ceiling, inside, person, belt 	 	Tree . . . third class. 	 	 	This is a ""design"" as in a ""pattern"", not a verb as in ""to design"". The tree grain design was too expensive for the third class airline to use for the panelling. They just painted it. 	 	On-Yomi: ヘイ   Kun-Yomi: がら、え、つか  	Examples: 柄 (え), 柄 (がら)"
meat	"meat 	 	肉   	   	Lesson: 27   Frame: 1098   Strokes: 6   —   Jouyou Grade: 2   JLPT: 4   	Constituents: meat, person, inside, belt, person, person2 	 	Let this doubling of one of the elements for ""inside"" yield the sense of ""insides"" to approach the key word, meat. The abbreviated form of this character gave us the primitive meaning of flesh or part of the body for the kanji 月. 	 	 	Here we are looking at an x-ray of a cannibal whose insides are full on people-meat. 	 	On-Yomi: ニク   Kun-Yomi: しし"
rot	"rot 	 	腐   	   	Lesson: 27   Frame: 1099   Strokes: 14   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: rot, borough, municipality, cave, adhere, sellotape, person, glue, meat, inside, belt, person, person2 	 	Municipality . . . meat. 	 	 	The rotting meat adheres to the cave walls. 	 	On-Yomi: フ   Kun-Yomi: くさ.る、-くさ.る、くさ.れる、くさ.れ、くさ.らす、くさ.す  	Examples: 腐らす (くさ.らす), 腐る (くさ.る), 腐れる (くさ.れる)"
sit	"sit 	 	座   	   	Lesson: 27   Frame: 1100   Strokes: 10   —   Jouyou Grade: 6   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: squat, sit, cave, shire, assembly line, person, soil, dirt, ground, person2 	 	Cave . . . assembly line . . . soil. 	 	 	CONGRATULATIONS YOU´RE HALFWAY THERE!!!! =). 	 	On-Yomi: ザ   Kun-Yomi: すわ.る  	Examples: 座る (すわ.る)"
graduate	"graduate 	 	卒   	   	Lesson: 27   Frame: 1102   Strokes: 8   —   Jouyou Grade: 4   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: graduate, top hat, assembly line, person, ten, needle, person2 	 	Top hat . . . assembly line . . . needle. 	 	 	Ph.D graduation for assembly line of doctors(needles) with the cap and tassel(top hat). It took them 10 years (Bachelor´s, Masters, PhD) to get there.... :-p. umbrella	"umbrella 	 	傘   	   	Lesson: 27   Frame: 1103   Strokes: 12   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: umbrella, umbrella, assembly line, person, ten, needle, person4, assembly line2 	 	Umbrella . . . two assembly lines . . . needle. 	 	 	FOUR PERSONS can fit under this UMBRELLA if they are thin as a NEEDLE. 	 	On-Yomi: サン   Kun-Yomi: かさ  	Examples: 傘 (かさ)"
monme	"monme 	 	匁   	   	Lesson: 28   Frame: 1104   Strokes: 4   —   Jouyou Grade: Names   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: monme, bound up, tucked under the arm 	 	This character obliges us once again to make use of a Japanese key word for want of an English equivalent. It refers to an old unit of weight, equal to about 3.75 grams. The word is only slightly more useful in modern Japanese than cubits and kites are in modern English. Its primitives, if you look closely, are: bound up . . . arm. 	 	 	Dude! What happened to your arm! It´s all bound up! ""Yeah man, it´s a bummer... with my arm like this I can only lift one monme!"". 	 	On-Yomi:    Kun-Yomi: もんめ、め  	Examples: 匁 (もんめ)"
by means of	"by means of 	 	以   	   	Lesson: 28   Frame: 1105   Strokes: 5   —   Jouyou Grade: 4   JLPT: 4   	Constituents: by means of, plow, drop, person 	 	Picture a person dragging a plow behind, and the drop of sweat which falls from his brow as he does his work. Think of him (or her, for that matter) making a living ""by means of the sweat of their brows."" 	 	 	A man earns his living by means of the plow. I imagine a sweating man dragging a bronze-age ""ard"" behind him as he plows his field himself, too poor to afford an ox. 	 	On-Yomi: イ   Kun-Yomi: もっ.て"
similar	"similar 	 	似   	   	Lesson: 28   Frame: 1106   Strokes: 7   —   Jouyou Grade: 5   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: becoming, similar, person, by means of, plow, drop, person 	 	Be sure to keep this key word distinct from likeness (Frame 104). Its elements: person . . . by means of. 	 	 	Mr. T finds that living by means of dragging a plow is similar to slavery. 	 	On-Yomi: ジ   Kun-Yomi: に.る、ひ.る  	Examples: 似る (に.る)"
join	"join 	 	併   	   	Lesson: 28   Frame: 1107   Strokes: 8   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: join, person, puzzle, horns, two hands 	 	The sense of the key word is one of joining things together that were previously separate. Its elements: person . . . puzzle. 	 	 	Mr. T furiously works a puzzle in an attempt to join Mensa, the high-IQ society. 	 	On-Yomi: ヘイ   Kun-Yomi: あわ.せる  	Examples: 併せる (あわ.せる)"
tile	"tile 	 	瓦   	   	Lesson: 28   Frame: 1108   Strokes: 5   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT:    	Constituents: tile, one, ceiling, cane, stick, drop, fishhook, ice 	 	Ceiling . . . plow . . . fishhook . . . a drop of. 	 	 	Horror scene: Hanging from the ceiling, a plough and fishhook dripping with blood down onto the tiled bathroom floor. 	 	On-Yomi: ガ   Kun-Yomi: かわら、ぐらむ  	Examples: 瓦 (かわら)"
flower pot	"flower pot 	 	瓶   	   	Lesson: 28   Frame: 1109   Strokes: 11   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: flower pot, puzzle, horns, two hands, tile, one, ceiling, cane, stick, drop, fishhook, ice 	 	Puzzle . . . tile. 	 	 	A flower pot that has been dropped on the floor is like a puzzle of ceramic tiles to glue together. 	 	On-Yomi: ビン   Kun-Yomi: かめ"
Shinto shrine	"Shinto shrine 	 	宮   	   	Lesson: 28   Frame: 1110   Strokes: 10   —   Jouyou Grade: 3   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: shinto shrine, house, spine, mouth, drop, mouth2 	 	Way back in lesson 2 we learned the character for spine. The two other characters in which it is used we can now learn together in this and the following frame. Here a Shinto shrine is composed of house and spine. 	 	 	This Shinto shrine is built with human spines. Have you ever seen the ossuary in Sedlec, near Kutna Hora in Czech Republic ? It is a small church entirely decorated with human bones. Do a web search for ""sedlec ossuary"", it´s quite a sight. 	 	On-Yomi: キュウ、グウ、ク、クウ   Kun-Yomi: みや  	Examples: 宮殿 (きゅうでん), 宮廷 (きゅうてい), 離宮 (りきゅう), 宮 (みや)"
occupation	"occupation 	 	営   	   	Lesson: 28   Frame: 1111   Strokes: 12   —   Jouyou Grade: 5   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: occupation, schoolhouse, owl, crown, spine, mouth, drop, mouth2 	 	Schoolhouse . . . spine. 	 	 	The schoolhouse is the backbone of a foundation that will allow you to find a good occupation. 	 	On-Yomi: エイ   Kun-Yomi: いとな.む、いとな.み  	Examples: 営む (いとな.む)"
virtuous	"virtuous 	 	善   	   	Lesson: 28   Frame: 1112   Strokes: 12   —   Jouyou Grade: 6   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: virtuous, sheep, horns, mouth 	 	Sheep . . . horns . . . mouth. Pay special attention to the writing of this character. 	 	 	Imagine a priest´s teaching: ""To achieve virtue one must first submit himself as a sheep to God´s flock, rejecting the horns of Satan and resisting the mouth of Hell. 	 	On-Yomi: ゼン   Kun-Yomi: よ.い、い.い、よ.く、よし.とする  	Examples: 善い (よ.い)"
year	"year 	 	年   	   	Lesson: 28   Frame: 1114   Strokes: 6   —   Jouyou Grade: 1   JLPT: 5   	Constituents: year, sign of the horse, sunglasses 	 	In an odd fashion, the kanji for year joins together the element for horse, on the top, and the right half of the element for sunglasses. Think of it as a horse wearing sunglasses with one of the lenses popped out. We will use this latter image again, so learn it now and save yourself the trouble later. 	 	 	A horse wears a pair of sunglasses with one lens popped out after a particularly raucous celebration to ring in the New Year. 	 	On-Yomi: ネン   Kun-Yomi: とし  	Examples: 年 (とし)"
night	"night 	 	夜   	   	Lesson: 28   Frame: 1115   Strokes: 8   —   Jouyou Grade: 2   JLPT: 4   	Constituents: night, top hat, person, walking legs, drop 	 	First of all, be sure not to confuse the connotations of night with those of evening (Frame 114) and nightbreak (Frame 30). Its elements: top hat . . . person . . . walking legs . . . drop. 	 	 	Actually, the lower-right primitive isn´t quite ""walking legs."" It´s a little more like ""evening"" with an extra stroke across it (look up the stroke order). So, it helps me to see this kanji for night as: evening plus an extra stroke representing the tuxedo tails to match the top hat which my special person is wearing out on the town... 	 	On-Yomi: ヤ   Kun-Yomi: よ、よる  	Examples: 夜 (よ), 夜 (よる)"
fluid	"fluid 	 	液   	   	Lesson: 28   Frame: 1116   Strokes: 11   —   Jouyou Grade: 5   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: fluid, water, water droplets, water pistol, night, top hat, person, walking legs, drop 	 	Water . . . night. 	 	 	A wet dream........water fluid that comes out at night.... 	 	On-Yomi: エキ   Kun-Yomi:"
hillock	"hillock 	 	塚   	   	Lesson: 28   Frame: 1117   Strokes: 12   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: hillock, soil, dirt, ground, crown, pig, sow 	 	Soil . . . crown . . . sow. Compare frame 582. 	 	 	There´s already King of the Hill. This is Queen of the Hillock. It´s Ms. Piggy sitting on top of a mound of soil in her crown. 	 	On-Yomi: チョウ   Kun-Yomi: つか、-づか  	Examples: 塚 (つか)"
cash	"cash 	 	幣   	   	Lesson: 28   Frame: 1118   Strokes: 15   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: cash, shredder, small, little, belt, taskmaster, towel 	 	Shredder . . . towel. 	 	 	A counterfeiter is using a shredder to shred a towel in order to print up some cash (he needs some rag paper) . 	 	On-Yomi: ヘイ   Kun-Yomi: ぬさ"
abuse	"abuse 	 	弊   	   	Lesson: 28   Frame: 1120   Strokes: 15   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: abuse, shredder, small, little, belt, taskmaster, two hands 	 	Shredder . . . two hands. 	 	 	The Bush administration taskmasters hid their abuse of power by shredding documents as fast as they could using both hands....　　　　　RTK2: 　ヘイ　弊害　へいがい(abuse)...　　　Pure Group:　幣1041. 	 	On-Yomi: ヘイ   Kun-Yomi:"
yell	"yell 	 	喚   	   	Lesson: 28   Frame: 1121   Strokes: 12   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: yell, mouth, bound up, four, large, St. Bernard 	 	The mouth on the left is obvious. The rest is harder. Try this: four St. Bernard dogs bound up in a bunch. Together they should supply a clear enough portrait of a yell, provided you are careful to see all four of them. Note how the final stroke of the four is supplied by the long horizontal stroke of the St .Bernard. 	 	 	Think yelp when you hear yell to help dinstinguish this from shout (1508). I think of the sounds that would come from the mouths of the 4 dogs if they were bound up together. I´m imagining lots of yelping. 	 	On-Yomi: カン   Kun-Yomi: わめ.く"
interchange	"interchange 	 	換   	   	Lesson: 28   Frame: 1122   Strokes: 12   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: interchange, finger, fingers, bound up, four, large, St. Bernard 	 	Fingers . . . four St. Bernard dogs bound up. 	 	 	After months of practice, you finally managed to teach a nice trick to your sled-pulling four bound up St. Bernard dogs: one snap of your fingers and they interchange their positions. 	 	On-Yomi: カン   Kun-Yomi: か.える、-か.える、か.わる  	Examples: 換える (か.える), 換わる (か.わる)"
dissolve	"dissolve 	 	融   	   	Lesson: 28   Frame: 1123   Strokes: 16   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: dissolve, tripod, one, ceiling, mouth, hood, human legs, street, nail, spike, insect 	 	Ceiling . . . mouth . . . hood . . . human legs . . . spike . . . insect. This is the maximum number of elements to appear in any story in the book. 	 	 	I have created the element ""old camera"" out of the left side of the kanji: from the subject´s point of view, the light is captured by one mouth (the lens). The photographer is under a big hood, we only see his legs, and he is holding a spike in his right hand, which is the shutter release. Now, at the time the photographer takes the photo, a little insect is flying near the flash. The flash is so powerful that the insect is burnt and dissolves in the air. 	 	On-Yomi: ユウ   Kun-Yomi: と.ける、と.かす"
alms	"alms 	 	施   	   	Lesson: 29   Frame: 1124   Strokes: 9   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: alms, banner, direction, compass, direction, reclining, lying down, scorpion 	 	Banner . . . scorpion. 	 	 	Under their banner, volunteers are requesting alms for scorpion sting victims. 	 	On-Yomi: シ、セ   Kun-Yomi: ほどこ.す  	Examples: 施設 (しせつ), 施政 (しせい), 実施 (じっし), 施す (ほどこ.す)"
rotation	"rotation 	 	旋   	   	Lesson: 29   Frame: 1125   Strokes: 11   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: rotation, banner, direction, compass, direction, reclining, lying down, zoo, critters 	 	A banner . . . a zoo. Hint: think of a merry-go-round. 	 	 	A merry-go-round with a big banner on top and below a veritable zoo of bakelite animals on poles in perpertual rotation accompanied by silly music. Giraffes, elephants, zebras, rhinos... 	 	On-Yomi: セン   Kun-Yomi:"
play	"play 	 	遊   	   	Lesson: 29   Frame: 1126   Strokes: 12   —   Jouyou Grade: 3   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: play, banner, direction, compass, direction, reclining, lying down, child, road 	 	Banners . . . children . . . road. 	 	 	The BANNER warns that CHILDREN PLAY on the ROAD. 	 	On-Yomi: ユウ、ユ   Kun-Yomi: あそ.ぶ、あそ.ばす  	Examples: 遊戯 (ゆうぎ), 遊離 (ゆうり), 交遊 (こうゆう), 遊ぶ (あそ.ぶ)"
trip	"trip 	 	旅   	   	Lesson: 29   Frame: 1127   Strokes: 10   —   Jouyou Grade: 3   JLPT: 4   	Constituents: trip, banner, direction, compass, direction, reclining, lying down, Carol in rags, person, rag 	 	Let the last 4 strokes, which are also the concluding strokes to the character for garment, represent a rag as its primitive meaning. We shall meet this only on one other occasion. This gives us as our elements: banner . . . rag. 	 	 	The boat starts to leave on it´s trip across the Atlantic. Underneath a huge banner that spans the width of the ship and says ""Bon Voyage"", the people wave their rags signalling a safe journey for all on board the Titanic. 	 	On-Yomi: リョ   Kun-Yomi: たび  	Examples: 旅 (たび)"
not	"not 	 	勿   	   	Lesson: 29   Frame: 1128   Strokes: 4   —   Jouyou Grade: Names   JLPT:    	Constituents: not, knot, piglet’s tail 	 	First take the primitive meaning of this character: knot. Think of it as the piglet minus its body (the horizontal stroke), that is, the curly tail that looks like a knot. As an exception, we will use the homonym to remember the abstract key word, not. 	 	 	This kanji is NOT a piglett. 	 	On-Yomi: モチ、ブツ、ボツ   Kun-Yomi: なか.れ、なし"
thing	"thing 	 	物   	   	Lesson: 29   Frame: 1129   Strokes: 8   —   Jouyou Grade: 3   JLPT: 4   	Constituents: thing, cow, knot, piglet’s tail 	 	Cow . . . knot. 	 	 	The cow´s ""thing"" is tied in a knot! ouch. 	 	On-Yomi: ブツ、モツ   Kun-Yomi: もの、もの-  	Examples: 物質 (ぶっしつ), 人物 (じんぶつ), 動物 (どうぶつ), 物 (もの)"

The sun is not an easy place to get to. 	 	On-Yomi: エキ、イ   Kun-Yomi: やさ.しい、やす.い  	Examples: 易者 (えきしゃ), 貿易 (ぼうえき), 不易 (ふえき), 易しい (やさ.しい)"

A grant is easy money. 	 	On-Yomi: シ   Kun-Yomi: たまわ.る、たま.う、たも.う  	Examples: 賜る (たまわ.る)"
urine	"urine 	 	尿   	   	Lesson: 29   Frame: 1132   Strokes: 7   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: urine, flag, water 	 	Flag . . . water. 	 	 	Animals use their urine to mark their territory. So for them, their body water works as a flag denoting their ""country"" (why bother? we all know which story you are going to pick). 	 	On-Yomi: ニョウ   Kun-Yomi:"
nun	"nun 	 	尼   	   	Lesson: 29   Frame: 1133   Strokes: 5   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: nun, flag, spoon, sitting on the ground 	 	Flag . . . spoon. mud	"mud 	 	泥   	   	Lesson: 29   Frame: 1135   Strokes: 8   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: mud, water, water droplets, water pistol, nun, flag, spoon, sitting on the ground 	 	Water . . . nun. 	 	 	TV gets weirder and weirder... Now they´re doing mud wrestling shows with nuns splashing around in the water. What will they think of next? 	 	On-Yomi: デイ、ナイ、デ、ニ   Kun-Yomi: どろ  	Examples: 泥 (どろ)"
fence	"fence 	 	塀   	   	Lesson: 29   Frame: 1136   Strokes: 12   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: fence, soil, dirt, ground, folding screen, flag, puzzle, horns, two hands 	 	Soil . . . flag . . . puzzle. 	 	 	[fence; wall; (kokuji)] A fence separates one soil from the other. On a large scale, large pieces of soils in the world have a virtual fence called nation. Picture a world map where all countries have their soil with one color, their national flag as the legend and a fence on the borders... don´t you think it looks like a giant puzzle? 	 	On-Yomi: ヘイ、ベイ   Kun-Yomi:"
footgear	"footgear 	 	履   	   	Lesson: 29   Frame: 1137   Strokes: 15   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: footgear, flag, restore, Nelson, column, going, line, fold back, double back, reclining, lying down, sun, day, walking legs 	 	Flag . . . restore. 	 	 	NOTE: The most common use is in はく, meaning to put on footgear, rather than actual footgear itself. STORY: You are asleep in camp when you are woken up with news that the FLAG has fallen to the enemy. You quickly PUT ON YOUR FOOTGEAR and run off to RESTORE the FLAG. 	 	On-Yomi: リ   Kun-Yomi: は.く  	Examples: 履く (は.く)"
roof	"roof 	 	屋   	   	Lesson: 29   Frame: 1138   Strokes: 9   —   Jouyou Grade: 3   JLPT: 4   	Constituents: roof, flag, climax, wall, one, ceiling, elbow, soil, dirt, ground 	 	Flag . . . climax. Note that this kanji has no relation to the drawing of a ""roof"" used in the primitive for house. 	 	 	Flag at the climax (highest point) of a castle roof. 	 	On-Yomi: オク   Kun-Yomi: や  	Examples: 屋 (や)"

Fingers gripping the roof as your about to fall to your death. Think of an action scene in some movie. 	 	On-Yomi: アク   Kun-Yomi: にぎ.る  	Examples: 握る (にぎ.る)"

Do not confuse with dwell (Frame 1027). 	 	 	A humongous American flag in Florida marks the place where all the old people reside. 	 	On-Yomi: キョ、コ   Kun-Yomi: い.る、-い、お.る  	Examples: 居る (い.る)"

The man set his finger firmly on the map and said ""Here is where they reside, I am certain of it"". 	 	On-Yomi: キョ   Kun-Yomi: す.える、す.わる  	Examples: 据える (す.える), 据わる (す.わる)"
