WATER always LEAKED in the spot left by the FLAG planted in the roof everytime it RAINED. Not too hard to picture a hole left in the ceiling from a flag, now leaking water. 	 	On-Yomi: ロウ   Kun-Yomi: も.る、も.れる、も.らす  	Examples: 漏らす (も.らす), 漏る (も.る), 漏れる (も.れる)"
printing	"printing 	 	刷   	   	Lesson: 29   Frame: 1150   Strokes: 8   —   Jouyou Grade: 4   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: printing, flag, towel, sword, sabre, saber 	 	Flag . . . towel . . . saber. 	 	 	We printed a japanese flag on his white towel by stabbing him with a saber while he was wearing it. 	 	On-Yomi: サツ   Kun-Yomi: す.る、-ず.り、-ずり、は.く  	Examples: 刷る (す.る)"
shaku	"shaku 	 	尺   	   	Lesson: 29   Frame: 1151   Strokes: 4   —   Jouyou Grade: 6   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: shaku, flag, stick 	 	The key word shaku has actually come into English in the word shakuhachi, the ancient Japanese flute that measured ""one shaku and eight sun"" (the ""sun"" being about an inch in length). Since the shaku is about one foot in length, this makes about 20 inches. Let the final sweeping stroke be like a tape measure added to the flag. 	  * As a primitive, this will mean the shakuhachi flute. 	 	Slang for blowjob and that´s priceless for stories...but also the character looks like the letter R which I think of as standing for RULER (12 inches) other meanings include: rule, measure, length. 	 	On-Yomi: シャク   Kun-Yomi:"
exhaust	"exhaust 	 	尽   	   	Lesson: 29   Frame: 1152   Strokes: 6   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: exhaust, shaku-hachi, flag, stick, ice 	 	Shakuhachi . . . ice. 	 	 	A women is so exhausted by her ""shakuhachi"" that see needs to ice her jaw. 	 	On-Yomi: ジン、サン   Kun-Yomi: つ.くす、-つ.くす、-づ.くし、-つ.く、-づ.く、-ず.く、つ.きる、つ.かす、さかづき、ことごと.く、つか、つき  	Examples: 尽かす (つ.かす), 尽きる (つ.きる), 尽くす (つ.くす)"
swamp	"swamp 	 	沢   	   	Lesson: 29   Frame: 1153   Strokes: 7   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: swamp, water, water droplets, water pistol, shaku-hachi, flag, stick 	 	Water . . . shakuhachi. 	 	 	You´re hiding from the enemy underwater in a swamp. To breathe, you have your shakuhachi flute poking up through the surface of the water. 	 	On-Yomi: タク   Kun-Yomi: さわ、うるお.い、うるお.す、つや  	Examples: 沢 (さわ)"
translate	"translate 	 	訳   	   	Lesson: 29   Frame: 1154   Strokes: 11   —   Jouyou Grade: 6   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: translate, say, words, keitai, mouth, shaku-hachi, flag, stick 	 	Words . . . shakuhachi. 	 	 	You cannot pretend to translate into words the melody of the shakuhachi! 	 	On-Yomi: ヤク   Kun-Yomi: わけ  	Examples: 訳 (わけ)"
choose	"choose 	 	択   	   	Lesson: 29   Frame: 1155   Strokes: 7   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: choose, finger, fingers, shaku-hachi, flag, stick 	 	Fingers . . . shakuhachi. 	 	 	Hand job or ""shakuhachi"", choose. 	 	On-Yomi: タク   Kun-Yomi: えら.ぶ"
daytime	"daytime 	 	昼   	   	Lesson: 29   Frame: 1156   Strokes: 9   —   Jouyou Grade: 2   JLPT: 4   	Constituents: daytime, shaku-hachi, flag, stick, nightbreak, sun, day, one, floor 	 	Shakuhachi . . . nightbreak. 	 	 	Roosters in Japan are very civilised, they play the shakuhachi at nightbreak to signify the beginning of daytime. 	 	On-Yomi: チュウ   Kun-Yomi: ひる  	Examples: 昼 (ひる)"
door	"door 	 	戸   	   	Lesson: 29   Frame: 1157   Strokes: 4   —   Jouyou Grade: 2   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: door, one, flag 	 	Ceiling . . . flag. 	 	 	Traditional Japanese storefront doors have several flags, known as ""noren,"" hanging down from a curtain rod in front of them. I see this as a pseudo-pictograph, and use the horizontal line across the top to represent the curtain rod, since noren don´t usually hang from the ceiling. 	 	On-Yomi: コ   Kun-Yomi: と  	Examples: 戸 (と)"
shoulder	"shoulder 	 	肩   	   	Lesson: 29   Frame: 1158   Strokes: 8   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: shoulder, door, one, ceiling, flag, moon, month, flesh, part of the body 	 	Door . . . flesh. 	 	 	The shoulder is the best part of the body to bash a door open with (Don´t ever try this. Use your foot). 	 	On-Yomi: ケン   Kun-Yomi: かた  	Examples: 肩 (かた)"
tassel	"tassel 	 	房   	   	Lesson: 29   Frame: 1159   Strokes: 8   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: tassel, door, one, ceiling, flag, compass, direction 	 	Door . . . compass. 	 	 	Explanation here: http://forum.koohii.com/viewtopic.php?pid=14684#p14684. 	 	On-Yomi: ボウ   Kun-Yomi: ふさ  	Examples: 房 (ふさ)"
fan	"fan 	 	扇   	   	Lesson: 29   Frame: 1160   Strokes: 10   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: fan, door, one, ceiling, flag, feathers, wings 	 	Door . . . wings. 	 	 	It´s insanely hot today! I´m standing in the doorway, fanning myself with feathers. 	 	On-Yomi: セン   Kun-Yomi: おうぎ  	Examples: 扇 (おうぎ)"
hearth	"hearth 	 	炉   	   	Lesson: 29   Frame: 1161   Strokes: 8   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: hearth-fire, door, one, ceiling, flag 	 	Hearth fire . . . door. 	 	 	This hearth is equipped with a fire-proof door. On the kanji you can see somewhat pictographically the fire-proof door keeping the fire behind, and nothing comes under the door primitive, where you would have expected to see another primitive. 	 	On-Yomi: ロ   Kun-Yomi: いろり"
re-	"re- 	 	戻   	   	Lesson: 29   Frame: 1162   Strokes: 7   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: re-, door, one, ceiling, flag, large, St. Bernard 	 	The key word signals a ""coming back"" or return to some place or activity. Its elements: door . . . St. Bernard dog. 	 	 	The St. Bernard dog whining at the door of his master’s house in order to re-enter / re-turn inside. 	 	On-Yomi: レイ   Kun-Yomi: もど.す、もど.る  	Examples: 戻す (もど.す), 戻る (もど.る)"
tears	"tears 	 	涙   	   	Lesson: 29   Frame: 1163   Strokes: 10   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: tears, water, water droplets, water pistol, re-, door, one, ceiling, flag, large, St. Bernard 	 	Water . . . re-. Do not confuse with cry (Frame 463). 	 	 	I see the story of Hachiko: the faithfull dog who still waited for his master to return long after he had died. Brings a tear to the eye. 	 	On-Yomi: ルイ、レイ   Kun-Yomi: なみだ  	Examples: 涙 (なみだ)"
employ	"employ 	 	雇   	   	Lesson: 29   Frame: 1164   Strokes: 12   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: employ, door, one, ceiling, flag, turkey 	 	Door . . . turkey. Be sure to keep distinct from both employee (Frame 59) and use (Frame 1065). 	 	 	Our company has no standards. We´ll employ any turkey who walks in the door. 	 	On-Yomi: コ   Kun-Yomi: やと.う  	Examples: 雇う (やと.う)"
look back	"look back 	 	顧   	   	Lesson: 29   Frame: 1165   Strokes: 21   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: look back, employ, door, one, ceiling, flag, turkey, head, page, one, ceiling, drop, shellfish, clam, oyster, eye, animal legs, eight 	 	Employ . . . head. 	 	 	I was EMPLOYED to give HEAD...when I look back, maybe that was not a wise career move. 	 	On-Yomi: コ   Kun-Yomi: かえり.みる  	Examples: 顧みる (かえり.みる)"
disclose	"disclose 	 	啓   	   	Lesson: 29   Frame: 1166   Strokes: 11   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: disclose, bouncer, door, one, ceiling, flag, taskmaster, mouth 	 	Door . . . taskmaster . . . mouth. 	 	 	Behind closed DOORS, the TASKMASTER tortures to get prisoners to open their MOUTHS and DISCLOSE information. 	 	On-Yomi: ケイ   Kun-Yomi: ひら.く、さと.す"
show	"show 	 	示   	   	Lesson: 30   Frame: 1167   Strokes: 5   —   Jouyou Grade: 5   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: show, altar, show, two, small 	 	Although the elements two and little are available for the using, it may be easier to remember this character as a picture of an altar. Something placed atop the altar is put on show for all to see. 	  * As a primitive, this kanji means altar. At the left, the abbreviated form that this element takes is made by chopping the altar in half and leaving only one dot behind to represent the right side. The new appearance of this primitive form, ネ, should be kept distinct from that for cloak, identical except for the one final short stroke. 	 	A boy made an altar, but he´s afraid to show it to God because he thinks it´s two little. 	 	On-Yomi: ジ、シ   Kun-Yomi: しめ.す  	Examples: 示威 (しい), 示談 (じだん), 指示 (しじ), 示す (しめ.す)"
salutation	"salutation 	 	礼   	   	Lesson: 30   Frame: 1168   Strokes: 5   —   Jouyou Grade: 3   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: salute, salutation, altar, fishhook 	 	This key word refers to the polite bows and ceremonious forms of salutation so important in Japanese culture. Its elements: altar . . . fishhook. 	 	 	Indy, my friend, you must be very careful! If you approach the altar and do not give the proper salutation a large fishhook will rip you away. 	 	On-Yomi: レイ、ライ   Kun-Yomi:   	Examples: 礼儀 (れいぎ), 謝礼 (しゃれい), 無礼 (ぶれい)"
auspicious	"auspicious 	 	祥   	   	Lesson: 30   Frame: 1169   Strokes: 10   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: auspicious, altar, sheep 	 	Altar . . . sheep. 	 	 	Bringing a sheep to sacrifice on the altar was a sign of an auspicious life. The poor could only afford a pigeon, the more auspicious an expensive sheep for an offering. 	 	On-Yomi: ショウ   Kun-Yomi: さいわ.い、きざ.し、よ.い、つまび.らか"
celebrate	"celebrate 	 	祝   	   	Lesson: 30   Frame: 1170   Strokes: 9   —   Jouyou Grade: 4   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: celebrate, altar, elder brother, teenager, mouth, human legs 	 	Altar . . . teenager. 	 	 	It´s a Bar Mitzvah. At the altar, the teenager is singing in his awful, mid-puberty voice. We´ll all celebrate when that part is over! 	 	On-Yomi: シュク、シュウ   Kun-Yomi: いわ.う  	Examples: 祝賀 (しゅくが), 祝日 (しゅくじつ), 慶祝 (けいしゅく), 祝う (いわ.う)"
blessing	"blessing 	 	福   	   	Lesson: 30   Frame: 1171   Strokes: 13   —   Jouyou Grade: 3   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: blessing, altar, wealth, one, ceiling, mouth, rice field, brains 	 	Altar . . . wealth. 	 	 	This recalls the selling of indulgences in the history of the Church (As an aside, Protestantism began as a protest of this practice). Basically, one gave wealth to the altar (i.e. priest) and received a blessing. If you prefer a Jewish version, think of the donation (wealth) that is expected when you´re called to the ark (altar in the kanji) to give a blessing over the torah. 	 	On-Yomi: フク   Kun-Yomi:"
welfare	"welfare 	 	祉   	   	Lesson: 30   Frame: 1172   Strokes: 8   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: welfare, altar, stop, footprint 	 	Altar . . . footprint. 	 	 	And in front of every altar, she stopped to pray for the welfare of the others. 	 	On-Yomi: シ   Kun-Yomi:"
company	"company 	 	社   	   	Lesson: 30   Frame: 1173   Strokes: 7   —   Jouyou Grade: 2   JLPT: 4   	Constituents: company, altar, soil, dirt, ground 	 	Altar . . . soil. The company referred to here is that of the modern business world. 	 	 	When you enter a Japanese company it´s like you join a cult... your workdesk becomes your altar and you worship the very soil the office is built on. 	 	On-Yomi: シャ   Kun-Yomi: やしろ  	Examples: 社 (やしろ)"
inspection	"inspection 	 	視   	   	Lesson: 30   Frame: 1174   Strokes: 11   —   Jouyou Grade: 6   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: inspection, altar, see, telescope, eye, human legs 	 	Altar . . . see. 	 	 	The beaurocracy in Japan is such that even altars need to be inspection approved. A little man with glasses comes once a year to give the altar a ""visual once over"" as he calls it (perhaps checking for unauthorised symbology?). 	 	On-Yomi: シ   Kun-Yomi: み.る"
Nara	"Nara 	 	奈   	   	Lesson: 30   Frame: 1175   Strokes: 8   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: nara, large, St. Bernard, altar, show, two, small 	 	We choose the city of Nara as the key word in this case because this kanji, frequently used in proper names, appears in Nara; and also because of Nara's famed religious monuments, which help us with the primitives: St. Bernard dog . . . altar. 	 	 	It´s beautiful place, but the dark side of Nara is that they sacrifice St. Bernards on evil altars every night after the tourists leave! 	 	On-Yomi: ナ、ナイ、ダイ   Kun-Yomi: いかん、からなし"
military officer	"military officer 	 	尉   	   	Lesson: 30   Frame: 1176   Strokes: 11   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: military officer, flag, altar, show, two, small, glue 	 	Flag . . . altar . . . glue. 	 	 	Of course it had to be the military officer´s idea to glue a national flag to the altar he´s stationed at. 	 	On-Yomi: イ、ジョウ   Kun-Yomi:"
consolation	"consolation 	 	慰   	   	Lesson: 30   Frame: 1177   Strokes: 15   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: consolation, military officer, flag, altar, show, two, small, glue, heart 	 	Military officer . . . heart. 	 	 	A military officer must offer consolation to the hearts of the families of his fallen men. 	 	On-Yomi: イ   Kun-Yomi: なぐさ.める、なぐさ.む  	Examples: 慰む (なぐさ.む), 慰める (なぐさ.める)"
goodwill	"goodwill 	 	款   	   	Lesson: 30   Frame: 1178   Strokes: 12   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: goodwill, samurai, altar, show, two, small, lack, yawn 	 	Samurai . . . altar . . . yawning. 	 	 	Samuari, altar, yawn The samurai is on the altar, preaching about goodwill. The audience just yawns however, they want to see the man fight! 	 	On-Yomi: カン   Kun-Yomi:"
prohibition	"prohibition 	 	禁   	   	Lesson: 30   Frame: 1179   Strokes: 13   —   Jouyou Grade: 5   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: prohibition, grove, tree, wood, altar, show, two, small, tree2, wood2 	 	Grove . . . altar. 	 	 	Similar to radical tyro´s story. If you live in Japan, your main exposure to this kanji is probably ""no smoking"" signs. So I imagine the government enacting a prohibition of tobacco, and burning whole groves of tobacco plants on an altar (the altar of public health, or self-righteousness, if you will). 	 	On-Yomi: キン   Kun-Yomi:"
collar	"collar 	 	襟   	   	Lesson: 30   Frame: 1180   Strokes: 18   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: collar, cloak, prohibition, grove, tree, wood, altar, show, two, small, tree2, wood2 	 	Cloak . . . prohibition. 	 	 	A collar is the part of your cloak that, if tightened too tight, will prohibit breathing. 	 	On-Yomi: キン   Kun-Yomi: えり  	Examples: 襟 (えり)"
religion	"religion 	 	宗   	   	Lesson: 30   Frame: 1181   Strokes: 8   —   Jouyou Grade: 6   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: religion, house, altar, show, two, small 	 	House . . . altar. 	 	 	I never really did figure out what religion my host family was - all I knew was that they kept an altar in their home. 	 	On-Yomi: シュウ、ソウ   Kun-Yomi: むね  	Examples: 宗教 (しゅうきょう), 宗派 (しゅうは), 改宗 (かいしゅう)"
adore	"adore 	 	崇   	   	Lesson: 30   Frame: 1182   Strokes: 11   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: adore, mountain, religion, house, altar, show, two, small 	 	Mountain . . . religion. 	 	 	In ancient Greece, it was the religion of the time to adore the gods who live on Mount Olympus. 	 	On-Yomi: スウ   Kun-Yomi: あが.める"
ritual	"ritual 	 	祭   	   	Lesson: 30   Frame: 1183   Strokes: 11   —   Jouyou Grade: 3   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: ritual, moon, month, flesh, part of the body, crotch, altar, show, two, small 	 	Flesh . . . crotch . . . altar. Note how the second element is cut short, giving a tent-like effect to the character. 	 	 	A ritual such as a circumcision: a small piece of flesh from the crotch is left on the altar. 	 	On-Yomi: サイ   Kun-Yomi: まつ.る、まつ.り、まつり  	Examples: 祭り (まつ.り), 祭る (まつ.る)"
guess	"guess 	 	察   	   	Lesson: 30   Frame: 1184   Strokes: 14   —   Jouyou Grade: 4   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: guess, house, ritual, moon, month, flesh, part of the body, crotch, altar, show, two, small 	 	""Guess"" here has the sense of a measured conjecture. Its elements: house . . . ritual. 	 	 	I have an informed guess about whose house the dark rituals are performet at. 	 	On-Yomi: サツ   Kun-Yomi:"
grate	"grate 	 	擦   	   	Lesson: 30   Frame: 1185   Strokes: 17   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: grate, finger, fingers, guess, house, ritual, moon, month, flesh, part of the body, crotch, altar, show, two, small 	 	Fingers . . . guess. 	 	 	If you mis-guess the cheese you´ll grate your fingers on the cheese-grater (happens to me all the time). 	 	On-Yomi: サツ   Kun-Yomi: す.る、す.れる、-ず.れ、こす.る、こす.れる  	Examples: 擦る (す.る), 擦れる (す.れる)"
wherefore	"wherefore 	 	由   	   	Lesson: 30   Frame: 1186   Strokes: 5   —   Jouyou Grade: 3   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: wherefore, sprout, shoot 	 	The ""wherefore"" of this kanji explains the reason or origin of a thing. It does this graphically by depicting a seed in a rice field sending up a single sprout, which is the whole why and wherefore of the seed's falling in the earth and dying. (When the flower appears, you will recall from frame 249, we have a full seedling.) 	  * As a primitive, in conformity to the explanation above, this kanji will be taken to mean shoot or sprout. 	 	Wherefore art thou, Sprouteo? (Juliet has fallen in love with a brussel sprout) (OR: A brussel sprout has fallen from Juliet´s dinner plate and rolled off). 	 	On-Yomi: ユ、ユウ、ユイ   Kun-Yomi: よし、よ.る  	Examples: 由来 (ゆらい), 経由 (けいゆ), 自由 (じゆう), 理由 (りゆう), 事由 (じゆう), 由 (よし)"
pluck	"pluck 	 	抽   	   	Lesson: 30   Frame: 1187   Strokes: 8   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: pluck, finger, fingers, sprout, shoot 	 	Fingers . . . sprout. 	 	 	[When I see the word pluck, I think eyebrows, not vegetables. So, to avoid confusing with pick (#733):] Each time this singular, long, wiry black hair starts to sprout out of my chin again, I pluck it with my fingers. 	 	On-Yomi: チュウ   Kun-Yomi: ひき-"
oil	"oil 	 	油   	   	Lesson: 30   Frame: 1188   Strokes: 8   —   Jouyou Grade: 3   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: oil, water, water droplets, water pistol, sprout, shoot 	 	Water . . . sprout. 	 	 	The liquid oil that sprouts from an oil field. 	 	On-Yomi: ユ、ユウ   Kun-Yomi: あぶら  	Examples: 油 (あぶら)"
sleeve	"sleeve 	 	袖   	   	Lesson: 30   Frame: 1189   Strokes: 10   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT:    	Constituents: sleeve, cloak, sprout, shoot 	 	Cloak . . . sprout. 	 	 	Imagine some magic cloak, that when worn, has little green sprouts appearing on the sides that grow into sleeves. 	 	On-Yomi: シュウ   Kun-Yomi: そで  	Examples: 袖 (そで)"
mid-air	"mid-air 	 	宙   	   	Lesson: 30   Frame: 1190   Strokes: 8   —   Jouyou Grade: 6   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: mid-air, house, sprout, shoot 	 	House . . . shoot. 	 	 	Jack´s beanstalk sprouted up, pushed at the roof and lifted the house so that it hangs in mid-air suspended on the SPROUT. 	 	On-Yomi: チュウ   Kun-Yomi:"
deliver	"deliver 	 	届   	   	Lesson: 30   Frame: 1191   Strokes: 8   —   Jouyou Grade: 6   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: deliver, flag, sprout, shoot 	 	Flag . . . sprout. 	 	 	In the US, when the mail is delivered, a flag sprouts up on your mailbox. (We don´t have that in Australia.). 	 	On-Yomi: カイ   Kun-Yomi: とど.ける、-とど.け、とど.く  	Examples: 届く (とど.く), 届ける (とど.ける)"
flute	"flute 	 	笛   	   	Lesson: 30   Frame: 1192   Strokes: 11   —   Jouyou Grade: 3   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: flute, bamboo, sprout, shoot 	 	Bamboo . . . sprout. 	 	 	Flute is made of bamboo sprout. 	 	On-Yomi: テキ   Kun-Yomi: ふえ  	Examples: 笛 (ふえ)"
axis	"axis 	 	軸   	   	Lesson: 30   Frame: 1193   Strokes: 12   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: axis, car, sprout, shoot 	 	Car . . . shoot. 	 	 	The Germans manufactured so many cars during World War II that it was almost as if they were sprouting from the factories of the Axis. 	 	On-Yomi: ジク   Kun-Yomi:"
armor	"armor 	 	甲   	   	Lesson: 30   Frame: 1194   Strokes: 5   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: armour, armor, roots 	 	This kanji reverses the element for sprout, giving the image of roots being sent down into the earth by a seed planted in the rice field. From there you must invent a connection to the keyword, armor. 	  * The primitive meaning is roots. Important to that word is the image of ""pushing downwards,"" as roots do. 	 	Funny.. this appeared to me as a pictograph of a samurai´s armor. Then I looked up images of the samurai armor and it is not even remotely similar. Then I realised it looks in fact like the belly of the Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles, which I somehow associated with the samurai armor because of the ""turtle samurai"" that appeared earlier. Fits me. The bit that pokes down is to protect the genitals, I guess. 	 	On-Yomi: コウ、カン、カ   Kun-Yomi: きのえ  	Examples: 甲乙 (こうおつ), 装甲車 (そうこうしゃ)"
push	"push 	 	押   	   	Lesson: 30   Frame: 1195   Strokes: 8   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: push, finger, fingers, armour, armor, roots 	 	Fingers . . . roots. Compare and contrast with pluck (Frame 1187). 	 	 	Push the roots down, instead of plucking the seedling. 	 	On-Yomi: オウ   Kun-Yomi: お.す、お.し-、お.っ-、お.さえる、おさ.える  	Examples: 押さえる (お.さえる), 押す (お.す)"
headland	"headland 	 	岬   	   	Lesson: 30   Frame: 1196   Strokes: 8   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: headland, mountain, armour, armor, roots 	 	Like the cape (Frame 164) and the promontory (Frame 840), the headland refers to a jut of land. Its elements: mountain . . . roots. 	 	 	A headland is a mountain that is firmly rooted despite being surrounded on 3 sides by water. (Just like your head is a mountain surrounded by air on 3 sides, a headland!). 	 	On-Yomi: コウ   Kun-Yomi: みさき  	Examples: 岬 (みさき)"
insert	"insert 	 	挿   	   	Lesson: 30   Frame: 1197   Strokes: 10   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: insert, finger, fingers, thousand, armour, armor, roots 	 	Fingers . . . thousand . . . roots. Observe how the writing order does not follow the elements in order, because the final stroke is used for two different elements. 	 	 	A rice farmer´s delicate fingers have inserted 1,000 rooted seedlings into his field. 	 	On-Yomi: ソウ   Kun-Yomi: さ.す、はさ.む  	Examples: 挿す (さ.す)"
speaketh	"speaketh 	 	申   	   	Lesson: 30   Frame: 1198   Strokes: 5   —   Jouyou Grade: 3   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: speaketh, monkey, sun, day, stick 	 	The olde English is used here to indicate a humble form of the third person singular of the verb ""to speak."" It is written by a tongue wagging in the mouth with a walking stick rammed through it and coming out at both ends. 	  * While this kanji has obvious affinities to the ""seed"" group, it also happens to be the zodiacal sign of the monkey (the one who speaketh no evil, among other things). We shall therefore take monkey as its primitive meaning. 	 	I imagine thomeone who can not pronounth the ""s"" and speaketh like thith becauth they have a cane in their mouth. 	 	On-Yomi: シン   Kun-Yomi: もう.す、もう.し-、さる  	Examples: 申す (もう.す)"
expand	"expand 	 	伸   	   	Lesson: 30   Frame: 1199   Strokes: 7   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: expand, person, monkey, sun, day, stick 	 	Person . . . monkey. 	 	 	Here we see Mr. T. expanding his gang with some trained fighter monkeys. 	 	On-Yomi: シン   Kun-Yomi: の.びる、の.ばす、の.べる、の.す  	Examples: 伸ばす (の.ばす), 伸びる (の.びる)"
gods	"gods 	 	神   	   	Lesson: 30   Frame: 1200   Strokes: 9   —   Jouyou Grade: 3   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: gods, altar, monkey, sun, day, stick 	 	Altar . . . monkey. 	 	 	The Gods are gathered around debating Zeus´ latest purchase for Mount Olympus. A huge and extremely kitsch gilded altar in the shape of giant ""speak no evil"" monkey. Hera decides she will never let him go shopping alone again . 	 	On-Yomi: シン、ジン   Kun-Yomi: かみ、かん-、こう-  	Examples: 神聖 (しんせい), 神経 (しんけい), 精神 (せいしん), 神 (かみ)"
search	"search 	 	捜   	   	Lesson: 30   Frame: 1201   Strokes: 10   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: search, finger, fingers, Buddha’s hand, monkey, sun, day, stick, crotch 	 	Fingers . . . monkey . . . crotch. 	 	 	The monkey searches around with his fingers for his crotch. 	 	On-Yomi: ソウ、シュ、シュウ   Kun-Yomi: さが.す  	Examples: 捜す (さが.す)"
fruit	"fruit 	 	果   	   	Lesson: 30   Frame: 1202   Strokes: 8   —   Jouyou Grade: 4   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: fruit, rice field, brains, tree, wood 	 	The final stage of the seed is reached when the plant has reached its full growth (the tree) and comes to fruition, producing fruit full of new seeds that can return to the earth and start the process all over again. The main thing to notice here is the element for brains at the top, which might prove more helpful than rice field for creating an image. The writing, however, follows the order of a sun with a tree whose trunk runs through the sun. 	 	 	If only Eve had used her brains and not taken the forbidden fruit from the tree. 	 	On-Yomi: カ   Kun-Yomi: は.たす、はた.す、-は.たす、は.てる、-は.てる、は.て  	Examples: 果たす (は.たす), 果て (は.て), 果てる (は.てる)"
confectionary	"confectionary 	 	菓   	   	Lesson: 30   Frame: 1203   Strokes: 11   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: candy, flowers, fruit, rice field, brains, tree, wood 	 	Flowers . . . fruits. 	 	 	This candy is made in the shape of a flower, each petal with the taste of a different fruit. 	 	On-Yomi: カ   Kun-Yomi:"
chapter	"chapter 	 	課   	   	Lesson: 30   Frame: 1204   Strokes: 15   —   Jouyou Grade: 4   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: chapter, say, words, keitai, mouth, fruit, rice field, brains, tree, wood 	 	Words . . . fruit. 	 	 	After I finish each chapter of RTK, I eat a piece of fruit to celebrate all the new words I´ve learned. (Thanks Misha!). 	 	On-Yomi: カ   Kun-Yomi:"
naked	"naked 	 	裸   	   	Lesson: 30   Frame: 1205   Strokes: 13   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: naked, cloak, fruit, rice field, brains, tree, wood 	 	Cloak . . . fruit. 	 	 	Here we have Adam and Eve eating of the forbidden fruit and realizing they were naked, and so clothing themselves in a cloak. 	 	On-Yomi: ラ   Kun-Yomi: はだか  	Examples: 裸 (はだか)"
ax	"ax 	 	斤   	   	Lesson: 31   Frame: 1206   Strokes: 4   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: axe 	 	This character represents a picture of an ax, the two vertical lines being the handle and the horizontal strokes of the blade. Note the writing order carefully. 	 	 	Errata: stroke order in 4th edition is wrong. Top stroke is first. 	 	On-Yomi: キン   Kun-Yomi: おの"
chop	"chop 	 	析   	   	Lesson: 31   Frame: 1207   Strokes: 8   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: chop, tree, wood, axe 	 	Tree . . . ax. 	 	 	We chop down trees with axes to analyze their rings. 	 	On-Yomi: セキ   Kun-Yomi:"
place	"place 	 	所   	   	Lesson: 31   Frame: 1208   Strokes: 8   —   Jouyou Grade: 3   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: place, door, one, ceiling, flag, axe 	 	Door . . . ax. 	 	 	You outsiders better learn your place! An axe stuck in the door when you get home is a pretty good indicator that this might not be the best place for you. 	 	On-Yomi: ショ   Kun-Yomi: ところ、-ところ、どころ、とこ  	Examples: 所 (ところ)"
pray	"pray 	 	祈   	   	Lesson: 31   Frame: 1209   Strokes: 8   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: pray, altar, axe 	 	Altar . . . ax. 	 	 	Religious freedom has not always been respected throughout history, and nobody knew how to force religion on an indigenous people like the Spanish missionaries. They posted conquistadors at either side of the altars at the local missions, and if anybody refused to pray, they would get the axe. 	 	On-Yomi: キ   Kun-Yomi: いの.る  	Examples: 祈る (いの.る)"
near	"near 	 	近   	   	Lesson: 31   Frame: 1210   Strokes: 7   —   Jouyou Grade: 2   JLPT: 4   	Constituents: near, axe, road 	 	Ax . . . road. Be careful not to confuse with draw near (Frame 204) or bystander (Frame 1090). 	 	 	The end is near. The axe-murderer is waiting for you on the road... 	 	On-Yomi: キン、コン   Kun-Yomi: ちか.い  	Examples: 近い (ちか.い)"
fold	"fold 	 	折   	   	Lesson: 31   Frame: 1211   Strokes: 7   —   Jouyou Grade: 4   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: fold, finger, fingers, axe 	 	Fingers . . . ax. Hint: make an image out of the Japanese art of ""origami"" (paper-folding). 	 	 	It´s the latest Japanese game show: Forudo! Contestants are given a sheet of paper and are told to fold it into a complex origami shape. If they´re not done in 60 seconds, a huge axe descends from the ceiling and chops their work in half. Contestants know to recoil their hands from the falling axe, but some have been so absorbed in folding, they ignore the buzzer and get their fingers chopped off. 	 	On-Yomi: セツ   Kun-Yomi: お.る、おり、お.り、-お.り、お.れる  	Examples: 折る (お.る), 折れる (お.れる), 折 (おり)"
philosophy	"philosophy 	 	哲   	   	Lesson: 31   Frame: 1212   Strokes: 10   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: philosophy, fold, finger, fingers, axe, mouth 	 	Fold . . . mouth. 	 	 	A two-hour lesson of philosophy in high school. All the students, bored to death, are folding sheets of paper into planes, love notes or whatever, while the mouth of the teacher is talking about Platon, Kierkegaard and many other notorious philosophers. 	 	On-Yomi: テツ   Kun-Yomi: さとい、あき.らか、し.る、さば.く"
departed	"departed 	 	逝   	   	Lesson: 31   Frame: 1213   Strokes: 10   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: departed, fold, finger, fingers, axe, road 	 	The connotation is of a ""dearly departed"" who has passed away. The elements: fold . . . road. 	 	 	One of the dearest of Japan´s dearly departed is Sasaki Sadako, who developed Leukemia after the bombing of Hiroshima, and became famous for folding more than a thousand paper cranes, never giving up hope. To this day, people in Hiroshima still fold origami cranes in her memory. For this character, let us imagine a parade in her honor, the entire road lined with folded cranes. 	 	On-Yomi: セイ   Kun-Yomi: ゆ.く、い.く  	Examples: 逝く (ゆ.く)"
vow	"vow 	 	誓   	   	Lesson: 31   Frame: 1214   Strokes: 14   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: vow, fold, finger, fingers, axe, say, words, keitai, mouth 	 	Fold . . . words. 	 	 	This Japanese couple wrote the vows that they had made to each other onto a piece of paper and then folded it into an origami, and put it somewhere in their appartment. To everybody else it is an origami, but to them it is also a symbol of their vows. -- ""the folded words are vows"". Note : in this story and a few others I use the image of an origami for the primitive ""fold"". 	 	On-Yomi: セイ   Kun-Yomi: ちか.う  	Examples: 誓う (ちか.う)"
temporarily	"temporarily 	 	暫   	   	Lesson: 31   Frame: 1216   Strokes: 15   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: temporarily, executioner, chop off, car, axe, sun, day 	 	Chop off . . . days. 	 	 	Your car has been savagely (see steadily) attacked by an ax. It will be some days before your car is fixed. So you are temporarily without car. 	 	On-Yomi: ザン   Kun-Yomi: しばら.く"
steadily	"steadily 	 	漸   	   	Lesson: 31   Frame: 1217   Strokes: 14   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: steadily, water, water droplets, water pistol, executioner, chop off, car, axe 	 	Water . . . chop off. 	 	 	I imagine firemen working steadily to rescue a man from a crashed car. First, they spray it with water; then, they use an axe to break through the window. 	 	On-Yomi: ゼン   Kun-Yomi: やや"
severance	"severance 	 	断   	   	Lesson: 31   Frame: 1218   Strokes: 11   —   Jouyou Grade: 5   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: severance, fishhook, rice, axe 	 	Fishhook . . . rice . . . ax. 	 	 	[Based on fuaburisu´s] A man puts some rice on a fishhook as bait, but catches a fish so strong, he needs to take out his axe and sever the line lest he be dragged into the depths. 	 	On-Yomi: ダン   Kun-Yomi: た.つ、ことわ.る、さだ.める  	Examples: 断る (ことわ.る), 断つ (た.つ)"
substance	"substance 	 	質   	   	Lesson: 31   Frame: 1219   Strokes: 15   —   Jouyou Grade: 5   JLPT: 4   	Constituents: substance, axe, shellfish, clam, oyster, eye, animal legs, eight, axe2 	 	Two axes . . . shells. 	 	 	What is this substance on this clam? I´ve already broken 2 axes on it! (Good question...質問). 	 	On-Yomi: シツ、シチ、チ   Kun-Yomi: たち、ただ.す、もと、わりふ  	Examples: 質問 (しつもん), 質実 (しつじつ), 本質 (ほんしつ), 質屋 (しちや), 人質 (ひとじち)"
reject	"reject 	 	斥   	   	Lesson: 31   Frame: 1220   Strokes: 5   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: reject, axe, drop 	 	Ax . . . a drop of. 	 	 	The kids at school used to reject me.. Made me feel really bad till I brought my axe to school. See the drop of blood on it? 	 	On-Yomi: セキ   Kun-Yomi: しりぞ.ける"
accusation	"accusation 	 	訴   	   	Lesson: 31   Frame: 1221   Strokes: 12   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: accusation, say, words, keitai, mouth, reject, axe, drop 	 	Words . . . reject. 	 	 	I strongly reject the accusation implicit in your words. 	 	On-Yomi: ソ   Kun-Yomi: うった.える  	Examples: 訴える (うった.える)"
yesterday	"yesterday 	 	昨   	   	Lesson: 31   Frame: 1222   Strokes: 9   —   Jouyou Grade: 4   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: yesterday, sun, day, saw 	 	Day . . . saw. 	 	 	One can use a simple word play to remember this character - the day that I saw before today was yesterday. 	 	On-Yomi: サク   Kun-Yomi:"
lie	"lie 	 	詐   	   	Lesson: 31   Frame: 1223   Strokes: 12   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: lie, say, words, keitai, mouth, saw 	 	The lie in this character refers to falsehoods and fibs. Its elements: words . . . saw. 	 	 	Pinnochio gets frustrated that every time he utters a word of a lie, his nose grows and he has to get the saw out again. 	 	On-Yomi: サ   Kun-Yomi: いつわ.る"
make	"make 	 	作   	   	Lesson: 31   Frame: 1224   Strokes: 7   —   Jouyou Grade: 2   JLPT: 4   	Constituents: make, person, saw 	 	Person . . . saw. 	 	 	Mr T.´s favorite magazine is Make. He loves to make things. But he´s a purist: he only uses saws, no power tools. 	 	On-Yomi: サク、サ   Kun-Yomi: つく.る、つく.り、-づく.り  	Examples: 作為 (さくい), 著作 (ちょさく), 豊作 (ほうさく), 作る (つく.る)"
snow	"snow 	 	雪   	   	Lesson: 31   Frame: 1225   Strokes: 11   —   Jouyou Grade: 2   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: snow, rain, weather, broom 	 	Rain that undergoes a change so that it can be swept aside with a broom is snow. 	 	 	SNOW isn´t all that different from RAIN, except it can be removed with a BROOM because it only forms in freezing temperatures. 	 	On-Yomi: セツ   Kun-Yomi: ゆき  	Examples: 雪 (ゆき)"
record	"record 	 	録   	   	Lesson: 31   Frame: 1226   Strokes: 16   —   Jouyou Grade: 4   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: record, metal, gold, dustpan, broom, grains of rice 	 	Metal . . . broom . . . rice. Note how the final stroke of the broom is extended slightly when an element below is attached directly to it. 	 	 	A monk won a gold metal for breaking the current record for most swept rice in one minute. 	 	On-Yomi: ロク   Kun-Yomi:"
inquire	"inquire 	 	尋   	   	Lesson: 31   Frame: 1228   Strokes: 12   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: inquire, broom, craft, mouth, glue 	 	Broom . . . craft . . . mouth . . . glue. 	 	 	The policed inquired into the erotica scandal. They tried to sweep away the evidence, but some of it stuck. (Note: katakana エロ ero in the middle of this kanji is the Japanese word for erotica.). 	 	On-Yomi: ジン   Kun-Yomi: たず.ねる、ひろ  	Examples: 尋ねる (たず.ねる)"
hurry	"hurry 	 	急   	   	Lesson: 31   Frame: 1229   Strokes: 9   —   Jouyou Grade: 3   JLPT: 4   	Constituents: hurry, bound up, broom, heart 	 	Bound up . . . broom . . . heart. 	 	 	She was always bound to a broom, her heart pounding in a hurry to finish before she was punished for being slow. 	 	On-Yomi: キュウ   Kun-Yomi: いそ.ぐ、いそ.ぎ  	Examples: 急ぐ (いそ.ぐ)"
calm	"calm 	 	穏   	   	Lesson: 31   Frame: 1230   Strokes: 16   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: calm, wheat, cereal, hideaway, claw, vulture, broom, heart 	 	Wheat . . . vulture . . . broom . . . heart. 	 	 	The farmer is calm knowing that his wheat fields are protected from vultures by his strawman with a heart (all the better to do the job properly). 	 	On-Yomi: オン   Kun-Yomi: おだ.やか  	Examples: 穏やか (おだ.やか)"
encroach	"encroach 	 	侵   	   	Lesson: 31   Frame: 1231   Strokes: 9   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: encroach, person, French maid, tickle, broom, crown, crotch 	 	Person . . . broom . . . crown . . . crotch. Gather the elements on the right into a composite image that can serve you in the next two frames. 	 	 	The parson ENCROACHES on the French maid; driven wild by her little broom, dainty tiara and sinfully short skirt showing her knickers (crotch)! 	 	On-Yomi: シン   Kun-Yomi: おか.す  	Examples: 侵す (おか.す)"
immersed	"immersed 	 	浸   	   	Lesson: 31   Frame: 1232   Strokes: 10   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: immersed, water, water droplets, water pistol, French maid, tickle, broom, crown, crotch 	 	Water . . . broom . . . crown . . . crotch. 	 	 	The French maid draws a bath for her amorous master, but slips and falls in - getting immersed. (thanks to Nukemarine for the French maid image!). 	 	On-Yomi: シン   Kun-Yomi: ひた.す、ひた.る  	Examples: 浸す (ひた.す), 浸る (ひた.る)"
lie down	"lie down 	 	寝   	   	Lesson: 31   Frame: 1233   Strokes: 13   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: lie down, house, turtle, French maid, tickle, broom, crown, crotch 	 	Do not confuse this key word with either the element for reclining or the character for prostrated (Frame 1035). Its primitive elements are: house . . . turtle . . . broom . . . crown . . . crotch. 	 	 	After work, the French maid goes home and lies down with a turtle. Turtle? Well, he´s sloooow and always hard... (thanks to Nukemarine and Wakela!). 	 	On-Yomi: シン   Kun-Yomi: ね.る、ね.かす、い.ぬ、みたまや、や.める  	Examples: 寝かす (ね.かす), 寝る (ね.る)"
lady	"lady 	 	婦   	   	Lesson: 31   Frame: 1234   Strokes: 11   —   Jouyou Grade: 5   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: lady, woman, feather duster, broom, apron, crown, towel 	 	Woman . . . broom . . . apron. 	 	 	In high society, a lady is a woman who never touches a broom or an apron. 	 	On-Yomi: フ   Kun-Yomi: よめ"
sweep	"sweep 	 	掃   	   	Lesson: 31   Frame: 1235   Strokes: 11   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: sweep, finger, fingers, feather duster, broom, apron, crown, towel 	 	Fingers . . . broom . . . apron. 	 	 	Whether I SWEEP something away with my FINGERS or my BROOM, I should always wear my APRON. 	 	On-Yomi: ソウ、シュ   Kun-Yomi: は.く  	Examples: 掃く (は.く)"
hit	"hit 	 	当   	   	Lesson: 31   Frame: 1236   Strokes: 6   —   Jouyou Grade: 2   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: hit, small, broom 	 	Little . . . broom. 	 	 	Some mothers use a small broom to hit their children when they misbehave. 	 	On-Yomi: トウ   Kun-Yomi: あ.たる、あ.たり、あ.てる、あ.て、まさ.に、まさ.にべし  	Examples: 当たる (あ.たる), 当てる (あ.てる)"
contend	"contend 	 	争   	   	Lesson: 31   Frame: 1238   Strokes: 6   —   Jouyou Grade: 4   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: contend, bound up, rake 	 	Bound up . . . rake. 	 	 	This can be seen as a Retarius, a roman gladiator. The Retiarius always fought with a net to bound up his opponents, and with a trident, which was able to pierce enemies after tying them. They were terrific contenders, so they were only paired with gladiators specially equipped to fight them. 	 	On-Yomi: ソウ   Kun-Yomi: あらそ.う、いか.でか  	Examples: 争う (あらそ.う)"
clean	"clean 	 	浄   	   	Lesson: 31   Frame: 1239   Strokes: 9   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: clean, water, water droplets, water pistol, contend, bound up, rake 	 	Water . . . contend. 	 	 	Bottled water marketers contend to make their version of tap water sound the cleanest. 	 	On-Yomi: ジョウ、セイ   Kun-Yomi: きよ.める、きよ.い"
matter	"matter 	 	事   	   	Lesson: 31   Frame: 1240   Strokes: 8   —   Jouyou Grade: 3   JLPT: 4   	Constituents: matter, one, ceiling, mouth, rake 	 	This key word here refers to abstract matters. The elements are: one . . . mouth . . . rake. Note how the rake handle reaches out the top and bottom of the character. 	 	 	I had to take one day off from work due to ´personal matters´ after stepping on a rake and having the handle snap up and smack me across the mouth. I certainly wasn´t going to tell anyone about it. 	 	On-Yomi: ジ、ズ   Kun-Yomi: こと、つか.う、つか.える  	Examples: 事物 (じぶつ), 無事 (ぶじ), 師事 (しじ), 事 (こと)"
T'ang	"T'ang 	 	唐   	   	Lesson: 31   Frame: 1241   Strokes: 10   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT:    	Constituents: T’ang, cave, rake, mouth 	 	The key word here refers of course to the T'ang Dynasty in China (and not to the name of the drink astronauts take with them into outer space, though this could be useful for the next frame). Its elements: cave . . . rake . . . mouth. 	 	 	Two archeologists are in a cave looking at Chinese artifacts from various eras. One picks up a rake and says, ""What about this – T´ang, do you think?"" The second puts the rake in his mouth and answers, ""Yes, it does tang a bit"". 	 	On-Yomi: トウ   Kun-Yomi: から  	Examples: 唐 (から)"
sugar	"sugar 	 	糖   	   	Lesson: 31   Frame: 1242   Strokes: 16   —   Jouyou Grade: 6   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: sugar, rice, T’ang, cave, rake, mouth 	 	Rice . . . T'ang. 	 	 	Sugar made from rice has a tangy flavour. 	 	On-Yomi: トウ   Kun-Yomi:"
sane	"sane 	 	康   	   	Lesson: 31   Frame: 1243   Strokes: 11   —   Jouyou Grade: 4   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: ease, sane, cave, sieve, rake, grains of rice 	 	Cave . . . sieve. 	 	 	A psychiatric hospital is located in a CAVE. To determine, which patients are sane and can be released, they are given a SIEVE and asked to empty a bathtub (the sane ones take out the plug and get the water out with ease). 	 	On-Yomi: コウ   Kun-Yomi:"
apprehend	"apprehend 	 	逮   	   	Lesson: 31   Frame: 1244   Strokes: 11   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: apprehend, sieve, rake, grains of rice, road 	 	Think of apprehending criminals. The elements are: sieve . . . road. 	 	 	Think police roadblocks. They act like road sieves, letting good people through but apprehending criminals. 	 	On-Yomi: タイ   Kun-Yomi:"
Italy	"Italy 	 	伊   	   	Lesson: 31   Frame: 1245   Strokes: 6   —   Jouyou Grade: Names   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: italy, person, mop 	 	Used chiefly in proper names, and given the sound ""i,"" this kanji can be remembered as an abbreviation of Italy, for which it is still used today in Japan. Its primitives: person . . . mop. 	 	 	The ""boot"" of Italy has gotten Europe all muddy. Who else could mop it up but Mr T? 	 	On-Yomi: イ   Kun-Yomi: かれ"
old boy	"old boy 	 	君   	   	Lesson: 31   Frame: 1246   Strokes: 7   —   Jouyou Grade: 3   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: old boy, mop, mouth 	 	The somewhat highbrow British term of address is chosen hereto represent the kanji for a form of address used towards one's juniors. It is composed of: mop . . . mouth. 	 	 	There´s a tendancy in Japan to make the younger members (kouhai) clean up after the older members (senpai) of a group, which results in a lot of grumbling and whining. ""Well old boy,"" a senpai might say, ""If you did as much work with the mop as you do with your mouth, you would have been done an hour ago"". 	 	On-Yomi: クン   Kun-Yomi: きみ、-ぎみ  	Examples: 君 (きみ)"
flock	"flock 	 	群   	   	Lesson: 31   Frame: 1247   Strokes: 13   —   Jouyou Grade: 5   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: flock, old boy, mop, mouth, sheep 	 	Old boys . . . sheep. 	 	 	Good ol´ boys are like sheep; they tend to flock together. 	 	On-Yomi: グン   Kun-Yomi: む.れる、む.れ、むら、むら.がる  	Examples: 群れ (む.れ), 群れる (む.れる)"
-proof	"-proof 	 	耐   	   	Lesson: 31   Frame: 1248   Strokes: 9   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: proof, comb, glue 	 	The key word is a suffix used to indicate ""safe from"" or ""protected against,"" as in the words rustproof, waterproof, and fireproof. It is composed of: comb . . . glue. 	 	 	[akrodha] My comb is rust-proof, water-proof, and fire-proof. But unfortunately it is not idiot-proof--and I glued it to myself. 	 	On-Yomi: タイ   Kun-Yomi: た.える  	Examples: 耐える (た.える)"
demand	"demand 	 	需   	   	Lesson: 31   Frame: 1249   Strokes: 14   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: demand, rain, weather, comb 	 	The sense of demand is best captured by thinking of the economic principle of ""supply and demand."" The primitives: rain . . . comb. 	 	 	Supply and demand is a simple concept: when it rains, the demand for combs goes up to deal with wet hair. 	 	On-Yomi: ジュ   Kun-Yomi:"
Confucian	"Confucian 	 	儒   	   	Lesson: 31   Frame: 1250   Strokes: 16   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: confucian, person, demand, rain, weather, comb 	 	Person . . . demand. 	 	 	No more Confucian jibba-jabba! I demand you tell me why it´s raining combs!"". 	 	On-Yomi: ジュ   Kun-Yomi:"
edge	"edge 	 	端   	   	Lesson: 31   Frame: 1251   Strokes: 14   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: edge, vase, stand up, pick-axe, mountain, comb 	 	Vase . . . mountain . . . comb. 	 	 	Have you ever seen those shots in movies where the hero is standing at the edge of a sheer mountain face, hair blowing in the wind? It probably wouldn´t seem so heroic if you saw him ten minutes earlier, when a crew of stylists was carefully combing his hair so it would fall perfectly. 	 	On-Yomi: タン   Kun-Yomi: はし、は、はた、-ばた、はな  	Examples: 端 (は), 端 (はし), 端 (はた)"
both	"both 	 	両   	   	Lesson: 31   Frame: 1252   Strokes: 6   —   Jouyou Grade: 3   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: both, street, nail, spike, belt, shovel 	 	Ceiling . . . belt . . .  mountain. Note that the writing order follows the order in which the primitives are given here. 	 	 	Primatives celing; belt; mountain as per Cumulative Errata. See volfy post for link. Both effective ways to commit suicide, hang your self from the celing with your belt or jump off a mountain. 	 	On-Yomi: リョウ   Kun-Yomi: てる、ふたつ"
full	"full 	 	満   	   	Lesson: 31   Frame: 1253   Strokes: 12   —   Jouyou Grade: 4   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: full, water, water droplets, water pistol, flowers, both, street, nail, spike, belt, shovel 	 	Water . . . flowers . . . both. Given the abstract nature of this last primitive, you may want to borrow the image from the previous frame. 	 	 	Add water THEN the flowers. With both the vase will be full. 	 	On-Yomi: マン、バン   Kun-Yomi: み.ちる、み.つ、み.たす  	Examples: 満たす (み.たす), 満ちる (み.ちる)"
brush-stroke	"brush-stroke 	 	画   	   	Lesson: 31   Frame: 1254   Strokes: 8   —   Jouyou Grade: 2   JLPT: 4   	Constituents: brush-stroke, one, ceiling, sprout, shoot, shovel 	 	In forming an image for the key word, it is helpful to know that this kanji is used for artistic representations (like a completed painting), and as a counter for the number of brush-strokes in a character (as, for instance, in Indexes II and III at the end of this book). Its elements are: ceiling . . . sprout . . . shovel. 	 	 	You decide one day to paint a kanji on your ceiling. Unfortunately, you don’t have a brush, so, being innovative, you use a sprout. Knowing it could be messy, you search for a drop-cloth, but can’t find one. Instead, you put a shovel down on the floor to catch any drips resulting from the BRUSH-STROKEs. 	 	On-Yomi: ガ、カク、エ、カイ   Kun-Yomi: えが.く、かく.する、かぎ.る、はかりごと、はか.る  	Examples: 画家 (がか), 図画 (ずが), 映画 (えいが)"
tooth	"tooth 	 	歯   	   	Lesson: 31   Frame: 1255   Strokes: 12   —   Jouyou Grade: 3   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: tooth, stop, footprint, bag of rice, shovel 	 	Footprint . . . rice . . . shovel. 	 	 	Stop shoveling rice into your mouth, you´ll hurt a tooth! Use chopsticks instead. 	 	On-Yomi: シ   Kun-Yomi: よわい、は、よわ.い、よわい.する  	Examples: 歯 (は)"
bend	"bend 	 	曲   	   	Lesson: 31   Frame: 1256   Strokes: 6   —   Jouyou Grade: 3   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: bend, rice field, brains, stick 	 	Picture yourself grabbing hold of the two strokes poking out the top of the kanji and wrenching them apart, thus giving the sense of bend. If you think of them as deriving from the element for brains beneath (of course, the middle stroke has been reduplicated and pulled out to where it can be grabbed hold of), you can associate the key word with bending someone's mind to your own point of view. 	 	 	It looks like the mouth of Bender the robot, from Matt Groening´s animated series ""Futurama"". Thus, I use the character Bender the robot as a primitive. 	 	On-Yomi: キョク   Kun-Yomi: ま.がる、ま.げる  	Examples: 曲がる (ま.がる), 曲げる (ま.げる)"
cadet	"cadet 	 	曹   	   	Lesson: 31   Frame: 1257   Strokes: 11   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: cadet, one, bend, sun, day 	 	This character is written in the order of its elements: one . . . bend . . . sun. 	 	 	A space cadet eager to make one bend around the sun. (a dangerous maneuver). 	 	On-Yomi: ソウ、ゾウ   Kun-Yomi: つかさ、ともがら、へや"
encounter	"encounter 	 	遭   	   	Lesson: 31   Frame: 1258   Strokes: 14   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: encounter, cadet, one, bend, sun, day, road 	 	Cadet . . . road. 	 	 	Close encounters of the third kind. The space cadet encounters aliens on the road. 	 	On-Yomi: ソウ   Kun-Yomi: あ.う、あ.わせる  	Examples: 遭う (あ.う)"
rowing	"rowing 	 	漕   	   	Lesson: 31   Frame: 1259   Strokes: 14   —   Jouyou Grade: Names   JLPT:    	Constituents: rowing, water, water droplets, water pistol, cadet, one, bend, sun, day 	 	Water . . . cadet. 	 	 	Bender the cadet (see frame 1172) is rowing, during some army exercise, and he´s very afraid of water (Bender is a robot). 	 	On-Yomi: ソウ   Kun-Yomi: こ.ぐ、はこ.ぶ"
vat	"vat 	 	槽   	   	Lesson: 31   Frame: 1260   Strokes: 15   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: vat, tree, wood, cadet, one, bend, sun, day 	 	Tree . . . cadet. 	 	 	Also as part of some army survival exercise, the cadets (including Bender see frame 1172) are sent into the woods to build a vat (for collecting water for example). 	 	On-Yomi: ソウ   Kun-Yomi: ふね"
Big Dipper	"Big Dipper 	 	斗   	   	Lesson: 31   Frame: 1261   Strokes: 4   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: big dipper, measuring cup, big dipper, The Plough, drop, ten, needle 	 	The Big Dipper here is of course the constellation of Ursa Major, of which this kanji is a sort of pictographic representation. 	  * Since we already have a primitive element for a ""dipper"" - namely, the ladle - we shall let this one stand for a measuring cup. By the way, it would make a rather large one, since the kanji is also used for a measure of about 18 liters! 	 	Since the meaning of ""big dipper"" is rather specific and the sense of measurement seems to be a more common usage, I concentrate on the primative meaning of measuring cup. This is a pictograph, with the first two strokes representing the measuring ticks on the side of the cup. 	 	On-Yomi: ト、トウ   Kun-Yomi:"
fee	"fee 	 	料   	   	Lesson: 31   Frame: 1262   Strokes: 10   —   Jouyou Grade: 4   JLPT: 4   	Constituents: fee, rice, measuring cup, big dipper, The Plough, drop, ten, needle 	 	Measuring cup . . . rice. 	 	 	When buying rice, the fee is calculated by the cup. Naturally we don´t just use any cup; it has to be a proper measuring cup. 	 	On-Yomi: リョウ   Kun-Yomi:"
department	"department 	 	科   	   	Lesson: 31   Frame: 1263   Strokes: 9   —   Jouyou Grade: 2   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: department, wheat, cereal, measuring cup, big dipper, The Plough, drop, ten, needle 	 	Think here of the faculty or department you entered in university, using the elements: measuring cup . . . wheat. 	 	 	The national DEPARTMENT of WHEATS and MEASURES. Get it? This one was hard until I came up with this. 	 	On-Yomi: カ   Kun-Yomi:"
map	"map 	 	図   	   	Lesson: 31   Frame: 1264   Strokes: 7   —   Jouyou Grade: 2   JLPT: 4   	Constituents: map, pent in, measuring cup, big dipper, The Plough, drop, ten, needle 	 	Pent in . . . Big Dipper. Hint: among the songs dating from the days of slavery that have become part of American folklore is one called ""Follow the Drinking Gourd."" It referred to the nighttime travel of runaway slaves (those pent in) who had no maps other than the stars to guide them, among them the bright and predominant Big Dipper, the ""Drinking Gourd."" 	 	 	Can´t see direct relation to Big Dipper (#1177) since its writing order is completely different. As raulir noted, it´s written as overlapping at the last stroke of ツ and the first of メ. I take it as a pictograph or treasure map. Two dots represent big trees and the cross (marking the treasure) is placed relative to them. 	 	On-Yomi: ズ、ト   Kun-Yomi: え、はか.る  	Examples: 図画 (ずが), 図表 (ずひょう), 地図 (ちず), 図る (はか.る)"
utilize	"utilize 	 	用   	   	Lesson: 31   Frame: 1265   Strokes: 5   —   Jouyou Grade: 2   JLPT: 4   	Constituents: utilize, moon, month, flesh, part of the body, walking stick 	 	Meat . . . walking stick. Be sure to keep this key word distinct from that for use (Frame 1065). The stroke order is exactly as you would expect it from the order of the primitive elements as given. 	  * As a primitive element, we shall substitute the image of a screwdriver, perhaps the most utilized of all tools around the house. 	 	To tenderize meat in an emergency wilderness situation, just utilize your walking stick! 	 	On-Yomi: ヨウ   Kun-Yomi: もち.いる  	Examples: 用いる (もち.いる)"
comfortable	"comfortable 	 	庸   	   	Lesson: 31   Frame: 1266   Strokes: 11   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: commonplace, comfortable, cave, rake, screwdriver, utilise, utilize, moon, month, flesh, part of the body, walking stick 	 	Cave . . . rake . . . screwdriver. 	 	 	To live a comfortable life, single men need only a cave for living, a rake for cleaning and a screwdriver for fixing. 	 	On-Yomi: ヨウ   Kun-Yomi:"
equip	"equip 	 	備   	   	Lesson: 31   Frame: 1267   Strokes: 12   —   Jouyou Grade: 5   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: equip, person, flowers, cliff, screwdriver, utilise, utilize, moon, month, flesh, part of the body, walking stick 	 	Person . . . flowers . . . cliff . . . screwdriver. In cases like this you can jumble up the primitive into any order that seems best for the composition of a story, provided you feel confident about the relative position that those primitives take to one another in the completed character. 	 	 	Mr. T wants to climb up and pick the flowers at the top of the cliff. He equips himself with screwdrivers to use as climbing spikes to reach the top of the cliff. Imagine a large AMMO belt full of philips screwdrivers instead of bullets. 	 	On-Yomi: ビ   Kun-Yomi: そな.える、そな.わる、つぶさ.に  	Examples: 備える (そな.える), 備わる (そな.わる)"
once upon a time	"once upon a time 	 	昔   	   	Lesson: 32   Frame: 1268   Strokes: 8   —   Jouyou Grade: 3   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: once upon a time, salad, flowers, one, floor, sun, day 	 	Salad . . . days. This is the character with which Japanese fairytales commonly begin. 	 	 	Once upon a time, the children were forced to eat their salad every day. 	 	On-Yomi: セキ、シャク   Kun-Yomi: むかし  	Examples: 昔日 (むかしにち), 昔年 (むかしねん), 昔時 (むかしとき), 昔 (むかし)"
confused	"confused 	 	錯   	   	Lesson: 32   Frame: 1269   Strokes: 16   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: confused, metal, gold, once upon a time, storyteller, salad, sun, day 	 	Metal . . . once upon a time. 	 	 	A long time ago, people of the world got confused because there were so many kinds of Metal coins. today we only have the euro. 	 	On-Yomi: サク、シャク   Kun-Yomi:"
borrow	"borrow 	 	借   	   	Lesson: 32   Frame: 1270   Strokes: 10   —   Jouyou Grade: 4   JLPT: 4   	Constituents: borrow, person, once upon a time, storyteller, salad, sun, day 	 	Person . . . once upon a time. 	 	 	Once upon a time I let Mr T borrow my salad bowl, but he won´t give it back. ""This be mine now, foo!"". 	 	On-Yomi: シャク   Kun-Yomi: か.りる  	Examples: 借りる (か.りる)"
pity	"pity 	 	惜   	   	Lesson: 32   Frame: 1271   Strokes: 11   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: pity, Freud, state of mind, once upon a time, storyteller, salad, sun, day 	 	State of mind . . . once upon a time. The sense of the key word is that of a lost opportunity or bad turn of affairs, as in the phrase ""What a pity!"" 	 	 	What a pity! My state of mind when i think of the opportunities I missed from once upon a time. 	 	On-Yomi: セキ   Kun-Yomi: お.しい、お.しむ  	Examples: 惜しい (お.しい), 惜しむ (お.しむ)"
set aside	"set aside 	 	措   	   	Lesson: 32   Frame: 1272   Strokes: 11   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: set aside, finger, fingers, once upon a time, storyteller, salad, sun, day 	 	Fingers . . . once upon a time. 	 	 	Long ago our ancestors set aside the use of fingers and began to use cutlery. (Raichu,11-7-2006) The way I remember it´s 昔 once upon a time (#1184) rather than 旧 olden times (#35) is that they began to use cutlery to eat salad. (I also think about how when you visit the Medieval Times theme park, which is set in Once upon a time, their gimmick is that you eat with your fingers.). 	 	On-Yomi: ソ   Kun-Yomi: お.く"
scatter	"scatter 	 	散   	   	Lesson: 32 &nbsp; Frame: 1273 &nbsp; Strokes: 12 &nbsp; &mdash; &nbsp; Jouyou Grade: 4 &nbsp; JLPT: 3   	Constituents: scatter, salad, moon, month, flesh, part of the body, taskmaster 	 	Salad . . . flesh . . taskmaster. 	 	 	The taskmaster is dissatisfied with the meal she´s served, and scatters the salad & meat across the floor for the servants to clean up. 	 	On-Yomi: サン &nbsp; Kun-Yomi: ち.る、ち.らす、-ち.らす、ち.らかす、ち.らかる、ばら  	Examples: 散らかす (ち.らかす), 散らかる (ち.らかる), 散らす (ち.らす), 散る (ち.る)"
twenty	"twenty 	 	廿   	   	Lesson: 32   Frame: 1274   Strokes: 4   —   Jouyou Grade: Names   JLPT:    	Constituents: twenty 	 	The two tens joined at the bottom by a short line is actually the old character for twenty, which we might as well learn since we need its primitive form. It is written the same as salad, except for the shorter final stroke. 	 	 	A generation is 30, one stroke less is twenty. 	 	On-Yomi: ジュウ、ニュウ   Kun-Yomi: にじゅう"
commoner	"commoner 	 	庶   	   	Lesson: 32   Frame: 1275   Strokes: 11   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: commoner, caverns, cave, twenty, oven-fire, barbecue 	 	Caverns . . . oven fire. 	 	 	Commoners have to huddle in caverns around a campfire, while higher class people get heating and central air conditioning in a hotel. 	 	On-Yomi: ショ   Kun-Yomi:"
intercept	"intercept 	 	遮   	   	Lesson: 32   Frame: 1276   Strokes: 14   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: intercept, commoner, caverns, cave, twenty, oven-fire, barbecue, road 	 	Commoner . . . road. 	 	 	The commoners are revolting! We must intercept them on the road before they reach the castle! 	 	On-Yomi: シャ   Kun-Yomi: さえぎ.る  	Examples: 遮る (さえぎ.る)"
seat	"seat 	 	席   	   	Lesson: 32   Frame: 1277   Strokes: 10   —   Jouyou Grade: 4   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: seat, caverns, cave, twenty, towel 	 	Caverns . . . towel. 	 	 	Remember those poor commoners huddled in groups of 20 in a cave? The only thing they had for a seat was some old toweling (while their lords could recline on luxurious couches). 	 	On-Yomi: セキ   Kun-Yomi: むしろ"
degrees	"degrees 	 	度   	   	Lesson: 32   Frame: 1278   Strokes: 9   —   Jouyou Grade: 3   JLPT: 4   	Constituents: degrees, caverns, cave, twenty, crotch 	 	This key word refers to a gradation of measurement, not to academic diplomas. Its primitives: caverns . . . crotch. 	 	 	The cavern refugees are so poor that they can´t afford thermometers. So, the menfolk expose their crotches inside the cavern, and approximate the temperature in degrees from how shrivelled everything looks downstairs... 	 	On-Yomi: ド、ト、タク   Kun-Yomi: たび、-た.い  	Examples: 度胸 (どきょう), 制度 (せいど), 限度 (げんど), 法度 (ほうど), 度 (たび)"
transit	"transit 	 	渡   	   	Lesson: 32   Frame: 1279   Strokes: 12   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: transit, water, water droplets, water pistol, degrees, caverns, cave, twenty, crotch 	 	Water . . . degrees. 	 	 	This particular form of transit is a ferry (one of the actual meanings of this character). Naturally it can only cross the water if it´s not frozen, so the temperature must be above 0 degrees. 	 	On-Yomi: ト   Kun-Yomi: わた.る、-わた.る、わた.す  	Examples: 渡す (わた.す), 渡る (わた.る)"
bustle	"bustle 	 	奔   	   	Lesson: 32   Frame: 1280   Strokes: 8   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: bustle, large, St. Bernard, haystack, ten, needle, needle3, ten3 	 	The hustle and bustle of this character is depicted by a St. Bernard dog and a haystack. 	 	 	Hustle and bustle = a big St. Bernard dog frisking about in a haystack, knocking it down and spreading the hay about, after the field hands just stacked it up. 	 	On-Yomi: ホン   Kun-Yomi: はし.る"
erupt	"erupt 	 	噴   	   	Lesson: 32   Frame: 1281   Strokes: 15   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: erupt, mouth, pitchfork, haystack, ten, needle, shellfish, clam, oyster, eye, animal legs, eight, needle3, ten3 	 	Mouth . . . haystack . . . clams. 	 	 	History of Pompei: An unexpect eruption and from the mouths of the volcano come lava that threatens the farmers collecting haystacks in the fields and the fisherman catching shells on the coast. 	 	On-Yomi: フン   Kun-Yomi: ふ.く  	Examples: 噴く (ふ.く)"
tomb	"tomb 	 	墳   	   	Lesson: 32   Frame: 1282   Strokes: 15   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: tomb, soil, dirt, ground, pitchfork, haystack, ten, needle, shellfish, clam, oyster, eye, animal legs, eight, needle3, ten3 	 	Soil . . . haystack . . . clams. In order not to confuse this kanji with that for a grave (Frame 246), something like the image of an Egyptian tomb should be adopted, with all its special connotations. 	 	 	After the eruption all is a tomb. The soil has covered the remains of the farmers gathering haystacks and of the fisherman collecting shells. 	 	On-Yomi: フン   Kun-Yomi:"
aroused	"aroused 	 	憤   	   	Lesson: 32   Frame: 1283   Strokes: 15   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: aroused, Freud, state of mind, pitchfork, haystack, ten, needle, shellfish, clam, oyster, eye, animal legs, eight, needle3, ten3 	 	State of mind . . . haystack . . . clams. 	 	 	Note: this word in Japanese has the idea of ""indignant"". So aroused here refers to being aroused because of anger over some unjust or wrong act, unfairness etc. It doesn´t seem to carry a meaning associated with arousal in the sense of sex or pleasure. So, my story: think of the angry state of mind aroused at finding all your clams buried under your haystack stolen, gone! 	 	On-Yomi: フン   Kun-Yomi: いきどお.る  	Examples: 憤る (いきどお.る)"
bake	"bake 	 	焼   	   	Lesson: 32   Frame: 1284   Strokes: 12   —   Jouyou Grade: 4   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: bake, hearth fire, lofty, strawman, wickerman, haystack, ten, needle, one, human legs, needle3, ten3 	 	Hearth . . . straw man. Take care to distinguish this kanji from cook (Frame 507) and burn (Frame 549) when you compose your story. 	 	 	Ah, there´s no better way to bake a pizza than an oven fueled by a burning strawman. And if you listen carefully, there are stifled strawman screams coming from the kitchen. Think of this image: http://users.mtrx.net/funnypics/content/-rdm1-ABCD1234-rdm1-/2005/2005-08-23-0002/Doughboy.jpg. 	 	On-Yomi: ショウ   Kun-Yomi: や.く、や.き、や.き-、-や.き、や.ける  	Examples: 焼く (や.く), 焼ける (や.ける)"
daybreak	"daybreak 	 	暁   	   	Lesson: 32   Frame: 1285   Strokes: 12   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: daybreak, sun, lofty, strawman, wickerman, haystack, ten, needle, one, human legs, needle3, ten3 	 	Sun . . . straw man. 	 	 	The sun rising beside a straw man in a corn field is a classic cartoon depiction of daybreak. 	 	On-Yomi: ギョウ、キョウ   Kun-Yomi: あかつき、さと.る  	Examples: 暁 (あかつき)"
half	"half 	 	半   	   	Lesson: 32   Frame: 1286   Strokes: 5   —   Jouyou Grade: 2   JLPT: 5   	Constituents: half, small, ten, needle 	 	Although the writing order is different, one can remember the appearance of this character by seeing it as a little needle - the kind used for splitting hairs in half. (Again, according to rule, little takes a stroke beneath it in order to be placed over an element that has no horizontal line at the top.) 	 	 	Imagine karate chopping the number three in half with a WALKING STICK and pausing the picture just as the first ""board"" breaks. 	 	On-Yomi: ハン   Kun-Yomi: なか.ば  	Examples: 半ば (なか.ば)"
consort	"consort 	 	伴   	   	Lesson: 32   Frame: 1287   Strokes: 7   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: consort, person, half 	 	Person . . . half. 	 	 	The person who is your consort is most commonly ""your other half"". 	 	On-Yomi: ハン、バン   Kun-Yomi: ともな.う  	Examples: 同伴 (どうはん), 随伴 (ずいはん), 伴う (ともな.う)"
paddy ridge	"paddy ridge 	 	畔   	   	Lesson: 32   Frame: 1288   Strokes: 10   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: paddy-ridge, rice field, brains, half 	 	Rice field . . . half. The key word here refers to the ridges that rise up between the sections of a rice paddy. 	 	 	A PADDY-RIDGE divides the RICE FIELD in HALF. 	 	On-Yomi: ハン   Kun-Yomi: あぜ、くろ、ほとり"
judgment	"judgment 	 	判   	   	Lesson: 32   Frame: 1289   Strokes: 7   —   Jouyou Grade: 5   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: judgement, half, sword, sabre, saber 	 	Half . . . saber. You might recall the famous judgment of King Solomon, who offered to slice a baby in two with a saber to give half to each of the mothers who claimed it as her own. 	 	 	In the bible, King Solomon´s JUDGMENT was admired not by saying to cut the baby in HALF with the SWORD, but that it revealed who the true mother was. 	 	On-Yomi: ハン、バン   Kun-Yomi: わか.る  	Examples: 判定 (はんてい), 判明 (はんめい), 裁判 (さいばん)"
ticket	"ticket 	 	券   	   	Lesson: 32   Frame: 1291   Strokes: 8   —   Jouyou Grade: 5   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: ticket, quarter, sword, dagger 	 	Quarter . . . dagger. 	 	 	Entering the movie, the dude asks for your ticket, so he can tear it in half. He looks at you funny when you hand him a ticket already torn in half. He quietly tears the stub into quarters after you show him your dagger with a smile. 	 	On-Yomi: ケン   Kun-Yomi:"
scroll	"scroll 	 	巻   	   	Lesson: 32   Frame: 1292   Strokes: 9   —   Jouyou Grade: 6   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: scroll, quarter, snake, self 	 	Quarter . . . snake. The key word refers to a manuscript rolled up into a scroll, not to a hanging scroll (Frame 435). 	 	 	At a mysterious bazaar, you happen to come across something interesting: a rolled-up scroll for only 25¢. You buy it up impulsively until you realize that the powerful spell contained within is cursed by a poisonous snake. If you try to cast this spell, the snake will pop out of nowhere and bite you! Hrmph. No wonder it was so cheap... 	 	On-Yomi: カン、ケン   Kun-Yomi: ま.く、まき、ま.き  	Examples: 巻き (ま.き), 巻く (ま.く)"
sphere	"sphere 	 	圏   	   	Lesson: 32   Frame: 1293   Strokes: 12   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: sphere, pent in, scroll, quarter, snake, self 	 	This key word refers to a realm or orbit, not to a ball. Its elements: pent in . . . scroll. 	 	 	I assosiate scrolls with spell casting, the efect of this spell is pent in a certain sphere of influence, outside it no damage is done. 	 	On-Yomi: ケン   Kun-Yomi: かこ.い"
victory	"victory 	 	勝   	   	Lesson: 32   Frame: 1294   Strokes: 12   —   Jouyou Grade: 3   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: victory, edam, moon, month, flesh, part of the body, quarter, power, muscle, arnold 	 	Moon . . . quarter . . . muscle. 	 	 	After your VICTORY cut your enemy´s FLESH into QUARTERs to show your POWER. 	 	On-Yomi: ショウ   Kun-Yomi: か.つ、-が.ち、まさ.る、すぐ.れる、かつ  	Examples: 勝つ (か.つ), 勝る (まさ.る)"
wisteria	"wisteria 	 	藤   	   	Lesson: 32   Frame: 1295   Strokes: 18   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: wisteria, flowers, edam, moon, month, flesh, part of the body, quarter, grains of rice 	 	Flower . . . moon . . . quarter . . . rice grains. 	 	 	According to legend, the great Ogaki wisteria tree grew and flowered from magical rice grains that were planted under the quarter moon. 	 	On-Yomi: トウ、ドウ   Kun-Yomi: ふじ  	Examples: 藤 (ふじ)"
facsimilie	"facsimilie 	 	謄   	   	Lesson: 32   Frame: 1296   Strokes: 17   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: mimeograph, facsimile, edam, moon, month, flesh, part of the body, quarter, say, words, keitai, mouth 	 	Moon . . . quarter . . . words. 	 	 	Sending a facsimile to the moon can be problematic only a quarter of the words actually get there. 	 	On-Yomi: トウ   Kun-Yomi:"
one-sided	"one-sided 	 	片   	   	Lesson: 32   Frame: 1297   Strokes: 4   —   Jouyou Grade: 6   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: one-sided, waiter with wine on tray 	 	This kanji is based on the pictograph of a tree with some branches going upwards and others hanging down, split right down the middle. When that picture's right side is isolated, it becomes the kanji for one-sided, in the sense of only one part of a whole. 	 	 	Fuaburisu´s pictograph of a man kneeling and presenting the ring to his future wife is a one-sided version of the story. Others say he was giving her the finger. 	 	On-Yomi: ヘン   Kun-Yomi: かた-、かた  	Examples: 片 (かた)"
printing block	"printing block 	 	版   	   	Lesson: 32   Frame: 1298   Strokes: 8   —   Jouyou Grade: 5   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: printing block, one-sided, waiter with wine on tray, anti-, demonstration, cliff, crotch 	 	Although this character also carries the sense of an ""edition"" of a publication, the elements, one-sided and anti-, more readily suggest its other meaning of a printing block. 	 	 	Before the advent of printers in Japan, typewriters couldn´t be built as they were in the west due to how many kanji there are. Lots of small printing blocks had to be used instead. One side of the printing block would have a mirrored (anti) image of the kanji. This is true. 	 	On-Yomi: ハン   Kun-Yomi:"
of	"of 	 	之   	   	Lesson: 32   Frame: 1299   Strokes: 3   —   Jouyou Grade: Names   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: of, Zorro, building blocks, zig-zag 	 	This character is now used chiefly in proper names, and is best learned as the character closest to the hiragana え, though in fact it has no relation to it. 	  * In order to give this kanji a more concrete meaning when it is used as a primitive element, think of it as referring to building blocks with the hiragana written on them, much the same as the A-B-C blocks you played with as a child. 	 	Of all the kanji, this is the only one 之orro can write. 	 	On-Yomi: シ   Kun-Yomi: の、これ、おいて、ゆく、この"
destitution	"destitution 	 	乏   	   	Lesson: 32   Frame: 1300   Strokes: 4   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: destitution, drop, of, Zorro, building blocks, zig-zag 	 	Drop of . . . building blocks. 	 	 	Children in complete destitution have no hope of ever getting toys to play with, so when they find even a tiny drop of a building block they are overjoyed. 	 	On-Yomi: ボウ   Kun-Yomi: とぼ.しい、とも.しい  	Examples: 乏しい (とぼ.しい)"
turf	"turf 	 	芝   	   	Lesson: 32   Frame: 1301   Strokes: 6   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: turf, flowers, of, Zorro, building blocks, zig-zag 	 	Flowers . . . building blocks. 	 	 	Artificial turf made easy: flowers stuck on top of building blocks that you can place anywhere. 	 	On-Yomi: シ   Kun-Yomi: しば  	Examples: 芝 (しば)"
negative	"negative 	 	不   	   	Lesson: 32   Frame: 1302   Strokes: 4   —   Jouyou Grade: 4   JLPT: 4   	Constituents: negative, one, ceiling, person, drop 	 	You may play with the primitives of this kanji as you wish (ceiling . . . person . . . a drop of), but you will probably find that its simplicity, and its frequency, make it easy to remember just as it is. 	 	 	[Smithsonian] Scene: Mr. T hanging from the ceiling being tortured. He is asked if he is going to talk. Spitting (a drop of saliva) in the torturer´s face, he says ""Negative"". 	 	On-Yomi: フ、ブ   Kun-Yomi:   	Examples: 不当 (ふとう), 不利 (ふり), 不賛成 (ふさんせい)"
negate	"negate 	 	否   	   	Lesson: 32   Frame: 1303   Strokes: 7   —   Jouyou Grade: 6   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: negate, negative, mouth 	 	Negative . . . mouth. 	 	 	To distinguish between 否 negate, and 不 negative (#1217): Note that negate contains 口, which is a kind of gate. 	 	On-Yomi: ヒ   Kun-Yomi: いな、いや  	Examples: 否 (いな)"
cupfuls	"cupfuls 	 	杯   	   	Lesson: 32   Frame: 1304   Strokes: 8   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: cupfuls, tree, wood, negative 	 	Tree . . . negative. 	 	 	The maple tree is very negative about it, but the farmer still collects cupfuls of maple syrup from it. 	 	On-Yomi: ハイ   Kun-Yomi: さかずき  	Examples: 杯 (さかずき)"
dart	"dart 	 	矢   	   	Lesson: 33   Frame: 1305   Strokes: 5   —   Jouyou Grade: 2   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: dart, drop, heavens 	 	When shot high into the heavens, the dart gets so small it looks like a mere drop. Although this character could as well mean ""arrow,"" it has no connection with the primitive of that meaning. Hence the new key word. 	 	 	Zeus ran out of lightning bolts and has to drop darts from the heavens. 	 	On-Yomi: シ   Kun-Yomi: や  	Examples: 矢 (や)"
rectify	"rectify 	 	矯   	   	Lesson: 33   Frame: 1306   Strokes: 17   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: rectify, dart, drop, heavens, angel, heavens, mouth, hood, mouth, mouth2 	 	Dart . . . angel. Compare your stories for correct (Frame 405), revise (Frame 362), and reformation (Frame 567). 	 	 	Angels have now been given a powerful tool to rectify human behavior instantly, without delay - they have been allowed to drop darts on those who misbehave... spare the dart and spoil the man... 	 	On-Yomi: キョウ   Kun-Yomi: た.める  	Examples: 矯める (た.める)"
tribe	"tribe 	 	族   	   	Lesson: 33   Frame: 1307   Strokes: 11   —   Jouyou Grade: 3   JLPT: 4   	Constituents: tribe, banner, direction, compass, direction, reclining, lying down, dart, drop, heavens 	 	Banner . . . dart. 	 	 	With a banner declaring ""Keep Out!"" and blow darts to back it up, the Amazon tribe is not that friendly. 	 	On-Yomi: ゾク   Kun-Yomi:"

Wisdom is knowing everything OVER the sun (fools assume everything UNDER). 	 	On-Yomi: チ   Kun-Yomi:"
halberd	"halberd 	 	矛   	   	Lesson: 33   Frame: 1311   Strokes: 5   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: halberd, beforehand 	 	The halberd's battle-ax head and long shaft are depicted here. [tender; weakness; gentleness; softness] Love me tender, Love me perfect, Never cheat on me. Or I´ll impale you on my Halberd, And hang ya atop a tree... This fog is the perfect weather for us to perform our task undetected. 	 	On-Yomi: ム、ボウ、ブ   Kun-Yomi: きり  	Examples: 霧 (きり)"
squad	"squad 	 	班   	   	Lesson: 33   Frame: 1315   Strokes: 10   —   Jouyou Grade: 6   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: squad, sword, spear, cutlass, king, jewel, ball, king2, jewel2, ball2 	 	Spear . . . two balls. 	 	 	Am I the only one who took this as penis and balls? In order to be in the man-squad, naturally you need to have two balls with your ""spear"" in the middle there. 	 	On-Yomi: ハン   Kun-Yomi:"
homecoming	"homecoming 	 	帰   	   	Lesson: 33   Frame: 1316   Strokes: 10   —   Jouyou Grade: 2   JLPT: 4   	Constituents: homecoming, sword, spear, cutlass, feather duster, broom, apron, crown, towel 	 	Spear . . . broom . . . apron. The character for lady (Frame 1234) shares the same right side as this character, which does not bode for a very happy homecoming. 	 	 	A female warrior returns home from battle. Her husband takes away her spear to symbolize the end of fighting and gives her a broom and an apron. “Boy, this is some kind of HOMECOMING,” thinks the veteran. (Adapted from johnskb). 	 	On-Yomi: キ   Kun-Yomi: かえ.る、かえ.す、おく.る、とつ.ぐ  	Examples: 帰す (かえ.す), 帰る (かえ.る)"
bow	"bow 	 	弓   	   	Lesson: 33   Frame: 1317   Strokes: 3   —   Jouyou Grade: 2   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: bow 	 	This character pictures the bent wooden bow. Later we will learn how to make the bowstring that goes with it (Frame 1490). If you stretch this character out and see the indentation on the left as its handle, the pictography should be clearer. 	 	 	My personification for this primative is Legolas from the Lord of the Rings: a master at the bow. I suppose robin hood etc would work too. 	 	On-Yomi: キュウ   Kun-Yomi: ゆみ  	Examples: 弓 (ゆみ)"
pull	"pull 	 	引   	   	Lesson: 33   Frame: 1318   Strokes: 4   —   Jouyou Grade: 2   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: pull, bow, stick 	 	Bow . . . walking stick. 	 	 	Put a walking stick in the bow and pull it back, ready to fire at the geezer. 	 	On-Yomi: イン   Kun-Yomi: ひ.く、ひ.き、ひ.き-、-び.き、ひ.ける  	Examples: 引く (ひ.く), 引ける (ひ.ける)"
condolences	"condolences 	 	弔   	   	Lesson: 33   Frame: 1319   Strokes: 4   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: condolences, bow, walking stick 	 	A bow . . . wrapped around a walking stick. 	 	 	Perhaps a pictograph of a soldier´s weapons--his sword and bow-placed ceremonially over his body before burial, while people offer their condolences.
