strong	"strong 	 	強   	   	Lesson: 33   Frame: 1321   Strokes: 11   —   Jouyou Grade: 2   JLPT: 4   	Constituents: strong, bow, elbow, insect 	 	Vast . . . insect. Note how the elbow of vast is shrunken and elevated to make room for the insect beneath. 	 	 	An insect who can fly vast distances is strong. 	 	On-Yomi: キョウ、ゴウ   Kun-Yomi: つよ.い、つよ.まる、つよ.める、し.いる、こわ.い  	Examples: 強弱 (きょうじゃく), 強要 (きょうよう), 勉強 (べんきょう), 強いる (し.いる), 強い (つよ.い), 強まる (つよ.まる), 強める (つよ.める)"
weak	"weak 	 	弱   	   	Lesson: 33   Frame: 1323   Strokes: 10   —   Jouyou Grade: 2   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: weak, bow, ice, bow2, ice2 	 	Two bows . . with ice on them. 	 	 	Two weak archers agree on a duel to the death. They constantly shoot at each other but never manage to hit their target. But what they lack in skill they make up in determination, and they keep shooting for hours, and days, and months, until it´s wintertime and their bows are coated in ice. 	 	On-Yomi: ジャク   Kun-Yomi: よわ.い、よわ.る、よわ.まる、よわ.める  	Examples: 弱い (よわ.い), 弱まる (よわ.まる), 弱める (よわ.める), 弱る (よわ.る)"
seethe	"seethe 	 	沸   	   	Lesson: 33   Frame: 1325   Strokes: 8   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: seethe, water, water droplets, water pistol, dollar, bow, stick, stick2 	 	Water . . . dollar sign. 	 	 	Re CharleyGarrett: This liquid looks like ordinary water, but it will instantly seethe when it comes in contact with counterfeit dollar bills. The inventor must be rich (and probably has dollar signs in his eyes). 	 	On-Yomi: フツ   Kun-Yomi: わ.く、わ.かす  	Examples: 沸かす (わ.かす), 沸く (わ.く)"
expense	"expense 	 	費   	   	Lesson: 33   Frame: 1326   Strokes: 12   —   Jouyou Grade: 4   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: expense, dollar, bow, stick, shellfish, clam, oyster, eye, animal legs, eight, stick2 	 	Dollar sign . . . shells/money. 	 	 	An expense is an expense, whether you put it in dollars or in local money. 	 	On-Yomi: ヒ   Kun-Yomi: つい.やす、つい.える  	Examples: 費える (つい.える), 費やす (つい.やす)"
No.	"No. 	 	第   	   	Lesson: 33   Frame: 1327   Strokes: 11   —   Jouyou Grade: 3   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: no., bamboo, dollar, bow, stick 	 	The key word No. is the abbreviation for ""number."" Its elements: bamboo . . . dollar sign. 	 	 	The No. 1 currency in the world is the dollar. But, the Asian nations are fast catching up and may in reality have already surpassed it. So, let the bamboo represent the No. 2 currencies (the yen, etc.). The reverse order (bamboo on top and the dollar on the bottom) is really a look at the future. 	 	On-Yomi: ダイ、テイ   Kun-Yomi:"
younger brother	"younger brother 	 	弟   	   	Lesson: 33   Frame: 1328   Strokes: 7   —   Jouyou Grade: 2   JLPT: 4   	Constituents: younger brother, horns, dollar, bow, stick 	 	Horns . . . dollar sign. 	 	 	Younger brothers are always more prone to mischief. Mine, you can almost see the little horns on him and the dollar signs on his eyes when he comes up with a money-making scheme. 	 	On-Yomi: テイ、ダイ、デ   Kun-Yomi: おとうと  	Examples: 弟妹 (ていまい), 義弟 (ぎてい), 子弟 (してい), 兄弟 (きょうだい), 弟 (おとうと)"
adroit	"adroit 	 	巧   	   	Lesson: 33   Frame: 1329   Strokes: 5   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: adroit, craft, snare 	 	Craft . . . snare. 	 	 	Adroit: dextrous, deft, skillful. Snare is a little generic so I´ll use BEAR TRAP, with huge teeth cartoon style that snares you around the ankle. In the crafting of a bear trap, one must be particularly adroit. Otherwise they will become the victim of their down device. 	 	On-Yomi: コウ   Kun-Yomi: たく.み、たく.む、うま.い  	Examples: 巧み (たく.み)"
nickname	"nickname 	 	号   	   	Lesson: 33   Frame: 1330   Strokes: 5   —   Jouyou Grade: 3   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: nickname, mouth, snare 	 	Mouth . . . snare. 	 	 	My nickname is ""No Lips"". Yep, I shouldn´t have put my mouth on that bear trap... 	 	On-Yomi: ゴウ   Kun-Yomi: さけ.ぶ、よびな"
decay	"decay 	 	朽   	   	Lesson: 33   Frame: 1331   Strokes: 6   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: decay, tree, wood, snare 	 	Tree . . . snare. Do not confuse with rot (Frame 1099). 	 	 	This snare isn´t terribly effective, because it´s swinging from a decaying tree. Imagine the tree as being so decayed that when an animal gets caught in the snare, its struggles cause the tree to collapse into a putrid mess. 	 	On-Yomi: キュウ   Kun-Yomi: く.ちる  	Examples: 朽ちる (く.ちる)"
boast	"boast 	 	誇   	   	Lesson: 33   Frame: 1332   Strokes: 13   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: boast, say, words, keitai, mouth, Batman, large, St. Bernard, chandelier, one, ceiling, snare 	 	Words . . . St. Bernard dog . . . ceiling . . . snare. 	 	 	The hunter´s boast: I say, it was a ""big one"", but the snare broke and it got away. (credit to many others before). 	 	On-Yomi: コ   Kun-Yomi: ほこ.る  	Examples: 誇る (ほこ.る)"
dirty	"dirty 	 	汚   	   	Lesson: 33   Frame: 1334   Strokes: 6   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: dirty, water, water droplets, water pistol, snare, one, spike, stick 	 	Water . . . two . . . snare. Note that the first two strokes for snare doubles up with the first stroke for two. 	 	 	A hunter Washes, with WATER, his TWO SNAREs, because they are dirty. 	 	On-Yomi: オ   Kun-Yomi: けが.す、けが.れる、けが.らわしい、よご.す、よご.れる、きたな.い  	Examples: 汚い (きたな.い), 汚す (けが.す), 汚らわしい (けが.らわしい), 汚れる (けが.れる), 汚す (よご.す), 汚れる (よご.れる)"
bestow	"bestow 	 	与   	   	Lesson: 33   Frame: 1335   Strokes: 3   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: bestow, slingshot, catapult, one 	 	Slingshot . . . one. Later we shall learn the character for give (Frame 2046), but even so, it is a good idea already at this point to distinguish this key word from impart (Frame 795) and grant (Frame 1131). 	 	 	David went to battle with a slingshot and it only took him one shot to slay Goliath. Partly because of this, the prophet Nathan was later instructed to bestow upon David the throne of all Israel. 	 	On-Yomi: ヨ   Kun-Yomi: あた.える、あずか.る、くみ.する、ともに  	Examples: 与える (あた.える)"
copy	"copy 	 	写   	   	Lesson: 33   Frame: 1336   Strokes: 5   —   Jouyou Grade: 3   JLPT: 4   	Constituents: copy, crown, bestow, slingshot, catapult, one 	 	Crown . . . bestow. 	 	 	A crown was bestowed to the British royalty museum, but it was only a copy. 	 	On-Yomi: シャ、ジャ   Kun-Yomi: うつ.す、うつ.る、うつ-、うつ.し  	Examples: 写す (うつ.す), 写る (うつ.る)"
somebody	"somebody 	 	身   	   	Lesson: 34   Frame: 1337   Strokes: 7   —   Jouyou Grade: 3   JLPT:    	Constituents: somebody, nose 	 	The key word somebody was chosen to convey the double meaning of this kanji: body and person. Its composition is based on the nose (which, you will recall, is also the kanji for oneself). The extension of the bottom and far right strokes of that element, together with the unusual diagonal stroke, forms the pictograph of somebody with a prominent paunch. 	 	 	Somebody was just looking for you. He had a longnose that reaches down below his mouth, and a long jaw that sticks out past his nose, and a scar across his face. (greenapple,16-3-2006) The way to remember that this is somebody rather than someone (#1256) is that the story is full of body descriptions. 	 	On-Yomi: シン   Kun-Yomi: み  	Examples: 身 (み)"
shoot	"shoot 	 	射   	   	Lesson: 34   Frame: 1338   Strokes: 10   —   Jouyou Grade: 6   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: shoot, somebody, nose, glue 	 	""I shot an arrow into the air, And it landed I know not where"" goes the poem. (The poor poet obviously loses a lot of arrows.) This kanji, however, tells us where it did land. Its elements: somebody . . . glued to. 	 	 	You SHOOT SOMEBODY with a GLUE-gun. 	 	On-Yomi: シャ   Kun-Yomi: い.る、さ.す  	Examples: 射る (い.る)"
apologize	"apologize 	 	謝   	   	Lesson: 34   Frame: 1339   Strokes: 17   —   Jouyou Grade: 5   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: apologize, say, words, keitai, mouth, shoot bang bang, somebody, nose, glue 	 	Words . . . shoot. 	 	 	Dick Cheney... 	 	On-Yomi: シャ   Kun-Yomi: あやま.る  	Examples: 謝る (あやま.る)"
old man	"old man 	 	老   	   	Lesson: 34   Frame: 1340   Strokes: 6   —   Jouyou Grade: 4   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: old man, old man, soil, dirt, ground, spoon, sitting on the ground 	 	First, do not confuse this character with venerable old man (Frame 849), which is far more rarely used. The character for an old man begins with an abbreviation of the character for somebody, the nose having been shortened into a simple crisscross of lines. But there is another, simpler way to remember it all: the soil drawn first indicates that one has come close to the age when ""dust to dust"" begins to take on a personal meaning; the diagonal walking stick for getting around; and the spoon for being spoon-fed. 	  * As a primitive, the meaning is the same, but the final two strokes are omitted so that they can be replaced with other elements. 	 	An old man, wondering what it´s like in a grave, sits in a freshly dug plot. When a gravekeeper mistakes him for dead and begins burying him with soil, the old man saves himself by flailing his walking stick in the air. 	 	On-Yomi: ロウ   Kun-Yomi: お.いる、ふ.ける  	Examples: 老いる (お.いる), 老ける (ふ.ける)"
consider	"consider 	 	考   	   	Lesson: 34   Frame: 1341   Strokes: 6   —   Jouyou Grade: 2   JLPT: 4   	Constituents: consider, old man, slingshot, catapult 	 	Old man . . . slingshot. Remember: you already have kanji for discriminating (Frame 521), deliberation (Frame 692), and think (Frame 651). 	 	 	Before shooting an old man with a slingshot, one shold carefully consider the possible consequences. 	 	On-Yomi: コウ   Kun-Yomi: かんが.える、かんが.え  	Examples: 考える (かんが.える)"
filial piety	"filial piety 	 	孝   	   	Lesson: 34   Frame: 1342   Strokes: 7   —   Jouyou Grade: 6   JLPT:    	Constituents: filial piety, old man, child 	 	Old man . . . child. 	 	 	This child has taken filial piety to the next level. He is actually carrying the old man on his shoulders. 	 	On-Yomi: コウ、キョウ   Kun-Yomi:"
teach	"teach 	 	教   	   	Lesson: 34   Frame: 1343   Strokes: 11   —   Jouyou Grade: 2   JLPT: 4   	Constituents: teach, filial piety, old man, child, taskmaster 	 	Filial piety . . . taskmaster. 	 	 	In early Japan, filial piety was the cornerstone of education, and harsh taskmasters were employed to teach it. 	 	On-Yomi: キョウ   Kun-Yomi: おし.える、おそ.わる  	Examples: 教える (おし.える), 教わる (おそ.わる)"
torture	"torture 	 	拷   	   	Lesson: 34   Frame: 1344   Strokes: 9   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: torture, finger, fingers, consider, old man, slingshot, catapult 	 	Fingers . . . consider. 	 	 	In Torture 101 class they teach you to Consider the Fingers as the first part to inflict pain to. Then you can move on to other parts (like feet, groin, head, etc. etc. ; ) ). 	 	On-Yomi: ゴウ   Kun-Yomi:"
someone	"someone 	 	者   	   	Lesson: 34   Frame: 1345   Strokes: 8   —   Jouyou Grade: 3   JLPT: 4   	Constituents: someone, puppet, sooty, old man, sun, day 	 	Old man . . . sun. This key word looks to be difficult because of its proximity to somebody. In fact, it is a very common kanji that will cause you no difficulty at all. Its meaning should be seen as the human referent for the abstract noun ""something."" 	  * As a primitive it means a puppet-on-a-string. 	 	I find the best way of memorizing this kanji is in conjunction with the Japanese compound for ninja: 忍者 -- i.e. someone who endures (see FRAME 597 for the kanji 忍). A 忍者 is not just a 身 (somebody), it´s 者 who can 忍 great 拷! 	 	On-Yomi: シャ   Kun-Yomi: もの  	Examples: 者 (もの)"
boil	"boil 	 	煮   	   	Lesson: 34   Frame: 1346   Strokes: 12   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: boil, someone, puppet, sooty, old man, sun, day, oven-fire, barbecue 	 	Puppet . . . oven fire. 	 	 	I had a hard time with the next several frame numbers trying to use ""puppet."" So i thought of ""voodoo doll"" but then found ""love doll"" (which is just a special type of puppet) fit well with these 8 frames. Observe: Here I am boiling my love doll over the flames to warm her up a bit... 	 	On-Yomi: シャ   Kun-Yomi: に.る、-に、に.える、に.やす  	Examples: 煮える (に.える), 煮やす (に.やす), 煮る (に.る)"
renowned	"renowned 	 	著   	   	Lesson: 34   Frame: 1347   Strokes: 11   —   Jouyou Grade: 6   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: renowned, flowers, someone, puppet, sooty, old man, sun, day 	 	Flowers . . . puppet. 	 	 	Here I am, putting a wreath of flowers on my love doll´s head and pretending she is someone of great renowned. 	 	On-Yomi: チョ、チャク   Kun-Yomi: あらわ.す、いちじる.しい  	Examples: 著す (あらわ.す), 著しい (いちじる.しい)"

Before giving your SIGNATURE to accept the LOVEDOLL, you should EYE over the LOVEDOLL for any damages, then give your SIGNATURE. 	 	On-Yomi: ショ   Kun-Yomi:"

Its elements are: water . . . puppet. 	 	 	I was stranded on a desert island surrounded by water for hundreds of miles on end. I wasn´t upset though - I had my love doll! What a great strand of sand to be stranded on - just me and my love doll! 	 	On-Yomi: ショ   Kun-Yomi: なぎさ"

A pack of wild dogs, waiting in a very cramped waiting room, to get their hair cut by Edward Scissors Hands, who is very popular. sandwiched	"sandwiched 	 	挟   	   	Lesson: 34   Frame: 1357   Strokes: 9   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: sandwiched, finger, fingers, scissors, husband, horns 	 	Fingers . . . scissors. Do not confuse with the kanji for pinch (Frame 709). 	 	 	挟まる 【はさまる】 (v5r,vi) to get between; to be caught in; (P) Story: You know how in tokyo there are those really packed trains where train staff in gloves shove people in? Well imagine being sandwiched in so tight, that when the doors close, only your FINGERS are sticking out. The train staff have no choice... they must cut them off with SCISSORS =( snip snip.. 	 	On-Yomi: キョウ、ショウ   Kun-Yomi: はさ.む、はさ.まる、わきばさ.む、さしはさ.む  	Examples: 挟まる (はさ.まる), 挟む (はさ.む)"

A maestro in a large auditorium with high ceilings is conducting his orchestra of expert musicians at a fever-pitch, sweat pouring out of him. When the piece is over he reaches for his towel to wipe his brow. 	 	On-Yomi: シ、ス   Kun-Yomi: もろもろ、なら.う"

bureaucrat	"bureaucrat 	 	官   	   	Lesson: 34   Frame: 1363   Strokes: 8   —   Jouyou Grade: 4   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: bureaucrat, house, maestro without baton 	 	By replacing the maestro's baton (the drop) with the roof of a house, we have his equivalent in the institutional world of big government: the bureaucrat. 	 	 	No one likes classical music anymore. Our Maestro is here at home without his baton sighing sadly before he heads off for another day as his new job as a bureaucrat. 	 	On-Yomi: カン   Kun-Yomi:"

The maestro at home was sick of being a bureaucrat, so he got some wood and built himself a coffin and got in. 	 	On-Yomi: カン   Kun-Yomi:"

father	"father 	 	父   	   	Lesson: 34   Frame: 1366   Strokes: 4   —   Jouyou Grade: 2   JLPT: 5   	Constituents: father 	 	The kindness and hard work of the ideal father is seen in this abbreviation of the taskmaster that leaves off his rod or whip (the first stroke) and replaces it with the sweat of the father's brow (the two drops at the top). 	 	 	Luke, I am your father. Darth Vader (really surprised nobody put this one up before: 2 laserswords). 	 	On-Yomi: フ   Kun-Yomi: ちち  	Examples: 父 (ちち)"
mingle	"mingle 	 	交   	   	Lesson: 34   Frame: 1368   Strokes: 6   —   Jouyou Grade: 2   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: mingle, top hat, father 	 	Top hat . . . father. 	 	 	Even though your FATHER is an old man, he can´t give up his party lifestyle. Once a week he still dons his cool TOP HAT (well, it was cool 40 years ago) and goes out on the town to MINGLE with the ladies. This is a pretty common thing in Japan, where old motherfuckers still think they can pick up 19 year old girls. 	 	On-Yomi: コウ   Kun-Yomi: まじ.わる、まじ.える、ま.じる、まじ.る、ま.ざる、ま.ぜる、-か.う、か.わす、かわ.す、こもごも  	Examples: 交う (か.う), 交わす (か.わす), 交ざる (ま.ざる), 交じる (ま.じる), 交ぜる (ま.ぜる), 交える (まじ.える), 交わる (まじ.わる)"

Note the distinct connotations that separate merit from achievement (Frame 927). 	 	 	Mingling with the powerful can bring you success, bypassing the need for any merit. 	 	On-Yomi: コウ   Kun-Yomi: き.く、ききめ、なら.う  	Examples: 効く (き.く)"
contrast	"contrast 	 	較   	   	Lesson: 34   Frame: 1370   Strokes: 13   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: contrast, car, mingle, top hat, father 	 	Cars . . . mingle. 	 	 	The people I had invited to the party were mingling quite well with one another, until they all suddenly started talking about the cars they own. Pretty soon the crowd divided itself into distinct, contrasting crowds: rich snobs with fancy cars, soccer moms with minivans, and hippies with bicycles. 	 	On-Yomi: カク、コウ   Kun-Yomi: くら.べる"

With the exam scores posted on a TREE, the students MINGLED around looking at the results. test. 試. 	 	On-Yomi: コウ、キョウ   Kun-Yomi:"
leg	"leg 	 	足   	   	Lesson: 34   Frame: 1372   Strokes: 7   —   Jouyou Grade: 1   JLPT: 4   	Constituents: leg, mouth, mending, mend 	 	Mouth . . . mending. Note that the last stroke of mouth and the first of mending overlap. 	  * As a primitive on the left, it is amended to something similar to correct in place of mending. Its meaning remains leg, but should be thought of as a wooden leg in order to avoid confusion with other similar elements, namely human legs, animal legs, and walking legs. 	 	Captain Ahab lost his leg to the great white whale´s mouth and had to mend it with a peg leg. 	 	On-Yomi: ソク   Kun-Yomi: あし、た.りる、た.る、た.す  	Examples: 足 (あし), 足す (た.す), 足りる (た.りる), 足る (た.る)"

Mr T, ever the optimist, is trying to stimulate Capt Ahab´s wooden leg by rubbing it down. Capt Ahab normally wouldn´t let anyone do that, but he appreciates Mr T´s stimulating conversation. 	 	On-Yomi: ソク   Kun-Yomi: うなが.す  	Examples: 促す (うなが.す)"

Well, there are weekdays weekday (#576) and there are laundry days laundry (#577), and on February 29th leap day, the manufacturer recommends servicing or replacing your peg leg because they tend to wear out every 4 years. step	"step 	 	踏   	   	Lesson: 34   Frame: 1381   Strokes: 15   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: step, wooden leg, mouth, stop, footprint, wednesday, boots, water, sun, day 	 	The meaning of this character is virtually identical with that of the last frame. Be sure to come up with distinct connotations suggested by phrases in which each is commonly used. Wooden leg . . . water . . . sun. 	 	 	You have to watch your step when moving your leg on a watery day. 	 	On-Yomi: トウ   Kun-Yomi: ふ.む、ふ.まえる  	Examples: 踏まえる (ふ.まえる), 踏む (ふ.む)"
skeleton	"skeleton 	 	骨   	   	Lesson: 34   Frame: 1383   Strokes: 10   —   Jouyou Grade: 6   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: skeleton, joint, moon, month, flesh, part of the body 	 	This kanji and primitive refers to the part of the body composed of the bones and their joints. The top part of the kanji, terminating in the element for crown, is a pictograph of a bone joint. I leave it to you to put the pieces together, so to speak. 	 	 	Your body meat is attached to the bone joints of your skeleton. 	 	On-Yomi: コツ   Kun-Yomi: ほね  	Examples: 骨 (ほね)"
slippery	"slippery 	 	滑   	   	Lesson: 34   Frame: 1384   Strokes: 13   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: slippery, water, water droplets, water pistol, skeleton, joint, moon, month, flesh, part of the body 	 	Water . . . skeleton. 	 	 	Don´t give water to a skeleton. When he drinks it, it´ll sluice right through his bones, forcing you to put one of those ""Caution - Slippery Floor"" signs up on the resultant puddle. 	 	On-Yomi: カツ、コツ   Kun-Yomi: すべ.る、なめ.らか  	Examples: 滑る (すべ.る), 滑らか (なめ.らか)"
marrow	"marrow 	 	髄   	   	Lesson: 34   Frame: 1385   Strokes: 19   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: marrow, skeleton, joint, moon, month, flesh, part of the body, highwayman, possess, by one’s side, road, moon2, month2, flesh2, part of the body2 	 	Skeleton . . . possess . . . road. 	 	 	A skeleton is shuffling along the shoulder of the road, so you pull up next to him and ask where he is going. He says he´s going to donate his marrow to the hospital because he got into some financial trouble and lost everything; his marrow is the only thing he still possesses. 	 	On-Yomi: ズイ   Kun-Yomi:"
calamity	"calamity 	 	禍   	   	Lesson: 34   Frame: 1386   Strokes: 13   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: calamity, altar, jawbone, joint, hood, mouth 	 	Altar . . . jawbone. 	 	 	Continued from auspicious (#1088). Once a year, the people pray for a sign from the gods. But if the gods are feeling particularly mischievous, they´ll send down a jawbone to the altar. The people see this as a sign of calamity to come. The gods think of it as an amusing prank. 	 	On-Yomi: カ   Kun-Yomi: わざわい"

Grampa´s flushing the toilet, when his denture (Jawbone) pops out and gets sucked down the whirlpool! 	 	On-Yomi: カ   Kun-Yomi: うず  	Examples: 渦 (うず)"
overdo	"overdo 	 	過   	   	Lesson: 34   Frame: 1389   Strokes: 12   —   Jouyou Grade: 5   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: overdo, jawbone, joint, hood, mouth, road 	 	Jawbone . . . road. 	 	 	Jaws XII~! Jaws strikes the highway! Man, they´re really overdoing it now. 	 	On-Yomi: カ   Kun-Yomi: す.ぎる、-す.ぎる、-す.ぎ、す.ごす、あやま.つ、あやま.ち、よ.ぎる  	Examples: 過ち (あやま.ち), 過つ (あやま.つ), 過ぎる (す.ぎる), 過ごす (す.ごす)"
Heights	"Heights 	 	阪   	   	Lesson: 35   Frame: 1390   Strokes: 7   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT:    	Constituents: heights, pinnacle, parthenon, acropolis, anti-, demonstration, cliff, crotch 	 	This character is used for proper names, much as the English word ""Heights"" is. Its primitives: pinnacle . . . anti-. 	 	 	If you´re scared of Heights, you don´t want to stay at The Pinnacle; you are anti- The Pinnacle. Primitive: The Pinnacle is a dream-like gated community at the top of a mount. This allows for innumerable stories for all the kanji with this primitive since you have a whole city to work with. Also prevents confusion with ""mountain"". 	 	On-Yomi: ハン   Kun-Yomi: さか  	Examples: 阪 (さか)"
Africa	"Africa 	 	阿   	   	Lesson: 35   Frame: 1391   Strokes: 8   —   Jouyou Grade: Names   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: africa, pinnacle, parthenon, acropolis, can, mouth, street, nail, spike 	 	This kanji, an abbreviation for Africa, is now used chiefly for its sound, ""a,"" not unlike the kanji for Italy and the sound ""i"" that we met earlier (Frame 1245). Its composite elements are: pinnacles . . . can. 	 	 	Can you see Africa from The Pinnacle? I can! I can! 	 	On-Yomi: ア、オ   Kun-Yomi: おもね.る"
occasion	"occasion 	 	際   	   	Lesson: 35   Frame: 1392   Strokes: 14   —   Jouyou Grade: 5   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: occasion, pinnacle, parthenon, acropolis, ritual, moon, month, flesh, part of the body, crotch, altar, show, two, small 	 	Pinnacle . . . ritual. 	 	 	Many rituals are practiced every day (blessing before meals, evening prayer, etc.) Only the peak rituals (wedding, Bar Mitzvah, etc.) qualify to be called an occasion. 	 	On-Yomi: サイ   Kun-Yomi: きわ、-ぎわ  	Examples: 際 (きわ)"
hinder	"hinder 	 	障   	   	Lesson: 35   Frame: 1393   Strokes: 14   —   Jouyou Grade: 6   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: hinder, pinnacle, parthenon, acropolis, badge, vase, stand up, sunflower, early, sun, day, ten, needle 	 	Pinnacle . . . badge. 	 	 	The officer at the gate to The Pinnacle with a giant badge sewn to his chest hinders all visitors. But not the handicapped. They´re hindered enough already. They´re given a badge and can pass right into The Pinnacle. 	 	On-Yomi: ショウ   Kun-Yomi: さわ.る  	Examples: 障る (さわ.る)"
follow	"follow 	 	随   	   	Lesson: 35   Frame: 1395   Strokes: 12   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: follow, pinnacle, parthenon, acropolis, highwayman, possess, by one’s side, moon, month, flesh, part of the body, road 	 	Pinnacle . . . possess . . . road. 	 	 	[Image: Follow the ´Yellow-Brick Road´ to success] The pinnacle signifies your personal goal and destination. What you´re seeking to possess lies at the end of the yellow-brick road. You must follow the road to get what you want. 	 	On-Yomi: ズイ   Kun-Yomi: まにまに、したが.う"
auxiliary	"auxiliary 	 	陪   	   	Lesson: 35   Frame: 1396   Strokes: 11   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: obeisance, auxiliary, pinnacle, parthenon, acropolis, muzzle, vase, stand up, mouth 	 	Pinnacle . . . muzzle. 	 	 	In case of emergency, The Pinnacle has auxiliary guard dogs, but they keep them muzzeled until they´re needed. 	 	On-Yomi: バイ   Kun-Yomi:"
sunshine	"sunshine 	 	陽   	   	Lesson: 35   Frame: 1397   Strokes: 12   —   Jouyou Grade: 3   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: sunshine, pinnacle, parthenon, acropolis, piggy bank, sun, day, piglets 	 	Different from the primitive for sun (which figures in the character) and the kanji for ray (Frame 125), the key word sunshine is meant to convey the meaning of the masculine principle in nature, or ""Yang."" (The dark is viewed mythically as the feminine principle; see frame 1718.) From there it comes to mean sun also. The elements are: pinnacle . . . piggy bank. 	 	 	A kid is perched on a pinnacle with his piggy bank. He uses the coins to catch the sunshine, and redirect it into people´s eyes, far below. 	 	On-Yomi: ヨウ   Kun-Yomi: ひ"
line up	"line up 	 	陳   	   	Lesson: 35   Frame: 1398   Strokes: 11   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: exhibit, line up, pinnacle, parthenon, acropolis, east, tree, wood, sun, day 	 	Pinnacle . . . east. 	 	 	Every morning at The Pinnacle, the residents line upon the East side for morning stretches and leisure. 	 	On-Yomi: チン   Kun-Yomi: ひ.ねる"
ward off	"ward off 	 	防   	   	Lesson: 35   Frame: 1399   Strokes: 7   —   Jouyou Grade: 5   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: ward off, pinnacle, parthenon, acropolis, compass, direction 	 	Pinnacle . . . compass. 	 	 	A giant compass is The Pinnacle´s self-defense system. It points in the direction of any invaders so the city is prepared well ahead to ward off the intruders. 	 	On-Yomi: ボウ   Kun-Yomi: ふせ.ぐ  	Examples: 防ぐ (ふせ.ぐ)"
affixed	"affixed 	 	附   	   	Lesson: 35   Frame: 1400   Strokes: 8   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: affixed, pinnacle, parthenon, acropolis, adhere, sellotape, person, glue 	 	Pinnacle . . . adhere. 	 	 	A sign was AFFIXED on the PINNACLE of the Acropolis so that tourists would ADHERE to the rules. 	 	On-Yomi: フ   Kun-Yomi: つ.ける、つ.く"
Inst.	"Inst. 	 	院   	   	Lesson: 35   Frame: 1401   Strokes: 10   —   Jouyou Grade: 3   JLPT: 4   	Constituents: Inst., pinnacle, parthenon, acropolis, perfect, house, beginnings, two, human legs 	 	This key word, the abbreviation for Institution, represents the use of that word as a suffix affixed to certain buildings and organizations. Its primitive elements: pinnacle . . . perfect. 	 	 	The Institution of The Pinnacle is perfect in every way. It is the new House of God, his chosen city. 	 	On-Yomi: イン   Kun-Yomi:"
camp	"camp 	 	陣   	   	Lesson: 35   Frame: 1402   Strokes: 10   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: camp, pinnacle, parthenon, acropolis, car 	 	Pinnacle . . . car. 	 	 	Paparazzi make camp outside of The Pinnacle in their cars, waiting for the celebs to come out. 	 	On-Yomi: ジン   Kun-Yomi:"
regiment	"regiment 	 	隊   	   	Lesson: 35   Frame: 1403   Strokes: 12   —   Jouyou Grade: 4   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: regiment, pinnacle, parthenon, acropolis, animal horns, sow, pig, wart hog, regimental mascot 	 	Pinnacle . . . animal horns . . . sow. 	 	 	Every regiment of The Pinnacle´s army is lead by a Miss Piggy with a viking helmet on. 	 	On-Yomi: タイ   Kun-Yomi:"
crash	"crash 	 	墜   	   	Lesson: 35   Frame: 1404   Strokes: 15   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: crash, regiment, pinnacle, parthenon, acropolis, animal horns, sow, pig, wart hog, regimental mascot, soil, dirt, ground 	 	Regiment . . . ground. 	 	 	One of the members of our air force regiment has been shot down; he managed to safely eject, but his plane crashed into the ground. 	 	On-Yomi: ツイ   Kun-Yomi: お.ちる、お.つ"
descend	"descend 	 	降   	   	Lesson: 35   Frame: 1405   Strokes: 10   —   Jouyou Grade: 6   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: descend, pinnacle, parthenon, acropolis, walking legs, sunglasses with one lens missing, monocle 	 	Pinnacle . . . walking legs . . . sunglasses with a lens popped out. Distinguish from fall (Frame 320) and crash, which we considered in the previous frame. 	 	 	Sunglasses-missing-one-lens is obviously the monocle. The proper, high-class way to descend The Pinnacle is wearing a monocle with your walking legs splayed to a full gentlemanly stride. 	 	On-Yomi: コウ、ゴ   Kun-Yomi: お.りる、お.ろす、ふ.る、ふ.り、くだ.る、くだ.す  	Examples: 降りる (お.りる), 降ろす (お.ろす), 降る (ふ.る)"
story	"story 	 	階   	   	Lesson: 35   Frame: 1406   Strokes: 12   —   Jouyou Grade: 3   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: storey, pinnacle, parthenon, acropolis, all, compare, spoon, sitting on the ground, white, dove, spoon2, sitting on the ground2 	 	The story of this character refers to floors in a building. The elements: pinnacle . . . all. 	 	 	All buildings of The Pinnacle are multi-storey. They don´t have much room, so they have to build up. It sucks when someone presses all the buttons on the elevator! You have to stop at each storey! 	 	On-Yomi: カイ   Kun-Yomi: きざはし"
highness	"highness 	 	陛   	   	Lesson: 35   Frame: 1407   Strokes: 10   —   Jouyou Grade: 6   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: highness, pinnacle, parthenon, acropolis, compare, spoon, sitting on the ground, soil, dirt, ground, spoon2, sitting on the ground2 	 	This key word indicates a title of address to royalty. Its elements: pinnacle . . . compare . . . ground. 	 	 	Your highness is the pinnacle of finesse compared to all of us commoners who are but like dirt on the ground. 	 	On-Yomi: ヘイ   Kun-Yomi:"
neighboring	"neighboring 	 	隣   	   	Lesson: 35   Frame: 1408   Strokes: 16   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: neighbouring, pinnacle, parthenon, acropolis, shoeshine, rice, sunglasses, dancing legs, ballerina, evening 	 	Pinnacle . . . rice . . . sunglasses. 	 	 	America thinks it is the pinnacle of the world, looking down on all neighboring countries through its mirrored, aviator sunglasses. 	 	On-Yomi: リン   Kun-Yomi: とな.る、となり  	Examples: 隣る (とな.る), 隣 (となり)"
isolate	"isolate 	 	隔   	   	Lesson: 35   Frame: 1409   Strokes: 13   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: isolate, pinnacle, parthenon, acropolis, tripod, one, ceiling, mouth, hood, human legs, street, nail, spike 	 	Pinnacle . . . ceiling . . . mouth . . . glass canopy . . . human legs . . . spike. You might want to compare the kanji for dissolve (Frame 1123). 	 	 	The Pinnacle, to me, is a city that makes itself out to be perfect but is filled with dirty secrets that photographers are always trying to reveal (see dissolve (#1044) The city´s councilmen have isolated all professional photographers to make sure they don´t photograph these ""dirty secrets"". (which are up to your imagination). 	 	On-Yomi: カク   Kun-Yomi: へだ.てる、へだ.たる  	Examples: 隔たる (ひだ.たる), 隔てる (へだ.てる)"
conceal	"conceal 	 	隠   	   	Lesson: 35   Frame: 1410   Strokes: 14   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: conceal, pinnacle, parthenon, acropolis, hideaway, claw, vulture, broom, heart 	 	Pinnacle . . . vulture . . . broom . . . heart. Compare the element sat the right to the kanji for calm (Frame 1230). 	 	 	The wheat farmer´s heart is calm (#1147) about the eagle not stealing his crops because of the broom scarecrow. But he still conceals all his wheat at The Pinnacle in case anyone else trys to steal it. 	 	On-Yomi: イン、オン   Kun-Yomi: かく.す、かく.し、かく.れる、かか.す、よ.る  	Examples: 隠す (かく.す), 隠れる (かく.れる)"
degenerate	"degenerate 	 	堕   	   	Lesson: 35   Frame: 1411   Strokes: 12   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: degenerate, pinnacle, parthenon, acropolis, possess, by one’s side, moon, month, flesh, part of the body, ground, soil, dirt, ground 	 	Pinnacle . . . possess . . . ground. 	 	 	Any attempt to possess the pinnacle will degenerate into a land (""ground"") war. 	 	On-Yomi: ダ   Kun-Yomi: お.ちる、くず.す、くず.れる"
collapse	"collapse 	 	陥   	   	Lesson: 35   Frame: 1412   Strokes: 10   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: collapse, pinnacle, parthenon, acropolis, straight-jacket, bound up, olden times, old days, stick, sun, day 	 	Pinnacle . . . bound up . . . olden times. 	 	 	The Pinnacle is actually bound up by supports from olden times. Eventually, they give out, and the whole thing starts to collapse. hole	"hole 	 	穴   	   	Lesson: 35   Frame: 1413   Strokes: 5   —   Jouyou Grade: 6   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: hole, house, eight 	 	House . . . eight. 	  * As a primitive, this kanji uses an alternate form: the primitive for eight is replaced with that for human legs. 	 	A black hole is a ""House of Infinity"". Infinity is of course represented by a sideways ""8"", but here we have a Japanese ""8"" instead. 	 	On-Yomi: ケツ   Kun-Yomi: あな  	Examples: 穴 (あな)"
empty	"empty 	 	空   	   	Lesson: 35   Frame: 1414   Strokes: 8   —   Jouyou Grade: 1   JLPT: 4   	Constituents: empty, hole, house, human legs, craft 	 	Hole . . . craft. 	 	 	The craft of creating a black hole is in creating an emptiness which can attract things. 	 	On-Yomi: クウ   Kun-Yomi: そら、あ.く、あ.き、あ.ける、から、す.く、す.かす、むな.しい  	Examples: 空く (あ.く), 空ける (あ.ける), 空 (から), 空 (そら)"

With my fingers, I punch in my bank code and withdraw some money from my account. And now it´s empty again, as usual! 	 	On-Yomi: コウ   Kun-Yomi: ひか.える、ひか.え  	Examples: 控える (ひか.える)"

depression	"depression 	 	窪   	   	Lesson: 35   Frame: 1421   Strokes: 14   —   Jouyou Grade: Names   JLPT:    	Constituents: depression, hole, house, human legs, water, water droplets, water pistol, ivy, square jewel, soil, dirt, ground, soil2, dirt2, ground2 	 	Hole . . . water . . . ivy. The depression referred to here is a sunken place in the ground, rather than in one's spirits. 	 	 	A depression is a hole in the ground. Water naturally collects there which provides moisture for vines to grow. 	 	On-Yomi: ワ、ア   Kun-Yomi: くぼ.む、くぼ.み、くぼ.まる、くぼ"

You have trouble squeezing your hand through the hole so you use a saw to enlarge it. 	 	On-Yomi: サク   Kun-Yomi: しぼ.る  	Examples: 搾る (しぼ.る)"
kiln	"kiln 	 	窯   	   	Lesson: 35   Frame: 1423   Strokes: 15   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: kiln, hole, house, human legs, sheep, oven-fire, barbecue 	 	Hole . . . sheep . . . oven fire. 	 	 	Be sure to put a hole in that ceramic sheep before you put it over the fire. Otherwise, it´ll just explode in the kiln. (If you´ve never done ceramics before, it´s important that the object have a hole in it, or this really will happen.). 	 	On-Yomi: ヨウ   Kun-Yomi: かま  	Examples: 窯 (かま)"
hard up	"hard up 	 	窮   	   	Lesson: 35   Frame: 1424   Strokes: 15   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: hard up, hole, house, human legs, somebody, nose, bow 	 	Hole . . . somebody . . . bow. A pictograph of a japanese schoolgirl getting groped by perverts on the train. The fingers of course, a crown (her too short skirt) and her legs below (which to be honest are pretty thick like tree trunks). 	 	On-Yomi: タン   Kun-Yomi: さぐ.る、さが.す  	Examples: 探す (さが.す), 探る (さぐ.る)"
deep	"deep 	 	深   	   	Lesson: 35   Frame: 1426   Strokes: 11   —   Jouyou Grade: 3   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: deep, water, water droplets, water pistol, paper punch, Miss World, hole, house, human legs, tree, wood 	 	Water . . . paper punch . . . tree. 	 	 	If the groper´s ""tree"" goes up the girl´s miniskirt too deep, he´ll ejaculate fluid. (Sorry it´s kinda coarse but it works.). 	 	On-Yomi: シン   Kun-Yomi: ふか.い、-ぶか.い、ふか.まる、ふか.める、み-  	Examples: 深い (ふか.い), 深まる (ふか.まる), 深める (ふか.める)"
hill	"hill 	 	丘   	   	Lesson: 35   Frame: 1427   Strokes: 5   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: hill, axe, one, floor 	 	Since this supposedly pictographic representation of a hill looks like anything but, picture a row of axes driven into the ground up to their heads, and see if that doesn't present a more memorable image of hill - at least a riskier one sliding down! 	 	 	Excalibur is the sword planted in a rock. Lesser known AXCAHILLBUR is the axe planted on top of a hill. 	 	On-Yomi: キュウ   Kun-Yomi: おか  	Examples: 丘 (おか)"
Point	"Point 	 	岳   	   	Lesson: 35   Frame: 1428   Strokes: 8   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: point, hill, axe, one, floor, mountain 	 	Think of the key word as referring to proper names of mountains, but do not confuse with mountain pass (Frame 835). The elements are: hill . . . mountain. 	 	 	A point is a extra little hill at the top of a mountain. We´ll call it ´Fireman´s Point´. 	 	On-Yomi: ガク   Kun-Yomi: たけ  	Examples: 岳 (たけ)"
soldier	"soldier 	 	兵   	   	Lesson: 35   Frame: 1429   Strokes: 7   —   Jouyou Grade: 4   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: soldier, hill, axe, one, floor, animal legs, eight 	 	Hill . . . animal legs. 	 	 	Listen up soldiers! We´re going to take that hill. You are no longer men with human legs. You are voracious animals, with animal legs! Got it? Animal legs! Now take that hill! 	 	On-Yomi: ヘイ、ヒョウ   Kun-Yomi: つわもの  	Examples: 兵器 (へいき), 兵隊 (へいたい), 撤兵 (てっぺい)"
seacoast	"seacoast 	 	浜   	   	Lesson: 35   Frame: 1430   Strokes: 10   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: seacoast, water, water droplets, water pistol, soldier, hill, axe, one, floor, animal legs, eight 	 	Water . . . soldier. 	 	 	Seacoast -> Coast Guard -> ""water soldiers"" lined up on the seacoast defending our shores. 	 	On-Yomi: ヒン   Kun-Yomi: はま  	Examples: 浜 (はま)"
thread	"thread 	 	糸   	   	Lesson: 36   Frame: 1431   Strokes: 6   —   Jouyou Grade: 1   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: thread, spiderman 	 	Remember when your granny used to ask you to bend your arms at the elbows and hold them out so that she could use them like a rack to hold a skein of string or yarn (here thread) while she rolled it up into a little ball? Now can you see the two elbows (with the second stroke doubling up) at the top, and the character for little below? 	 	 	I also went with Spiderman. However, in the cases where this primitive appears under other primitives, as opposed to on the left (I think there are ~5 times in this chapter) I´ve opted to use a similar character: Venom. This helps keep the positioning clear, especially on such characters as dainty (#1363) and accumulate (#1364). 	 	On-Yomi: シ   Kun-Yomi: いと  	Examples: 糸 (いと)"
weave	"weave 	 	織   	   	Lesson: 36   Frame: 1432   Strokes: 18   —   Jouyou Grade: 5   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: weave, thread, spiderman, kazoo, sound, vase, stand up, sun, day, fiesta 	 	Thread . . . kazoo. 	 	 	Spiderman weaves his way through the skyline while listening to his theme song on his ipod. It is played, of course, by kazoos. 	 	On-Yomi: ショク、シキ   Kun-Yomi: お.る、お.り、おり、-おり、-お.り  	Examples: 織機 (しょっき), 染織 (せんしょく), 紡織 (ぼうしょく), 織る (お.る)"

After a day being virtuouos and keeping the city safe, Spiderman´s outfit is in need of some repair. Luckily, as he can shoot out threads darning is very easy for him to do. After spending the night at an inn, spider man discovered to his dismay that his costume had shrunk in the wash, and no longer fit! luxuriant	"luxuriant 	 	繁   	   	Lesson: 36   Frame: 1435   Strokes: 16   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: luxuriant, cleverness, reclining, lying down, mother, breasts, taskmaster, thread, spiderman 	 	Cleverness . . . thread. 	 	 	Important: Luxuriant does NOT mean luxurious, as the other stories indicate. Definition: abundant or lush in growth, as vegetation. When Venom realized he couldn´t beat Spider-Man in a fair fight, he showed his cleverness by spraying venom all over Spider-Man´s luxuriant garden. 	 	On-Yomi: ハン   Kun-Yomi: しげ.る、しげ.く"

line	"line 	 	線   	   	Lesson: 36   Frame: 1438   Strokes: 15   —   Jouyou Grade: 2   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: line, thread, spiderman, spring, white, dove, water 	 	Thread . . . spring. 	 	 	This kanji is used for train lines. Spiderman does a hot spring tour of Japan using the train lines. You can see the Spidey costume hanging on the washing line as he enjoys the onsen. tighten	"tighten 	 	締   	   	Lesson: 36   Frame: 1440   Strokes: 15   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: tighten, thread, spiderman, sovereign, vase, stand up, apron, crown, towel 	 	Thread . . . sovereign. 	 	 	The sovereign appears to be ruling, but in reality someone behind him (for instance his wife) has a thread around his throat, and if he dares to make a decision she doesn´t like, she starts pulling the thread and tightens it around his throat. 	 	On-Yomi: テイ   Kun-Yomi: し.まる、し.まり、し.める、-し.め、-じ.め  	Examples: 締まる (し.まる), 締める (し.める)"

Eat that turkey if you want, but make sure you eat some fibers: you want spidey threads, don´t ya? 	 	On-Yomi: イ   Kun-Yomi:"
gauze	"gauze 	 	羅   	   	Lesson: 36   Frame: 1442   Strokes: 19   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: gauze, eye, cross-eyed, net, fibre, thread, spiderman, turkey 	 	Eye . . . fiber. 	 	 	Lots of girls in Japan wear gauze patches over one eye made of course white fibers. They think it is cute, and I must admit, I have come to think so too. 	 	On-Yomi: ラ   Kun-Yomi: うすもの"
practice	"practice 	 	練   	   	Lesson: 36   Frame: 1443   Strokes: 14   —   Jouyou Grade: 3   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: practice, thread, spiderman, east, tree, wood, sun, day 	 	Thread . . . east. 	 	 	You practice your Japanese skills in a discussion thread with lots of people from the Far East (since many of the people who are interested in studying Japanese are Asian). 	 	On-Yomi: レン   Kun-Yomi: ね.る、ね.り  	Examples: 練る (ね.る)"
thong	"thong 	 	緒   	   	Lesson: 36   Frame: 1444   Strokes: 14   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: thong, thread, spiderman, someone, puppet, sooty, old man, sun, day 	 	Thread . . . puppet. Although we usually think of a thong as coming at the end of a piece of string, this character's meaning allows for it to come at the beginning as well. 	 	 	Spiderman has a secret fetish, he likes nothing better than to dress his lovedoll in a thong. Wierd, eh! 	 	On-Yomi: ショ、チョ   Kun-Yomi: お、いとぐち  	Examples: 緒戦 (しょせん), 由緒 (ゆいしょ), 端緒 (たんしょ), 緒 (お)"
continue	"continue 	 	続   	   	Lesson: 36   Frame: 1445   Strokes: 13   —   Jouyou Grade: 4   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: continue, thread, spiderman, sell, samurai, crown, human legs 	 	Thread . . . sell. 	 	 	If you attach strings to the things you sell, you will be able to continue making profit from them even after the fact. 	 	On-Yomi: ゾク、ショク、コウ、キョウ   Kun-Yomi: つづ.く、つづ.ける、つぐ.ない  	Examples: 続く (つづ.く), 続ける (つづ.ける)"
picture	"picture 	 	絵   	   	Lesson: 36   Frame: 1446   Strokes: 12   —   Jouyou Grade: 2   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: picture, thread, spiderman, meeting, one, wall, umbrella, rising cloud, two, elbow, wall 	 	Thread . . . meeting. 	 	 	There´s never a picture of Spiderman meeting Peter Parker... I wonder why? 	 	On-Yomi: カイ、エ   Kun-Yomi:   	Examples: 絵画 (かいが)"
overall	"overall 	 	統   	   	Lesson: 36   Frame: 1447   Strokes: 12   —   Jouyou Grade: 5   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: overall, thread, spiderman, allot, infant, toddler, top hat, elbow, human legs 	 	Thread . . . allot. 	 	 	Spidey is alloted the biggest crime fighter jurisdiction in NYC because his OVERALL arrest record is the best. 	 	On-Yomi: トウ   Kun-Yomi: す.べる、ほび.る  	Examples: 統べる (す.べる)"
strangle	"strangle 	 	絞   	   	Lesson: 36   Frame: 1448   Strokes: 12   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: strangle, thread, spiderman, mingle, top hat, father 	 	Thread . . . mingle. 	 	 	Spiderman hates going to parties and having to mingle. He wants to strangle someone after just a little small talk. 	 	On-Yomi: コウ   Kun-Yomi: しぼ.る、し.める、し.まる  	Examples: 絞まる (し.まる), 絞める (し.める), 絞る (しぼ.る)"
salary	"salary 	 	給   	   	Lesson: 36   Frame: 1449   Strokes: 12   —   Jouyou Grade: 4   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: salary, thread, spiderman, fit, meeting, umbrella, one, mouth 	 	Thread . . . fit. 	 	 	If your threads 糸 don't fit 合 right you're not going to be able to get a job with a decent salary. 	 	On-Yomi: キュウ   Kun-Yomi: たま.う、たも.う、-たま.え"
entwine	"entwine 	 	絡   	   	Lesson: 36   Frame: 1450   Strokes: 12   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: entwine, thread, spiderman, each, walking legs, mouth 	 	Thread . . . each. 	 	 	When threads become entwined, each thread is tangled to another. 	 	On-Yomi: ラク   Kun-Yomi: から.む、から.まる  	Examples: 絡まる (から.まる), 絡む (から.む)"
tie	"tie 	 	結   	   	Lesson: 36   Frame: 1451   Strokes: 12   —   Jouyou Grade: 4   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: tie, thread, spiderman, aerosol, samurai, mouth 	 	Thread . . . aerosol can. 	 	 	Ok, here, you have to think of the phrase ""TIE the knot"" , which means a wedding (this kanji is used in the marriage compound 結婚 けっこん ). Now, at US weddings, it ends with the couple driving away with cans being dragged behind the car. So here, think of SPIDERMAN, who will TIE the knot with Mary Jane. At his wedding, Spider THREAD attached (or TIED) to SPRAYCANS are being drug behind the limo as they drive off. 	 	On-Yomi: ケツ、ケチ   Kun-Yomi: むす.ぶ、ゆ.う、ゆ.わえる  	Examples: 結ぶ (むす.ぶ), 結う (ゆ.う), 結わえる (ゆ.わえる)"
end	"end 	 	終   	   	Lesson: 36   Frame: 1452   Strokes: 11   —   Jouyou Grade: 3   JLPT: 4   	Constituents: end, thread, spiderman, winter, walking legs, ice, drop, drop2 	 	Thread . . . winter. 	 	 	This winter is so cold that spiderman´s web gets brittle! Could this be the end of spiderman? 	 	On-Yomi: シュウ   Kun-Yomi: お.わる、-お.わる、おわ.る、お.える、つい、つい.に  	Examples: 終える (お.える), 終わる (お.わる)"
class	"class 	 	級   	   	Lesson: 36   Frame: 1453   Strokes: 9   —   Jouyou Grade: 3   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: class, thread, spiderman, reach out, outstretched hands 	 	Threads . . . outstretched hands. 	 	 	This Kanji is the same ones used in the Japanese Language proficiency tests; i.e. ikkyuu (一級) The Kanji doesnt describe class as in a ""class of students"" or ""classroom,"" but rather a grade of quality or ability. ---------- Spiderman is taking the JLPT Level 1. In desperation he REACHES OUT to grab his friend´s answer sheet next to him, who seems to be doing well. The other test takers are obviously a class above him. Looks like this test is above his class of knowledge. 	 	On-Yomi: キュウ   Kun-Yomi:"
chronicle	"chronicle 	 	紀   	   	Lesson: 36   Frame: 1454   Strokes: 9   —   Jouyou Grade: 4   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: chronicle, thread, spiderman, snake, self 	 	Thread . . . snake. 	 	 	In a CHRONICLE the THREAD of the story can twist and turn like a SNAKE. 	 	On-Yomi: キ   Kun-Yomi:"
crimson	"crimson 	 	紅   	   	Lesson: 36   Frame: 1455   Strokes: 9   —   Jouyou Grade: 6   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: crimson, thread, spiderman, craft 	 	Thread . . . craft. 	 	 	After Spider-Man is whacked in the head with a I-beam, crimson blood flows from the wound. 	 	On-Yomi: コウ、ク   Kun-Yomi: べに、くれない、あか.い  	Examples: 紅白 (こうはく), 紅茶 (こうちゃ), 紅葉 (こうよう), 紅 (くれない), 紅 (べに)"

Have you heard about patients who have surgery and the doctor mistakenly leaves a medical instrument INSIDE the patient’s body and proceeds to stitch up the patient’s incisions with stitching THREAD? Can you say “malpractice SETTLEMENT”?　. 	 	On-Yomi: ノウ、ナッ、ナ、ナン、トウ   Kun-Yomi: おさ.める、-おさ.める、おさ.まる  	Examples: 納入 (のうにゅう), 納涼 (のうりょう), 収納 (しゅうのう), 納得 (なっとく), 納豆 (なっとう), 納屋 (なや), 納戸 (なんど), 納まる (おさ.まる), 納める (おさ.める)"

Spiderman can spin his webs in any direction. 	 	On-Yomi: ボウ   Kun-Yomi: つむ.ぐ  	Examples: 紡ぐ (つむ.ぐ)"

It is easy for arguments to get distracted from the main thread by a tendency to part threads (splitting hairs). sūtra	"sūtra 	 	経   	   	Lesson: 36   Frame: 1460   Strokes: 11   —   Jouyou Grade: 5   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: sutra, thread, spiderman, spool, clod, toilet paper, crotch, soil, dirt, ground 	 	Thread . . . spool. 	 	 	The word ‘sutra’ literally means a rope or thread that holds things together. Here we see that it is a spool that is holding the threads together. 	 	On-Yomi: ケイ、キョウ   Kun-Yomi: へ.る、た.つ、たていと、はか.る、のり  	Examples: 経費 (けいひ), 経済 (けいざい), 経験 (けいけん), 経る (へ.る)"
sire	"sire 	 	紳   	   	Lesson: 36   Frame: 1461   Strokes: 11   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: sire, thread, spiderman, monkey, sun, day, stick 	 	Thread . . . monkey. 	 	 	Monkeys are very adept at swinging around trees. But when they met Spiderman, who could swing around even better than they could, they all quickly addressed him as sire. 	 	On-Yomi: シン   Kun-Yomi:"
promise	"promise 	 	約   	   	Lesson: 36   Frame: 1462   Strokes: 9   —   Jouyou Grade: 4   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: promise, thread, spiderman, ladle 	 	Consider for a moment the etymology of the word ""promise"" in order to notice its roots in the activity of putting one thing (e.g., one's word of honor) in place of another (e.g., the fulfillment of a task). For as it turns out, this character also means ""to abridge, economize, and abbreviate"" - all activities that involve putting one thing in place of another. With that in mind, we may now work with the elements: thread . . . ladle. 	 	 	He tied a thread around the ladle as a reminder of his promise to do more house work. 	 	On-Yomi: ヤク   Kun-Yomi:"
dainty	"dainty 	 	細   	   	Lesson: 36   Frame: 1463   Strokes: 11   —   Jouyou Grade: 2   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: dainty, thread, spiderman, rice field, brains 	 	Thread . . . brains. 	 	 	Dainty women would always rather work with thread than in a field. 	 	On-Yomi: サイ   Kun-Yomi: ほそ.い、ほそ.る、こま.か、こま.かい  	Examples: 細か (こま.か), 細かい (こま.かい), 細い (ほそ.い), 細る (ほそ.る)"
accumulate	"accumulate 	 	累   	   	Lesson: 36   Frame: 1464   Strokes: 11   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: accumulate, rice field, brains, thread, spiderman 	 	Rice field . . . threads. Make use of the position of the elements to distinguish this kanji from that of the previous frame. 	 	 	When you accumulate knowledge in your brain, neural pathways are constructed. All those pathways end up like a huge ball of thread tangled together. The more knowledge you accumulate the more threads you throw into the mix!! 	 	On-Yomi: ルイ   Kun-Yomi:"
cord	"cord 	 	索   	   	Lesson: 36   Frame: 1465   Strokes: 10   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: cord, bishop, cross, ten, needle, crown, thread, spiderman 	 	Chapel (see frame 930) . . . thread. 	 	 	A coaxial cord has a needle-like pin, a crown cap for screwing it in, and insulation made of thread. 	 	On-Yomi: サク   Kun-Yomi:"

Spiderman could not achieve general acceptance by the media even after winning the public´s heart. 	 	On-Yomi: ソウ   Kun-Yomi: す.べて、すべ.て、ふさ"

Compare frame 1218. 	 	 	A poor chinese fisherman could expect to inherit: the thread for his pole, a hook for catching something to eat, and some rice to live off of. (not concentrating on stroke order, sorry if that throws anyone off). (Adapted from bigloui,12-4-2006). 	 	On-Yomi: ケイ   Kun-Yomi: つ.ぐ、まま-  	Examples: 継ぐ (つ.ぐ)"
green	"green 	 	緑   	   	Lesson: 36   Frame: 1471   Strokes: 14   —   Jouyou Grade: 3   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: green, thread, spiderman, dustpan, broom, grains of rice 	 	Thread . . . broom . . . rice grains. 	 	 	When you attend a green tea (緑茶=りょくちゃ) ceremony, you can cherish the threadwork on the kimonos people don, the broom-like whisk (茶筌 =ちゃせん) you use to grind up your tea, and the delicious rice cakes you eat with your tea! affinity	"affinity 	 	縁   	   	Lesson: 36   Frame: 1472   Strokes: 15   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: affinity, thread, spiderman, broom, sow, pig 	 	Thread . . . broom . . . sow. 	 	 	There once was a lonely little pig that constantly followed Spiderman, always nuzzling his leg and oinking tenderly. Spiderman finally caved in and decided to keep the little pig under one condition: the pig was to take a broom and sweep up all of Spiderman´s leftover threads after having fought crime. The pig felt such affinity for Spiderman, he happily accepted—and did a good job too. 	 	On-Yomi: エン、ネン   Kun-Yomi: ふち、ふちど.る、ゆかり、よすが、へり、えにし  	Examples: 縁 (ふち)"

Spiderman traps The Rhino under the hood of his famous netting, where even Rhino´s horns can not break free, in fact if the netting did not dissappear after a few hours then Rhino might even perish in there. 	 	On-Yomi: モウ   Kun-Yomi: あみ  	Examples: 網 (あみ)"

Whenever Venom is tense, he loses control of his sex drive and becomes a slave to his crotch. 	 	On-Yomi: キン   Kun-Yomi:"
purple	"purple 	 	紫   	   	Lesson: 36   Frame: 1475   Strokes: 12   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: purple, Prince, this here, stop, footprint, spoon, sitting on the ground, thread, spiderman 	 	Footprint . . . spoon . . . thread. 	 	 	Stop sitting for so long - or else you'll get those purple threads (veins) on your legs from bad circulation. [link purple with those huge purple, bulging, crawling, worm-like varicose veins .....]. 	 	On-Yomi: シ   Kun-Yomi: むらさき  	Examples: 紫 (むらさき)"
truss	"truss 	 	縛   	   	Lesson: 36   Frame: 1476   Strokes: 16   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: truss, thread, spiderman, acupuncturist, specialty, drop, ten, needle, rice field, brains, glue 	 	Threads . . . acupuncturist. 	 	 	Spidey received good word that the acupuncturist working down the road was actually the evil Doctor Octopus! Spidey headed over to the clinic, and trussed the acupuncturist Doc Oc up using the maniac´s own metal limbs! 	 	On-Yomi: バク   Kun-Yomi: しば.る  	Examples: 縛る (しば.る)"
straw rope	"straw rope 	 	縄   	   	Lesson: 36   Frame: 1477   Strokes: 15   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: straw rope, thread, spiderman, eels, sun, day 	 	Thread . . . eels. 	 	 	The tortoise has escaped! We tied it up with a straw rope, but all that´s left of the rope are some torn threads, and the unbound tortoise is nowhere to be found. (Note that the right half here is not ""eels"". This is (in my opinion) a mistake in the RTK book, as we already decided in waterfall (#537) to refer to the simplified form of dragon as ""eels"". It is much better to call the right half of this character an ""unbound tortoise"".). 	 	On-Yomi: ジョウ   Kun-Yomi: なわ、ただ.す  	Examples: 縄 (なわ)"
infancy	"infancy 	 	幼   	   	Lesson: 36   Frame: 1478   Strokes: 5   —   Jouyou Grade: 6   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: infancy, cocoon, power, muscle, arnold 	 	Cocoon . . . muscle. 	 	 	In its infancy, a butterfly is protected by a cocoon, as it doesn´t yet have any power of its own. 	 	On-Yomi: ヨウ   Kun-Yomi: おさな.い  	Examples: 幼い (おさな.い)"
behind	"behind 	 	後   	   	Lesson: 36   Frame: 1479   Strokes: 9   —   Jouyou Grade: 2   JLPT: 5   	Constituents: behind, Nelson, column, going, line, cocoon, walking legs 	 	Line . . . cocoon . . . walking legs. 	 	 	Column of walking legs (caterpillar) getting into a cocoon, about to leave its past self behind. faint	"faint 	 	幽   	   	Lesson: 36   Frame: 1480   Strokes: 9   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: seclude, faint, cocoon, mountain, cocoon2 	 	Two cocoons . . . mountain. Observe how the two vertical strokes of the mountain are extended upwards to serve as a kind of enclosure. 	 	 	The villagers haven´t the faintest idea that giant coccoons resting in the mountain are soon to hatch. 	 	On-Yomi: ユウ、ヨウ   Kun-Yomi: ふか.い、かす.か、くら.い、しろ.い"
how many	"how many 	 	幾   	   	Lesson: 36   Frame: 1481   Strokes: 12   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: how many, cocoon, person, fiesta, cocoon2 	 	Two cocoons . . . person . . . fiesta. 	  * As a primitive, this kanji will mean an abacus, the bead-instrument used in the Orient to calculate how many. 	 	It is a little awkward when you are at a fiesta and the host serves some rare delicacy, like moth cocoons, the guests must decide how many it would be polite to eat. You do the math in your head and it comes out to two cocoons per person. This is why the horizontal line is a fraction bar with two cocoons on the top, and one person the bottom. 	 	On-Yomi: キ   Kun-Yomi: いく-、いく.つ、いく.ら  	Examples: 幾 (いく)"
mechanism	"mechanism 	 	機   	   	Lesson: 36   Frame: 1482   Strokes: 16   —   Jouyou Grade: 4   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: mechanism, tree, wood, abacus, how many, cocoon, person, fiesta, cocoon2 	 	Tree . . . abacus. 	 	 	An abacus is a mechanism made of wood used to calculate how many ´anythings´. 	 	On-Yomi: キ   Kun-Yomi: はた  	Examples: 機 (はた)"
mysterious	"mysterious 	 	玄   	   	Lesson: 36   Frame: 1484   Strokes: 5   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: mysterious, top hat, cocoon 	 	Top hat . . . cocoon. 	 	 	What could be more mysterious than a cocoon in a top hat trying to sneak in...? (Pimitive: GANDALF). 	 	On-Yomi: ゲン   Kun-Yomi:"

The livestock are disappearing! I´ve placed Gandalf over the rice field to protect them. 	 	On-Yomi: チク   Kun-Yomi:"
amass	"amass 	 	蓄   	   	Lesson: 36   Frame: 1486   Strokes: 13   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: amass, flowers, livestock, mysterious, top hat, cocoon, rice field, brains 	 	Flowers . . . livestock. 	 	 	One sneaky farmer wanted to amass a large collection of livestock. We all know that cows like to eat flowers, so he planted lines of flowers leading to his own fields. The livestock followed the lines, eating the flowers one by one, and amassed in his field. 	 	On-Yomi: チク   Kun-Yomi: たくわ.える  	Examples: 蓄える (たくわ.える)"
bowstring	"bowstring 	 	弦   	   	Lesson: 36   Frame: 1487   Strokes: 8   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: bowstring, bow, mysterious, top hat, cocoon 	 	Bow . . . mysterious. 	 	 	A magic bow that only Gandalf can yield: there is no bowstring on it, and he uses his magic to fire arrows. 	 	On-Yomi: ゲン   Kun-Yomi: つる  	Examples: 弦 (つる)"
hug	"hug 	 	擁   	   	Lesson: 36   Frame: 1488   Strokes: 16   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: hug, finger, fingers, mysterious, top hat, cocoon, turkey 	 	Fingers . . . mysterious . . . turkey. Note that the top hat is extended across both elements, though it belongs only to the cocoon. This means that you may either use mysterious - as we did here - or take the three elements separately. 	 	 	A mysterious turkey with human fingers wants to hug me... I will never go to Tokyo Disneyland again! 	 	On-Yomi: ヨウ   Kun-Yomi:"
nourishing	"nourishing 	 	滋   	   	Lesson: 36   Frame: 1489   Strokes: 12   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: nourishing, water, water droplets, water pistol, double-mysterious, mothballs, horns, one, cocoon, cocoon2 	 	Water . . . double-mysterious. Note the doubling up of the element for top hat in the primitive for mysterious and assign it a special image, as it will come up in the next two frames. 	 	 	Water is doubly mysterious. It´s in all our nourishment...and yet, it´s really not nourishing at all. 	 	On-Yomi: ジ   Kun-Yomi:"
mercy	"mercy 	 	慈   	   	Lesson: 36   Frame: 1490   Strokes: 13   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: mercy, double-mysterious, mothballs, horns, one, cocoon, heart, cocoon2 	 	Double-mysterious . . . heart. 	 	 	Here we see the DOUBLE-MYSTERIOUS Siamese twins again, at the MERCY of the machines that pump blood through their veins, since the single HEART they share won't do the job... 	 	On-Yomi: ジ   Kun-Yomi: いつく.しむ  	Examples: 慈しむ (いつく.しむ)"
magnet	"magnet 	 	磁   	   	Lesson: 36   Frame: 1491   Strokes: 14   —   Jouyou Grade: 6   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: magnet, stone, rock, double-mysterious, mothballs, horns, one, cocoon, cocoon2 	 	Stone . . . double-mysterious. 	 	 	A magnet is a rock with two sides; one that mysteriously pushes and one that pulls; doubly mysterious. (see astridtops´ story). 	 	On-Yomi: ジ   Kun-Yomi:"
lineage	"lineage 	 	系   	   	Lesson: 36   Frame: 1492   Strokes: 7   —   Jouyou Grade: 6   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: lineage, stick, drop, thread, spiderman 	 	The single stroke added to the beginning of the primitive for thread gives the image of threads woven into a single cord. Hence the meaning, lineage. 	  * As a primitive, we shall give this kanji the meaning of yarn, as the uniting of many threads into a single strand is most obvious with yarn. 	 	A single drop of your blood holds the proof of the unbroken thread of your lineage. 	 	On-Yomi: ケイ   Kun-Yomi:"
person in charge	"person in charge 	 	係   	   	Lesson: 36   Frame: 1493   Strokes: 9   —   Jouyou Grade: 3   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: person in charge, person, lineage, drop, thread, spiderman 	 	Person . . . yarn. 	 	 	Mister T gets a DNA test, and discovers that he was meant to be the person in charge after all. 	 	On-Yomi: ケイ   Kun-Yomi: かか.る、かかり、-がかり、かか.わる  	Examples: 係る (かか.る), 係 (かかり)"
grandchild	"grandchild 	 	孫   	   	Lesson: 36   Frame: 1494   Strokes: 10   —   Jouyou Grade: 4   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: grandchild, child, lineage, drop, thread, spiderman 	 	Child . . . yarn. 	 	 	Your grandchild is the child of your DNA. 	 	On-Yomi: ソン   Kun-Yomi: まご  	Examples: 孫 (まご)"
suspend	"suspend 	 	懸   	   	Lesson: 36   Frame: 1495   Strokes: 20   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: suspend, prefecture, eye, fishhook, small, little, lineage, stick, drop, thread, spiderman, heart 	 	Prefecture . . . yarn . . . heart. 	 	 	The prefecture has suspended all DNA research for heart disease because of corruption. All involved will be suspended by their wrists. 	 	On-Yomi: ケン、ケ   Kun-Yomi: か.ける、か.かる  	Examples: 懸垂 (けんすい), 懸賞 (けんしょう), 懸命 (けんめい), 懸かる (か.かる), 懸ける (か.ける)"
instead	"instead 	 	却   	   	Lesson: 37   Frame: 1497   Strokes: 7   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: instead, gone, soil, dirt, ground, elbow, stamp 	 	Gone . . . stamp. 	 	 	[instead; on the contrary; rather] Gone is the time for stamps - use e-mail instead. 	 	On-Yomi: キャク   Kun-Yomi: かえ.って、しりぞ.く、しりぞ.ける"
shins	"shins 	 	脚   	   	Lesson: 37   Frame: 1498   Strokes: 11   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: skids, shins, moon, month, flesh, part of the body, instead, gone, soil, dirt, ground, elbow, stamp 	 	Part of the body . . . instead. This character has more or less the same meaning as that for leg learned back in frame 1372. It can also indicate the part of the legs from the shins down, which explains the choice of the key word. 	 	 	Shins are the part of the body that one uses instead of one´s eyes, for finding furniture in the dark. (Ouch!). 	 	On-Yomi: キャク、キャ、カク   Kun-Yomi: あし  	Examples: 脚部 (きゃくぶ), 脚本 (きゃくほん), 三脚 (さんきゃく), 脚 (あし)"
wholesale	"wholesale 	 	卸   	   	Lesson: 37   Frame: 1499   Strokes: 9   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: wholesale, horseshoe, horse, pantomime horse, noon, sign of the horse, stop, footprint, stamp 	 	The left primitive is a union of a horse and footprint. To the right, the stamp. 	 	 	Wholesale refers to the sale of goods in quantity to retailers for resale. When this kanji was invented, large loads of goods needed to be transported by horses who left steep footprints because of the weight they carried. The wholesale goods needed a special stamp to indicate that they were legal for resale. 	 	On-Yomi: シャ   Kun-Yomi: おろ.す、おろし、おろ.し  	Examples: 卸す (おろ.す), 卸 (おろし)"
honorable	"honorable 	 	御   	   	Lesson: 37   Frame: 1500   Strokes: 12   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: honorable, Nelson, column, going, line, wholesale, horseshoe, pantomime horse, noon, sign of the horse, stop, footprint, stamp 	 	Line . . . wholesale. 	 	 	An honorable man will not try to cut in front of the line at the wholesale stamp store. (Imagine just how much honor it takes facing those long lines at the post office!). 	 	On-Yomi: ギョ、ゴ   Kun-Yomi: おん-、お-、み-  	Examples: 御者 (ぎょしゃ), 制御 (せいぎょ), 御 (おん)"
clothing	"clothing 	 	服   	   	Lesson: 37   Frame: 1501   Strokes: 8   —   Jouyou Grade: 3   JLPT: 4   	Constituents: clothing, moon, month, flesh, part of the body, underpants, stamp, crotch 	 	Flesh . . . stamp . . . crotch. Note how the stamp is stretched out here. 	 	 	It´s customary to cover the flesh with clothing, but some designs are so outrageous they´re not bigger than a stamp that just covers your crotch. 	 	On-Yomi: フク   Kun-Yomi:"
fate	"fate 	 	命   	   	Lesson: 37   Frame: 1502   Strokes: 8   —   Jouyou Grade: 3   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: fate, fit, meeting, umbrella, one, mouth, stamp 	 	This character connotes life in general, but also the particular life that is fated one by virtue of the distinctive character with which one is born. Its elements are: fit . . . stamp. The bottom portion of fit is nudged to the left in order to make room for the stamp. 	 	 	When you´re born, your fate is measured, fitted, and stamped onto your soul. Good luck defying it. 	 	On-Yomi: メイ、ミョウ   Kun-Yomi: いのち  	Examples: 命令 (めいれい), 運命 (うんめい), 生命 (せいめい), 命 (いのち)"
orders	"orders 	 	令   	   	Lesson: 37   Frame: 1503   Strokes: 5   —   Jouyou Grade: 4   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: orders, meeting, chop-seal, hanko 	 	Meeting . . . chop-seal. 	 	 	(re: dingomick) ""These are your orders,"" declares the general while passing out documents at the meeting. As everyone started to leave, the general exclaims ""Oh wait! I need to certify these orders!"" and went around stamping each paper with his personal chop-seal. 	 	On-Yomi: レイ   Kun-Yomi:"
zero	"zero 	 	零   	   	Lesson: 37   Frame: 1504   Strokes: 13   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: zero, rain, weather, orders, meeting, chop-seal, hanko 	 	Rain . . . orders. 	 	 	The amount of people that can order the rain to rain. 	 	On-Yomi: レイ   Kun-Yomi: ぜろ、こぼ.す、こぼ.れる"
age	"age 	 	齢   	   	Lesson: 37   Frame: 1505   Strokes: 17   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: age, teeth, tooth, stop, footprint, rice, shovel, orders, meeting, chop-seal, hanko 	 	This character is used to express the years of one's age. Its elements: teeth . . . orders. 	 	 	You know you are fast approaching a ripe old AGE when you get ORDERS from the dentist to get new TEETH. 	 	On-Yomi: レイ   Kun-Yomi: よわ.い、とし"
cool	"cool 	 	冷   	   	Lesson: 37   Frame: 1506   Strokes: 7   —   Jouyou Grade: 4   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: cool, ice, orders, meeting, chop-seal, hanko 	 	Ice . . . orders. 	 	 	To keep your water cool, just order some ice. 	 	On-Yomi: レイ   Kun-Yomi: つめ.たい、ひ.える、ひ.や、ひ.ややか、ひ.やす、ひ.やかす、さ.める、さ.ます  	Examples: 冷ます (さ.ます), 冷める (さ.める), 冷たい (つめ.たい), 冷える (ひ.える), 冷や (ひ.や), 冷やかす (ひ.やかす), 冷やす (ひ.やす)"
jurisdiction	"jurisdiction 	 	領   	   	Lesson: 37   Frame: 1507   Strokes: 14   —   Jouyou Grade: 5   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: jurisdiction, orders, meeting, chop-seal, hanko, head, page, one, ceiling, drop, shellfish, clam, oyster, eye, animal legs, eight 	 	Orders . . . head. 	 	 	Two cowboys are crossing a state limit. One says to him “Did you know that in this Jurisdiction there are Orders to get your head?”, so he takes out his gun and shoots him. He claims the reward afterwards. (Thanks Fuaburisu). 	 	On-Yomi: リョウ   Kun-Yomi: えり"
small bell	"small bell 	 	鈴   	   	Lesson: 37   Frame: 1508   Strokes: 13   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: small bell, metal, gold, orders, meeting, chop-seal, hanko 	 	Gold . . . orders. 	 	 	Some restaurants have a small gold bell to call someone to take customers´ orders. 	 	On-Yomi: レイ、リン   Kun-Yomi: すず  	Examples: 電鈴 (でんれい), 振鈴 (しんすず), 予鈴 (よれい), 鈴 (すず)"
courage	"courage 	 	勇   	   	Lesson: 37   Frame: 1509   Strokes: 9   —   Jouyou Grade: 4   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: courage, chop-seal, hanko, male, rice field, brains, power, muscle, arnold 	 	Chop-seal . . . man. 	 	 	I imagined some kind of initiation rite in old China, where every young man has to show his courage. They then receive a chopseal which is a mark of their courage. 	 	On-Yomi: ユウ   Kun-Yomi: いさ.む  	Examples: 勇む (いさ.む)"
traffic	"traffic 	 	通   	   	Lesson: 37   Frame: 1511   Strokes: 10   —   Jouyou Grade: 2   JLPT: 4   	Constituents: traffic, pogo stick, chop-seal, hanko, utilise, utilize, road 	 	Chop-seal . . . utilize . . . road. By combining the first two primitives into a single image, you will be able to use that image in a few instances later, one of which comes immediately. 	 	 	I bounce down the road on my pogo stick, easily getting through the dense traffic. (Note: New primitive: chop-seal + utilize = pogo stick. Because a chop-seal is long and thin with a rubbery bit at the end. If it were big enough, you could utilize it as a pogo stick). [Edit: pogo stick also appears in 1409, 1690, 2530]. 	 	On-Yomi: ツウ、ツ   Kun-Yomi: とお.る、とお.り、-とお.り、-どお.り、とお.す、とお.し、-どお.し、かよ.う  	Examples: 通行 (つうこう), 通読 (つうどく), 普通 (ふつう), 通う (かよ.う), 通す (とお.す), 通る (とお.る)"
jump	"jump 	 	踊   	   	Lesson: 37   Frame: 1512   Strokes: 14   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: jump, wooden leg, mouth, stop, footprint, pogo stick, chop-seal, hanko, utilise, utilize 	 	Wooden leg . . . chop-seal . . . utilize. 	 	 	The winner of the long jump competition was disqualified when they found he used a pogo stick tied to his leg to jump further. 	 	On-Yomi: ヨウ   Kun-Yomi: おど.る  	Examples: 踊り (おど.り), 踊る (おど.る)"
doubt	"doubt 	 	疑   	   	Lesson: 37   Frame: 1513   Strokes: 14   —   Jouyou Grade: 6   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: doubt, spoon, sitting on the ground, dart, drop, heavens, chop-seal, hanko, zoo, critters 	 	Spoon . . . dart . . . chop-seal . . . zoo. 	 	 	(Katsuo) You come at the zoo entrance. ´Here sir, a spoon to feed the animals.´ cool ´and a dart(gun) in case stuff go wrong´ ....´ please chop-seal (sign) here for in case of accidents the zoo is not responsible.´ ´lion feeding time is. bla bla´ You are having serious doubts about if you still want to go into this zoo. 	 	On-Yomi: ギ   Kun-Yomi: うたが.う  	Examples: 疑う (うたが.う)"
mimic	"mimic 	 	擬   	   	Lesson: 37   Frame: 1514   Strokes: 17   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: mimic, finger, fingers, doubt, spoon, sitting on the ground, dart, drop, heavens, chop-seal, hanko, zoo, critters 	 	Fingers . . . doubt. 	 	 	Ask a MIMIC to give an impression of DOUBT, and he will no DOUBT scratch his head with his FINGER. 	 	On-Yomi: ギ   Kun-Yomi: まが.い、もど.き"

I doubt that the jello would congeal sitting on the counter, so I placed it in the icebox. 	 	On-Yomi: ギョウ   Kun-Yomi: こ.る、こ.らす、こご.らす、こご.らせる、こご.る  	Examples: 凝らす (こ.らす), 凝る (こ.る)"

If you live a dangerous life, eventually you're bound to get unlucky. 	 	On-Yomi: キ   Kun-Yomi: あぶ.ない、あや.うい、あや.ぶむ  	Examples: 危ない (あぶ.ない), 危うい (あや.うい), 危ぶむ (あや.ぶむ)"

Your address should be displayed on your house and mailbox. 	 	On-Yomi: エン   Kun-Yomi: あ.てる、-あて、-づつ、あたか.も  	Examples: 宛てる (あ.てる)"
