This is a special sickle with metal blades on both sides. It can cut many things concurrently! 	 	On-Yomi: レン、ケン   Kun-Yomi: かま  	Examples: 鎌 (かま)"
self-effacing	"self-effacing 	 	謙   	   	Lesson: 41   Frame: 1726   Strokes: 17   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: self-effacing, say, words, keitai, mouth, concurrently, animal horns, rake 	 	Words . . . concurrently. 	 	 	When you are self-effacing you use words to concurrently bring yourself down and make yourself look better. 	 	On-Yomi: ケン   Kun-Yomi:"
bargain	"bargain 	 	廉   	   	Lesson: 41   Frame: 1727   Strokes: 13   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: bargain, cave, concurrently, animal horns, rake 	 	Cave . . . concurrently. 	 	 	Stores don´t want you to know it, but if you find the secret cave, they run bargains there concurrently to their regular prices. (Image: pulling a certain level in a store to find the ""bargain cave). 	 	On-Yomi: レン   Kun-Yomi:"
west	"west 	 	西   	   	Lesson: 41   Frame: 1728   Strokes: 6   —   Jouyou Grade: 2   JLPT: 5   	Constituents: west, one, four 	 	To our way of counting directions, the west always comes fourth. So it is convenient to find the character for four in this kanji. But since we want only one of the four directions, the west adds the one at the top and sucks the human legs a bit out of their mouth in the process. 	  * As a primitive, the meaning of west can be expanded to refer to the Old West of cowboy-movie fame, just as the meaning of the character for east was expanded into the East. Note, however, that in its primitive form the legs are straightened out and reach down to the bottom of the mouth. Hence, we get the shape ⻃. With the exception of one kanji, given in the following frame, this element always appears at the top of its relative primitives. 	 	The old west represented by a completely empty whiskey bottle (compare sign of the bird (#1427) whiskey bottle about one third full). 	 	On-Yomi: セイ、サイ、ス   Kun-Yomi: にし  	Examples: 西暦 (せいれき), 西部 (せいぶ), 北西 (ほくせい), 西 (にし)"
value	"value 	 	価   	   	Lesson: 41   Frame: 1729   Strokes: 8   —   Jouyou Grade: 5   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: value, person, old west 	 	Person . . . Old West. 	 	 	In the West, people have no value. Only money is important. 	 	On-Yomi: カ、ケ   Kun-Yomi: あたい  	Examples: 価 (あたい)"
need	"need 	 	要   	   	Lesson: 41   Frame: 1730   Strokes: 9   —   Jouyou Grade: 4   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: need, old west, woman 	 	Old West . . . woman. 	 	 	(ヨウ) When Clint needs a woman, he likes to be on top. 	 	On-Yomi: ヨウ   Kun-Yomi: い.る  	Examples: 要る (い.る)"
loins	"loins 	 	腰   	   	Lesson: 41   Frame: 1731   Strokes: 13   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: loins, moon, month, flesh, part of the body, need, old west, woman 	 	Part of the body . . . need. 	 	 	If you want to get closer to the actual meaning, then I think that 腰(こし) is more like the hips or the small of the back. After being sat down in the office too long, people often say 腰がいたい！It´s the part of the body that needs massaging. 	 	On-Yomi: ヨウ   Kun-Yomi: こし  	Examples: 腰 (こし)"
ballot	"ballot 	 	票   	   	Lesson: 41   Frame: 1732   Strokes: 11   —   Jouyou Grade: 4   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: ballot, old west, altar, show, two, small 	 	Old West . . . altar. 	 	 	In the Old West there were no ballot boxes. Afraid of fraud and fighting among the gunslingers, the ballots were posted into a slot in the top of the local church altar instead. They may have been rough, but the cowboys wouldn´t fight in the church. 	 	On-Yomi: ヒョウ   Kun-Yomi:"
drift	"drift 	 	漂   	   	Lesson: 41   Frame: 1733   Strokes: 14   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: drift, water, water droplets, water pistol, ballot, old west, altar, show, two, small 	 	Water . . . ballot. 	 	 	In Florida, Bush through Kerry´s ballots into the water, watching them drift away and setting the whole country adrift. 	 	On-Yomi: ヒョウ   Kun-Yomi: ただよ.う  	Examples: 漂う (ただよ.う)"
signpost	"signpost 	 	標   	   	Lesson: 41   Frame: 1734   Strokes: 15   —   Jouyou Grade: 4   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: signpost, tree, wood, ballot, old west, altar, show, two, small 	 	Tree . . . ballot. 	 	 	Trees were frequenly used as signposts in those days, indicating where one had to go to cast their ballots. 	 	On-Yomi: ヒョウ   Kun-Yomi: しるべ、しるし"
chestnut	"chestnut 	 	栗   	   	Lesson: 41   Frame: 1735   Strokes: 10   —   Jouyou Grade: Names   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: chestnut, old west, tree, wood 	 	Old West . . . tree. 	 	 	Chestnut tree, west nut tree. 	 	On-Yomi: リツ、リ   Kun-Yomi: くり、おののく"
transition	"transition 	 	遷   	   	Lesson: 41   Frame: 1737   Strokes: 15   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: transition, old west, large, St. Bernard, snake, self, road 	 	West . . . St. Bernard dog . . . snake . . . road. 	 	 	Since the days of the Old West, traveling has transitioned from trying not to step on big snakes to driving on big roads. 	 	On-Yomi: セン   Kun-Yomi: うつ.る、うつ.す、みやこがえ"
capsize	"capsize 	 	覆   	   	Lesson: 41   Frame: 1738   Strokes: 18   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: capsize, old west, restore, Nelson, column, going, line, fold back, double back, reclining, lying down, sun, day, walking legs 	 	West . . . restore. 	 	 	The U.S.S. Old West has capsized, and all the cowboys on board are trying to restore her upright. 	 	On-Yomi: フク   Kun-Yomi: おお.う、くつがえ.す、くつがえ.る  	Examples: 覆う (おお.う), 覆す (くつがえ.す), 覆る (くつがえ.る)"
smoke	"smoke 	 	煙   	   	Lesson: 41   Frame: 1739   Strokes: 13   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: smoke, hearth fire, old west, soil, dirt, ground 	 	Hearth . . . Old West . . . ground. 	 	 	In the Old West, they used to light fires in the ground to make smoke signals. 	 	On-Yomi: エン   Kun-Yomi: けむ.る、けむり、けむ.い  	Examples: 煙い (けむ.い), 煙る (けむ.る), 煙 (けむり)"
south	"south 	 	南   	   	Lesson: 41   Frame: 1740   Strokes: 9   —   Jouyou Grade: 2   JLPT: 5   	Constituents: south, ten, needle, belt, happiness, ten, needle, stand up, vase, ten2, needle2 	 	Belt . . . happiness. Note how the belt runs through the middle of happiness. 	 	 	South of my belt leads to happiness. 	 	On-Yomi: ナン、ナ   Kun-Yomi: みなみ  	Examples: 南北 (なんぼく), 南端 (なんたん), 指南 (しなん), 南 (みなみ)"
camphor tree	"camphor tree 	 	楠   	   	Lesson: 41   Frame: 1741   Strokes: 13   —   Jouyou Grade: Names   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: camphor tree, tree, wood, south, ten, needle, belt, happiness, ten, needle, stand up, vase, ten2, needle2 	 	Tree . . . south. 	 	 	We traveled to southern Japan just to see a camphor tree. It´s what we came for. 	 	On-Yomi: ナン、ダン、ゼン、ネン   Kun-Yomi: くす、くすのき"
offering	"offering 	 	献   	   	Lesson: 41   Frame: 1742   Strokes: 13   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: offering, south, ten, needle, belt, happiness, ten, needle, stand up, vase, chihuahua, dog, large, drop, ten2, needle2 	 	South . . . chihuahua. 	 	 	A South Korean street vendor is offering chihuahu snacks. 	 	On-Yomi: ケン、コン   Kun-Yomi: たてまつ.る  	Examples: 献上 (けんじょう), 献身的 (けんしんてき), 文献 (ぶんけん)"
gates	"gates 	 	門   	   	Lesson: 42   Frame: 1743   Strokes: 8   —   Jouyou Grade: 2   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: gates 	 	The pictograph of two swinging gates is so clear in this kanji that only its stroke order needs to be memorized. In case you should have any trouble, though, you might doodle with the shapes on a piece of paper, taking care to note the difference in the stroke order of the two facing doors. The gates usually serve as an enclosure, and are written BEFORE whatever it is they enclose. 	  * As a primitive, we shall continue to give it the meaning of gates, but recommend the image of swinging doors (like the kind once common at entrances to saloons) to distinguish it from the primitive for door. 	 	Heisig´s stroke order in the 4th edition (and earlier) is wrong, so be careful -- first is the left-most vertical stroke, then draw the rest of the ""sun"" attachment as you would normally. In fact, if you just wrote it out as two suns with elongated sides, you´ll get the stroke order exactly correct. 	 	On-Yomi: モン   Kun-Yomi: かど、と  	Examples: 門 (かど)"
question	"question 	 	問   	   	Lesson: 42   Frame: 1744   Strokes: 11   —   Jouyou Grade: 3   JLPT: 4   	Constituents: question, gates, mouth 	 	Gates . . . mouth. 	 	 	A mouth on the Gates of Hell says ""Answer me these questions three, or thru the gates ye soon will be"". 	 	On-Yomi: モン   Kun-Yomi: と.う、と.い、とん  	Examples: 問い (と.い), 問う (と.う)"
review	"review 	 	閲   	   	Lesson: 42   Frame: 1745   Strokes: 15   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: review, gates, devil, horns, elder brother, teenager, mouth, human legs 	 	Gates . . . devil. Keep the connotation of this key word distinct from those of inspection (Frame 1174), revise (Frame 362), and perusal (Frame 919). 	 	 	A little devil at the gates of hell reviews your record to see if you´re evil enough to get in. 	 	On-Yomi: エツ   Kun-Yomi: けみ.する"
clique	"clique 	 	閥   	   	Lesson: 42   Frame: 1746   Strokes: 14   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: clique, gates, fell, person, fiesta 	 	Gates . . . fell. 	 	 	You only get through the gates into that person's fiesta if you are in the same clique. 	 	On-Yomi: バツ   Kun-Yomi:"
interval	"interval 	 	間   	   	Lesson: 42   Frame: 1747   Strokes: 12   —   Jouyou Grade: 2   JLPT: 5   	Constituents: interval, gates, sun, day 	 	Gates . . . sun/day. This interval applies to time and space alike, but the latter is better for creating an image. 	 	 	The interval between star systems (suns) was too large, so the stargates were created to travel between them. 	 	On-Yomi: カン、ケン   Kun-Yomi: あいだ、ま、あい  	Examples: 間隔 (かんかく), 中間 (ちゅうかん), 時間 (じかん), 間 (あいだ), 間 (ま)"
simplicity	"simplicity 	 	簡   	   	Lesson: 42   Frame: 1749   Strokes: 18   —   Jouyou Grade: 6   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: simplicity, bamboo, interval, gates, sun, day 	 	Bamboo . . . interval. 	 	 	[simplicity; brevity] The ししおどし is a bamboo device for scaring birds from the gates of your garden by clacking against a stone at regular intervals. Its design is simplicity itself. (Inspired by PepeSeco). 	 	On-Yomi: カン   Kun-Yomi:"
open	"open 	 	開   	   	Lesson: 42   Frame: 1750   Strokes: 12   —   Jouyou Grade: 3   JLPT: 4   	Constituents: open, gates, two hands 	 	Gates . . . two hands. 	 	 	Sure you can squeeze through these gates by kicking them or pushing them with your body, but if you want to get them wide open, you need to do that with both your hands. 	 	On-Yomi: カイ   Kun-Yomi: ひら.く、ひら.き、-びら.き、ひら.ける、あ.く、あ.ける  	Examples: 開く (あ.く), 開ける (あ.ける), 開く (ひら.く), 開ける (ひら.ける)"
closed	"closed 	 	閉   	   	Lesson: 42   Frame: 1751   Strokes: 11   —   Jouyou Grade: 6   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: closed, gates, genie 	 	Gates . . . genie. 	 	 	The gates are too big to be closed by man. Only a genie can. ""Close sesame!"". 	 	On-Yomi: ヘイ   Kun-Yomi: と.じる、と.ざす、し.める、し.まる、た.てる  	Examples: 閉まる (し.まる), 閉める (し.める), 閉ざす (と.ざす), 閉じる (と.じる)"
tower	"tower 	 	閣   	   	Lesson: 42   Frame: 1752   Strokes: 14   —   Jouyou Grade: 6   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: tower, gates, each, walking legs, mouth 	 	Gates . . . each. 	 	 	To keep this distinct from other kanji such as ""watchtower"" and ""pagoda"", I use the mnemonic ""towering tower"". -- In some old 8-bit kung-fu videogame, with a plot similar as Bruce Lee´s last, unfinished movie, the hero must break through a gate at each level of the towering tower, fighting with opponents using various styles of kung-fu until he meets the finale at the topmost level of the ""towering tower"". 	 	On-Yomi: カク   Kun-Yomi:"
leisure	"leisure 	 	閑   	   	Lesson: 42   Frame: 1753   Strokes: 12   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: leisure, gates, tree, wood 	 	Gates . . . tree. 	 	 	Imagine the gates the Garden of Eden, the ultimate land of leisure. You´re not allowed in, but if you peek through you can see trees. 	 	On-Yomi: カン   Kun-Yomi:"
hear	"hear 	 	聞   	   	Lesson: 42   Frame: 1754   Strokes: 14   —   Jouyou Grade: 2   JLPT: 5   	Constituents: hear, gates, ear 	 	Gates . . . ear. Compare the story you invented for the kanji meaning listen (Frame 890). 	 	 	Press your ear to the gates and see if you can hear what is going on inside. 	 	On-Yomi: ブン、モン   Kun-Yomi: き.く、き.こえる  	Examples: 新聞 (しんぶん), 風聞 (ふうぶん), 見聞 (けんぶん), 聞く (き.く), 聞こえる (き.こえる)"
wet	"wet 	 	潤   	   	Lesson: 42   Frame: 1755   Strokes: 15   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: wet, water, water droplets, water pistol, intercalate, gates, king, jewel, ball 	 	Water . . . gates . . . king. 	 	 	Forgetting about the moat, the king stepped out of his gate and landed in the water. Needless to say he got wet. 	 	On-Yomi: ジュン   Kun-Yomi: うるお.う、うるお.す、うる.む  	Examples: 潤む (うる.む), 潤う (うるお.う), 潤す (うるお.す)"
column	"column 	 	欄   	   	Lesson: 42   Frame: 1756   Strokes: 20   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: column, tree, wood, gates, east, tree, wood, sun, day, tree2, wood2 	 	Tree . . . gates . . . east. 	 	 	[column; handrail; blank; space] I think about oriental (eastern) Torii gates: they have two supporting columns made of wood. 	 	On-Yomi: ラン   Kun-Yomi: てすり"
fight	"fight 	 	闘   	   	Lesson: 42   Frame: 1757   Strokes: 18   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: fight, gates, beans, table, one, mouth, glue 	 	Gates . . . table . . . glue. Do not confuse with contend (Frame 1238). 	 	 	During the saloon brawl, one guy got glued to a table and was tossed out through the saloon gates. But he really wanted to fight, so he ran back through those gates (with the table still glued to his back) only to be tossed out again. Imagine him repeatedly running in and being tossed back out. 	 	On-Yomi: トウ   Kun-Yomi: たたか.う、あらそ.う  	Examples: 闘う (たたか.う)"
godown	"godown 	 	倉   	   	Lesson: 42   Frame: 1758   Strokes: 10   —   Jouyou Grade: 4   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: godown, meeting, single gate, umbrella, stable door, mouth 	 	The single gate is used here not in order to represent one gate, but many of them, indeed a meeting of gates. Add mouth (as an entrance here) and you end up with godown. That should help keep this character distinct from warehouse (Frame 633). 	 	 	A godown is a dockside warehouse. This is actually a meeting of large doors and mouths. The stroke order is the same as door, not gates, just with the top stroke moved down into the now larger door. 	 	On-Yomi: ソウ   Kun-Yomi: くら  	Examples: 倉 (くら)"
genesis	"genesis 	 	創   	   	Lesson: 42   Frame: 1759   Strokes: 12   —   Jouyou Grade: 6   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: genesis, godown, meeting, single gate, umbrella, stable door, mouth, sword, sabre, saber 	 	Godown . . . saber. 	 	 	Back in the day the people were so excited to get hold of the Sega genesis they looted the godown with sabers. 	 	On-Yomi: ソウ、ショウ   Kun-Yomi: つく.る、はじ.める、きず、けず.しける"
un-	"un- 	 	非   	   	Lesson: 42   Frame: 1760   Strokes: 8   —   Jouyou Grade: 5   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: un-, jail cell, prison bars 	 	This key word, a negating prefix, is a doodle of a heavy iron pole with bars extending in both directions, to create the picture of a jail cell. From there to ""un-"" is but a short step. 	  * As a primitive, we shall draw on the explanation above for the meaning of jail cell. 	 	This looks like a pictogram of 3 fingers from each hand trying to open up a crack in a wall. That´s an un-believable way to escape from prison OR the UN- have a prison in the Hague. 	 	On-Yomi: ヒ   Kun-Yomi: あら.ず"
haiku	"haiku 	 	俳   	   	Lesson: 42   Frame: 1761   Strokes: 10   —   Jouyou Grade: 6   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: haiku, person, un-, jail cell, prison bars 	 	This character is used for the haiku, the 17-syllable poem that is one of Japan's best-known literary forms. Its elements: person .. . jail cell. 	 	 	I pity the fool/ Who put me in this jail cell/ I pity the fool. (Credit taijuando). 	 	On-Yomi: ハイ   Kun-Yomi:"
repudiate	"repudiate 	 	排   	   	Lesson: 42   Frame: 1762   Strokes: 11   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: repudiate, finger, fingers, un-, jail cell, prison bars 	 	Fingers . . . jail cell. 	 	 	When ordered to go to the jail cell, the defendant gave the judge the finger and said he repudiated all that the legal system stood for if they were going to send an innocent man like him to jail. 	 	On-Yomi: ハイ   Kun-Yomi:"
sad	"sad 	 	悲   	   	Lesson: 42   Frame: 1763   Strokes: 12   —   Jouyou Grade: 3   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: sad, un-, jail cell, prison bars, heart 	 	Jail cell . . . heart. 	 	 	Saddness is like having your heart captured and jailed because of some sad or terrible event, etc. Here the sad heart waits for someone to come and un-lock their jail cell and set them free again. 	 	On-Yomi: ヒ   Kun-Yomi: かな.しい、かな.しむ  	Examples: 悲しい (かな.しい), 悲しむ (かな.しむ)"
guilt	"guilt 	 	罪   	   	Lesson: 42   Frame: 1764   Strokes: 13   —   Jouyou Grade: 5   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: guilt, eye, cross-eyed, net, un-, jail cell, prison bars 	 	Eye . . . jail cell. 	 	 	Guilty under the eyes of the law, therefore sentenced to jail. [note: ´UNDER the eye of the law´ works in penalty (#833) as well.]. 	 	On-Yomi: ザイ   Kun-Yomi: つみ  	Examples: 罪 (つみ)"
comrade	"comrade 	 	輩   	   	Lesson: 42   Frame: 1765   Strokes: 15   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: comrade, un-, jail cell, prison bars, car 	 	Jail cell . . . car. 	 	 	Some man jailed in Russia, is freed by his comrade (from the Communist party perhaps), who crashes into the jail cell with a vehicle. 	 	On-Yomi: ハイ   Kun-Yomi: ともがら、 -ばら、 やかい、 やから"
front door	"front door 	 	扉   	   	Lesson: 42   Frame: 1766   Strokes: 12   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: front door, door, one, ceiling, flag, un-, jail cell, prison bars 	 	Door . . . jail cell. 	 	 	The only way out of a jail cell is to serve your time and walk out the front door. There are no other doors. 	 	On-Yomi: ヒ   Kun-Yomi: とびら  	Examples: 扉 (とびら)"
marquis	"marquis 	 	侯   	   	Lesson: 42   Frame: 1767   Strokes: 9   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: marquis, person, key, dart, drop, heavens 	 	Person . . . key . . . dart. Hint: the pun suggested by the pronunciation of the key word and the primitive for key may come in helpful. 	 	 	Marquis Keydartee (make-believe french name, Key+dart+T). 	 	On-Yomi: コウ   Kun-Yomi:"
climate	"climate 	 	候   	   	Lesson: 42   Frame: 1769   Strokes: 10   —   Jouyou Grade: 4   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: climate, marquis, person, stick, fred astaire, key, dart, drop, heavens 	 	Marquis . . . walking stick. Note where the walking stick is positioned in this kanji. 	 	 	The marquis has absolutely no interest in issuses of climate change. He´s old and near death. [Don´t forget the walking stick to symbolize his old age.]. 	 	On-Yomi: コウ   Kun-Yomi: そうろう  	Examples: 候 (そうろう)"
decide	"decide 	 	決   	   	Lesson: 42   Frame: 1770   Strokes: 7   —   Jouyou Grade: 3   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: decide, water, water droplets, water pistol, guillotine, key, St. Bernard 	 	The etymology of decide (de-cidere = cut off) will help here; the elements are: water . . . guillotine. 	 	 	Decide! ""Decide?! Death by drowning in polluted water or death by guillotine. How can I decide?"" I asked. 	 	On-Yomi: ケツ   Kun-Yomi: き.める、-ぎ.め、き.まる、さ.く  	Examples: 決まる (き.まる), 決める (き.める)"
cheerful	"cheerful 	 	快   	   	Lesson: 42   Frame: 1771   Strokes: 7   —   Jouyou Grade: 5   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: cheerful, Freud, state of mind, guillotine, key, St. Bernard 	 	State of mind . . . guillotine. 	 	 	A large crowd in a cheerful state of mind applaude each criminal as they become victims of the guillotine. 	 	On-Yomi: カイ   Kun-Yomi: こころよ.い  	Examples: 快い (こころよ.い)"
admirable	"admirable 	 	偉   	   	Lesson: 42   Frame: 1772   Strokes: 12   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: admirable, person, locket, stick, key, mouth, monocle, sunglasses with one lens missing 	 	Person . . . locket. 	 	 	LOCKETs often carry inside them a picture of a PERSON we find ADMIRABLE. 	 	On-Yomi: イ   Kun-Yomi: えら.い  	Examples: 偉い (えら.い)"
difference	"difference 	 	違   	   	Lesson: 42   Frame: 1773   Strokes: 13   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: difference, locket, stick, key, mouth, monocle, sunglasses with one lens missing, road 	 	Locket . . . road. 	 	 	You lose your precious locket on the road to somewhere. You ask people if they´ve seen it, but no luck. ""Just buy another one,"" someone says. ""I mean, what´s the difference?"" Then of course you say ""Well, it makes a huge difference!! Since it has sentimental value, I don´t want a different one! "" Then of course they understand. 	 	On-Yomi: イ   Kun-Yomi: ちが.う、ちが.い、ちが.える、-ちが.える、たが.う、たが.える  	Examples: 違う (ちが.う), 違える (ちが.える)"
horizontal	"horizontal 	 	緯   	   	Lesson: 42   Frame: 1774   Strokes: 16   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: horizontal, thread, spiderman, locket, stick, key, mouth, monocle, sunglasses with one lens missing 	 	Thread . . . locket. 	 	 	The thread that holds the locket around my neck is choker-length so it stays horizontal. 	 	On-Yomi: イ   Kun-Yomi: よこいと、ぬき"
defense	"defense 	 	衛   	   	Lesson: 42   Frame: 1775   Strokes: 16   —   Jouyou Grade: 5   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: defence, boulevard, going, locket, stick, key, mouth, monocle, sunglasses with one lens missing 	 	Boulevard . . . locket. Do not confuse with ward off (Frame 1399), protect (Frame 1072), guard (Frame 198), or safeguard (Frame 756). 	 	 	[defense; protection] For ""defense against the dark arts"" class, you go the magical boulevard and buy an enchanted locket. 	 	On-Yomi: エイ、エ   Kun-Yomi:"
Korea	"Korea 	 	韓   	   	Lesson: 42   Frame: 1776   Strokes: 18   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT:    	Constituents: korea, mist, ten, needle, early, sun, day, locket, stick, key, mouth, monocle, sunglasses with one lens missing, ten2, needle2 	 	As with Italy (Frame 1245) and Africa (Frame 1391), this character simply abbreviates the full name of Korea. Its elements: mist . . . locket. 	 	 	There´s a young Korean male actor, Yon-sama, famous amongst middle-aged Japanese women. Extremely famous. Read about his affect on Japan/Korean relations on Everything2.com. In any case, women just flipped over this guy, traveled to Korea to see his home, started taking Korean language classes, etc. So, imagine here the misty eyes of the Japanese women as they clutch their lockets with Yon-sama´s picture inside watching his Korean romantic mini series called ""Winter Sonata"". 	 	On-Yomi: カン   Kun-Yomi: から、いげた"
dry	"dry 	 	干   	   	Lesson: 43   Frame: 1777   Strokes: 3   —   Jouyou Grade: 6   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: dry, clothesline 	 	It is best to see this kanji as a pictograph of a revolving circular clothesline (viewed from the side). Spin it around quickly in your mind's eye to give it the connotation of to dry. 	  * The primitive meaning is clothesline. 	 	Dry one item in ten minutes on the clothesline. 	 	On-Yomi: カン   Kun-Yomi: ほ.す、ほ.し-、-ぼ.し、ひ.る  	Examples: 干る (ひ.る), 干す (ほ.す)"
liver	"liver 	 	肝   	   	Lesson: 43   Frame: 1778   Strokes: 7   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: liver, moon, month, flesh, part of the body, dry, clothesline 	 	Part of the body . . . dry. 	 	 	Well you all know that the liver is the part of the body that would be quite grateful if you led a dry lifestyle (i.e. no alcohol). 	 	On-Yomi: カン   Kun-Yomi: きも  	Examples: 肝 (きも)"
publish	"publish 	 	刊   	   	Lesson: 43   Frame: 1779   Strokes: 5   —   Jouyou Grade: 5   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: publish, dry, clothesline, sword, sabre, saber 	 	Dry . . . saber. 	 	 	The newspaper pages are hung on the clotheseline to dry and then cut down with a sabre to be published. 	 	On-Yomi: カン   Kun-Yomi:"
sweat	"sweat 	 	汗   	   	Lesson: 43   Frame: 1780   Strokes: 6   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: sweat, water, water droplets, water pistol, dry, clothesline 	 	Water . . . dry. 	 	 	The way sweat is supposed to work: it gets your skin wet, and then as it evaporates/dries, it cools you off. 	 	On-Yomi: カン   Kun-Yomi: あせ  	Examples: 汗 (あせ)"
flats	"flats 	 	軒   	   	Lesson: 43   Frame: 1781   Strokes: 10   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: flats, car, dry, clothesline 	 	This kanji, a counter for houses, is made up of cars . . . dry. 	 	 	Flats in the city are crowded. You get a space for your car in front, and a clothesline out back. Nothing else. 	 	On-Yomi: ケン   Kun-Yomi: のき  	Examples: 軒 (のき)"
beach	"beach 	 	岸   	   	Lesson: 43   Frame: 1782   Strokes: 8   —   Jouyou Grade: 3   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: beach, mountain, cliff, dry, clothesline 	 	Mountain . . . cliff . . . dry. 	 	 	At the base of mountain cliffs, there is usually a beach. You often can see people lying there, drying off after a swim. 	 	On-Yomi: ガン   Kun-Yomi: きし  	Examples: 岸 (きし)"
tree trunk	"tree trunk 	 	幹   	   	Lesson: 43   Frame: 1783   Strokes: 13   —   Jouyou Grade: 5   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: tree trunk, mist, ten, needle, early, sun, day, umbrella, dry, clothesline, ten2, needle2 	 	Mist . . . umbrella . . . dry. The meaning of this key word extends beyond tree trunks to represent the main stem or line of anything from railway lines to managerial staffs. This should help distinguish it from the stories used earlier for book (Frame 224) and body (Frame 1030), both of which made use of the image of a tree trunk, as well as the kanji for trunk (Frame 194). 	 	 	A fine mist is falling, and so everyone gathers around near the tree-trunk, effectively using the rest of the tree as an umbrella in order to keep dry. 	 	On-Yomi: カン   Kun-Yomi: みき  	Examples: 幹 (みき)"
potato	"potato 	 	芋   	   	Lesson: 43   Frame: 1784   Strokes: 6   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: potato, flowers, potato 	 	Flowers . . . potato. 	 	 	If your potatos are growing flowers and those little hooked roots, you should either buy less or eat them faster. 	 	On-Yomi: ウ   Kun-Yomi: いも  	Examples: 芋 (いも)"
eaves	"eaves 	 	宇   	   	Lesson: 43   Frame: 1785   Strokes: 6   —   Jouyou Grade: 6   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: eaves, house, potato 	 	House . . . potato. 	 	 	Under the eaves of the house the poor family has potate plants. 	 	On-Yomi: ウ   Kun-Yomi:"
too much	"too much 	 	余   	   	Lesson: 43   Frame: 1786   Strokes: 7   —   Jouyou Grade: 5   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: too much, umbrella, potato, small 	 	Umbrella . . . potato . . . little. The last stroke of potato and the first of little coincide in this character. 	  * Since the phrase ""too much"" is overly abstract, we shall take the image of a scale whose indicator spins round and round on the dial because too much weight has been set on it. It will help to use this image in learning the kanji itself. 	 	You hang an umbrella upside-down on a hook of the scales and fill it with little potatoes. No luck: it weights too much. 	 	On-Yomi: ヨ   Kun-Yomi: あま.る、あま.り、あま.す、あんま.り  	Examples: 余す (あま.す), 余る (あま.る)"
exclude	"exclude 	 	除   	   	Lesson: 43   Frame: 1787   Strokes: 10   —   Jouyou Grade: 6   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: exclude, pinnacle, parthenon, acropolis, scales, too much, umbrella, potato, small 	 	Pinnacle . . . scale. 	 	 	You won´t make it unless you exclude something. The climb to the pinacle cannot be completed if you are carrying too much. You just have to decide what you can afford to exclude. 	 	On-Yomi: ジョ、ジ   Kun-Yomi: のぞ.く、-よ.け  	Examples: 除外 (じょがい), 除数 (じょすう), 解除 (かいじょ), 除く (のぞ.く)"
gradually	"gradually 	 	徐   	   	Lesson: 43   Frame: 1788   Strokes: 10   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: gradually, Nelson, column, going, line, scales, too much, umbrella, potato, small 	 	Line . . . scale. 	 	 	You can´t expect weight loss to happen overnight. You should limit going to the scale to weigh yourself to once a day or once a week, in order to observe the anticipated weight loss gradually. 	 	On-Yomi: ジョ   Kun-Yomi: おもむ.ろに"
confer	"confer 	 	叙   	   	Lesson: 43   Frame: 1789   Strokes: 9   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: confer, scales, too much, umbrella, potato, small, crotch 	 	Scale . . crotch. The key word has to do with conferring ranks, titles, and awards. It should not be confused with bestow (Frame 1335) or impart (Frame 795). 	 	 	Amazed at the weight of his crotch, they conferred every honor upon him. (Image: guy with his junk on a scale getting a medal pinned to his chest/around his neck/being knighted, etc.). 	 	On-Yomi: ジョ   Kun-Yomi: つい.ず、ついで"
route	"route 	 	途   	   	Lesson: 43   Frame: 1790   Strokes: 10   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: route, scales, too much, umbrella, potato, small, road 	 	Scale . . . road. 	 	 	On this route, all trucks have to check in at the scales before they can get on the road. 	 	On-Yomi: ト   Kun-Yomi: みち"
diagonal	"diagonal 	 	斜   	   	Lesson: 43   Frame: 1791   Strokes: 11   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: diagonal, scales, too much, umbrella, potato, small, mmeasuring cup, big dipper, The Plough, drop, ten, needle 	 	Scale . . . measuring cup. 	 	 	The main bar of an old-fashioned scale(balance) will be very diagonal if you place a giant measuring cup on one side. 	 	On-Yomi: シャ   Kun-Yomi: なな.め、はす  	Examples: 斜め (なな.め)"
paint	"paint 	 	塗   	   	Lesson: 43   Frame: 1792   Strokes: 13   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: paint, water, water droplets, water pistol, scales, too much, umbrella, potato, small, soil, dirt, ground 	 	Water . . . scale . . . ground. 	 	 	If you add too much water to the paint it will drip onto the ground. 	 	On-Yomi: ト   Kun-Yomi: ぬ.る、ぬ.り、まみ.れる  	Examples: 塗る (ぬ.る)"
bundle	"bundle 	 	束   	   	Lesson: 43   Frame: 1793   Strokes: 7   —   Jouyou Grade: 4   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: bundle, Chaplin, tree, wood, mouth 	 	In the same way that we were able to see the sun in the tree within the kanji for east, here we see a square container in the shape of a mouth. 	 	 	Mnemonic: Bundle of joy. Here I see the proverbial stork with a baby hanging from its mouth fly straight into a tree. Painful, but he doesn´t drop the bundle. 	 	On-Yomi: ソク   Kun-Yomi: たば、たば.ねる、つか、つか.ねる  	Examples: 束 (たば)"
trust	"trust 	 	頼   	   	Lesson: 43   Frame: 1794   Strokes: 16   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: trust, bundle, Chaplin, tree, wood, mouth, head, page, one, ceiling, drop, shellfish, clam, oyster, eye, animal legs, eight 	 	Bundle . . . head. 	 	 	When you trust in something, you've got your head 頁 all bundled 束 up (wrapped up) in it. 	 	On-Yomi: ライ   Kun-Yomi: たの.む、たの.もしい、たよ.る  	Examples: 頼む (たの.む), 頼もしい (たの.もしい), 頼る (たよ.る)"
rapids	"rapids 	 	瀬   	   	Lesson: 43   Frame: 1795   Strokes: 19   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: rapids, water, water droplets, water pistol, trust, bundle, Chaplin, tree, wood, mouth, head, page, one, ceiling, drop, shellfish, clam, oyster, eye, animal legs, eight 	 	Water . . . bundle . . . head. 	 	 	You need complete trust in your water guide to attempt Class 5 rapids. 	 	On-Yomi: ライ   Kun-Yomi: せ  	Examples: 瀬 (せ)"
imperial order	"imperial order 	 	勅   	   	Lesson: 43   Frame: 1796   Strokes: 9   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: imperial order, bundle, Chaplin, tree, wood, mouth, power, muscle, arnold 	 	In order to keep this character distinct from that for an imperial edict (Frame 366), we must draw again on a pun. Think of the order here as a mail order or an order of pizza phoned in by the Emperor for delivery to the imperial palace. Then it will not be hard to put together bundle and muscle to form a story about an imperial order. 	 	 	This is an imperial order for pizza. To deliver the huge bundle of pizzas to the emperor, the pizza boy needs huge muscles. 	 	On-Yomi: チョク   Kun-Yomi: いまし.める、みことのり"
alienate	"alienate 	 	疎   	   	Lesson: 43   Frame: 1797   Strokes: 12   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: alienate, zoo, critters, stop, footprint, bundle, Chaplin, tree, wood, mouth 	 	Zoo . . . bundle. Note that the element for zoo is flattened out on the left just as leg (Frame 1372) had been. This is the only time we will meet this form in this book. 	 	 	[True story] In Osaka the homeless (the alienated) live in large numbers around the city zoo. Picture them in winter all bundled up in rags trying to keep warm, alienated from the society, living literally worst than the animals in the zoo who at least are bundled in their natural furs and have pens to live in sheltered from the elements. 	 	On-Yomi: ソ、ショ   Kun-Yomi: うと.い、うと.む、まば.ら  	Examples: 疎い (うと.い), 疎む (うと.む)"
quick	"quick 	 	速   	   	Lesson: 43   Frame: 1799   Strokes: 10   —   Jouyou Grade: 3   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: quick, bundle, Chaplin, tree, wood, mouth, road 	 	Bundle . . . road. 	 	 	Jack be nimble, Jack be quick, Jack jump over the bundled sticks in the middle of the road. (dingomick). 	 	On-Yomi: ソク   Kun-Yomi: はや.い、はや-、はや.める、すみ.やか  	Examples: 速やか (すみ.やか), 速い (はや.い), 速める (はや.める)"
organize	"organize 	 	整   	   	Lesson: 43   Frame: 1800   Strokes: 16   —   Jouyou Grade: 3   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: organise, bundle, Chaplin, tree, wood, mouth, taskmaster, correct, one, ceiling, stop, footprint 	 	Bundle . . . taskmaster . . . correct. 	 	 	Recycling in Japan, you have to make sure all your bundles are organized correctly otherwise the taskmasters won´t accept them. 	 	On-Yomi: セイ   Kun-Yomi: ととの.える、ととの.う  	Examples: 整う (ととの.う), 整える (ととの.える)"
saber	"saber 	 	剣   	   	Lesson: 43   Frame: 1801   Strokes: 10   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: sabre, saber, awl, fit, meeting, umbrella, mouth, person, sword, sabre, saber 	 	Awl . . . saber. As we promised way back in frame 87, here at last is the kanji on which the primitive element of the same name is based. 	 	 	If it helps, make the awl primitive ice pick instead. They´re basically the same thing. This kanji is an easy David vs. Goliath story of the icepick vs. the saber... 	 	On-Yomi: ケン   Kun-Yomi: つるぎ  	Examples: 剣 (つるぎ)"
precipitous	"precipitous 	 	険   	   	Lesson: 43   Frame: 1802   Strokes: 11   —   Jouyou Grade: 5   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: precipitous, pinnacle, parthenon, acropolis, awl, fit, meeting, umbrella, mouth, person 	 	Pinnacle . . . awl. 	 	 	The rock climber trying to get up to the pinnacle is dangling from a precipitous edge, hanging only one with his icepick. 	 	On-Yomi: ケン   Kun-Yomi: けわ.しい  	Examples: 険しい (けわ.しい)"
examination	"examination 	 	検   	   	Lesson: 43   Frame: 1803   Strokes: 12   —   Jouyou Grade: 5   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: examination, tree, wood, awl, fit, meeting, umbrella, mouth, person 	 	Tree . . . awl. 	 	 	After intense cross-examination from the prosecutor, the tree confessed to murdering the wood-pecker with an awl... ""He just kept at it, he kept poking at me with that beak, so I thought I'd see how HE liked it!!"" The autopsy examination revealed at least a dozen puncture wounds, what a brutal case. 	 	On-Yomi: ケン   Kun-Yomi: しら.べる"
frugal	"frugal 	 	倹   	   	Lesson: 43   Frame: 1804   Strokes: 10   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: frugal, person, awl, fit, meeting, umbrella, mouth, person, person2 	 	Person . . . awl. 	 	 	Mr. T is as frugal as they come. He uses his one ice pick for everything: to eat, pick his teeth, clean his toilet, kill people, cook, etc. 	 	On-Yomi: ケン   Kun-Yomi: つま.しい、つづまやか"
heavy	"heavy 	 	重   	   	Lesson: 43   Frame: 1805   Strokes: 9   —   Jouyou Grade: 3   JLPT: 4   	Constituents: heavy, thousand, computer, rice field, brains, soil, dirt, ground 	 	Thousand . . . ri. Note how the long vertical stroke doubles up to serve both elements. 	 	 	The first computer in the world was as heavy as thousand computers are now. 	 	On-Yomi: ジュウ、チョウ   Kun-Yomi: え、おも.い、おも.り、おも.なう、かさ.ねる、かさ.なる、おも  	Examples: 重量 (じゅうりょう), 重大 (じゅうだい), 二重 (にじゅう), 重 (え), 重い (おも.い), 重なる (かさ.なる), 重ねる (かさ.ねる)"
move	"move 	 	動   	   	Lesson: 43   Frame: 1806   Strokes: 11   —   Jouyou Grade: 3   JLPT: 4   	Constituents: move, heavy, thousand, ri, computer, power, muscle, arnold 	 	Heavy . . . muscle. 	 	 	Even though the furniture is heavy, it´ll be easy to move with all the muscles that he has. 	 	On-Yomi: ドウ   Kun-Yomi: うご.く、うご.かす  	Examples: 動かす (うご.かす), 動く (うご.く)"
meritorious deed	"meritorious deed 	 	勲   	   	Lesson: 43   Frame: 1808   Strokes: 15   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: meritorious deed, move, heavy, thousand, ri, computer, power, muscle, arnold, oven-fire, barbecue 	 	Move . . . oven fire. So as not to confuse this kanji with the general character for merit (Frame 1369), you may associate the key word with military decorations and medals of distinction, both of which it is used for. 	 	 	A meritorious deed? Like moving a damsel in distress out of a fire, maybe. 	 	On-Yomi: クン   Kun-Yomi: いさお"
work	"work 	 	働   	   	Lesson: 43   Frame: 1809   Strokes: 13   —   Jouyou Grade: 4   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: work, person, move, heavy, thousand, ri, computer, power, muscle, arnold 	 	Person . . . move. Do not confuse with labor (Frame 924). 	 	 	A person who moves something is doing work, physically speaking. 	 	On-Yomi: ドウ、リュク、リキ、ロク、リョク   Kun-Yomi: はたら.く  	Examples: 働く (はたら.く)"

Two heavy trucks in a game of chicken collide while racing toward each other on the boulevard. 	 	On-Yomi: ショウ   Kun-Yomi: つ.く"

Well you take some FLOWERS, compress them with a HEAVY weight, and put them on an OVEN FIRE for a while... (cmp perfume (#493)). 	 	On-Yomi: クン   Kun-Yomi: かお.る  	Examples: 薫る (かお.る)"

Caveman got ill after flying third class. The cabin air and food got to him. (Primitive: these all got MUCH easier when using CAVEMAN instead. ). Once you have all the symptoms right, you have correctly identified the sickness. 	 	On-Yomi: ショウ   Kun-Yomi:"
rapidly	"rapidly 	 	疾   	   	Lesson: 44   Frame: 1819   Strokes: 10   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: rapidly, sickness, hospital, dart, drop, heavens 	 	Be sure to keep this character distinct from quick (Frame 1799) and swift (Frame 298). Picture a succession of poison darts (the sort that inflict sickness) flying out rapid-fire from a blowgun, so that ""rapid-fire"" can conjure up the proper image. 	 	 	I picture a sick caveman, and two people rapidly blowing darts at him. One is blowing poison darts, the other is blowing antidote darts. Will the sick caveman live or die? Depends on how rapidly they fire. 	 	On-Yomi: シツ   Kun-Yomi: はや.い"

For a country full of pay-per-use public toilets, sudden diarrhea is certainly the most profitable sickness! 	 	On-Yomi: リ   Kun-Yomi:"

Sickness-missiles are being engineered by bio-terrorists to spread epidemics all over the world. Imagine seeing footage of a place where those sickness-missiles are built : rows after rows of missiles, and if you look closely on each is inscribed in tiny letters the name of different sickness such as ""flu"", ""plague"", etc. 	 	On-Yomi: エキ、ヤク   Kun-Yomi:   	Examples: 疫病 (えきびょう), 悪疫 (あくえき), 防疫 (ぼうえき)"

Think of the phrase pain in the xxx. Then think of a pogostick up your xxx. That's painful, right? The real question is why a pogostick is up your xxx. That's sick, dude. 	 	On-Yomi: ツウ   Kun-Yomi: いた.い、いた.む、いた.ましい、いた.める  	Examples: 痛い (いた.い), 痛む (いた.む), 痛める (いた.める)"

Caveman has a bad mannerism of putting ketchup on everything he eats. I guess that´s ok since raw mammoth can´t be too good... 	 	On-Yomi: ヘキ   Kun-Yomi: くせ、くせ.に  	Examples: 癖 (くせ)"
hide	"hide 	 	匿   	   	Lesson: 44   Frame: 1827   Strokes: 10   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: hide, box, young, flowers, right, by one’s side, mouth 	 	Box . . . young. 	 	 	Young kids likes to hide in cardboard boxes. (Primitive: CARDBOARD BOX, especially kids playing with them.). 	 	On-Yomi: トク   Kun-Yomi: かくま.う"

Hint: Artisan/Ax Def: An artisan is a skilled manual worker; a craftsperson. Here we see his tools represented by the artisan's ax stored in his toolbox. 	 	On-Yomi: ショウ   Kun-Yomi: たくみ"
doctor	"doctor 	 	医   	   	Lesson: 44   Frame: 1829   Strokes: 7   —   Jouyou Grade: 3   JLPT: 4   	Constituents: doctor, box, dart, drop, heavens 	 	Box . . . dart. 	 	 	Easily confused: Dr. (#47), doctor (#1694), examination (#1673), check-up (#1724), medicine (#1736). To avoid confusion I renamed this medic, and picture the medic from Team Fortress 2 returning to his box of darts in the supply cupboard every time his syringe gun is empty. equal	"equal 	 	匹   	   	Lesson: 44   Frame: 1830   Strokes: 4   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: equal, box, human legs 	 	Box . . . human legs. 	 	 	This kanji is used commonly as a counter for small animals. This is a pictograph of a SMALL ANIMAL´S view from inside a CARDBOARD BOX looking out at his masters HUMAN LEGS. He´s probably hiding so the master does not COUNT him with the other animals which will probably be eaten (thus he avoids everyones EQUAL fate on the farm: the kitchen table). 	 	On-Yomi: ヒツ   Kun-Yomi: ひき  	Examples: 匹 (ひき)"
ward	"ward 	 	区   	   	Lesson: 44   Frame: 1831   Strokes: 4   —   Jouyou Grade: 3   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: ward, box, sheaf 	 	The ward referred to here is a subdivision of a large city. Its elements: box . . . sheaves. When used as a primitive element, it may be helpful at times to break it up into these same composite elements. 	 	 	In the homeless ward of the city you see people sleeping in CARDBOARD BOXES using a SHEAF as a pillow. 	 	On-Yomi: ク、オウ、コウ   Kun-Yomi:"
hinge	"hinge 	 	枢   	   	Lesson: 44   Frame: 1832   Strokes: 8   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: hinge, tree, wood, ward, box, sheaf 	 	Tree . . . ward. 	 	 	Make sure you install the hinge the right way. If it opens treeward (= tree ward), you won't be able to get the fence open, make sure it opens houseward. 	 	On-Yomi: スウ、シュ   Kun-Yomi: とぼそ、からくり"
assault	"assault 	 	殴   	   	Lesson: 44   Frame: 1833   Strokes: 8   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: assault, ward, box, sheaf, missile, cruise missile, wind, crotch 	 	Ward . . . missile. 	 	 	The biggest assault on Japan during WW2 is when the wards in Hiroshima and Nagasaki were wiped out by nuclear missiles. 	 	On-Yomi: オウ   Kun-Yomi: なぐ.る  	Examples: 殴る (なぐ.る)"
Europe	"Europe 	 	欧   	   	Lesson: 44   Frame: 1834   Strokes: 8   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: europe, ward, box, sheaf, lack, yawn 	 	Ward . . . yawn. Like the kanji of frame 1776, this character is an abbreviation of the name of a geographical region. 	 	 	Do japanese consider Europe like just a ward, boring enough to make them yawn?? This kanji is offensive! 	 	On-Yomi: オウ   Kun-Yomi: うた.う、は.く"

They would repress dissents by cutting off their fingers and mailing them to relatives in small boxes (of course including stamps for proper postage). Its elements: person . . . box . . . stamps. 	 	 	Mr T with the post package at the post office: ´these stamps don´t stick to the box, foo´ Postguy:´ Try it again but this time with the stamp, face-up.´. Welcome home daddy! Is that box for me? You were on the road a long time! I collected all the stamps from the letters you wrote me　:-) ...　　RTK2:　ゲイ　歓迎　かんげい(welcome). ascend	"ascend 	 	登   	   	Lesson: 44   Frame: 1838   Strokes: 12   —   Jouyou Grade: 3   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: ascend, teepee, wigwam, beans, table, one, mouth 	 	Teepee . . . table. Do not confuse with rise up (Frame 43). 	 	 	When an American Indian warrior dies, his body is placed on a TABLE inside a TEEPEE, and a ritualistic ceremony is held to encourage his spirit to ASCEND to that big buffalo hunting ground in the sky. 	 	On-Yomi: トウ、ト、ドウ、ショウ、チョウ   Kun-Yomi: のぼ.る、あ.がる  	Examples: 登壇 (とうだん), 登校 (とうこう), 登記 (とうき), 登る (のぼ.る)"
lucidity	"lucidity 	 	澄   	   	Lesson: 44   Frame: 1839   Strokes: 15   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: lucidity, water, water droplets, water pistol, ascend, teepee, wigwam, beans, table, one, mouth 	 	Water . . . ascend. 	 	 	Scuba divers know that when you ascend in the water, your lucidity increases (For non-divers, the deeper you go, the more you become mentally impaired by nitrogen narcosis, every 50 feet is like drinking one martini). Scuba divers also know that as you ascend in the water, the lucidity of the water improves, too. 	 	On-Yomi: チョウ   Kun-Yomi: す.む、す.ます、-す.ます  	Examples: 澄ます (す.ます), 澄む (す.む)"
discharge	"discharge 	 	発   	   	Lesson: 44   Frame: 1840   Strokes: 9   —   Jouyou Grade: 3   JLPT: 4   	Constituents: discharge, teepee, wigwam, two, human legs 	 	This key word refers to the discharging of guns, trains, people, and even words. The elements: teepee . . . two . . . human legs. Contrast the writing with frame 63. 	 	 	Two pairs of human legs poking out of a teepee: you know there´ll be a discharge soon, be it sexual, violent (husband returns home with a weapon), or dishonourable (soldier caught molesting a native), or perhaps all of the above. 	 	On-Yomi: ハツ、ホツ   Kun-Yomi: た.つ、あば.く、おこ.る、つか.わす、はな.つ  	Examples: 発明 (はつめい), 発射 (はっしゃ), 突発 (とっぱつ)"
abolish	"abolish 	 	廃   	   	Lesson: 44   Frame: 1841   Strokes: 12   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: abolish, cave, dicharge, teepee, wigwam, two, human legs 	 	Cave . . . discharge. 	 	 	Slaves have been discharged from the caves where they were kept thanks to the abolition of slavery. 	 	On-Yomi: ハイ   Kun-Yomi: すた.れる、すた.る  	Examples: 廃る (すた.る), 廃れる (すた.れる)"
colleague	"colleague 	 	僚   	   	Lesson: 44   Frame: 1842   Strokes: 14   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: colleague, person, pup tent, large, St. Bernard, sun, day, small, little 	 	Person . . . pup tent. Choose some connotation of the key word that will keep it distinct for you from companion (Frame 19), friend (Frame 760), consort (Frame 1287), and comrade (Frame 1765). 	 	 	A colleague implies someone that you share work with, such as in your company or profession, etc. Here your colleague helps you to erect your pup tent during a company outing. Note: Heisig's warning to keep this distinct from other similiar kanji such as companion (#19), friend (#704), consort (#1203) and comrade (#1637). That is why I chose to have the person element pictured as someone (the colleague in this case) helping with the work of building the pup tent. 	 	On-Yomi: リョウ   Kun-Yomi:"
dormitory	"dormitory 	 	寮   	   	Lesson: 44   Frame: 1844   Strokes: 15   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: dormitory, house, pup tent, large, St. Bernard, sun, day, small, little 	 	House . . . pup tent. 	 	 	A dormitory is right in the middle between living in a house and living in a pup tent. 	 	On-Yomi: リョウ   Kun-Yomi:"
heal	"heal 	 	療   	   	Lesson: 44   Frame: 1845   Strokes: 17   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: heal, sickness, hospital, pup tent, large, St. Bernard, sun, day, small, little 	 	Sickness . . . pup tent. 	 	 	On the battlefield, the only place to heal from your sickness is inside the medic's pup tent. Think of M.A.S.H. 	 	On-Yomi: リョウ   Kun-Yomi:"
carve	"carve 	 	彫   	   	Lesson: 45   Frame: 1846   Strokes: 11   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: carve, circumference, running track, glass hood, earthenware jar, lidded crock, soil, dirt, ground, mouth, shape 	 	The two primitives here, circumference and shape, belong naturally to the special connotations that differentiate carving from engraving (see frame 1639). 	 	 	A lathe is used to carve a shape with circumference into wood or metal. 	 	On-Yomi: チョウ   Kun-Yomi: ほ.る、-ぼ.り  	Examples: 彫る (ほ.る)"
shape	"shape 	 	形   	   	Lesson: 45   Frame: 1847   Strokes: 7   —   Jouyou Grade: 2   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: shape, two hands, shape 	 	Two hands . . . shape. 	 	 	Everyone in the kindergarten came up with fun and interesting shapes made out of Play-Doh, except for the kid with the amputated arm. Seems like you really need both hands. 	 	On-Yomi: ケイ、ギョウ   Kun-Yomi: かた、-がた、かたち、なり  	Examples: 形態 (けいたい), 形成 (けいせい), 図形 (ずけい), 形 (かた), 形 (かたち)"
shadow	"shadow 	 	影   	   	Lesson: 45   Frame: 1848   Strokes: 15   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: shadow, scenery, sun, day, capital, tall, top hat, mouth, small, little, shape 	 	Scenery . . . shape. 	 	 	The sun over the capital cast a shadow with the same shape. 	 	On-Yomi: エイ   Kun-Yomi: かげ  	Examples: 影 (かげ)"
cedar	"cedar 	 	杉   	   	Lesson: 45   Frame: 1849   Strokes: 7   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: cedar, tree, wood, shape 	 	Tree . . . shape. 	 	 	Cedar is an evergreen tree that keeps its SHAPE all year long. That is, it doesn´t loose its needles/leaves in the winter. 	 	On-Yomi: サン   Kun-Yomi: すぎ  	Examples: 杉 (すぎ)"
coloring	"coloring 	 	彩   	   	Lesson: 45   Frame: 1850   Strokes: 11   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: coloring, claw, vulture, grab, tree, wood, shape 	 	Vulture . . . tree . . . shape. 	 	 	In Sydney we occasionally get exotic birds. You first notice a colouring in a tree. You look more carefully and you make out the shape of a bird (here represented by its claws). 	 	On-Yomi: サイ   Kun-Yomi: いろど.る  	Examples: 彩る (いろど.る)"
patent	"patent 	 	彰   	   	Lesson: 45   Frame: 1851   Strokes: 14   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: patent, badge, vase, stand up, sunflower, early, sun, day, ten, needle, shape 	 	Badge . . . shape. The key word is synonymous with ""clear"" or ""openly expressed."" 	 	 	The shape of a sheriff´s badge makes it patent who he is. 	 	On-Yomi: ショウ   Kun-Yomi:"
lad	"lad 	 	彦   	   	Lesson: 45   Frame: 1852   Strokes: 9   —   Jouyou Grade: Names   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: lad, vase, stand up, cliff, shape 	 	Vase . . . cliff . . . shape. 	 	 	A lad standing on the top of a cliff, looking into the far, and thinking how to shape his future. 	 	On-Yomi: ゲン   Kun-Yomi: ひこ"
face	"face 	 	顔   	   	Lesson: 45   Frame: 1853   Strokes: 18   —   Jouyou Grade: 2   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: face, lad, vase, stand up, cliff, shape, head, page, one, ceiling, drop, shellfish, clam, oyster, eye, animal legs, eight 	 	Lad . . . head. 	 	 	A lad's head still has a baby's face. 	 	On-Yomi: ガン   Kun-Yomi: かお  	Examples: 顔 (かお)"
ought	"ought 	 	須   	   	Lesson: 45   Frame: 1854   Strokes: 12   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: ought, shape, head, page, one, ceiling, drop, shellfish, clam, oyster, eye, animal legs, eight 	 	Shape . . . head. This is the only time that shape is placed to the left of its relative element, the head. 	 	 	Why, I OUGHT to RESHAPE your HEAD... 	 	On-Yomi: ス、シュ   Kun-Yomi: すべから.く、すべし、ひげ、まつ、もち.いる、もと.める"
swell	"swell 	 	膨   	   	Lesson: 45   Frame: 1855   Strokes: 16   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: swell, moon, month, flesh, part of the body, drum, samurai, beans, table, one, mouth, shape 	 	Part of the body . . . drum . . . shape. Compare expand (Frame 1199). 	 	 	This kanji does not mean swell as in a inflammation. There is a different kanji for that meaning (腫れる). This kanji means swell as in, a tire swelling/expanding, your income swelling/expanding, dough swelling/expanding, etc. Johnskb's story is best b/c it does not involve swelling in the sense of inflammation, just general expansion of the stomach. STORY: ""If a PART OF your BODY begins to SWELL/EXPAND and resembles the SHAPE of a bass DRUM, you’re either pregnant or in desperate need of a diet."". 	 	On-Yomi: ボウ   Kun-Yomi: ふく.らむ、ふく.れる  	Examples: 膨らむ (ふく.らむ), 膨れる (ふく.れる)"
visit	"visit 	 	参   	   	Lesson: 45   Frame: 1856   Strokes: 8   —   Jouyou Grade: 4   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: nonplussed, visit, elbow, large, St. Bernard, shape 	 	Elbow . . . St. Bernard dog . . . shape. 	 	 	I´m going to visit my grandpa in the hospital. He broke his elbow, and it became really big and contorted into a weird shape. I hope he will be all right! 	 	On-Yomi: サン、シン   Kun-Yomi: まい.る、まい-、まじわる、みつ  	Examples: 参る (まい.る)"

Whenever I have to visit the relatives... that puts me in one hell of a wretched state of mind. 	 	On-Yomi: サン、ザン   Kun-Yomi: みじ.め、いた.む、むご.い  	Examples: 惨劇 (さんげき), 悲惨 (ひさん), 陰惨 (いんさん), 惨め (みじ.め)"

Mr. T is a harsh taskmaster who will discipline you (beat you into shape) with his walking stick. rare	"rare 	 	珍   	   	Lesson: 45   Frame: 1859   Strokes: 9   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: rare, king, jewel, ball, parasol, umbrella, shape 	 	Jewel . . . umbrella . . . shape. 	 	 	It's rare to see the king carrying his own parasol - typically he gets one of his attendants to do it for him (thanks to Katsuo for umbrella + shape = parasol and to Peppi for the story idea). checkup	"checkup 	 	診   	   	Lesson: 45   Frame: 1860   Strokes: 12   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: check up, say, words, keitai, mouth, parasol, umbrella, shape 	 	Words . . . umbrella . . . shape. The key word refers to a medical examination. 	 	 	At my last check-up, the doctor said to me: ""Start carrying a parasol, or you might get skin cancer. You've been tanning too much!"" [Umbrella over shape = parasol]. 	 	On-Yomi: シン   Kun-Yomi: み.る  	Examples: 診る (み.る)"
sentence	"sentence 	 	文   	   	Lesson: 45   Frame: 1861   Strokes: 4   —   Jouyou Grade: 1   JLPT: 4   	Constituents: sentence, plaid, kilt, Billy Connolly 	 	Under the familiar top hat we see a crisscross pattern or design, like that found on woodwork or garments. This should make an ugly enough image to help remember it. It can be associated with sentence by thinking of a sentence as a grammatical pattern. 	  * The primitive meaning for this character will be plaid, the familiar crisscross pattern frequently used in textiles. 	 	A twist on greenapple: The teacher puts a tophat on all pupils with gramatically correct sentences, while the rest are left with a big red X on their homework. 	 	On-Yomi: ブン、モン   Kun-Yomi: ふみ、あや  	Examples: 文学 (ぶんがく), 文化 (ぶんか), 作文 (さくぶん), 文 (ふみ)"

When sitting vis-a-vis, Scots will glue their kilt down to avoid embaressment. 	 	On-Yomi: タイ、ツイ   Kun-Yomi: あいて、こた.える、そろ.い、つれあ.い、なら.ぶ、むか.う  	Examples: 対立 (たいりつ), 絶対 (ぜったい), 反対 (はんたい)"

Do not confuse with just so (Frame 414). 	 	 	The Scotsman goalkeeper adjusted himself. He reached down and adjusted the two things between his skinny fencepost legs. Think of this as a dose of medicine. 	 	 	When my medicine dose is way too large, I adjust it by cutting it into smaller pieces with my saber. 	 	On-Yomi: ザイ、スイ、セイ   Kun-Yomi: かる、けず.る"
finish	"finish 	 	済   	   	Lesson: 45   Frame: 1868   Strokes: 11   —   Jouyou Grade: 6   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: finish, water, water droplets, water pistol, adjust, adjusted, sentence, plaid, kilt, Billy Connolly, two, fenceposts, cabers 	 	Water . . . adjust. Do not confuse with complete (Frame 101), end (Frame 1452), or perfect (Frame 199). 	 	 	When the goalkeeper finishes the game, he drinks a lot of water and adjusts himself. 	 	On-Yomi: サイ、セイ   Kun-Yomi: す.む、-ず.み、-ずみ、す.まない、す.ます、-す.ます、すく.う、な.す、わたし、わた.る  	Examples: 済ます (す.ます), 済む (す.む)"
purification	"purification 	 	斎   	   	Lesson: 45   Frame: 1869   Strokes: 11   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: purification, sentence, plaid, kilt, Billy Connolly, fenceposts, cabers, altar, show, two, small 	 	Plaid . . . fenceposts . . . altar. This is a ""religious"" purification, which distinguishes it from the simple kanji for pure (Frame 1659). 	 	 	Purification? I think of Japanese during new year's eve praying(saying sentences) in front of Itsukushima's shrine torii(fenceposts) and its altar. They expect to enter the new year totally purified. 	 	On-Yomi: サイ   Kun-Yomi: とき、つつし.む、ものいみ、い.む、いわ.う、いつ.く"
solemn	"solemn 	 	粛   	   	Lesson: 45   Frame: 1870   Strokes: 11   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: solemn, rake, fenceposts, cabers, rice 	 	Rake . . . rice . . . fenceposts. Take special care to draw this character in the same order as the primitive. Note too, that the fourth stroke for rice is already taken care of by the fourth stroke of rake. 	 	 	Even though it´s a maddening task, the monks stay solemn as they rake rice between the fenceposts. 	 	On-Yomi: シュク、スク   Kun-Yomi: つつし.む"
bases	"bases 	 	塁   	   	Lesson: 45   Frame: 1871   Strokes: 12   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: bases, rice field, brains, sparkler, soil, dirt, ground 	 	The kanji of this frame refers to the four bases that are placed at the corners of a baseball infield. The elements: field . . . sparkler . . . ground. 	 	 	Playing baseball in a rice field with sparklers stuck into the ground to act as bases. 	 	On-Yomi: ルイ、ライ、スイ   Kun-Yomi: とりで"

Zelda: Ocarina of Time - The white sparkly thing is Navi. She´s hovering/dancing around a tree to the legendary Lost Woods music. New-age medicine involves using things like music and flowers (aromatherapy) as treatment. 	 	On-Yomi: ヤク   Kun-Yomi: くすり  	Examples: 薬 (くすり)"
ratio	"ratio 	 	率   	   	Lesson: 45   Frame: 1874   Strokes: 11   —   Jouyou Grade: 5   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: ratio, mysterious, question mark, top hat, cocoon, sparkler, ten, needle 	 	Mysterious . . . sparkler . . . ten. Do not confuse with proportion (Frame 1673). 	 	 	It´s quite mysterious how each sparkler gives of sparkles at a precise ratio of ten to one. Physicists have been studying this effect for decades, known as the Sparkler Effect, and using it to explain why stars look like sparklers in the night sky. 	 	On-Yomi: ソツ、リツ、シュツ   Kun-Yomi: ひき.いる  	Examples: 率先 (そっせん), 引率 (いんそつ), 軽率 (けいそつ), 率いる (ひき.いる)"
astringent	"astringent 	 	渋   	   	Lesson: 45   Frame: 1875   Strokes: 11   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: astringent, water, water droplets, water pistol, stop, footprint, sparkler 	 	Water . . . footprint . . . sparkler. 	 	 	I think that Heisig meant this as the ""slightly bitter but fresh"" meaning that it can have to describe foods like lemons (しぶい). So imagine a guy trying a cocktail (water), feeling like he´s been kicked in the face (footprint) and sparks are flying from his tongue. ´How did it taste?´. ´Hmm, yes, slightly bitter, but fresh"". 	 	On-Yomi: ジュウ、シュウ   Kun-Yomi: しぶ、しぶ.い、しぶ.る  	Examples: 渋 (しぶ), 渋い (しぶ.い), 渋る (しぶ.る)"
vicarious	"vicarious 	 	摂   	   	Lesson: 45   Frame: 1876   Strokes: 13   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: vicarious, finger, fingers, ear, sparkler 	 	Fingers . . . ear . . . sparkler. Do not confuse with substitute (Frame 1080). 	 	 	Now that I´m a responsible adult, I have to get my vicarious thrills from watching stupid people put sparklers up to their ears and burn their fingers. 	 	On-Yomi: セツ、ショウ   Kun-Yomi: おさ.める、かね.る、と.る"
center	"center 	 	央   	   	Lesson: 45   Frame: 1877   Strokes: 5   —   Jouyou Grade: 3   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: center, large, St. Bernard, box body 	 	The elements depict a St. Bernard with its head and paws keeping their stick-like form, but with the middle or center of its body filled out in a box-like shape. 	 	 	Youve got the st bernard dead centre in your sights (the box). 	 	On-Yomi: オウ   Kun-Yomi:"
England	"England 	 	英   	   	Lesson: 45   Frame: 1878   Strokes: 8   —   Jouyou Grade: 4   JLPT: 4   	Constituents: England, flowers, centre, center, large, St. Bernard 	 	Flowers . . . center. This is another abbreviation used to identify a country by the pronunciation of the kanji. 	 	 	The original great seal of the king of England had a very ornate flower in the center. 	 	On-Yomi: エイ   Kun-Yomi: はなぶさ"
reflect	"reflect 	 	映   	   	Lesson: 45   Frame: 1879   Strokes: 9   —   Jouyou Grade: 6   JLPT: 4   	Constituents: reflect, sun, day, centre, center, large, St. Bernard 	 	Sun . . . center. 	 	 	In the solar system, the Sun is the central source of all light, everything else just reflects it. 	 	On-Yomi: エイ   Kun-Yomi: うつ.る、うつ.す、は.える、-ば.え  	Examples: 映す (うつ.す), 映る (うつ.る), 映える (は.える)"
red	"red 	 	赤   	   	Lesson: 45   Frame: 1880   Strokes: 7   —   Jouyou Grade: 1   JLPT: 4   	Constituents: red, soil, dirt, ground, sword, dagger, small 	 	Ground . . . dagger . . . little. The two strokes of the dagger take the place of the middle stroke of little. 	  * As a primitive on the left, this kanji keeps the same form. Elsewhere, the first two strokes are abbreviated to a single dot. This latter form will take the meaning of an apple. 	 	He was stabbed with a dagger, and little drops of red blood dropped onto the ground. 	 	On-Yomi: セキ、シャク   Kun-Yomi: あか、あか-、あか.い、あか.らむ、あか.らめる  	Examples: 赤道 (せきどう), 赤貧 (せきひん), 発赤 (はつあか), 赤 (あか), 赤い (あか.い), 赤らむ (あか.らむ), 赤らめる (あか.らめる)"

color	"color 	 	色   	   	Lesson: 45   Frame: 1890   Strokes: 6   —   Jouyou Grade: 2   JLPT: 4   	Constituents: color, bound up, mosaic 	 	Bound up . . . mosaic. 	 	 	Ever look closely at mosaics? They contain a bunch of images bound up into a larger one. It seems amazing until you realize that the only quality of the smaller images that really matters is their colour. I can't finish my sewing project because the thread color I was using was discontinued. 	 	On-Yomi: ゼツ   Kun-Yomi: た.える、た.やす、た.つ  	Examples: 絶える (た.える), 絶つ (た.つ), 絶やす (た.やす)"

To print something with bountiful colour, they use glossy paper. 	 	On-Yomi: エン   Kun-Yomi: つや、なま.めかしい、あで.やか、つや.めく、なま.めく  	Examples: 艶 (つや)"
fertilizer	"fertilizer 	 	肥   	   	Lesson: 45   Frame: 1893   Strokes: 8   —   Jouyou Grade: 5   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: fertilizer, moon, month, flesh, part of the body, mosaic 	 	Flesh . . . mosaic. 	 	 	PART OF YOUR BODY excretes something that is commonly used for FERTILIZER. Sometimes this process is slow, so you solve a RUBIK´S CUBE while you sit and wait. 	 	On-Yomi: ヒ   Kun-Yomi: こ.える、こえ、こ.やす、こ.やし、ふと.る  	Examples: 肥える (こ.える), 肥やし (こ.やし), 肥やす (こ.やす), 肥 (こえ)"
sweet	"sweet 	 	甘   	   	Lesson: 46   Frame: 1894   Strokes: 5   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: sweet, wicker basket, picnic basket 	 	This kanji is a pictograph of a small wicker basket. (The extra short stroke in the middle helps keep it distinct from the character for twenty.) All one needs to add is some image of sweet cakes or breads carried in the basket, and the union of picture and meaning is complete. Take care not to confuse with confectionary (Frame 1203). 	  * As a primitive, the pictograph's meaning of a wicker basket is used, a small one like the kind used for picnics. 	 	Little red riding hood is carrying around a wicker basket filled with sweet baked cookies for granny. 	 	On-Yomi: カン   Kun-Yomi: あま.い、あま.える、あま.やかす、うま.い  	Examples: 甘い (あま.い), 甘える (あま.える), 甘やかす (あま.やかす)"
navy blue	"navy blue 	 	紺   	   	Lesson: 46   Frame: 1895   Strokes: 11   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: navy blue, thread, spiderman, sweet, wicker basket, picnic basket 	 	Thread . . . wicker basket. 	 	 	Thanks raulir - As many Japanese perverts know, navy blue threads conceal school girl sweetness underneath. 	 	On-Yomi: コン   Kun-Yomi:"
so-and-so	"so-and-so 	 	某   	   	Lesson: 46   Frame: 1896   Strokes: 9   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: so-and-so, sweet, wicker basket, picnic basket, tree, wood 	 	The key word here refers to the adjective for an unspecified person or thing. Its elements: wicker basket . . . tree. 	 	 	I had the same idea as fuabrisu. A generic person is described here as having body sort of like a tree trunk and head sort of like a wicker basket. 	 	On-Yomi: ボウ   Kun-Yomi: それがし、なにがし"
conspire	"conspire 	 	謀   	   	Lesson: 46   Frame: 1897   Strokes: 16   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: conspire, say, words, keitai, mouth, so-and-so, sweet, wicker basket, picnic basket, tree, wood 	 	Words . . . so-and-so. 	 	 	I imagine a clique of catty girls conspiring against a another girl...they are exchanging lots of words, chatting about how so-and-so girl is now up to such-and-such (gasp!), and how they will spread the word about it. 	 	On-Yomi: ボウ、ム   Kun-Yomi: はか.る、たばか.る、はかりごと  	Examples: 謀略 (ぼうりゃく), 無謀 (むぼう), 首謀者 (しゅぼうしゃ), 謀る (はか.る)"
mediator	"mediator 	 	媒   	   	Lesson: 46   Frame: 1898   Strokes: 12   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: mediator, woman, so-and-so, sweet, wicker basket, picnic basket, tree, wood 	 	Woman . . . so-and-so. 	 	 	The woman 女 hoped her friend would act as mediator to set her up with the guy she liked. She didn't mention his name, just referred to him as ""A certain unnamed person -- I'll call him 'Mr. So-and-So 某' ...."" 	 	On-Yomi: バイ   Kun-Yomi: なこうど"
deceit	"deceit 	 	欺   	   	Lesson: 46   Frame: 1899   Strokes: 12   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: deceit, bushel basket, hamper, animal legs, eight, lack, yawn 	 	Bushel basket . . . yawn. 	 	 	He escaped using deceit. That is, he ran past while the guard was yawning and hid in the bushel basket. 	 	On-Yomi: ギ   Kun-Yomi: あざむ.く  	Examples: 欺く (あざむ.く)"
chess piece	"chess piece 	 	棋   	   	Lesson: 46   Frame: 1900   Strokes: 12   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: chess piece, tree, wood, bushel basket, hamper, animal legs, eight 	 	Tree . . . bushel basket. 	 	 	Tree + Bushel Bucket: Chess pieces carved from trees were tossed into a bushel bucket for sorting into sets. 	 	On-Yomi: キ   Kun-Yomi: ご"

The national flag of Croatia. It's a banner with the Croatian coat of arms, commonly referred to as the Chessboard (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coat_of_arms_of_Croatia). period	"period 	 	期   	   	Lesson: 46   Frame: 1902   Strokes: 12   —   Jouyou Grade: 3   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: period, bushel basket, hamper, animal legs, eight, moon, month, flesh, part of the body 	 	Bushel basket . . . month. As the month indicates, this has to do with periods of time. 	 	 	The slowest remote chess game ever: a one month period between every move. 	 	On-Yomi: キ、ゴ   Kun-Yomi:   	Examples: 期間 (きかん), 期待 (きたい), 予期 (よき)"
Go	"Go 	 	碁   	   	Lesson: 46   Frame: 1903   Strokes: 13   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: go, bushel basket, hamper, animal legs, eight, stone, rock 	 	Bushel basket . . . stones. The key word refers to the Japanese game played with black and white colored stones on a lined board. 	 	 	Go is chess played with stones. 	 	On-Yomi: ゴ   Kun-Yomi:"
