Fundamentals of chess: use the rooks to protect your ground. 	 	On-Yomi: キ   Kun-Yomi: もと、もとい  	Examples: 基 (もと), 基 (もとい)"
tremendously	"tremendously 	 	甚   	   	Lesson: 46   Frame: 1905   Strokes: 9   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: tremendously, bushel basket, hamper, equal, human legs 	 	Bushel basket . . . equal. Note how the first stroke of equal doubles up with the sixth stroke of the bushel basket, and how the animal legs of the bushel basket are dropped to make room for the human legs of equal. 	 	 	It´s a tremendous match between the two chess-players. They are clearly eachother´s equal. 	 	On-Yomi: ジン   Kun-Yomi: はなは.だ、はなは.だしい  	Examples: 甚だ (はなは.だ), 甚だしい (はなは.だしい)"
intuition	"intuition 	 	勘   	   	Lesson: 46   Frame: 1906   Strokes: 11   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: intuition, tremendously, bushel basket, hamper, equal, human legs, power, muscle, arnold 	 	Tremendously . . . muscle. 	 	 	Intuition is a tremendously powerful resource of the mind. 	 	On-Yomi: カン   Kun-Yomi:"
withstand	"withstand 	 	堪   	   	Lesson: 46   Frame: 1907   Strokes: 12   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: withstand, soil, dirt, ground, tremendously, bushel basket, hamper, equal, human legs 	 	Soil . . . tremendously. 	 	 	Because I hid myself behind a huge dirt barrier I dug, I was able to withstand the tremendous nuclear blast. 	 	On-Yomi: カン、タン   Kun-Yomi: た.える、たま.る、こ.らえる、こた.える  	Examples: 堪える (た.える)"
precious	"precious 	 	貴   	   	Lesson: 46   Frame: 1908   Strokes: 12   —   Jouyou Grade: 6   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: precious, Takanohana, purse, in, one, floor, shellfish, clam, oyster, eye, animal legs, eight 	 	Purse . . . shells. 	 	 	Inside your purse is all of your money and your keys (き) etc. All of your precious valuables. 	 	On-Yomi: キ   Kun-Yomi: たっと.い、とうと.い、たっと.ぶ、とうと.ぶ  	Examples: 貴い (たっと.い), 貴ぶ (たっと.ぶ), 貴い (とうと.い), 貴ぶ (とうと.ぶ)"
bequeath	"bequeath 	 	遺   	   	Lesson: 46   Frame: 1909   Strokes: 15   —   Jouyou Grade: 6   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: bequeath, precious, Takanohana, purse, in, one, floor, shellfish, clam, oyster, eye, animal legs, eight, road 	 	Precious . . . road. 	 	 	Bequeath is an odd old word, isn´t it? Basically, it just deals with how I want my precious possessions dealt out, after I die, later down the road. ""Being of sound, but antiquated, mind, I bequeath this to you!"". 	 	On-Yomi: イ、ユイ   Kun-Yomi: のこ.す  	Examples: 遺棄 (いき), 遺産 (いさん), 遺失 (いしつ)"
dispatch	"dispatch 	 	遣   	   	Lesson: 46   Frame: 1910   Strokes: 13   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: dispatch, purse, in, one, floor, maestro without baton, road 	 	This kanji takes away the maestro's baton and replaces it with a purse. The road represents his being dispatched on his way a san obvious misfit. You will remember that when he did have his baton, he was being chased down the road by his fans. All of which shows what a difference a single stroke can make! 	 	 	Bond has stolen a lady spy's purse while she was asleep after their evening together. When she discovers it's gone, she dispatches some henchmen on the road after him to dispatch him, but Bond evades them and escapes with the purse. 	 	On-Yomi: ケン   Kun-Yomi: つか.う、-つか.い、-づか.い、つか.わす、や.る  	Examples: 遣う (つか.う), 遣わす (つか.わす)"
dance	"dance 	 	舞   	   	Lesson: 46   Frame: 1912   Strokes: 15   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: dance, reclining, lying down, tub, sunglasses, dancing legs, ballerina, evening 	 	The top two strokes show someone reclining, and the next six are a pictograph of an oaken tub ribbed with metal strips, like the kind once used for bathing. At the bottom, the sunglasses round off the character. 	 	 	The yakuza boss reclines in the oaken bathtub wearing his shades while his personal harem dances naked for him. 	 	On-Yomi: ブ   Kun-Yomi: ま.う、-ま.う、まい  	Examples: 舞い (ま.い), 舞う (ま.う)"
nothingness	"nothingness 	 	無   	   	Lesson: 46   Frame: 1913   Strokes: 12   —   Jouyou Grade: 4   JLPT:    	Constituents: nothingness, reclining, lying down, tub, oven-fire, barbecue 	 	This character is the Japanese character for the supreme philosophical principle of much Oriental thought: nothingness. Make use of the oaken tub from the previous frame, and add to that the oven fire at the bottom. 	 	 	When I enter the wooden tub heated by flames in the onsen, I can let all my worries slip away and be submerged into nothingness. 	 	On-Yomi: ム、ブ   Kun-Yomi: な.い  	Examples: 無名 (むめい), 無理 (むり), 皆無 (かいむ), 無い (な.い)"
association	"association 	 	組   	   	Lesson: 47   Frame: 1914   Strokes: 11   —   Jouyou Grade: 2   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: association, thread, spiderman, shelf, my bookshelves 	 	Thread . . . shelf. 	 	 	A common thread associates the knick-knacks on your knick-knack shelf. Souveneirs from Spain on one, from Japan on the other. 	 	On-Yomi: ソ   Kun-Yomi: く.む、くみ、-ぐみ  	Examples: 組む (く.む), 組 (くみ)"
coarse	"coarse 	 	粗   	   	Lesson: 47   Frame: 1915   Strokes: 11   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: coarse, rice, shelf, my bookshelves 	 	Rice . . . shelf. 	 	 	Japanese carpenters don't use sandpaper, they use rice-paper(rice glued on to some paper). Here the carpenter is using the coarse paper to smooth out the shelf he's making. 	 	On-Yomi: ソ   Kun-Yomi: あら.い、あら-  	Examples: 粗い (あら.い)"
tariff	"tariff 	 	租   	   	Lesson: 47   Frame: 1916   Strokes: 10   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: tariff, wheat, cereal, shelf, my bookshelves 	 	Wheat . . . shelf. 	 	 	The EU and US impose such high tariffs on food imports that third world wheat (the most basic of staples) never reaches first world supermarket shelves. 	 	On-Yomi: ソ   Kun-Yomi:"
ancestor	"ancestor 	 	祖   	   	Lesson: 47   Frame: 1918   Strokes: 9   —   Jouyou Grade: 5   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: ancestor, altar, shelf, my bookshelves 	 	Altar . . . shelf. 	 	 	The ancestor worship is so common in Daoist and buddhist countries that you can buy tiny altars to put on the shelves, one for each deceased family member. 	 	On-Yomi: ソ   Kun-Yomi:"
thwart	"thwart 	 	阻   	   	Lesson: 47   Frame: 1919   Strokes: 8   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: thwart, pinnacle, parthenon, acropolis, shelf, my bookshelves 	 	Pinnacle . . . shelf. 	 	 	Keeping porn on the pinnacle of a bookshelf can thwart snooping kids (thanks bodhisamaya). 	 	On-Yomi: ソ   Kun-Yomi: はば.む  	Examples: 阻む (はば.む)"
investigate	"investigate 	 	査   	   	Lesson: 47   Frame: 1920   Strokes: 9   —   Jouyou Grade: 5   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: investigate, tree, wood, shelf, my bookshelves 	 	Tree . . . shelf. 	 	 	Like the ""ero inquiry"" that had been partially swept under the rug (see inquire (#1145)), this kanji depicts the investigation into the forestry scandal being shelved. 	 	On-Yomi: サ   Kun-Yomi:"
help	"help 	 	助   	   	Lesson: 47   Frame: 1921   Strokes: 7   —   Jouyou Grade: 3   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: help, shelf, my bookshelves, power, muscle, arnold 	 	Shelf . . . power. The reason why the shelf appears on the left here is that the right side is the normal position for power, the stronger primitive. Indeed, the only exception in all the kanji is the character for add (Frame 932). 	 	 	HELP! Someone´s pinned under this bookshelf and it´s gonna take a lot of muscle to lift it off! 	 	On-Yomi: ジョ   Kun-Yomi: たす.ける、たす.かる、す.ける、すけ  	Examples: 助 (すけ), 助かる (たす.かる), 助ける (たす.ける)"
best regards	"best regards 	 	宜   	   	Lesson: 47   Frame: 1922   Strokes: 8   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: best regards, house, shelf, my bookshelves 	 	This kanji, a polite way of expressing one's best regards to another. Its elements: house . . . shelf. 	 	 	It seems like every time my Japanese friends send me their best regards, they accompany them with a gift. Over time, I´ve gotten so many that I had to buy a second house which contains nothing but several fancy shelves. Each shelf is dedicated to a certain friend of mine and contains every last one of their presents. 	 	On-Yomi: ギ   Kun-Yomi: よろ.しい、よろ.しく"
tatami mat	"tatami mat 	 	畳   	   	Lesson: 47   Frame: 1923   Strokes: 12   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: tatami mat, rice field, brains, crown, shelf, my bookshelves 	 	Rice field . . . crown . . . shelf. 	 	 	The king is peacefully sleeping on his new tatami mat when all of a sudden a shelf falls over and kills him. You can see his crown poking out and the brains splatter out the top of his head from all the pressure. 	 	On-Yomi: ジョウ、チョウ   Kun-Yomi: たた.む、たたみ、かさ.なる  	Examples: 畳む (たた.む), 畳 (たたみ)"
row	"row 	 	並   	   	Lesson: 47   Frame: 1924   Strokes: 8   —   Jouyou Grade: 6   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: row 	 	This character represents a slightly stylized duplication of the kanji for stand up. By lengthening the sixth and seventh strokes, you will see how this is done. 	  * The primitive meaning remains the same as that of the kanji, but special attention has to be given to the varieties of shape this element can undergo. It is the most difficult one you will meet in this book. When it appears BENEATH its relative primitive, the top three strokes are omitted, though the third horizontal stroke may be doubled up with the bottom horizontal stroke of the element above it. ATOP its relative primitive, it can keep its kanji shape. When it does not, the top three strokes are removed and all of them are replaced BELOW the primitive's bottom line. We shall acknowledge this latter transformation by changing its meaning to upside down in a row. 	 	This is a simplification of 竝, a ideogram of two people standing in a row. 	 	On-Yomi: ヘイ、ホウ   Kun-Yomi: な.み、なら.べる、なら.ぶ、なら.びに  	Examples: 並 (なみ), 並びに (なら.びに), 並ぶ (なら.ぶ), 並べる (なら.べる)"
universal	"universal 	 	普   	   	Lesson: 47   Frame: 1925   Strokes: 12   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: universal, row, sun, day 	 	Row . . . sun. 	 	 	A row of suns is actually a normal, plain, and ordinary occurrence in an infinitely large and expanding universe. FUtsuu. 	 	On-Yomi: フ   Kun-Yomi: あまね.く、あまねし"
musical score	"musical score 	 	譜   	   	Lesson: 47   Frame: 1926   Strokes: 19   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: musical score, say, words, keitai, mouth, universal, row, sun, day 	 	Words . . . universal. 	 	 	Musical scores are in a universal language. 	 	On-Yomi: フ   Kun-Yomi:"
damp	"damp 	 	湿   	   	Lesson: 47   Frame: 1927   Strokes: 12   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: damp, water, water droplets, water pistol, sun, day, row 	 	Water . . . sun . . . row. 	 	 	You first wash you clothes with water and wring them until they are just damp before hanging them in a row under the sun to dry. If you don´t wring them damp first they will take days to dry! 	 	On-Yomi: シツ、シュウ   Kun-Yomi: しめ.る、しめ.す、うるお.う、うるお.す  	Examples: 湿す (しめ.す), 湿る (しめ.る)"
appear	"appear 	 	顕   	   	Lesson: 47   Frame: 1928   Strokes: 18   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: appear, sun, day, row, head, page, one, ceiling, drop, shellfish, clam, oyster, eye, animal legs, eight 	 	Sun . . . row . . . heads. 	 	 	Somebody's head appears from behind the laundry in a row drying under the sun 	 	On-Yomi: ケン   Kun-Yomi: あきらか、あらわ.れる"
slender	"slender 	 	繊   	   	Lesson: 47   Frame: 1929   Strokes: 17   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: slender, thread, spiderman, Thanksgiving, harvest festival, ten, needle, fiesta, row 	 	Thread . . . Thanksgiving . . . row. 	 	 	At the end of Thanksgiving it's tradition for everyone to stand in a row and measure their waist with a strip of thread. Whoever is the most slender wins the leftovers. 	 	On-Yomi: セン   Kun-Yomi:"
spirits	"spirits 	 	霊   	   	Lesson: 47   Frame: 1930   Strokes: 15   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: spirits, rain, weather, two, row 	 	Rain . . . two . . . row. This character will refer only to the inhabitants of the ""spirit world,"" and not to moods or temperaments, for which we will learn another character in frame 2030. 	 	 	After raining for two days in a row, you plead with the SPIRITS for some relief. (Adapted from johnskb,21-5-2006). 	 	On-Yomi: レイ、リョウ   Kun-Yomi: たま  	Examples: 霊感 (れいかん), 霊魂 (れいこん), 霊長類 (れいちょうるい), 霊 (たま)"
profession	"profession 	 	業   	   	Lesson: 47   Frame: 1931   Strokes: 13   —   Jouyou Grade: 3   JLPT: 4   	Constituents: business, profession, upside down in a row, not yet, tree, wood 	 	In a row upside down . . . not yet. 	 	 	The oldest profession: prostitution. I was once in a brothel in Amsterdam where the working girls had a group of businessmen blindfolded and hanging upside down in a row, not yet spanked and whipped, but waiting eagerly. 	 	On-Yomi: ギョウ、ゴウ   Kun-Yomi: わざ  	Examples: 業績 (ぎょうせき), 職業 (しょくぎょう), 卒業 (そつぎょう), 業 (わざ)"
slap	"slap 	 	撲   	   	Lesson: 47   Frame: 1932   Strokes: 15   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: slap, finger, fingers, upside down in a row, husband 	 	Fingers . . . upside down in a row . . . husbands. 	 	 	After a row husbands take their wives upsides down over the knee and slap them with their fingers on the bottom (if that doesn´t get me banned…). 	 	On-Yomi: ボク   Kun-Yomi:"
me	"me 	 	僕   	   	Lesson: 47   Frame: 1933   Strokes: 14   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: me, person, upside down in a row, husband 	 	This key word is yet another synonym for ""I,"" somewhat more familiar in tone. As a rule, it is a word that boys and men use to refer to themselves. Its elements: person . . . husbands . . . in a row upside down. 	 	 	Mr. T also finds himself as one of the HUSBANDs, whose wives have had them hung UPSIDE DOWN IN A ROW. But when his wife comes up to punish him, he pleads, “It’s ME, Baby. I wasn’t behaving badly like these other foo’s.”. 	 	On-Yomi: ボク   Kun-Yomi: しもべ"
together	"together 	 	共   	   	Lesson: 47   Frame: 1934   Strokes: 6   —   Jouyou Grade: 4   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: together, salad, animal legs, eight 	 	Salad . . . animal legs. 	  * The primitive retains the meaning of together. Imagine things strung together like fish on a line, beads on a thread, or whatever. The main thing is to avoid putting them in a straight row, which would confound this element with the previous one. As we saw with bushel basket, this primitive can join its legs to the final horizontal stroke and stretch them to form an enclosure. 	 	The character for deluge (#1799) gave me the idea to use together as a primitive for Noah´s Ark. Noah kept plenty of salad on board to entice the animals with their animal legs to scurry on board together, two by two. 	 	On-Yomi: キョウ   Kun-Yomi: とも、とも.に、-ども  	Examples: 共 (とも)"
submit	"submit 	 	供   	   	Lesson: 47   Frame: 1935   Strokes: 8   —   Jouyou Grade: 6   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: submit, person, strung together, salad, animal legs, eight 	 	Submit here is a transitive verb, meaning to offer or present. Its elements: person . . . strung together. 	 	 	You have to SUBMIT all required documents together, in person! 	 	On-Yomi: キョウ、ク、クウ、グ   Kun-Yomi: そな.える、とも、-ども  	Examples: 供給 (きょうきゅう), 提供 (ていきょう), 自供 (じきょう), 供える (そな.える), 供 (とも)"
uncommon	"uncommon 	 	異   	   	Lesson: 47   Frame: 1936   Strokes: 11   —   Jouyou Grade: 6   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: uncommon, rice field, brains, strung together, salad, animal legs, eight 	 	Brains . . . together. 	 	 	Brains together with beauty is an uncommon combination. 	 	On-Yomi: イ   Kun-Yomi: こと、こと.なる、け  	Examples: 異 (こと)"
wing	"wing 	 	翼   	   	Lesson: 47   Frame: 1937   Strokes: 17   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: wing, feathers, wings, uncommon, rice field, brains, strung together, salad, animal legs, eight 	 	Feathers . . . uncommon. 	 	 	The thing about feathers is that they usually cover the entire bird. A creature with feathers only on its wings would be very uncommon. 	 	On-Yomi: ヨク   Kun-Yomi: つばさ  	Examples: 翼 (つばさ)"
deluge	"deluge 	 	洪   	   	Lesson: 47   Frame: 1939   Strokes: 9   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: deluge, water, water droplets, water pistol, strung together, salad, animal legs, eight 	 	Water . . . strung together. 	 	 	Lots of water coming together is called a deluge. 	 	On-Yomi: コウ   Kun-Yomi:"
harbor	"harbor 	 	港   	   	Lesson: 47   Frame: 1940   Strokes: 12   —   Jouyou Grade: 3   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: harbor, deluge, water, water droplets, water pistol, scene, strung together, salad, animal legs, eight, snake, self 	 	Deluge . . . snakes. 	 	 	During a deluge, all the poor snakes get washed into the harbour. 	 	On-Yomi: コウ   Kun-Yomi: みなと  	Examples: 港 (みなと)"
outburst	"outburst 	 	暴   	   	Lesson: 47   Frame: 1941   Strokes: 15   —   Jouyou Grade: 5   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: outburst, sun, day, strung together, salad, animal legs, eight, grains of rice 	 	Sun . . . strung together . . . rice grains. 	 	 	If you think of it as of outburst of an atomic bomb (which will also prove useful in the next frame), then imagining thousands of suns blasting in one single outburst of rage and turning people into rice grains is not that hard. 	 	On-Yomi: ボウ、バク   Kun-Yomi: あば.く、あば.れる  	Examples: 暴言 (ぼうげん), 横暴 (おうぼう), 乱暴 (らんぼう), 暴く (あば.く), 暴れる (あば.れる)"
bomb	"bomb 	 	爆   	   	Lesson: 47   Frame: 1942   Strokes: 19   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: bomb, fire, outburst, strung together, salad, animal legs, eight, grains of rice 	 	Fire . . . outburst. 	 	 	Actually means explosion, like an outburst of fire. 	 	On-Yomi: バク   Kun-Yomi: は.ぜる"
respect	"respect 	 	恭   	   	Lesson: 47   Frame: 1943   Strokes: 10   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: respect, strung together, salad, animal legs, eight, valentine 	 	Strung together . . . valentine. 	 	 	If you wanna stay together you have to show your valentine respect. 	 	On-Yomi: キョウ   Kun-Yomi: うやうや.しい  	Examples: 恭しい (うやうや.しい)"
elect	"elect 	 	選   	   	Lesson: 47   Frame: 1944   Strokes: 15   —   Jouyou Grade: 4   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: elect, southeast, snake, self, strung together, salad, animal legs, eight, road, snake2, self2 	 	Two snakes . . . strung together . . . road. 	 	 	Isn't this how the US presedential election works? You are given a choice between two snakes. Their politics are actually strung together but you get to feel as though you chose which one you want to lead you down the political road for the next four years. So which snake are you going to elect? 	 	On-Yomi: セン   Kun-Yomi: えら.ぶ  	Examples: 選ぶ (えら.ぶ)"
Mr.	"Mr. 	 	殿   	   	Lesson: 47   Frame: 1945   Strokes: 13   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: Mr, flag, strung together, salad, animal legs, eight, cruise missile, missile, wind, crotch 	 	Flags . . . strung together . . . missile. 	 	 	Mr. President in his palace, ordering missiles to be fired at a harmless enemy in order to unite us together under the flag. 	 	On-Yomi: デン、テン   Kun-Yomi: との、-どの  	Examples: 殿堂 (でんどう), 宮殿 (きゅうでん), 貴殿 (きでん), 殿 (との), 殿 (どの)"
well	"well 	 	井   	   	Lesson: 48   Frame: 1946   Strokes: 4   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: well 	 	Recalling that there are no circular strokes, and that the shape of the square and the square within a square (Frame 630) have already been used, it should be relatively easy to see how this character can be consider a pictograph of a well. 	 	 	I nearly died by falling in a well. Actually, on two separate occasions. I´m glad to see they´ve added these fence posts. Now the well will be much safer. 	 	On-Yomi: セイ、ショウ   Kun-Yomi: い  	Examples: 油井 (ゆい), 市井 (しせい), 井 (い)"
surround	"surround 	 	囲   	   	Lesson: 48   Frame: 1948   Strokes: 7   —   Jouyou Grade: 4   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: surround, pent in, well 	 	Well . . . pent in. 	 	 	The village surrounded the well with a wall so kids wouldn´t fall in. 	 	On-Yomi: イ   Kun-Yomi: かこ.む、かこ.う、かこ.い  	Examples: 囲う (かこ.う), 囲む (かこ.む)"
till	"till 	 	耕   	   	Lesson: 48   Frame: 1949   Strokes: 10   —   Jouyou Grade: 5   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: till, christmas tree, well 	 	Christmas tree . . . well. 	 	 	If you just grow your christmas tree in a well, there will be no need to till the soil. 	 	On-Yomi: コウ   Kun-Yomi: たがや.す  	Examples: 耕す (たがや.す)"
Asia	"Asia 	 	亜   	   	Lesson: 48   Frame: 1950   Strokes: 7   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: Asia, roman two, mouth 	 	In this kanji, the abbreviation for Asia, you should be able to see the character for mouth behind the Roman numeral II. 	 	 	In Asian countries, people use II chopsticks to get things into their mouths. Just imagine someone shoving a piece of sushi into their mouths with chopsticks. 	 	On-Yomi: ア、アシア   Kun-Yomi: つ.ぐ"
bad	"bad 	 	悪   	   	Lesson: 48   Frame: 1951   Strokes: 11   —   Jouyou Grade: 3   JLPT: 4   	Constituents: bad, Asia, roman two, mouth, heart 	 	Asia . . . heart. 	 	 	Because Asian people started to eat Western food, their hearts became bad and they started having heart attacks. 	 	On-Yomi: アク、オ   Kun-Yomi: わる.い、わる-、あ.し、にく.い、-にく.い、ああ、いずくに、いずくんぞ、にく.む  	Examples: 悪事 (あくじ), 悪意 (あくい), 醜悪 (しゅうあく), 悪い (わる.い)"
circle	"circle 	 	円   	   	Lesson: 48   Frame: 1952   Strokes: 4   —   Jouyou Grade: 1   JLPT: 5   	Constituents: circle, yen 	 	This kanji, also used for Yen, is one you are not likely to need to study formally, since you can hardly get around in Japan without it. The connection is that the yennies, like pennies, are circular in shape. In any case, the elements are: glass canopy . . . walking stick . . . one. 	 	 	The shape of a Yen coin. 	 	On-Yomi: エン   Kun-Yomi: まる.い、まる、まど、まど.か、まろ.やか  	Examples: 円い (まる.い)"
angle	"angle 	 	角   	   	Lesson: 48   Frame: 1953   Strokes: 7   —   Jouyou Grade: 2   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: angle, bound up, glass canopy, hood, walking cane, stick, two 	 	Bound up . . . glass canopy . . . walking stick . . . two. If you write the character once, you will see why we avoided using the element for soil, which would prompt you to write it in improper order. 	  * As a primitive, imagine the tool used by draftsmen and carpenters to draw right-angles. 	 	A museum display of two walking sticks bound together under a glass canopy, showing the first device used to measure an angle. 	 	On-Yomi: カク   Kun-Yomi: かど、つの  	Examples: 角 (かど), 角 (つの)"
contact	"contact 	 	触   	   	Lesson: 48   Frame: 1954   Strokes: 13   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: contact, angle, bound up, glass canopy, hood, walking cane, stick, two, insect 	 	Angle . . . insect. 	 	 	For insects to get in contact with each other, they need to place their antennae at just the right angle. 	 	On-Yomi: ショク   Kun-Yomi: ふ.れる、さわ.る、さわ  	Examples: 触る (さわ.る), 触れる (ふ.れる)"
unravel	"unravel 	 	解   	   	Lesson: 48   Frame: 1955   Strokes: 13   —   Jouyou Grade: 5   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: unravel, angle, bound up, glass canopy, hood, walking cane, stick, two, sword, dagger, cow 	 	Angle . . . dagger . . . cow. 	 	 	Did you know that you can unravel a cow? If you stick the dagger in at exactly the correct angle, the whole cow will just unravel. 	 	On-Yomi: カイ、ゲ   Kun-Yomi: と.く、と.かす、と.ける、ほど.く、ほど.ける、わか.る、さと.る  	Examples: 解決 (かいけつ), 解禁 (かいきん), 理解 (りかい), 解かす (と.かす), 解く (と.く), 解ける (と.ける)"
again	"again 	 	再   	   	Lesson: 48   Frame: 1956   Strokes: 6   —   Jouyou Grade: 5   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: again, king, jewel, ball, belt 	 	Jewel . . . with a belt hung on it. Note how the belt is drawn right after the first stroke of jewel. 	 	 	The king has eaten too much and has to get a new belt again. See his fat rolls hanging over? 	 	On-Yomi: サイ、サ   Kun-Yomi: ふたた.び  	Examples: 再度 (さいど), 再選 (さいせん), 再出発 (さいしゅっぱつ), 再び (ふたた.び)"
lecture	"lecture 	 	講   	   	Lesson: 48   Frame: 1957   Strokes: 17   —   Jouyou Grade: 5   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: lecture, say, words, keitai, mouth, funnel, cone, celery, again 	 	Words . . . funnel. 	 	 	I have a funnel attached to my laptop that takes my prof´s lecture and puts the words into a text file. The bigger the funnel, the more accurate the conversion, so picture a bunch of laptops with large, unwieldy funnels attached to the USB port. 	 	On-Yomi: コウ   Kun-Yomi:"
subscription	"subscription 	 	購   	   	Lesson: 48   Frame: 1958   Strokes: 17   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: subscription, shellfish, clam, oyster, eye, animal legs, eight, funnel, cone, celery, again 	 	Shells . . . funnel. The key word is meant to suggest magazine subscriptions and the like. 	 	 	Subscription is like a money funnel, because the receiving end is small (just one company) and the other end is wide (the whole country). 	 	On-Yomi: コウ   Kun-Yomi:"
posture	"posture 	 	構   	   	Lesson: 48   Frame: 1959   Strokes: 14   —   Jouyou Grade: 5   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: posture, tree, wood, funnel, cone, celery, again 	 	Tree . . . funnel. 	 	 	Ideal posture is standing tall like a tree and having a V shape like a funnel 	 	On-Yomi: コウ   Kun-Yomi: かま.える、かま.う  	Examples: 構う (かま.う), 構える (かま.える)"
gutter	"gutter 	 	溝   	   	Lesson: 48   Frame: 1960   Strokes: 13   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: gutter, water, water droplets, water pistol, funnel, cone, celery, again 	 	Water . . . funnel. 	 	 	A gutter funnels water. 	 	On-Yomi: コウ   Kun-Yomi: みぞ  	Examples: 溝 (みぞ)"
argument	"argument 	 	論   	   	Lesson: 48   Frame: 1961   Strokes: 15   —   Jouyou Grade: 6   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: argument, say, words, keitai, mouth, post-it note, meeting, scrapbook, glass canopy, hood, flowers 	 	Words . . . meeting . . . scrapbook. The argument here is a process of academic reasoning, not a personal quarrel or spat. 	 	 	Right part: academic conference (a meeting, some of the attendees making notes in scrapbooks during presentation). Argument at academic conferences is naturally carried out using words. 	 	On-Yomi: ロン   Kun-Yomi:"
ethics	"ethics 	 	倫   	   	Lesson: 48   Frame: 1962   Strokes: 10   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: ethics, person, post-it note, meeting, scrapbook, glass canopy, hood, flowers 	 	Person . . . meeting . . . scrapbook. 	 	 	Mr. T talks about ethics at the academic conference. ""I pity the fool who gets caught plagarizing someone else´s stuff!"". 	 	On-Yomi: リン   Kun-Yomi:"
wheel	"wheel 	 	輪   	   	Lesson: 48   Frame: 1963   Strokes: 15   —   Jouyou Grade: 4   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: wheel, car, post-it note, meeting, scrapbook, glass canopy, hood, flowers 	 	Car . . . meeting . . . scrapbook. 	 	 	During a talk at the academic conference, speaker shows an introductory slide depicting the structure of car, and then moves on to the more narrow topic of wheels. 	 	On-Yomi: リン   Kun-Yomi: わ  	Examples: 輪 (わ)"
partial	"partial 	 	偏   	   	Lesson: 48   Frame: 1964   Strokes: 11   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: partial, person, fishfinger, door, one, ceiling, flag, scrapbook, glass canopy, hood, flowers 	 	Person . . . door . . . scrapbook. The sense of the key-word is that of having a bias or preference for someone or something. 	 	 	Mr. T is partial to konbini hentai. He reads them for hours every day after work at his local konbini. (Primitive: KONBINI HENTAI, all the magazines(scrapbooks) by every konbini door in Japan). 	 	On-Yomi: ヘン   Kun-Yomi: かたよ.る  	Examples: 偏る (かたよ.る)"
everywhere	"everywhere 	 	遍   	   	Lesson: 48   Frame: 1965   Strokes: 12   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: everywhere, fishfinger, door, one, ceiling, flag, scrapbook, glass canopy, hood, flowers, road 	 	Door . . . scrapbook . . . a road. 	 	 	Go down the road in Japan and you will find comics EVERYWHERE, newpaper stands, 7-11, Tsutaya, even the supermarket. Comics are everywhere here along the road. 	 	On-Yomi: ヘン   Kun-Yomi: あまね.く"
compilation	"compilation 	 	編   	   	Lesson: 48   Frame: 1966   Strokes: 15   —   Jouyou Grade: 5   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: compilation, thread, spiderman, fishfinger, door, one, ceiling, flag, scrapbook, glass canopy, hood, flowers 	 	Thread . . . door . . . scrapbook. 	 	 	Raulir has a good idea. I prefer to think of the manga compilations as the individual comics (serials from the anthologies) bound together with a coarse thread down the spine, produced quickly and put on the market. Good way to recycle those pulpy manga, and since when has the consumer not gotten screwed in Japan? ;-). 	 	On-Yomi: ヘン   Kun-Yomi: あ.む、-あ.み  	Examples: 編む (あ.む)"
tome	"tome 	 	冊   	   	Lesson: 48   Frame: 1967   Strokes: 5   —   Jouyou Grade: 6   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: tome 	 	This key word is a counter for books. It differs from scrapbook both in the writing order and in the extension of the second horizontal stroke. 	 	 	Pictograph. I think of that Harry Potter spell book that had to be bound shut coz it wanted to eat you. 	 	On-Yomi: サツ、サク   Kun-Yomi: ふみ  	Examples: 冊子 (さっし), 別冊 (べっさつ)"
code	"code 	 	典   	   	Lesson: 48   Frame: 1969   Strokes: 8   —   Jouyou Grade: 4   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: code, bend, tool 	 	We introduce this character here because of its connection to the book-related kanji treated above. It is based on the character for bend (frame 1256), whose last stroke is lengthened to coincide with the first stroke of the element for tool. 	 	 	Coding is a tool which you can use to bend the computer to your will. 	 	On-Yomi: テン、デン   Kun-Yomi:"
family name	"family name 	 	氏   	   	Lesson: 49   Frame: 1970   Strokes: 4   —   Jouyou Grade: 4   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: family name, drop, fishhook, fishhook2 	 	Pay close attention to the stroke order of the elements when learning to write this character. The elements: a long drop . . . fishhook . . . a one . . . fishhook. 	 	 	Looks a bit like Ft => Family title => Family name. 	 	On-Yomi: シ   Kun-Yomi: うじ、-うじ  	Examples: 氏 (うじ)"
paper	"paper 	 	紙   	   	Lesson: 49   Frame: 1971   Strokes: 10   —   Jouyou Grade: 2   JLPT: 4   	Constituents: paper, thread, spiderman, family name 	 	Thread . . . family name. 	 	 	All that threads you to your family name is a piece of paper. (birth certificate). 	 	On-Yomi: シ   Kun-Yomi: かみ  	Examples: 紙 (かみ)"
marriage	"marriage 	 	婚   	   	Lesson: 49   Frame: 1972   Strokes: 11   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: marriage, woman, dusk, family name, day 	 	Woman . . . family name . . . day. 	 	 	Marriage is the day in this woman´s life where she gets a new family name. 	 	On-Yomi: コン   Kun-Yomi:"
lower	"lower 	 	低   	   	Lesson: 49   Frame: 1973   Strokes: 7   —   Jouyou Grade: 4   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: lower, person, calling card, family name, one, floor 	 	Person . . . calling card. 	 	 	A person bows low when presenting his business card. 	 	On-Yomi: テイ   Kun-Yomi: ひく.い、ひく.める、ひく.まる  	Examples: 低い (ひく.い), 低まる (ひく.まる), 低める (ひく.める)"
resist	"resist 	 	抵   	   	Lesson: 49   Frame: 1974   Strokes: 8   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: resist, finger, fingers, calling card, family name, one, floor 	 	Fingers . . . calling card. 	 	 	Japan business etiquette tip: When someone hands you a business card, resist the impulse to fiddle around with it with your fingers, and by all means resist the urge to use the card to pick gunk from under your fingernails. Just examine it carefully, ask politely about the (few by now) kanji that you don´t know, and put it away carefully in a location that shows your counterparts how important they are to you. 	 	On-Yomi: テイ   Kun-Yomi:"
bottom	"bottom 	 	底   	   	Lesson: 49   Frame: 1975   Strokes: 8   —   Jouyou Grade: 4   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: bottom, cave, calling card, family name, one, floor 	 	Cave . . . calling card. 	 	 	I put all those useless business cards at the bottom of a cave. 	 	On-Yomi: テイ   Kun-Yomi: そこ  	Examples: 底 (そこ)"
people	"people 	 	民   	   	Lesson: 49   Frame: 1976   Strokes: 5   —   Jouyou Grade: 4   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: people, mouth, family name 	 	In place of the drop at the start of the character for family name, we have a mouth, which makes you think of the ""vox populi."" 	 	 	All the people of the world with all their family names shouting with their big mouths. 	 	On-Yomi: ミン   Kun-Yomi: たみ  	Examples: 民 (たみ)"
sleep	"sleep 	 	眠   	   	Lesson: 49   Frame: 1977   Strokes: 10   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: sleep, eye, people, mouth, family name 	 	Eyes . . . people. 	 	 	In an Orwellian sense, the eye watching the people never sleeps. 	 	On-Yomi: ミン   Kun-Yomi: ねむ.る、ねむ.い  	Examples: 眠い (ねむ.い), 眠る (ねむ.る)"
catch	"catch 	 	捕   	   	Lesson: 49   Frame: 1978   Strokes: 10   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: catch, finger, fingers, dog-tag, arrowhead, screwdriver, utilize, utilise 	 	Fingers . . . dog tag. 	 	 	I was retreating from the battlefield. In the chaos, my friend threw his dogtags at me to give to his family. I managed to catch them with my fingers as the chopper was lifting off. 	 	On-Yomi: ホ   Kun-Yomi: と.らえる、と.らわれる、と.る、とら.える、とら.われる、つか.まえる、つか.まる  	Examples: 捕まえる (つか.まえる), 捕まる (つか.まる), 捕らえる (と.らえる), 捕らわれる (と.らわれる), 捕る (と.る)"
bay	"bay 	 	浦   	   	Lesson: 49   Frame: 1980   Strokes: 10   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: bay, water, water droplets, water pistol, dog-tag, arrowhead, screwdriver, utilize, utilise 	 	Water . . . dog tag. 	 	 	The water of the bay washes all the dog tags up after the battle. 	 	On-Yomi: ホ   Kun-Yomi: うら  	Examples: 浦 (うら)"
bullrush	"bullrush 	 	蒲   	   	Lesson: 49   Frame: 1981   Strokes: 13   —   Jouyou Grade: Names   JLPT:    	Constituents: bulrush, flowers, bay, water, water droplets, water pistol, dog-tag, arrowhead, screwdriver, utilize, utilise 	 	Flowers . . . bay. 	 	 	Bulrush was the flower that you could see near almost all bays in japan before the japanese started putting concrete everywhere. Just check how many percent of Japan´s coastline that is concretised... you´ll be surprised. 	 	On-Yomi: ホ、ボ、フ、ブ   Kun-Yomi: がま、かば、かま"
shop	"shop 	 	舗   	   	Lesson: 49   Frame: 1982   Strokes: 15   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: shop, cottage, little-thatch, umbrella, earthenware jar, lidded crock, soil, dirt, ground, mouth, dog-tag, arrowhead, screwdriver, utilize, utilise 	 	Cottage . . . dog tag. The key word refers to the noun, not the verb. 	 	 	A shop in an impoverished country is just a cottage with a dog tag identifying it. 	 	On-Yomi: ホ   Kun-Yomi:"
supplement	"supplement 	 	補   	   	Lesson: 49   Frame: 1983   Strokes: 12   —   Jouyou Grade: 6   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: supplement, cloak, dog-tag, arrowhead, screwdriver, utilize, utilise 	 	Cloak . . . dog tag. 	 	 	I usually hear supplement in ""dietry supplement"". So you´re given a cloak for extra fibre and dogtags for extra iron. Keeps you regular and stops you feeling tired and run-down. 	 	On-Yomi: ホ   Kun-Yomi: おぎな.う  	Examples: 補う (おぎな.う)"
residence	"residence 	 	邸   	   	Lesson: 49   Frame: 1984   Strokes: 8   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: residence, calling card, family name, one, floor, city walls 	 	Calling card . . . city walls. 	 	 	The business card says his residence is just to the left of the city walls. Can you find it? Yep, got it. 	 	On-Yomi: テイ   Kun-Yomi: やしき"
enclosure	"enclosure 	 	郭   	   	Lesson: 49   Frame: 1985   Strokes: 11   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: enclosure, receive, tall, top hat, mouth, child, children, city walls 	 	Receive . . . city walls. 	 	 	The city finally received the enclosure that it desperately needed, city walls to protect it against attacks from the tall kids. 	 	On-Yomi: カク   Kun-Yomi: くるわ"
county	"county 	 	郡   	   	Lesson: 49   Frame: 1986   Strokes: 10   —   Jouyou Grade: 4   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: county, old boy, mop, mouth, city walls 	 	Old boy . . . city walls. 	 	 	The old boy had never been outside of his own county because he couldn't get over the city walls. 	 	On-Yomi: グン   Kun-Yomi: こうり"
outskirts	"outskirts 	 	郊   	   	Lesson: 49   Frame: 1987   Strokes: 9   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: outskirts, mingle, top hat, father, city walls 	 	Mingle . . . city walls. 	 	 	The country folk and and the city folk mingle at the outskirts of town, just past the city walls. 	 	On-Yomi: コウ   Kun-Yomi:"
section	"section 	 	部   	   	Lesson: 49   Frame: 1988   Strokes: 11   —   Jouyou Grade: 3   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: section, muzzle, vase, stand up, mouth, city walls 	 	Muzzle . . . city walls. 	 	 	Within the city walls, this section of town was so noisy that we had to muzzle them up. 	 	On-Yomi: ブ   Kun-Yomi: -べ"
metropolis	"metropolis 	 	都   	   	Lesson: 49   Frame: 1989   Strokes: 11   —   Jouyou Grade: 3   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: metropolis, someone, puppet, sooty, old man, sun, day, city walls 	 	Someone . . . city walls. 	 	 	In a metropolis people are just puppets inside city walls, there is no individuality if you live so close together. 	 	On-Yomi: ト、ツ   Kun-Yomi: みやこ  	Examples: 都会 (とかい), 都心 (としん), 首都 (しゅと), 都 (みやこ)"
mail	"mail 	 	郵   	   	Lesson: 49   Frame: 1990   Strokes: 11   —   Jouyou Grade: 6   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: mail, droop, silage, city walls 	 	Droop . . . city walls. 	 	 	The drooping citywalls was generating a lot of angry mail for the city officials. Hint: think ""hate mail"" and you will remember this one. [thx CharleyGarrett]. 	 	On-Yomi: ユウ   Kun-Yomi:"
home country	"home country 	 	邦   	   	Lesson: 49   Frame: 1991   Strokes: 7   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: home country, bushes, city walls 	 	Bushes . . . city walls. 	 	 	He reminisced about his home country: ""Ah, back in my home country, the bushes grew so high that they covered the city walls!"". 	 	On-Yomi: ホウ   Kun-Yomi: くに"
hometown	"hometown 	 	郷   	   	Lesson: 49   Frame: 1993   Strokes: 11   —   Jouyou Grade: 6   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: home town, cocoon, silver, city walls 	 	Cocoon . . . silver . . . city walls. 	 	 	Your hometown is where you broke out of your cocoon (born), and where you left when your hair was silver (died), your whole life was spent inside the city walls. 	 	On-Yomi: キョウ、ゴウ   Kun-Yomi: さと  	Examples: 郷里 (きょうり), 郷土 (きょうど), 異郷 (いきょう)"
echo	"echo 	 	響   	   	Lesson: 49   Frame: 1994   Strokes: 20   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: echo, home town, cocoon, silver, city walls, sound, vase, stand up, sun, day, tongue wagging 	 	Hometown . . . sound. 	 	 	People´s voices are like echoes of sounds from their hometowns....you can always tell where they´re from by how they talk. 	 	On-Yomi: キョウ   Kun-Yomi: ひび.く  	Examples: 響く (ひび.く)"
son	"son 	 	郎   	   	Lesson: 49   Frame: 1995   Strokes: 9   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: son, halo, good, drop, silver, city walls 	 	Halo . . . city walls. 	 	 	The daughter is a good girl that grows up to be a woman. The son is a good boy that grows up to defend the city walls. 	 	On-Yomi: ロウ、リョウ   Kun-Yomi: おとこ"

sequential	"sequential 	 	循   	   	Lesson: 50   Frame: 1998   Strokes: 12   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: sequential, Nelson, column, going, line, shield, drag, ten, needle, eye 	 	Line . . . shield. 	 	 	This is mostly used in the word 循環, ""circulation"" (of buses through their routes, of blood, etc). So I think of a column of little Roman soldiers with their shields marching sequentially through the veins of a person, as an anthropomorphization of the immune system. 	 	On-Yomi: ジュン   Kun-Yomi:"
faction	"faction 	 	派   	   	Lesson: 50   Frame: 1999   Strokes: 9   —   Jouyou Grade: 6   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: faction, water, water droplets, water pistol, caveman, drag, person, rag 	 	Water . . . drag . . . rag. Back in frame 1127 we indicated that this latter radical would come up once again, as it does in this and the following two frames. 	 	 	Drag + rag gave me trouble until I came up with zombie for it. The zombie population became more diverse, separating into different factions. One of them being the water Zombies. 	 	On-Yomi: ハ   Kun-Yomi:"
vein	"vein 	 	脈   	   	Lesson: 50 &nbsp; Frame: 2000 &nbsp; Strokes: 10 &nbsp; &mdash; &nbsp; Jouyou Grade: 4 &nbsp; JLPT: 1   	Constituents: vein, moon, month, flesh, part of the body, caveman, drag, person, rag 	 	Part of body . . . drag . . . rag. parcel post	"parcel post 	 	逓   	   	Lesson: 50   Frame: 2002   Strokes: 10   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: parcel post, drag, cornstalk, belt, road 	 	Drag . . . cornstalk . . . belt . . . road. 	 	 	Picture a crude drag-sled - in this case, made from cornstalks that have been belted together - filled with parcels, that the postman drags along behind him down the road along his delivery route. grade	"grade 	 	段   	   	Lesson: 50   Frame: 2003   Strokes: 9   —   Jouyou Grade: 6   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: grade, staple gun, cruise missile, missile, wind, crotch 	 	The kanji connoting rank or class shows us a new element on the left: the familiar primitive for staples with an additional stroke cutting through the vertical stroke. It is easiest in these cases to make a primitive related to what we already know. Hence, we call it a staple gun. To the right, missile. 	 	 	This is a military-grade staple gun! It can be loaded with real missiles. 	 	On-Yomi: ダン、タン   Kun-Yomi:"
forge	"forge 	 	鍛   	   	Lesson: 50   Frame: 2004   Strokes: 17   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: forge, metal, gold, grade, staple gun, cruise missile, missile, wind, crotch 	 	Metal . . . grade. 	 	 	As a discriminating metalsmith, I use the highest grade metals when forging such precision devices as staple guns and missiles. 	 	On-Yomi: タン   Kun-Yomi: きた.える  	Examples: 鍛える (きた.える)"
empress	"empress 	 	后   	   	Lesson: 50   Frame: 2005   Strokes: 6   —   Jouyou Grade: 6   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: empress, drag, one, ceiling, mouth 	 	Drag . . . one . . . mouth. 	 	 	The empress is cruel. Normally she´ll violently pull her servants by the ear when they´ve failed to follow orders. But one time she dragged this one guy around the palace by the mouth. She must have been really angry—ever since that moment, he´s never been seen again. 	 	On-Yomi: コウ、ゴ   Kun-Yomi: きさき"

parts of speech	"parts of speech 	 	詞   	   	Lesson: 50   Frame: 2009   Strokes: 12   —   Jouyou Grade: 6   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: part of speech, say, words, keitai, mouth, director, Ken Russel, clothes hanger, coat hanger, one, mouth, mouth2 	 	The key word, parts of speech, refers to nouns, verbs, adjective, adverbs, and so on. The elements: words . . . directors. 	 	 	Parts of speech act as word directors, giving it meaning and indicating its correct placement and usage in grammar. 	 	On-Yomi: シ   Kun-Yomi:"
domesticate	"domesticate 	 	飼   	   	Lesson: 50   Frame: 2010   Strokes: 13   —   Jouyou Grade: 5   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: domesticate, eat, food, umbrella, good, halo, drop, silver, director, Ken Russel, clothes hanger, coat hanger, one, mouth 	 	Eat . . . director. The sense is of rearing of animals. 	 	 	When you DOMESTICATE a animal, you are the DIRECTOR of it´s life and what it EATS. 	 	On-Yomi: シ   Kun-Yomi: か.う  	Examples: 飼う (か.う)"
heir	"heir 	 	嗣   	   	Lesson: 50   Frame: 2011   Strokes: 13   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: heir, mouth, scrapbook, glass canopy, hood, flowers, director, Ken Russel, clothes hanger, coat hanger, one, mouth 	 	Mouth . . . scrapbook . . . director. 	 	 	The lawyer called all the heirs into a meeting. Everybody else received cars, property, and the like. When it got to be my turn the lawyer informed me I would be receiving a scrapbook. My mouth dropped open. A scrapbook?! No Ferrari, no mansion, ...scrapbook?! Turns out the scrapbook was of my great uncle's company, and I had been named the new director of the multi-million dollar business. My mouth literally hit the scrapbook when I learned I'd be director. 	 	On-Yomi: シ   Kun-Yomi:"
boat	"boat 	 	舟   	   	Lesson: 50   Frame: 2012   Strokes: 6   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: boat 	 	After the drop and the glass canopy, we come to a combination of three strokes that we met only once before, in the character for mama (frame 105). The pictographic meaning we gave it there has no etymological relationship to this character, but use it if it helps. 	 	 	I see this kanji as a pictograph of a two story boat seen from the front. The glass canopy is the body of the boat. The drop on top is the chimney. The horizontal line is the ceiling/floor between the the 1st/2nd floor. Finally, the two drops in the middle are the lights on the decks. 	 	On-Yomi: シュウ   Kun-Yomi: ふね、ふな-、-ぶね  	Examples: 舟 (ふね)"
liner	"liner 	 	舶   	   	Lesson: 50   Frame: 2013   Strokes: 11   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: liner, boat, white, dove 	 	The type of boat connoted by this key word is a large oceangoing liner. The important thing here is to work with the elements boat and dove to make an image distinct from that of the former frame. Don't count on size alone to distinguish the boat from the liner. 	 	 	The most famous LINER is the Titanic, which struck an iceberg and sunk. Just imagine that huge LINER strucking an even huger mass of white ice. 	 	On-Yomi: ハク   Kun-Yomi:"
navigate	"navigate 	 	航   	   	Lesson: 50   Frame: 2014   Strokes: 10   —   Jouyou Grade: 4   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: navigate, boat, whirlwind, top hat, wind 	 	Boat . . . whirlwind. 	 	 	To navigate a ""boat"" through a ""whirlwind"" takes a skilled navigator. 	 	On-Yomi: コウ   Kun-Yomi:"
carrier	"carrier 	 	般   	   	Lesson: 50   Frame: 2016   Strokes: 10   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: carrier, boat, cruise missile, missile, wind, crotch 	 	Boat . . . missile. 	 	 	Carrier?! This means ""general"" (as in the general public or generally). OK.. Carriers, i.e. boats with missiles, are not available to the general public. 	 	On-Yomi: ハン   Kun-Yomi:"

When workers neglect workplace safety, their fingers get cut off and carried away by the conveyor belt, which looks like a ´finger carrier´ in that case. 	 	On-Yomi: ハン   Kun-Yomi:"
