arc	"arc 	 	弧   	   	Lesson: 50   Frame: 2023   Strokes: 9   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: arc, bow, melon, claw, vulture, elbow 	 	Bow . . . melon. 	 	 	When you use a bow to shoot a melon, the arc varies depending on how far away you are. 	 	On-Yomi: コ   Kun-Yomi:"
orphan	"orphan 	 	孤   	   	Lesson: 50   Frame: 2024   Strokes: 9   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: orphan, child, melon, claw, vulture, elbow 	 	Child . . . melon. 	 	 	An orphan will never know the joys on sucking on his mother´s melons........ 	 	On-Yomi: コ   Kun-Yomi:"
cocoon	"cocoon 	 	繭   	   	Lesson: 51   Frame: 2025   Strokes: 18   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: cocoon, flowers, hood, stick, thread, spiderman, insect 	 	Though it's a good thing that the primitive for cocoon has been radically abbreviated from this, its full form as a kanji, the story it holds is a charming one. The silkworm (insect) eats the leaves of the mulberry bush (the flowers), digests them and transforms them into thread with which it spins about itself, in mystic wisdom, its own coffin (the hood). The dividing line that separates the two elements helps the picture of the little worm cutting itself off from contact with the outside world, but as a character stroke, it is a clear exception. 	 	 	This is a simple two-column manga showing the metamorphosis of a caterpillar into a cocoon. First, the caterpillar gets under a large flower (bees tend to hang around flowers, which scare away other predators). Then, in the first frame, we see the caterpillar (insect). Then, a bar separating this frame from the next frame (remember that Japanese manga run the other way!), in which we see the insect covered with thread, making a beautiful cocoon. 	 	On-Yomi: ケン   Kun-Yomi: まゆ、きぬ  	Examples: 繭 (まゆ)"
benefit	"benefit 	 	益   	   	Lesson: 51   Frame: 2026   Strokes: 10   —   Jouyou Grade: 5   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: benefit, animal horns, one, floor, animal legs, eight, dish 	 	Poised over the dish here is a pair of animal horns that are attached to a pair of animal legs by a single horizontal stroke. 	 	 	The benefit of having sharp horns and fast legs is that an animal can get to the food dish first. 	 	On-Yomi: エキ、ヤク   Kun-Yomi: ま.す  	Examples: 有益 (ゆうえき), 利益 (りえき), 益する (まする), 益 (やく)"
spare time	"spare time 	 	暇   	   	Lesson: 51   Frame: 2027   Strokes: 13   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: spare time, sun, day, hobby, staples, mouth, box, crotch, box2 	 	The element for day on the left is logical enough. Next to it we see staples being held in mouth (one stroke is doubled up), indicating working in one's hobby or handicrafts at home on one's spare time. The small box at the top right is facing backwards, or more properly ""inside out."" Finally, we have the crotch at the bottom. 	 	 	Some jackass-like people have way too much spare time. You can find video´s of them all over the internet, if you like such things, you can watch it all day. You see them stapling their mouths shut, or throwing eachother upside down in boxes or kicking each other in the crotch. 	 	On-Yomi: カ   Kun-Yomi: ひま、いとま  	Examples: 暇 (ひま)"
spread	"spread 	 	敷   	   	Lesson: 51   Frame: 2028   Strokes: 15   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: spread, arrowhead, rice field, brains, compass, direction, taskmaster 	 	At the top we have the arrowhead whose vertical line joins it to the rice field (or brains) below it. Beneath it, the compass; and to the right, the taskmaster. 	 	 	Instead of being glued to one specialty (#46) 専, I decided to spread my attention in many directions 方, and be a taskmaster at none. 	 	On-Yomi: フ   Kun-Yomi: し.く、-し.き  	Examples: 敷く (し.く)"
come	"come 	 	来   	   	Lesson: 51   Frame: 2029   Strokes: 7   —   Jouyou Grade: 2   JLPT: 5   	Constituents: come, not yet, animal horns 	 	This odd but common kanji is built up of the character for not yet into which a pair of animal horns has been inserted. 	 	 	You horny bastard, don´t come, at least not yet! 	 	On-Yomi: ライ、タイ   Kun-Yomi: く.る、きた.る、きた.す、き.たす、き.たる、き、こ  	Examples: 来す (きた.す), 来る (きた.る), 来る (く.る)"
spirit	"spirit 	 	気   	   	Lesson: 51   Frame: 2030   Strokes: 6   —   Jouyou Grade: 1   JLPT: 5   	Constituents: spirit, landed fish, reclining, lying down, one, floor, fishhook, sheaf 	 	The spirit in this character refers to the changeable moods and airs of one's personality as well as to the more essential combination of vital forces that distinguish things and individuals one from the other. Its elements are: reclining . . . floor . . . fishhook . . . sheaf. Do not confuse with spirits (Frame 1930). 	 	 	You´re reclining on the floor trying to hook a sheaf with a small hook through the cracks. That you´ve been doing this for seven hours without success shows your burning spirit. 	 	On-Yomi: キ、ケ   Kun-Yomi: いき  	Examples: 気体 (きたい), 気候 (きこう), 元気 (げんき)"
vapor	"vapor 	 	汽   	   	Lesson: 51   Frame: 2031   Strokes: 7   —   Jouyou Grade: 2   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: vapor, water, water droplets, water pistol, landed fish, reclining, lying down, one, floor, fishhook 	 	Think of this character as a sibling of that for spirit. Simply replace sheaves with drops of water on the left in order to get vapor. 	 	 	Water vapor almost looks like a spirit but has no soul. 	 	On-Yomi: キ   Kun-Yomi:"
fly	"fly 	 	飛   	   	Lesson: 51   Frame: 2032   Strokes: 9   —   Jouyou Grade: 4   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: fly, hook, propeller, measuring box, thousand, needles, propeller2 	 	The two large hooks have little propellers (the two drops on each hook) attached to them for flying. Beneath is the measuring box, which serves as the body of this flying contraption. The stroke order will cause some problems, so take care with it. 	 	 	Hooks with small wings attached look like hummingbirds with a long beak. Two hummingbirds are trying to fly away with our little measuring box. What do they want it for? 	 	On-Yomi: ヒ   Kun-Yomi: と.ぶ、と.ばす、-と.ばす  	Examples: 飛ばす (と.ばす), 飛ぶ (と.ぶ)"
sink	"sink 	 	沈   	   	Lesson: 51   Frame: 2033   Strokes: 7   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: sink, water, water droplets, water pistol, garter, crown, human legs 	 	The technique for sinking used in this kanji is unique. Rather than the biblical image of tying a millstone about the victim's neck, here we see a crown tied about one leg before the unfortunate party is tossed into the water. 	 	 	(thx geezer) The maimed waitress (no head and arms just her legs and trunk) is dropped into the water with a cement crown to make sure she sinks. She shouldn´t have been so nosy about her yakuza-boyfriend´s schemes. 	 	On-Yomi: チン、ジン   Kun-Yomi: しず.む、しず.める  	Examples: 沈む (しず.む), 沈める (しず.める)"
wife	"wife 	 	妻   	   	Lesson: 51   Frame: 2035   Strokes: 8   —   Jouyou Grade: 5   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: wife, ten, needle, rake, woman 	 	Ten . . . rakes . . . woman. 	 	 	Ten rakes woman. your wife digs her fingernails into you and it feels like 10 rakes when she finds you ontop of another woman. 	 	On-Yomi: サイ   Kun-Yomi: つま  	Examples: 妻 (つま)"
decline	"decline 	 	衰   	   	Lesson: 51   Frame: 2037   Strokes: 10   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: decline, pathetic, stick, top hat, scarf, mouth 	 	Let this key word connote the decline and fall of the Roman Empire. It shows a fellow in a top hat and scarf, trying hard to look happy by putting a walking stick in his mouth sideways to twist his face into a grotesque but semi permanent smile. 	 	 	If you thought that the dude in 哀 was pathetic, you haven´t seen him after his decline. Here he is carrying a stick around in his mouth like a dog, begging people to throw it for him. Note that the mouth is closed only after the stick goes in, as is only logical. 	 	On-Yomi: スイ   Kun-Yomi: おとろ.える  	Examples: 衰える (おとろ.える)"
inmost	"inmost 	 	衷   	   	Lesson: 51   Frame: 2038   Strokes: 9   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: inmost, ten, needle, mouth, scarf 	 	Between the top hat and the scarf you will see the character for in which is truncated at the bottom so as not to interfere with the scarf. You can think of this character forming as a pair with that of the former frame: there the in (the walking stick in the mouth) was set on its side; here it is set upright. 	 	 	The guy from pathetic (#401) shared his inmost feelings with a girl and she rammed a walking stick down his throat. It ruptured his inmost organs. 	 	On-Yomi: チュウ   Kun-Yomi:"
mask	"mask 	 	面   	   	Lesson: 51   Frame: 2039   Strokes: 9   —   Jouyou Grade: 3   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: mask, hundred, one, ceiling, drop, pent in, eye 	 	Imagine a mask over your head with eyes peeping out from all over the head, a hundred in all (the element for eye displacing the fifth stroke of that for hundred). 	 	 	If you´re wearing a mask, a hundred eyes can look at you but none of them will know who you are. 	 	On-Yomi: メン、ベン   Kun-Yomi: おも、おもて、つら  	Examples: 面 (おも), 面 (おもて), 面 (つら)"
leather	"leather 	 	革   	   	Lesson: 51   Frame: 2041   Strokes: 9   —   Jouyou Grade: 6   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: leather, flowers, car, mouth, ten, needle 	 	After the flowers at the top (painted on the leather for decoration), we see the element for car with the middle stroke left out. Think of the seats having been taken out so that they can be reupholstered with this decorated leather. 	 	 	I asked the street vendor the price of the LEATHER jacket. He said TWENTY, but with my MOUTH, I talked him down to TEN. (correct stroke order). 	 	On-Yomi: カク   Kun-Yomi: かわ  	Examples: 革 (かわ)"
shoes	"shoes 	 	靴   	   	Lesson: 51   Frame: 2042   Strokes: 13   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: shoes, leather, flowers, car, mouth, ten, needle, change, person, spoon, sitting on the ground 	 	Leather . . . change. 	 	 	Leather shoes are nice because they change shape to fit your foot. 	 	On-Yomi: カ   Kun-Yomi: くつ  	Examples: 靴 (くつ)"
hegemony	"hegemony 	 	覇   	   	Lesson: 51   Frame: 2043   Strokes: 19   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: hegemony, old west, leather, flowers, car, mouth, ten, needle, moon, month, flesh, part of the body 	 	Old West . . . leather . . . moon. 	 	 	In the old west, animal skins were made into leather and their flesh was eaten, thus using the whole animal, which viewed from the animal side could be taken as humans asserting complete hegemony over them. All your base are belong to us. 	 	On-Yomi: ハ、ハク   Kun-Yomi: はたがしら"
voice	"voice 	 	声   	   	Lesson: 51   Frame: 2044   Strokes: 7   —   Jouyou Grade: 2   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: voice, samurai, flag, stick 	 	The samurai at the top is familiar enough. The combination beneath, which looks like a flag with a line running through it, is not. Try to devise some way to take note of it, and pay attention to the writing. 	 	 	Having lost his voice, the samurai comunicated to his troops with a striped flag. 	 	On-Yomi: セイ、ショウ   Kun-Yomi: こえ、こわ-  	Examples: 声楽 (せいがく), 声援 (せいえん), 名声 (めいせい), 声 (こえ)"
give	"give 	 	呉   	   	Lesson: 51   Frame: 2046   Strokes: 7   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: give, mouth, chair, tool, animal legs 	 	The complex of strokes in this kanji is unusual and difficult, because of the fourth stroke, which is rare (see frames 33 and 34). The mouth and tool are already familiar. 	 	 	Picture of a person facing you. 口 is the head. His right arm is raised (your left), to give you something from a tray 一. His legs ハ are below the tray. 呉れる、くれる, to give: 伯父がこの時計を呉れました, ""My uncle gave me this watch."" Following -て form of another verb, means ""to do the favor of"": 窓を開けて呉れませんか, ""Won't you open the window [do the favor of opening/kindly open the window]?"" Usu. written in hiragana. 	 	On-Yomi: ゴ   Kun-Yomi: く.れる、くれ"
recreation	"recreation 	 	娯   	   	Lesson: 51   Frame: 2047   Strokes: 10   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: recreation, woman, give, mouth, chair, tool, animal legs 	 	Woman . . . give. 	 	 	A woman gives up her recreation time in order to raise a family. 	 	On-Yomi: ゴ   Kun-Yomi:"
mistake	"mistake 	 	誤   	   	Lesson: 51   Frame: 2048   Strokes: 14   —   Jouyou Grade: 6   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: mistake, say, words, keitai, mouth, give, mouth, chair, tool, animal legs, mouth2 	 	Words . . . give. 	 	 	You must give words of apology when you make a mistake. 	 	On-Yomi: ゴ   Kun-Yomi: あやま.る、-あやま.る  	Examples: 誤る (あやま.る)"
steam	"steam 	 	蒸   	   	Lesson: 51   Frame: 2049   Strokes: 13   —   Jouyou Grade: 6   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: steam, flowers, helping hand, complete, water, one, floor, oven-fire, barbecue 	 	The flower at the top and the floor with the oven fire beneath are familiar. The problem is what comes in between. It is formed by the character for complete, whose vertical stroke doubles up as the first stroke of water. 	 	 	Think of a picture of someone steaming vegetables. On top you see the flowers of cauliflower or something else that is being steamed. Underneath, the pan is completely full of water. Below the pan is a floor - that's the hotplate - and under that the oven fire. Caution: don't confuse with boil (#1257), or the steam radical in spirit (#1885). 	 	On-Yomi: ジョウ、セイ   Kun-Yomi: む.す、む.れる、む.らす  	Examples: 蒸す (む.す), 蒸らす (む.らす), 蒸れる (む.れる)"
acquiesce	"acquiesce 	 	承   	   	Lesson: 51   Frame: 2050   Strokes: 8   —   Jouyou Grade: 5   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: acquiesce, water, complete, three 	 	The sense of passive acceptance or reception of information is contained in this key word. The form is based on the middle portion of the preceding character, with three additional strokes, best thought of as the kanji for three. 	 	 	To get someone to completely acquiesce it takes 3 dunks in the water before they give. 	 	On-Yomi: ショウ、ジョウ   Kun-Yomi: うけたまわ.る、う.ける、ささ.げる、とど.める、たす.ける、こ.らす、つい.で、すく.う  	Examples: 承る (うけたまわ.る)"
bin	"bin 	 	函   	   	Lesson: 51   Frame: 2051   Strokes: 8   —   Jouyou Grade: Names   JLPT:    	Constituents: bin, snare, sparkler, shovel 	 	This is the character from which the element for shovel derives. Within it comes the element for snare, with the sparkler surrounding it. 	 	 	Damn racoons ill show them. I put a snare in the bin as well as a few phosphorous sparklers so as to scare the shit out of the buggers as they rummage through my bin. 	 	On-Yomi: カン   Kun-Yomi: はこ、い.れる"
poles	"poles 	 	極   	   	Lesson: 51   Frame: 2052   Strokes: 12   —   Jouyou Grade: 4   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: poles, decay, tree, wood, snare, mouth, crotch, one, floor 	 	The poles this key word refers to are the extremities of the earth or the terminals of an electric field. The elements are: tree . . . snare . . . mouth . . . crotch . . . floor. 	 	 	Can simplify this using decay (#1243). Then: The expedition to the poles is bad for your health, and the decay that started in your mouth spreads to your crotch – at which point you fall to the floor. 	 	On-Yomi: キョク、ゴク   Kun-Yomi: きわ.める、きわ.まる、きわ.まり、きわ.み、き.める、-ぎ.め、き.まる  	Examples: 極限 (きょくげん), 終極 (おわりきょく), 積極的 (せっきょくてき), 極まる (きわ.まる), 極み (きわ.み), 極める (きわ.める)"
tusk	"tusk 	 	牙   	   	Lesson: 52   Frame: 2053   Strokes: 4   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT:    	Constituents: tusk 	 	If you play with this primitive's form with pencil and paper, you will see that it begins with a box-like shape, and ends with the final two strokes of the halberd, a convenient combination for the tusk protruding from the mouth of an animal. 	  * Since this kanji has 4 strokes, you would expect that as a primitive it would also have 4 - but in fact it has 5 in the following two frames (the second stroke between divided into 2 strokes) and reverts to 4 again in frame 2056. 	 	The kanji looks like an elephant with tusks. the box is the elephant´s eye. The final stroke is the tusk. 	 	On-Yomi: ガ、ゲ   Kun-Yomi: きば、は、きばへん  	Examples: 牙 (きば)"
bud	"bud 	 	芽   	   	Lesson: 52   Frame: 2054   Strokes: 8   —   Jouyou Grade: 4   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: bud, flowers, tusk 	 	Flowers . . . tusk. 	 	 	Buds while they´re still small tend to be tusk-shaped. 	 	On-Yomi: ガ   Kun-Yomi: め  	Examples: 芽 (め)"
wicked	"wicked 	 	邪   	   	Lesson: 52   Frame: 2055   Strokes: 8   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: wicked, tusk, city walls 	 	Tusk . . . city walls. 	 	 	The wicked queen builds her city walls out of menacing tusks. 	 	On-Yomi: ジャ   Kun-Yomi: よこし.ま"
gracious	"gracious 	 	雅   	   	Lesson: 52   Frame: 2056   Strokes: 13   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: gracious, tusk, turkey 	 	Tusk . . . an old turkey. 	 	 	Goodness gracious! Such an elegant turkey with a tusk. This mnemonic is meant to join RtK´s keyword with a better proposition. Heisig could have used ""elegant"" here, which is not confounded so easily with graceful (#721), and accurately represents the character´s meaning (it is also the chosen keyword in Kodansha´s Kanji Learner´s Dictionary). 	 	On-Yomi: ガ   Kun-Yomi: みや.び"
interpretation	"interpretation 	 	釈   	   	Lesson: 52   Frame: 2057   Strokes: 11   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: explanation, animal tracks, drop, rice, shaku-hachi, flag, stick 	 	Animal tracks . . . shakuhachi. 	 	 	Animal track primitive: As expected, animal tracks were left in place of the trail of rice I´d purposely dropped the night before. EDIT - also try the footprint for a primitive meaning, the classic symbol of detective films. STORY: This shakuhachi player is so talented, he can do interpretations of animal noises too. They´re so realistic he soon has animal tracks leading straight to wherever he´s playing. 	 	On-Yomi: シャク、セキ   Kun-Yomi: とく、す.てる、ゆる.す"
turn	"turn 	 	番   	   	Lesson: 52   Frame: 2058   Strokes: 12   —   Jouyou Grade: 2   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: turn, dice, animal tracks, drop, rice, rice field, brains 	 	This key word has been chosen for its overlay of several meanings similar to those of the kanji: a turn of duty, a round, a number, and so forth. Its composite elements: animal tracks . . . rice field. 	  * As a primitive element, we choose the image of a pair of dice which it is your turn to throw. 	 	The famers take it in turns to watch out for any animal tracks on their rice field. 	 	On-Yomi: バン   Kun-Yomi: つが.い"
hearing	"hearing 	 	審   	   	Lesson: 52   Frame: 2059   Strokes: 15   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: hearing, house, dice, animal tracks, drop, rice, rice field, brains 	 	The hearing referred to in this character relates to trials in the courts. The elements: house . . . dice. 	 	 	At your divorce hearing the judge tells you to roll dice to see who keeps the house. (""I can´t believe what I´m hearing!"" you say). 	 	On-Yomi: シン   Kun-Yomi: つまび.らか、つぶさ.に"
flip	"flip 	 	翻   	   	Lesson: 52   Frame: 2060   Strokes: 18   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: flip, dice, animal tracks, drop, rice, rice field, brains, feathers, wings 	 	Dice . . . feathers. 	 	 	Flipping the bird: After finding out the dice is crooked, you kindly present the middle feather to the dealer. 	 	On-Yomi: ホン、ハン   Kun-Yomi: ひるがえ.る、ひるがえ.す  	Examples: 翻す (ひるがえ.す), 翻る (ひるがえ.る)"
clan	"clan 	 	藩   	   	Lesson: 52   Frame: 2061   Strokes: 18   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: clan, flowers, water, water droplets, water pistol, dice, animal tracks, drop, rice, rice field, brains 	 	Flowers . . . water . . . dice. 	 	 	This character refers to feudal clans that were abolished in 1871 (Meiji 4) in favor of prefectures (廃藩置県), and thus were predecessors of the modern prefectures. As we know from 落, flowers and water drops each have their own way of falling. This character says that clans´ location was decided in the way flowers, water drops and dice fall: at random. See http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Han_%28country_subdivision%29. 	 	On-Yomi: ハン   Kun-Yomi:"
fur	"fur 	 	毛   	   	Lesson: 52   Frame: 2062   Strokes: 4   —   Jouyou Grade: 2   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: fur 	 	This character simply reverses the direction of the final stroke of hand to produce fur. If you reverse your hand and put its palm down, you will have the side on which fur grows. 	 	 	I´ve heard of people having hair on the back of their hands, but this is ridiculous! That´s not hair, that´s fur! 	 	On-Yomi: モウ   Kun-Yomi: け  	Examples: 毛 (け)"
decrease	"decrease 	 	耗   	   	Lesson: 52   Frame: 2063   Strokes: 10   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: decrease, christmas tree, fur 	 	Christmas tree . . . fur. 	 	 	The amount of ""fur"" (needles) on a Christmas tree decreases, until it doesn´t look all that good. 	 	On-Yomi: モウ、コウ、カウ   Kun-Yomi:   	Examples: 消耗 (しょうもう)"
tail	"tail 	 	尾   	   	Lesson: 52   Frame: 2064   Strokes: 7   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: tail, flag, fur 	 	Flag . . . fur. 	 	 	A dog waves its furry tail like a flag. 	 	On-Yomi: ビ   Kun-Yomi: お  	Examples: 尾 (お)"
home	"home 	 	宅   	   	Lesson: 52   Frame: 2065   Strokes: 6   —   Jouyou Grade: 6   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: home, house, lock of hair 	 	House . . . lock of hair. 	 	 	This kanji is, of course, pronounced ""taku"", and it seems the owner of this home is a little bit otaku himself. He has hung up locks of hair suruptitiously obtained from various females all over his house. A veritable hair fetishist, and certainly someone whose home you wouldn´t want to visit. 	 	On-Yomi: タク   Kun-Yomi:"
consign	"consign 	 	託   	   	Lesson: 52   Frame: 2066   Strokes: 10   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: consign, say, words, keitai, mouth, lock of hair 	 	Words . . . lock of hair. 	 	 	When you consign a matter to someone, you get their word and a lock of their hair (to be used in a voodoo ritual if they don´t keep their word). 	 	On-Yomi: タク   Kun-Yomi: かこつ.ける、かこ.つ、かこ.つける"
do	"do 	 	為   	   	Lesson: 52   Frame: 2067   Strokes: 9   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: do, so, strange building, tail feathers 	 	This character rightly belongs to the previous lesson, but we held it until now because of the final element, the tail feathers. After the drop at the outset, the next three strokes are completely novel and should be given special attention. 	 	 	In this kanji, you can see 3 katakana characters: ソ, ユ, and then ユ again followed by TAIL FEATHERS. STORY: ""So (ソ) you (ユ) wanna DO it?"" ""Only if you (ユ) do"" says the female bird as she raises her TAIL FEATHERS. 	 	On-Yomi: イ   Kun-Yomi: ため、な.る、な.す、す.る、たり、つく.る、なり"
falsehood	"falsehood 	 	偽   	   	Lesson: 52   Frame: 2068   Strokes: 11   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: falsehood, person, do, so, strange building, tail feathers 	 	Person . . . do. 	 	 	A person who claims he didn't do something while he actually did, is telling a falsehood. 	 	On-Yomi: ギ、カ   Kun-Yomi: いつわ.る、にせ、いつわ.り  	Examples: 偽る (いつわ.る), 偽 (にせ)"
long	"long 	 	長   	   	Lesson: 52   Frame: 2070   Strokes: 8   —   Jouyou Grade: 2   JLPT: 5   	Constituents: long, hair, hairpin, safety-pin 	 	In line with the story of the preceding frame, the hair that needs the hairpin is long. 	  * The primitive of this kanji has two more shapes in addition to that of the kanji itself. Above its relative primitive, it is abbreviated form will mean hair. Further abbreviated,  it will mean the long, mangy mane of an animal. 	 	The Geisha with long hair uses an ornate lacquered hairpin to bundle it all up. 	 	On-Yomi: チョウ   Kun-Yomi: なが.い、おさ  	Examples: 長い (なが.い)"
lengthen	"lengthen 	 	張   	   	Lesson: 52   Frame: 2071   Strokes: 11   —   Jouyou Grade: 5   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: lengthen, bow, long 	 	Bow . . . long. 	 	 	The longbow is follows the design of a standard bow, only it has been lengthened. 	 	On-Yomi: チョウ   Kun-Yomi: は.る、-は.り、-ば.り  	Examples: 張る (は.る)"
notebook	"notebook 	 	帳   	   	Lesson: 52   Frame: 2072   Strokes: 11   —   Jouyou Grade: 3   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: notebook, towel, long 	 	Towel . . . long. 	 	 	In ancient China books were rolled-up scrolls of paper. So notebooks were nothing more than long towels. 	 	On-Yomi: チョウ   Kun-Yomi: とばり"
dilate	"dilate 	 	脹   	   	Lesson: 52   Frame: 2073   Strokes: 12   —   Jouyou Grade: Names   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: dilate, moon, month, flesh, part of the body, long 	 	Flesh . . . long. 	 	 	Taking Viagra let´s your blood vessels dilate...resulting in a body part getting long. 	 	On-Yomi: チョウ   Kun-Yomi: は.れる、ふく.らむ、ふく.れる"
hair of the head	"hair of the head 	 	髪   	   	Lesson: 52   Frame: 2074   Strokes: 14   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: hair of the head, hairstyle, hair, shape, friend 	 	Hair . . . shape . . . friend. 	 	 	Japanese teenage girls consider the style of the hair of the head very important. If a particular style is trendy, soon they all want their own hair in the same shape as that of their friends. 	 	On-Yomi: ハツ   Kun-Yomi: かみ  	Examples: 髪 (かみ)"
unfold	"unfold 	 	展   	   	Lesson: 52   Frame: 2075   Strokes: 10   —   Jouyou Grade: 6   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: unfold, flag, salad, hairpin, safety-pin 	 	Flag . . . salad . . . hairpin. 	 	 	Unfold flag, take out the salad, pin the flag down with hairpins and have a picnic. 	 	On-Yomi: テン   Kun-Yomi:"
miss	"miss 	 	喪   	   	Lesson: 52   Frame: 2076   Strokes: 12   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: miss, soil, dirt, ground, mouth, hairpin, safety-pin, mouth2 	 	Soil . . . two mouths . . . hairpin. Hint: see spit (Frame 162). The key word carries the wide range of meanings readily associated with it: error, loss, absence, and so on. 	 	 	I miss my parents dearly. Here they lay, under a big cross, their mouths side by side. I stick hairpins in their graves. CAREFUL: the stroke order/primitive order is: ten, L mouth, R mouth, hairpin. ""Soil"" is not drawn in its stroke order. 	 	On-Yomi: ソウ   Kun-Yomi: も  	Examples: 喪 (も)"
nest	"nest 	 	巣   	   	Lesson: 53   Frame: 2077   Strokes: 11   —   Jouyou Grade: 4   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: nest, owl, fruit, rice field, brains, tree, wood 	 	Owl . . . fruit. 	 	 	The nest atop of a tree contains the fruit of the owl: its offspring. 	 	On-Yomi: ソウ   Kun-Yomi: す、す.くう  	Examples: 巣 (す)"
simple	"simple 	 	単   	   	Lesson: 53   Frame: 2078   Strokes: 9   —   Jouyou Grade: 4   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: simple, owl, rice field, brains, ten, needle 	 	Owl . . . brain . . . needle. The sense is ""not complex."" 	 	 	Owls are smart...for this owl everything is simple coz his brain is ten times more powerful than mine. 	 	On-Yomi: タン   Kun-Yomi: ひとえ"
war	"war 	 	戦   	   	Lesson: 53   Frame: 2079   Strokes: 13   —   Jouyou Grade: 4   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: war, simple, owl, rice field, brains, ten, needle, fiesta 	 	Simple . . . fiesta. 	 	 	George W. Bush´s plans for war were so SIMPLE. To him, its all just a big FIESTA. 	 	On-Yomi: セン   Kun-Yomi: いくさ、たたか.う、おのの.く、そよぐ、わなな.く  	Examples: 戦 (いくさ), 戦う (たたか.う)"
Zen	"Zen 	 	禅   	   	Lesson: 53   Frame: 2080   Strokes: 13   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: zen, altar, simple, owl, rice field, brains, ten, needle 	 	Altar . . . simple. 	 	 	Knowing ZEN’s emphasis on “nothingness,” it’s not hard to envision a ZEN ALTAR being quite clean and SIMPLE. 	 	On-Yomi: ゼン、セン   Kun-Yomi: しずか、ゆず.る"
bullet	"bullet 	 	弾   	   	Lesson: 53   Frame: 2081   Strokes: 12   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: bullet, bow, simple, owl, rice field, brains, ten, needle 	 	Bow . . . simple. 	 	 	Hunting with a bow is too complicated. I´m switching to something simpler--using a bullet. 	 	On-Yomi: ダン、タン   Kun-Yomi: ひ.く、-ひ.き、はず.む、たま、はじ.く、はじ.ける、ただ.す、はじ.きゆみ  	Examples: 弾 (たま), 弾む (はず.む), 弾く (ひ.く)"
cherry tree	"cherry tree 	 	桜   	   	Lesson: 53   Frame: 2082   Strokes: 10   —   Jouyou Grade: 5   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: cherry tree, tree, wood, owl, woman 	 	Tree . . . owl . . . woman. 	 	 	I was taking a picture of my girlfriend under the cherry tree during 花見, when an owl happened to poop on her at the exact moment the shutter snapped. It´s really my favorite picture , just don´t tell her that. 	 	On-Yomi: オウ、ヨウ   Kun-Yomi: さくら  	Examples: 桜 (さくら)"
animal	"animal 	 	獣   	   	Lesson: 53   Frame: 2083   Strokes: 16   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: animal, owl, rice field, brains, one, mouth, chihuahua, dog, large, drop 	 	Owl . . . rice field . . . one . . . mouth . . . chihuahua. 	 	 	The owl looks for its prey in the rice field. It sees so many potential animals to eat but since it only has one mouth, it decides that the tasty looking chihuahua will be its meal for tonight. (adapted from Copycatken,1-9-2006). 	 	On-Yomi: ジュウ   Kun-Yomi: けもの、けだもの  	Examples: 獣 (けもの)"
brain	"brain 	 	脳   	   	Lesson: 53   Frame: 2084   Strokes: 11   —   Jouyou Grade: 6   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: brain, moon, month, flesh, part of the body, owl, villain, sheaf, shovel 	 	Part of the body . . . owl . . . villain. By way of exception, the kanji for brain has no connection with the primitive for brains. 	 	 	The brain is the part of the body that can give you the wisdom of the owl... or the wickedness of the villain. 	 	On-Yomi: ノウ、ドウ   Kun-Yomi: のうずる"
trouble	"trouble 	 	悩   	   	Lesson: 53   Frame: 2085   Strokes: 10   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: trouble, Freud, state of mind, owl, villain, sheaf, shovel 	 	State of mind . . . owl . . . villain. 	 	 	When I am in trouble, my state of mind is on two sides: 1. The wise part of me (owl) 2. The villain part of me (villain) Think of the devil and the angel on your shoulders in a troubled situation. 	 	On-Yomi: ノウ   Kun-Yomi: なや.む、なや.ます、なや.ましい、なやみ  	Examples: 悩ます (なや.ます), 悩む (なや.む)"
stern	"stern 	 	厳   	   	Lesson: 53   Frame: 2086   Strokes: 17   —   Jouyou Grade: 6   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: stern, owl, cliff, daring, spike, ear, taskmaster 	 	Owl . . . cliff . . . daring. 	 	 	This represents a stern looking owl, perched up on a cliff. This cliff is quite famous for daring individuals to cliff dive off of, but is any of them daring enough to threaten the owl? 	 	On-Yomi: ゲン、ゴン   Kun-Yomi: おごそ.か、きび.しい、いか.めしい、いつくし  	Examples: 厳格 (げんかく), 厳重 (げんじゅう), 威厳 (いげん), 厳か (おごそ.か), 厳しい (きび.しい)"
chain	"chain 	 	鎖   	   	Lesson: 53   Frame: 2087   Strokes: 18   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: chain, metal, gold, small, shellfish, clam, oyster, eye, animal legs, eight 	 	Metal . . . little . . . shells. We have saved this character until no win order to draw attention to the visual difference between the owl and little. By now your eyes should be so accustomed to these apparently infinitesimal differences that the point is obvious. 	 	 	The chain on this chainsaw is made of little metal shells. 	 	On-Yomi: サ   Kun-Yomi: くさり、とざ.す  	Examples: 鎖 (くさり)"
raise	"raise 	 	挙   	   	Lesson: 53   Frame: 2088   Strokes: 10   —   Jouyou Grade: 4   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: raise, owl, tool, hand 	 	Owl . . . tool . . . hand. 	 	 	The owl was asked to raise his hand if he needed anything, but he had a wing, not a hand! So he made a tool that looked like a hand which he used when he needed to raise his hand. For raiseing, owl has a tool hand. 	 	On-Yomi: キョ   Kun-Yomi: あ.げる、あ.がる、こぞ.る  	Examples: 挙がる (あ.がる), 挙げる (あ.げる)"
reputation	"reputation 	 	誉   	   	Lesson: 53   Frame: 2089   Strokes: 13   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: reputation, owl, tool, say, words, keitai, mouth 	 	Owl . . . tool . . . saying. 	 	 	This owl´s reputation skyrocketed after he created a tool in order to speak human words. 	 	On-Yomi: ヨ   Kun-Yomi: ほま.れ、ほ.める  	Examples: 誉 (ほまれ)"
game hunting	"game hunting 	 	猟   	   	Lesson: 53   Frame: 2090   Strokes: 11   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: game hunting, pack of wild dogs, anemometer, owl, wind, cornstalk 	 	Pack of wild dogs . . . owl . . . wind . . . cornstalk. 	 	 	[game-hunting; shooting; game; bag] According to unicode.org and wwwjdic, 鼡 and 鼠 (mouse (#2065)) are variants. So, for 鼡 (which I´ll call rat) I have: an owl, flying in the wind, can easily spot a rat even if it´s hiding in the cornstalks. Now 猟 is easy: wild dogs are having fun by game-hunting rats. 	 	On-Yomi: リョウ、レフ   Kun-Yomi: かり、か.る"
bird	"bird 	 	鳥   	   	Lesson: 53   Frame: 2091   Strokes: 11   —   Jouyou Grade: 2   JLPT: 4   	Constituents: bird, white, dove, one, tail feathers 	 	Dove . . . one . . . tail feathers. This is, of course, the character from which we derived the primitive meaning of dove. Note the lengthening of the second stroke. 	 	 	There is only one bird with such beautiful white tail feathers: the albino peakcock. 	 	On-Yomi: チョウ   Kun-Yomi: とり  	Examples: 鳥 (とり)"
chirp	"chirp 	 	鳴   	   	Lesson: 53   Frame: 2092   Strokes: 14   —   Jouyou Grade: 2   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: chirp, mouth, bird 	 	Mouth . . . bird. 	 	 	A chirp is quite simply the sound that comes from the mouth of birds. 	 	On-Yomi: メイ   Kun-Yomi: な.く、な.る、な.らす  	Examples: 鳴く (な.く), 鳴らす (な.らす), 鳴る (な.る)"
crane	"crane 	 	鶴   	   	Lesson: 53   Frame: 2093   Strokes: 21   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: crane, turkey house, bird 	 	Turkey house . . . bird. The first element appears on only one other occasion, back in frame 609. 	 	 	Do you know how cranes came to be? Well, they used to keep the poor bird cooped all the time. But the crane really wanted to be free, so it would always streatch its head and neck out of the coop trying to be free. 	 	On-Yomi: カク   Kun-Yomi: つる  	Examples: 鶴 (つる)"
crow	"crow 	 	烏   	   	Lesson: 53   Frame: 2094   Strokes: 10   —   Jouyou Grade: Names   JLPT:    	Constituents: crow, drop, mouth, one, tail feathers 	 	The only thing that distinguishes this character from that for bird is the omission of the one stroke that makes it white. Which is logical enough, when you consider that there are no crows of that color. 	 	 	The book´s story is just fine, but I found a kanji dictionary explanation also interesting: As crows are all black, it´s hard to see where their eyes are (black on black), so a stroke is removed from the part in the pictograph where the eyes would be. 	 	On-Yomi: ウ、オ   Kun-Yomi: からす、いずくんぞ、なんぞ"
vine	"vine 	 	蔦   	   	Lesson: 53   Frame: 2095   Strokes: 14   —   Jouyou Grade: Names   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: vine, flowers, bird 	 	Flower . . . bird. 	 	 	In the jungle there is a flowery vine called hedera rhombea that attracts humming birds by the dozens. They scoot around the flowers sucking up nectar off the vine. 	 	On-Yomi: チョウ   Kun-Yomi: つた"
pigeon	"pigeon 	 	鳩   	   	Lesson: 53   Frame: 2096   Strokes: 13   —   Jouyou Grade: Names   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: pigeon, nine, baseball, bird 	 	Baseball . . . bird. 	 	 	Feed one pigeon and nine more birds will be swarming you immediately…　RTK2:　On list of rare or no official Chinese reading. 	 	On-Yomi: キュウ、ク   Kun-Yomi: はと、あつ.める"
chicken	"chicken 	 	鶏   	   	Lesson: 53   Frame: 2097   Strokes: 19   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: chicken, claw, vulture, husband, bird 	 	Vulture . . . husband . . . bird. 	 	 	There are two types of birds often compared to husbands. Yes there are a few vultures out there, but most husbands are CHICKENS. 鶏 【にわとり】 (n) (domestic) chicken, (P) 鶏肉 【けいにく】 (n) chicken meat, (P). 	 	On-Yomi: ケイ   Kun-Yomi: にわとり、とり  	Examples: 鶏 (にわとり)"
island	"island 	 	島   	   	Lesson: 53   Frame: 2098   Strokes: 10   —   Jouyou Grade: 3   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: island, bird, mountain 	 	The bird's tail is tucked under here, because it has come to stop on a mountain to rest from its journey across the waters. Thus the kanji comes to mean an island. 	 	 	This island is the home of the terrible mythical bird Roc. It sits mighty atop the mountain waiting for the next hapless ship to pass by. 	 	On-Yomi: トウ   Kun-Yomi: しま  	Examples: 島 (しま)"
warmth	"warmth 	 	暖   	   	Lesson: 53   Frame: 2099   Strokes: 13   —   Jouyou Grade: 6   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: warmth, sun, day, migrating ducks, claw, vulture, one, friend 	 	Unlike the character for warm weather learned earlier (Frame 1560), this kanji and its key word can also refer to the warmth of human congeniality. Its elements are: sun . . . migrating ducks. 	 	 	Note: Just confirming Heisig has confused these two characters. This is used primarily for weather and climate (and colours). slacken	"slacken 	 	緩   	   	Lesson: 53   Frame: 2102   Strokes: 15   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: slacken, thread, spiderman, migrating ducks, claw, vulture, one, friend 	 	Thread . . . migrating ducks. 	 	 	[slacken; loosen; relax; lessen; be moderate; ease] The thread in this story is a cable line, something like a power or phone line. The thread was tense with all the migrating ducks perched on it, but got back to being slackened when the entire flock flew away. (darg_sama-modified,2-11-2005). 	 	On-Yomi: カン   Kun-Yomi: ゆる.い、ゆる.やか、ゆる.む、ゆる.める  	Examples: 緩い (ゆる.い), 緩む (ゆる.む), 緩める (ゆる.める), 緩やか (ゆる.やか)"

These bugs BELONG TO an extremist group promoting insect independence. They are parading the FLAG of their group, the Nationalist GNATS, and wearing explosives BELTS for their planned terrorist war. 	 	On-Yomi: ゾク、ショク   Kun-Yomi: さかん、つく、やから"

accidentally	"accidentally 	 	偶   	   	Lesson: 53   Frame: 2105   Strokes: 11   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: accidentally, person, talking cricket, brains, insect, belt 	 	The person on the left is familiar. As for the right side, we may combine the insect with a brain (observe the writing) and a belt to create the Talking Cricket who served as Pinocchio's conscience. (The belt is there because he pulls it off to give unrepentant little Pinocchio a bit of ""strap"" now and again.) 	 	 	Mr. T accidentially stepped on Jiminy Cricket (a brainy insect, with a belt sort of sash to hold his ""conscience"" badge). 	 	On-Yomi: グウ   Kun-Yomi: たま"

In the capital they have been having hearings concerning bioethics and bioengineering they call as their first witness a chihuahua with one human leg. The skunk here is Pepe LePew of Looney Tunes fame. He´s a very sociable skunk, as far as skunks go, but instead of having a ""heart of gold"" he has a heart of silver (since he always finishes second in the game of love). groundbreaking	"groundbreaking 	 	墾   	   	Lesson: 53   Frame: 2124   Strokes: 16   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: groundbreaking, skunk, silver, soil, dirt, ground 	 	The groundbreaking referred to here is not for the erection of new buildings but for the opening of farmlands. The elements: skunk . . . silver . . . soil. 	 	 	It was the groundbreaking of the new farm, but there was an uninvited guest to the ceremony. It was a famous skunk, the one with the familiar silver stripe. The feet of the crowd rushing from the ceremony site churned up the soil very nicely. The ceremony was ruined but the groundbreaking was a great success. 	 	On-Yomi: コン   Kun-Yomi:"
excuse	"excuse 	 	免   	   	Lesson: 53   Frame: 2126   Strokes: 8   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: excuse, village stocks, rabbit, bound up, human legs 	 	This character is used for excusing oneself for a failure of courtesy. The elements are: bound up . . . sun (oddly enough, laid on its side) . . . human legs. 	  * For the primitive meaning, we shall refer to this character as a rabbit, for which the old form of the character is 兔. 	 	Obviously this is the rabbit from Alice, excusing himself and rushing away on his legs, as he has a binding day schedule. This is at the same time an image, with bound=ears, day=head and legs are just legs. The image is used in rabbit (#2093). 	 	On-Yomi: メン   Kun-Yomi: まぬか.れる、まぬが.れる  	Examples: 免れる (まぬか.れる)"
elude	"elude 	 	逸   	   	Lesson: 53   Frame: 2127   Strokes: 11   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: deviate, elude, village stocks, rabbit, bound up, human legs, road 	 	Rabbit . . . road. 	 	 	Word play to differentiate elude/evade: elude ~= e-lewd. Alice is following Mr. Rabbit on the road. Mr. Rabbit flashes her in a lewd way and disappears, completely eluding her. 	 	On-Yomi: イツ   Kun-Yomi: そ.れる、そ.らす、はぐ.れる"

Notice how the last stroke of rabbit is stretched out to underlie the element for muscle. 	 	 	When RABBITS hop around, they EXERT tremendous force using their MUSCULAR legs. elephant	"elephant 	 	象   	   	Lesson: 53   Frame: 2130   Strokes: 12   —   Jouyou Grade: 4   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: elephant, colour, color, bound up, sow, pig 	 	A rabbit's head with the body of a sow represents an elephant. Little wonder that the kanji also means ""phenomenon""! 	 	 	An elephant has huge ears, like a rabbit, and a big, fat body, like a sow. statue	"statue 	 	像   	   	Lesson: 53   Frame: 2131   Strokes: 14   —   Jouyou Grade: 5   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: statue, person, elephant, colour, color, bound up, sow, pig 	 	Person . . . elephant. 	 	 	Statues of people are made the same size as statues of elephants. 	 	On-Yomi: ゾウ   Kun-Yomi:"
horse	"horse 	 	馬   	   	Lesson: 54   Frame: 2132   Strokes: 10   —   Jouyou Grade: 2   JLPT: 3   	Constituents: horse, team of horses 	 	Let the extra vertical stroke in the mane combine with the first vertical stroke to give an image of the horse's long neck. The only odd thing is the tail feathers at the end, but that should present a good image to remember the character by. The fact that the last stroke of mane and the first of tail feathers coincide should no longer surprise you. 	  * As a primitive, this kanji will mean a team of horses as distinct from the single horse whose primitive we met earlier. 	 	Turkey with the drops at the top removed and tail feathers added (this matches stroke order and there are the tail feathers already, why not have the whole bird). If you take the two drops of 隹 as wings, then horses are like turkeys, but have no wings and have more prominent tail ""feathers"". Both are actually supposed to be pictographs, though. 	 	On-Yomi: バ   Kun-Yomi: うま、うま-、ま  	Examples: 馬 (うま)"
pony	"pony 	 	駒   	   	Lesson: 54   Frame: 2133   Strokes: 15   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: pony, team of horses, phrase, bound up, mouth 	 	Team of horses . . . phrase. In American slang, a pony is an underground translation of a classical text, which students who cannot manage the difficult phrases of the original language consult and pass on from one generation to the next. 	 	 	The new My Little Ponies show is all about magic horses who utter cute catch phrases. 	 	On-Yomi: ク   Kun-Yomi: こま  	Examples: 駒 (こま)"
verification	"verification 	 	験   	   	Lesson: 54   Frame: 2134   Strokes: 18   —   Jouyou Grade: 4   JLPT: 4   	Constituents: verification, team of horses, awl, fit, meeting, umbrella, mouth, person 	 	Team of horses . . . awl. 	 	 	We just verification that there are indeed no soldiers in the belly of this trojan horse. We´re just gonna stab it in the belly with this awl to check. 	 	On-Yomi: ケン、ゲン   Kun-Yomi: あかし、しるし、ため.す、ためし  	Examples: 試験 (しけん), 経験 (けいけん), 実験 (じっけん)"

Equestrian events are where you get horses to do strange things. 	 	On-Yomi: キ   Kun-Yomi:"
parking	"parking 	 	駐   	   	Lesson: 54   Frame: 2136   Strokes: 15   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: stop-over, parking, team of horses, candlestick, lord, drop, king, jewel, ball 	 	Team of horses . . . candlestick. 	 	 	In the olden days you had to park your horse next to a candlestick, a primitive parking meter that you start by lighting a fire and tracks the time by burning down. 	 	On-Yomi: チュウ   Kun-Yomi:"
drive	"drive 	 	駆   	   	Lesson: 54   Frame: 2137   Strokes: 14   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: drive, team of horses, ward, box, sheaf 	 	Team of horses . . . ward. 	 	 	You have to be craaazzzzyy to drive a buggy led by a team of horses through a ward of Tokyo! 	 	On-Yomi: ク   Kun-Yomi: か.ける、か.る  	Examples: 駆ける (か.ける), 駆る (か.る)"
station	"station 	 	駅   	   	Lesson: 54   Frame: 2138   Strokes: 14   —   Jouyou Grade: 3   JLPT: 4   	Constituents: station, team of horses, shaku-hachi, flag, stick 	 	Team of horses . . . shakuhachi. 	 	 	Anyone living in Japan knows that train stations play little melodies when the train is about to arrive. In Ye Olden Days, when horses and carriages were used for transport, the carriage driver would play a little melody on his shakuhachi to let the passengers know the carriage was arriving at the next station. 	 	On-Yomi: エキ   Kun-Yomi:"
boisterous	"boisterous 	 	騒   	   	Lesson: 54   Frame: 2139   Strokes: 18   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: boisterous, team of horses, crotch, insect 	 	Team of horses . . . crotch . . . insect. 	 	 	Or more precisely: the team of horses are getting boisterous because one of them got bitten in the crotch by a horse fly. The kanji also means to roar, make up noise, to kick up a fuss and to make merry. Perhaps it is exactly the etymology behind this kanji. 	 	On-Yomi: ソウ   Kun-Yomi: さわ.ぐ、うれい、さわ.がしい  	Examples: 騒ぐ (さわ.ぐ)"
burdensome	"burdensome 	 	駄   	   	Lesson: 54   Frame: 2140   Strokes: 14   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: burdensome, team of horses, plump, large, St. Bernard, drop 	 	Team of horses . . . plump. 	 	 	If a passenger is too plump and heavy, its too burdensome for the horse. 	 	On-Yomi: ダ、タ   Kun-Yomi:"
wonder	"wonder 	 	驚   	   	Lesson: 54   Frame: 2141   Strokes: 22   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: wonder, awe, flowers, phrase, bound up, mouth, taskmaster, team of horses 	 	Awe . . . team of horses. 	 	 	You stand in AWE at the 8th WONDER of the world, a huge TROJAN HORSE. 	 	On-Yomi: キョウ   Kun-Yomi: おどろ.く、おどろ.かす  	Examples: 驚かす (おどろ.かす), 驚く (おどろ.く)"
fervent	"fervent 	 	篤   	   	Lesson: 54   Frame: 2142   Strokes: 16   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: fervent, bamboo, team of horses 	 	Bamboo . . . team of horses. 	 	 	A fervent horse doesnt need to be whipped with a bamboo stick during a race, it will go fast by itself. 	 	On-Yomi: トク   Kun-Yomi: あつ.い"
inflation	"inflation 	 	騰   	   	Lesson: 54   Frame: 2144   Strokes: 20   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: inflation, edam, moon, month, flesh, part of the body, quarter, team of horses 	 	Meat . . . quarter . . . team of horses. 	 	 	Flesh+quarter=McDonald´s quarter pounder. Due to inflation, McDonald´s has had to start making quarter pounders out of horse meat. 	 	On-Yomi: トウ   Kun-Yomi:"
tiger	"tiger 	 	虎   	   	Lesson: 54   Frame: 2145   Strokes: 8   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: tiger, magic wand, augury, cliff, hook, diced, seven, human legs 	 	The kanji in this frame recalls the famous Bengali fable about the group of magicians (the magic wand) who decided to make a tiger. It seems that each of them knew how to make one part of the beast, so they pooled their talents and brought all the pieces (diced into pieces) together, at which point the fabricated tiger promptly ate its makers up (the bodiless human legs). Whatever the parable's significance for modern civilization and its arsenals, it should help with this kanji. Oh yes, we should not forget that cliff-like element. Think of it as an abbreviation of the primitive for zoo (the first and fourth strokes, actually), in order to fit the tiger somewhere into the picture. In fact, the abbreviation is perfectly logical, since the bottom elements usurp the room for the rest of the primitive for zoo. 	  * As a primitive element itself, the human legs are also swallowed up, but the meaning of tiger is kept, and the whole serves as a roof for what comes beneath 虍, giving the tiger something else to eat. 	 	Magic wand + first two strokes of pelt (皮) + diced + human legs. A wizard who turns people he doesn´t like into newts with his magic wand goes for variety - he has always wanted a tiger pelt - but things go awry when the tiger promptly dices and eats him, leaving only a pair of legs. (a fitting end for a wicked wizard). 	 	On-Yomi: コ   Kun-Yomi: とら  	Examples: 虎 (とら)"
captive	"captive 	 	虜   	   	Lesson: 54   Frame: 2146   Strokes: 13   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: captive, tiger, male, rice field, brains, power, muscle, arnold 	 	Tiger . . . man. 	 	 	Captive men are thrown to the tigers. I think you can imagine something else is done to captive women... 	 	On-Yomi: リョ、ロ   Kun-Yomi: とりこ、とりく"
skin	"skin 	 	膚   	   	Lesson: 54   Frame: 2147   Strokes: 15   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: skin, tiger, stomach, rice field, brains, moon, month, flesh, part of the body 	 	Tiger . . . stomach. 	 	 	Ending up in a tiger´s stomach is not good for your skin, as it´s full of stomach acids. 	 	On-Yomi: フ   Kun-Yomi: はだ"
void	"void 	 	虚   	   	Lesson: 54   Frame: 2148   Strokes: 11   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: void, tiger, row 	 	Tigers . . . row. 	 	 	In Japanese folklore there is no hell, but there is the void. There, a row of tigers waits in the blackness to devour those souls who have failed in their spiritual life. 	 	On-Yomi: キョ、コ   Kun-Yomi: むな.しい、うつ.ろ  	Examples: 虚無 (きょむ), 虚偽 (きょぎ), 空虚 (くうきょ)"

This is a story about the end of the universe. The universe is turning into a featureless void. There´s nothing we can do about it except for throw a fiesta and frolic a little bit before it´s all over. 	 	On-Yomi: ギ、ゲ   Kun-Yomi: たわむ.れる、ざ.れる、じゃ.れる  	Examples: 戯れる (たわむ.れる)"

prudence	"prudence 	 	慮   	   	Lesson: 54   Frame: 2151   Strokes: 15   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: prudence, tiger, think, rice field, brains, heart 	 	Tiger . . . think. 	 	 	Real meaning: ""to ponder"". You have to think with prudence (ponder carefully) about approaching a tiger, as is evident from 虎. 	 	On-Yomi: リョ   Kun-Yomi: おもんぱく.る、おもんぱか.る"

tyrannize	"tyrannize 	 	虐   	   	Lesson: 54   Frame: 2153   Strokes: 9   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: tyrannize, tiger, one, box 	 	Tiger . . . box with a one in it (or a backwards broom, if that makes it easier). 	 	 	Here we see the evil tyrannizing tiger. What is on his chest? A giant E, for EVIL, of course. 	 	On-Yomi: ギャク   Kun-Yomi: しいた.げる  	Examples: 虐げる (しいた.げる)"
deer	"deer 	 	鹿   	   	Lesson: 54   Frame: 2154   Strokes: 11   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: deer, cave, antlers, compare, spoon, sitting on the ground, spoon2, sitting on the ground2 	 	Drawn on the walls of a complex of caves near Niaux in southern France are a number of animal likenesses dating from the Upper Paleolithic period. Among them we find pictures of deer, some of them showing men in deer masks. By comparing their drawings to real deer, Stone Age people hoped to acquire power over the animal in the hunt; and by comparing themselves to the deer, to take on that animal's characteristics. But time has locked with a ""double-key"" (the extra stroke through the element for key) the real secret of this art form from us, and we can only surmise such meanings. But more important than the enigmas of the troglodytic mind is the way in which caves, a double-key, and comparing gives us the kanji for deer. 	  * As a primitive, this kanji is abbreviated much the same as the tiger was: the lower element is dropped to leave room for a replacement. Its meaning, however, remains the same. There are a very few cases (see frame 2158) in which there is no abbreviation. When this happens, we may keep the image suggested by the above explanation: painting of a deer. 	 	Bambi wanders into a cave and sees a side order of salad and 2 spoons...but what´s the main course? 	 	On-Yomi: ロク   Kun-Yomi: しか、か  	Examples: 鹿 (しかか)"
recommend	"recommend 	 	薦   	   	Lesson: 54   Frame: 2156   Strokes: 16   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: recommend, flowers, deer, cave, antlers, slingshot, catapult, tail feathers 	 	Flowers . . . deer . . . one . . . tail feathers. Note the doubling up in these last two elements as in frame 2091. 	 	 	Customer in restaurant asks you (waiter) what you recommend: ""I recommend ze deer or ze 'eadless chicken. And I recommend you garnish it wiz some flowers."" (let last six strokes = headless chicken). 	 	On-Yomi: セン   Kun-Yomi: すす.める  	Examples: 薦める (すす.める)"
jubilation	"jubilation 	 	慶   	   	Lesson: 54   Frame: 2157   Strokes: 15   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: jubilation, deer, cave, antlers, crown, heart, walking legs 	 	Deer . . . crown (note the doubling up) . . . heart . . . walking legs. You may recall that we met the relative primitives at the bottom here before, in the kanji for melancholy (Frame 663). 	 	 	The hunter experienced jubilation when the deer with melancholy walked up to him and said, ""just shoot me, whats the point in running. Everyone dies someday..."" 	 	On-Yomi: ケイ   Kun-Yomi: よろこ.び"
lovely	"lovely 	 	麗   	   	Lesson: 54   Frame: 2158   Strokes: 19   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: lovely, one, ceiling, mediocre, deer, cave, antlers, compare, ceiling2, mediocre2, compare2 	 	The painting of a deer itself with its form and color is enough to fill the bill for an image of something lovely. But to give a bit of contrast, we see two mediocre drawings from a later age on two patches of ceiling above. Note that the drop in mediocre has been lengthened somewhat and the second stroke drawn down straight. 	 	 	The anthropologist made an exact deer painting from the cave ceiling on the ceiling of his house. Too bad they´re both mediocre. All his wife could say was, ""How...lovely."". 	 	On-Yomi: レイ   Kun-Yomi: うるわ.しい、うら.らか  	Examples: 麗しい (うるわ.しい)"

Most don´t know it, but bears have the ability to walk on fire. They´re invincible creatures! 	 	On-Yomi: ユウ   Kun-Yomi: くま  	Examples: 熊 (くま)"

This man may have the dis-ability of no flesh below the elbows, but he can eat with 2 spoons, on in each foot. 	 	On-Yomi: ノウ   Kun-Yomi: よ.く"

with child	"with child 	 	娠   	   	Lesson: 55   Frame: 2168   Strokes: 10   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: with child, woman, sign of the dragon, cliff, two, hairpin, safety-pin 	 	Woman . . . sign of the dragon. The key word is a synonym for pregnant, whose character we met earlier (Frame 546). Although the two kanji are often used together, they should be kept distinct. 	 	 	A woman who is with child can't be sacrificed to the dragon; virgins only need apply. 	 	On-Yomi: シン   Kun-Yomi:"

agriculture	"agriculture 	 	農   	   	Lesson: 55   Frame: 2170   Strokes: 13   —   Jouyou Grade: 3   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: agriculture, bend, sign of the dragon, cliff, two, hairpin, safety-pin 	 	Bend . . . sign of the dragon. 	 	 	Imagine if you could bend a dragon to your will. Helpful in war, yes, but also a boon for agriculture. The dragon could use its sharp claws to plough the ground, and use its firey breath to clear the land. But first you'd have to bend the dragon to your will -- not an easy task. concentrated	"concentrated 	 	濃   	   	Lesson: 55   Frame: 2171   Strokes: 16   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 2   	Constituents: concentrated, water, water droplets, water pistol, agriculture, bend, sign of the dragon, cliff, two, hairpin, safety-pin 	 	Among other things, the key word refers to the thick consistency of liquids. ghost	"ghost 	 	鬼   	   	Lesson: 55   Frame: 2175   Strokes: 10   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: ghost, oni, drop, brains, rice field, human legs, elbow 	 	Drop of . . . brains . . . human legs . . . elbow. 	 	 	鬼(おに) is not a ghost. An ogre or a troll would be a more fitting translation. Such a thing has but a drop of brains and uses its legs and elbows as deadly weapons (a concept which should be familiar from the license (#765) to kill). I'll use ""ogre"" for this. clod	"clod 	 	塊   	   	Lesson: 55   Frame: 2180   Strokes: 13   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: clod, soil, dirt, ground, ghost, oni, drop, brains, rice field, human legs, elbow 	 	Soil . . . ghost. attack	"attack 	 	襲   	   	Lesson: 55   Frame: 2181   Strokes: 22   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: attack, old dragon, vase, stand up, moon, month, flesh, part of the body, slingshot, catapult, snake, self, three, cloth, clothes, clothing, garment, dragon* 	 	Vase . . . meat . . . slingshot (doubled up with) snake . . . three . . . garment. The top half of this character is the old form for the kanji in frame 575. 	 	 	The top 16 strokes are the chinese radical for ""dragon"". Joining up both meanings of the radical we can name the top part of this kanji ""imperial dragon"". Two-headed snakes do exist as biological curiosities, and they look a bit like a slingshot (with the heads splitting at a junction). Our imperial dragon here, the pet of a Chinese emperor, is a rare ""three-headed slingshot-snake"" kept in a vase and fed with meat. When the emperor attacked neighbours, his army wore the imperial dragon garment. 	 	On-Yomi: シュウ   Kun-Yomi: おそ.う、かさ.ね  	Examples: 襲う (おそ.う)"
upbraid	"upbraid 	 	嚇   	   	Lesson: 56   Frame: 2182   Strokes: 17   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: menacing, upbraid, mouth, incandescent, red, red2 	 	 	 	 	To upbraid someone, you criticize them in a menacing way. In other words, you jaw at them with your MOUTH until both sides of their face turn RED (hence the double-red). 	 	On-Yomi: カク   Kun-Yomi: おど.かす"

""We (majestic plural) are not amused that the hunger for the flesh of the wooly mammoth has caused it's extinction. Poor Charles is particularly upset. 	 	On-Yomi: チン   Kun-Yomi:"

You know how nori, ie: seaweed, comes in sheets for putting in your ramen or for your sushi? Well that's because it's water paper! Seaweed is also a sea flower of sorts, so it all just works out. 	 	On-Yomi: ソウ   Kun-Yomi: も  	Examples: 藻 (も)"

We were in dire need of healing. Our party was fighting the cavemen, but we didn't fare too well. It was more like a butcher's meeting than a fight... just as they were about to pierce my heart, luckily a priest came along and used his healing spell in the nick of time (#2433). lagoon	"lagoon 	 	潟   	   	Lesson: 56   Frame: 2195   Strokes: 15   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: lagoon, water, water droplets, water pistol, mortar, tail feathers 	 	 	 	 	Right part: mortar bound up over oven fire, comprising boiling cauldron. sign of the cow	"sign of the cow 	 	丑   	   	Lesson: 56   Frame: 2197   Strokes: 5   —   Jouyou Grade: Names   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: sign of the cow, dagger, two 	 	 	 	 	Pictograph of a stanchion, which includes two vertical posts to restrain cows so they can be milked, with a horizontal stroke showing the number of cows per stanchion: one. A stanchion is a great symbol for the SIGN OF THE COW, since modern, domesticated cows are often stanchioned in barns. 	 	On-Yomi: チュウ   Kun-Yomi: うし"
sign of the hare	"sign of the hare 	 	卯   	   	Lesson: 56   Frame: 2199   Strokes: 5   —   Jouyou Grade: Names   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: sign of the hare, blown eggs 	 	 	 	 	You know how missing childrens´ pictures often appear on milk cartons? Well here we have a missing hare. His concerned family is having his picture printed on the backs of receipts and even on stamps. So far, however, there has been no SIGN OF THE HARE. 	 	On-Yomi: ボウ、モウ   Kun-Yomi: う"

crystal	"crystal 	 	璃   	   	Lesson: 39   Frame: 1606   Strokes: 14   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: crystal, king, jewel, ball, sheik, top hat, villain, sheaf, shovel, belt, elbow 	 	This kanji refers to one of the seven classical stones of China. myself	"myself 	 	俺   	   	Lesson: 27   Frame: 1091   Strokes: 10   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT:    	Constituents: myself, person, dachshund, large, St. Bernard, eel, sun, day 	 	The key word refers to a very familiar way of referring to oneself, typically used by men. Its component elements: person . . . St. Bernard . . . eel. 	 	 	I did it all by myself! Mr T stands there proud as holding a moray eel in his hand. He´s brought down terrorist organisations, drug syndicates, but gets all worked up when catching a fish... what a guy. 	 	On-Yomi: エン   Kun-Yomi: おれ、われ  	Examples: 俺 (おれ)"
mortar	"mortar 	 	臼   	   	Lesson: 37   Frame: 1531   Strokes: 6   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT:    	Constituents: mortar, back to back staples 	 	The image here is of back-to-back staples. The mortar referred to in this key word is a stone or wooden basin used for grinding with a pestle. 	 	 	I removed all the back to back staples and grinded them in a mortar to create metal dust. 	 	On-Yomi: キュウ、グ   Kun-Yomi: うす、うすづ.く  	Examples: 臼 (うす)"
break	"break 	 	毀   	   	Lesson: 37   Frame: 1532   Strokes: 13   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT:    	Constituents: break, mortar, soil, dirt, ground, cruise missile, missile, wind, crotch 	 	Mortar . . . soil . . . missile. 	 	 	To ""break the soil"" is to make a symbolic gesture that indicates the beginning of construction. Like when a politician in a hardhat gets a shovel and lifts a piece of dirt. This particular project is behind schedule, so to speed things up, they blow it up with mortar and an air-to-ground missile. 	 	On-Yomi: キ   Kun-Yomi: こぼ.つ、こわ.す、こぼ.れる、こわ.れる、そし.る、やぶ.る"
spinal column	"spinal column 	 	脊   	   	Lesson: 12   Frame: 268   Strokes: 10   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT:    	Constituents: spinal column, I Ching, Master Po, umbrella, moon, month, flesh, part of the body 	 	The spinal column has sprouted out of the flesh of your back into an umbrella that you always have with you, rain or shine. The pair of 2s on each side are the ""ribs"" of the umbrella. Take care to keep your image of the key word distinct from that for spine (Frame 24). 	 	 	Look, says the teacher in biology class. ""The spinal column holds your flesh together, just like the metal rod of this umbrella (he demonstrates this with an umbrella covered in I-Ching symbols) holds the umbrella together"". 	 	On-Yomi: セキ   Kun-Yomi: せ、せい"

However when the letter arrives it has been raining on it and you see that the drops of rain have been transformed into little x’s where some animal legs have run over it. 	 	On-Yomi: ジ   Kun-Yomi:"

derision	"derision 	 	嘲   	   	Lesson: 3   Frame: 54   Strokes: 15   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT:    	Constituents: derision, mouth, morning , mist, ten, needle, early, sun, day, moon, month, flesh, part of the body, ten2, needle2 	 	The bad feeling created by words spoken in derision often leaves a bad taste in the mouth of the one who speaks them, kind of like the foul aftertaste that follows a night before of too much of the wrong stuff - or what we call morning mouth. 	 	 	When I wake up, I am always late, so I hurry to work. With a bad case of perpetual morning breath, I am the subject of derision at my office whenever I open my mouth. curse	"curse 	 	呪   	   	Lesson: 6   Frame: 108   Strokes: 8   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT:    	Constituents: curse, mouth, elder brother, teenager, mouth, human legs, mouth2 	 	For some reason, the inventor of this kanji associated a curse with the mouth of an older brother. I leave it to you to decide if he is on the giving or receiving end of the sorcery. 	 	 	Caution: this means a spell, not to swear. I put a curse on my elder brother so that he can never open his mouth. 	 	On-Yomi: ジュ、シュ、シュウ、ズ   Kun-Yomi: まじな.う、のろ.い、まじな.い、のろ.う  	Examples: 呪う (のろ.う)"

This is depicted here as a stream of clams spewing out of the mouth of someone performing a pop song. 	 	 	The new generation of pop songs have no depth. They just mouth empty lyrics to get money. Not like the pop songs of my day. 	 	On-Yomi: バイ   Kun-Yomi: うた、うた.う  	Examples: 唄 (うた)"

inlay	"inlay 	 	填・塡   	   	Lesson: 8   Frame: 166   Strokes: 13   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT:    	Constituents: stuff up, soil, dirt, ground, true, truth, ten, needle, eye, tool, one, animal legs, eight 	 	When we hear the world inlay, we usually think of setting precious stones in pieces of jewelery, but the primitive elements here suggest truth being inlaid in the soil. You might think instead of the cosmic wisdom that inlaid the truth of the universe in the stuff of the earth. 	 	 	In a hole in the ground, the body of the victim was placed. And then the killer stuffed it up so that the truth would not be found out, he hoped. 	 	On-Yomi: テン、チン   Kun-Yomi: は.まる、は.める、うず.める、しず.める、ふさ.ぐ"

The jealous woman bashed the brains in of the guy who betrayed her, with a stone. 	 	On-Yomi: ト、ツ   Kun-Yomi: ねた.む、そね.む、つも.る、ふさ.ぐ  	Examples: 妬む (ねた.む)"

In the busy pub, one of the dart players shoved his dart into my elbow by accident when it nearly slipped out of his fingers. 	 	On-Yomi: アイ   Kun-Yomi: ひら.く"
wrench	"wrench 	 	捻   	   	Lesson: 41   Frame: 1716   Strokes: 11   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT:    	Constituents: wrenching, finger, fingers, wish, wishbone, now, clock, heart 	 	This kanji does not refer to the tool but to the act of twisting. Its elements: fingers . . . wish. 	 	 	Ever try WRENCHING a bolt with just your FINGERS? Trust me, you´ll WISH you had a wrench for WRENCHING to save your FINGERS. 	 	On-Yomi: ネン、ジョウ   Kun-Yomi: ね.じる、ねじ.る、ひね.くる、ひね.る"

Why carry a handkerchief? I wipe my nose finger-style. 	 	On-Yomi: ショク、シキ   Kun-Yomi: ぬぐ.う、ふ.く  	Examples: 拭う (ぬぐ.う), 拭く (ふ.く)"

The old lady said that there was a flood imminent, because her fingers hurt in the evening. 	 	On-Yomi: サツ   Kun-Yomi: せま.る"
make headway	"make headway 	 	捗   	   	Lesson: 23   Frame: 728   Strokes: 11   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT:    	Constituents: make headway, finger, fingers, walk, stop, footprint, few 	 	Let your fingers do the walking as you make headway through the Yellow Pages in search of something hard to find. 	 	 	Come on people, the only way to make headway in this business is to let your fingers do the walking! bust out the yellow pages and dial as many numbers as possible, surely someone is a sucker for a cold call sell. bubble up	"bubble up 	 	湧   	   	Lesson: 37   Frame: 1510   Strokes: 12   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: bubble up, water, water droplets, water pistol, courageous, courage, chop-seal, hanko, male, rice field, brains, power, muscle, arnold 	 	Water . . . courage. 	 	 	The courageous man who went into the water to save a drowning victim couldn´t be seen, except by the air that bubbled up. 	 	On-Yomi: ユウ、ヨウ、ユ   Kun-Yomi: わ.く  	Examples: 湧く (わ.く)"
grains of sand	"grains of sand 	 	沙   	   	Lesson:    Frame: 151   Strokes:    —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: grains of sand, water, water droplets, water pistol, few 	 	We have already learned the kanji for sand (Frame 122), so let's use it to remember the character for grains of sand. Instead of the ""few stones"" that make for nice sand, here we have a few drops of water, one for each grand of sand - a beach in perfect ecological balance. 	 	 	Wet sand is simply sand but to see beautiful grains of sand, the water must be few. 	 	On-Yomi: サ、シャ   Kun-Yomi: すな、よなげる"

The vulture is on top of the porter and appears to be commiting a lewd act, so I throw water over the pair of them. 	 	On-Yomi: イン   Kun-Yomi: ひた.す、ほしいまま、みだ.ら、みだ.れる、みだり  	Examples: 淫ら (みだ.ら)"
widespread	"widespread 	 	氾   	   	Lesson: 37   Frame: 1518   Strokes: 5   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT:    	Constituents: widespread, water, water droplets, water pistol, fingerprint 	 	Water . . . fingerprint. 	 	 	It´s a widespread belief that they cannot find fingerprints on a body that has been deposited in the water. 	 	On-Yomi: ハン   Kun-Yomi: ひろ.がる"
drowning	"drowning 	 	溺   	   	Lesson: 33   Frame: 1324   Strokes: 13   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT:    	Constituents: drowning, water, water droplets, water pistol, weak, bow, ice, bow2, ice2 	 	Water . . . weak. Do not confuse the meaning of this key word with ""Drown"" (Frame 763), which is closer to ""founder."" 	 	 	Weak people placed in the water start drowning. Get some strength in those arms and learn how to swim! 	 	On-Yomi: デキ、ジョウ、ニョウ   Kun-Yomi: いばり、おぼ.れる  	Examples: 溺れる (おぼ.れる)"
cleanse	"cleanse 	 	汰   	   	Lesson:    Frame: 149   Strokes:    —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: cleanse, water, water droplets, water pistol, plump, large, St. Bernard, drop 	 	This character can mean both to cleanse and to make dirty. We will choose the latter and imagine someone who is displeasingly plump going to a skinny spa whose medicinal waters promise to cleanse him of his unwanted corpulence. Picture him sitting in the spa as the pounds melt away, leaving a greasy scum on top of the water. 	 	 	I couldn´t find any reference to this kanji as meaning cleanse. It seems to be most often used in the following compound 沙汰（さた）to mean affair. The other meanings seem to be closer to ´select´ so maybe Heisig meant cleanse in the ethnic sense here.. I´m going to use the keyword ""selection"", as in natural selection. Story: natural selection first began in the water, and those that were too plump were selected out. 	 	On-Yomi: タ、タイ   Kun-Yomi: おご.る、にご.る、よな.げる"
defile	"defile 	 	潰   	   	Lesson: 46   Frame: 1911   Strokes: 15   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT:    	Constituents: defile, water, water droplets, water pistol, precious, Takanohana, purse, in, one, floor, shellfish, clam, oyster, eye, animal legs, eight 	 	Water . . . precious. 	 	 	Man continues to defile precious water and it may prove to be his downfall (Think of Exxon, BP, etc.). 	 	On-Yomi: カイ、エ   Kun-Yomi: つぶ.す、つぶ.れる、つい.える"
pan-	"pan- 	 	汎   	   	Lesson: 8   Frame: 147   Strokes: 6   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT:    	Constituents: pan-, water, water droplets, water pistol, mediocre, wind, drop 	 	The sense of the key word here is the ""all-inclusive"" we find in terms like ""Pan-American Games."" (It is also the character used in mathematics for ""partial"" as in partial differentials, in case you are a math major and want to take your story in that direction.) Instead of a water sports event that brings together the best talent, think of a meet of the region's most mediocre athletes, many of whom cannot even tread water. Now try to find a sponsor for the ""Pan-Mediocre Water Sports Competition."" 	 	 	Yeah, all our water is fairly mediocre, but if we work together in some pan-continental union, we can make some better water! As if. 	 	On-Yomi: ハン、ブ、フウ、ホウ、ホン   Kun-Yomi: ただよ.う、ひろ.い"

Note the stroke overlap between father and metal. 	 	 	Your father uses his legs to stop himself from being put in a metal cauldron. 	 	On-Yomi: フ   Kun-Yomi: かま  	Examples: 釜 (かま)"

They gays were reviled by society, so they put flowers above their eyes and marched around. 	 	On-Yomi: ベツ   Kun-Yomi: ないがしろ、なみ.する、くらい、さげす.む  	Examples: 蔑む (さげす.む)"
kudzu	"kudzu 	 	葛   	   	Lesson: 18   Frame: 492   Strokes: 11   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT:    	Constituents: kudzu, flowers, mexican bandit, muchacho, siesta, sun, day, aroma, bound up, spoon, sitting on the ground 	 	Kudzu is a word taken over from Japanese to name the crawling vines that creep up and completely take over trees. Seeing it at its worst in the Georgia countryside makes it easy to understand why it has a reputation as the ""plague of the South."" From there it should not be hard to arrange the primitives, flowers and siesta into a memorable image. 	 	 	Flower, siesta: The muchacho was not careful. He passed the warning signs and decided to hold a siesta in the kudzu field. The kudzu grew so fast, he was completely covered by it in a few hours and not able to escape. Now, the kudzu flowers mark his grave. 	 	On-Yomi: カツ、カチ   Kun-Yomi: つづら、くず  	Examples: 葛 (くず)"

My parents aren´t at all modest about their grandchildren, at every opportunity they take them on the road showing them off to their friends! 	 	On-Yomi: ソン   Kun-Yomi: したが.う、へりくだ.る、ゆず.る"
chink	"chink 	 	隙   	   	Lesson: 35   Frame: 1394   Strokes: 13   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT:    	Constituents: chink, pinnacle, parthenon, acropolis, small, little, sun, day, small2, little, 2 	 	Pinnacle . . . little . . . sun . . . little. Note that the form of the first element for little given here is the simpler form that has become standard in general-use characters (See Frame 110). For the time being, until typesetting fonts have made the adjustment, the official approved drawing has the drops similar to the bottom little. 	 	 	There was only one chink in his plan. Even standing atop the highest pinnacle, standing above even the sun, the little man was still just as little as when he was under the sun. 	 	On-Yomi: ゲキ、キャク、ケキ   Kun-Yomi: すき、す.く、す.かす、ひま  	Examples: 隙 (すき)"

Sometimes I get carried away and do elbow curls until the point where my forearm snaps off! When that happens I simply pull out the glue and re-attach the elbow to my flesh. pillow	"pillow 	 	枕   	   	Lesson: 51   Frame: 2034   Strokes: 8   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT:    	Constituents: pillow, tree, wood, garter, crown, human legs 	 	Tree . . . crown tied around leg of person. 	 	 	The guy who was thrown into the river to sink was given one last request. ""If I´m gonna be sleeping with the fishes,"" he said, ""can I at least have a pillow? I´m real sensitive."" The mafia bosses laughed. ""Look, my doctor said I can only use wooden pillows, I have a real serious condition. Can I at least die comfortable-like?"" The mafia dudes said fine, and let him have his pillow. They tossed him the river and drove off...and after a minute, he bobbed to the top, thanks to his floating wood pillow. 	 	On-Yomi: チン、シン   Kun-Yomi: まくら  	Examples: 枕 (まくら)"
chair	"chair 	 	椅   	   	Lesson: 10   Frame: 218   Strokes: 12   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT:    	Constituents: chair, tree, wood, strange, large, St. Bernard, street, nail, spike, mouth 	 	Instead of making a chair out of wood from a tree, this kanji has us making the whole tree into a chair, which looks most strange sitting in your living room where the sofa used to be. 	 	 	To the Japanese, the first time they saw a chair, it looked like a strange use of wood! Probably why they still like to sit on the floor... 	 	On-Yomi: イ   Kun-Yomi:"
persimmon	"persimmon 	 	柿   	   	Lesson: 18   Frame: 441   Strokes: 9   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT:    	Constituents: persimmon, tree, wood, market, top hat, towel 	 	Imagine a village market with stalls set up around an immense persimmon tree with watermelon-sized fruit. If it weren't for the fact that the tree is sacred to the village, people would get impatient as the persimmons fall from the tree and wreak havoc on buyers and sellers alike. 	 	 	Nobody buys persimmons at the market, because there´s a tree in the middle where you can pick them for free. 	 	On-Yomi: シ   Kun-Yomi: かき、こけら  	Examples: 柿 (かき)"

spiny	"spiny 	 	梗   	   	Lesson: 23   Frame: 751   Strokes: 11   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT:    	Constituents: spiny, tree, wood, grow late, Ameratasu, one, ceiling, sun, tucked under the arm 	 	This character refers originally to a deciduous, rough tree that grows on mountain plains. From this it gets the secondary sense of rugged or spiny. Its primitive elements: tree . . . grow late. 	 	 	I learned this one from the movie Evil Dead, but when it grows late, trees change shape and become spiny creatures! Lesson: don´t go out at night. 	 	On-Yomi: コウ、キョウ   Kun-Yomi: ふさぐ、やまにれ、おおむね"

palisade	"palisade 	 	柵   	   	Lesson: 48   Frame: 1968   Strokes: 9   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT:    	Constituents: palisade, tree, wood, tome 	 	Tree . . . tome. 	 	 	A palisade is a ""fence of stakes especially for defense,"" usually the stakes are very strong, set closely together, and pointed on top. Tome can be seen as a pictograph of several close-set wooden stakes, braced by one horizontal bar. 	 	On-Yomi: サク、サン   Kun-Yomi: しがら.む、しがらみ、とりで、やらい"

In many asian restaurants, meat is roasted right in front of you over flames. 	 	On-Yomi: セン   Kun-Yomi: せん.じる、い.る、に.る  	Examples: 煎る (い.る)"
marine blue	"marine blue 	 	瑠   	   	Lesson: 37   Frame: 1528   Strokes: 14   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: marine blue, king, jewel, ball, detain, receipt, dagger, sword, rice field, brains 	 	Jewel . . . detain. 	 	 	“The king has been detained by some marines!” “How do you know they were marines?” “Because they were wearing marine blue.”. 	 	On-Yomi: ル、リュウ   Kun-Yomi:"

toy	"toy 	 	玩   	   	Lesson: 12   Frame: 276   Strokes: 8   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT:    	Constituents: toy, king, jewel, ball, beginning, two, human legs 	 	If, at some aboriginal level, Toys Я Us, then the archetypal ball must have been there at the beginning, before evolving into beach balls, ping-pong balls, rugby balls, and marbles. 	 	 	The ball was the only thing that people at the beginning of time had to use as a toy. Poor cavemen. 	 	On-Yomi: ガン   Kun-Yomi: もちあそ.ぶ、もてあそ.ぶ"
apprehensive	"apprehensive 	 	畏   	   	Lesson: 52   Frame: 2069   Strokes: 9   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT:    	Constituents: apprehensive, rice field, brains, hairpin, safety-pin 	 	Field . . . hairpin. 	 	 	The girl was apprehensive about going home, having lost her precious hairpin in the paddy field. But then, it wasn't like she'd lost both, just ONE... basket	"basket 	 	篭・籠   	   	Lesson: 26   Frame: 1022   Strokes: 16   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT:    	Constituents: cage, bamboo, dragon, vase, stand up, eel, sun, day 	 	Bamboo . . . dragon. Note that the older (and still official) form of this kanji uses the old character for dragon 龍, which is good to learn and is fun to write in any case. It is made up of five primitive elements: vase . . . flesh . . . slingshot . . . fishhook (enclosure) . . . three. 	 	 	The only cage that can keep a dragon is made of bamboo. 	 	On-Yomi: ロウ、ル   Kun-Yomi: かご、こ.める、こも.る、こ.む"

Bamboo, lovedoll: At dinner, my lovedoll decided to eat her meal the Japanese way using chopsticks. But well, what a problems she had getting those bamboo shoots into her mouth (which should not be that difficult, I would say!). 	 	On-Yomi: チョ、チャク   Kun-Yomi: はし  	Examples: 箸 (はし)"

insult	"insult 	 	罵   	   	Lesson: 54   Frame: 2143   Strokes: 15   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT:    	Constituents: insult, eye, cross-eyed, net, team of horses 	 	Eyeball . . . team of horses. 	 	 	In ancient Japan, the most grievous insult was to poke a rival´s horse in the eye (consider how rare an expensive a steed was in those days). It was the final step in preparation for a duel to the death. 	 	On-Yomi: バ   Kun-Yomi: ののし.る  	Examples: 罵る (ののし.る)"

At Thanksgiving, it’s uncommon for people to accept humbly the food: most people just dig in. 	 	On-Yomi: タイ   Kun-Yomi: いただ.く"
