visit a shrine	"visit a shrine 	 	詣   	   	Lesson: 18   Frame: 495   Strokes: 13   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT:    	Constituents: visit a shrine, say, words, keitai, mouth, delicious, spoon, sitting on the ground, sun, day 	 	Here you ""savor your words"" as something delicious when you describe your recent visit to a shrine or pilgrimage site. 	 	 	To fat, effete Japanophiles (cheerily munching on 肉まん in the back of the tour bus) hearing the words of the tour guide ""Now we will visit a shrine"" elicits squeals of joy. ""Oooooh, how absolutely delicious!"". 	 	On-Yomi: ケイ、ゲイ   Kun-Yomi: けい.する、まい.る、いた.る、もう.でる  	Examples: 詣でる (もう.でる)"
renunciation	"renunciation 	 	諦   	   	Lesson: 18   Frame: 467   Strokes: 16   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT:    	Constituents: give up, say, words, keitai, mouth, sovereign, vase, stand up, apron, crown, towel 	 	The key word renunciation has to do with the wisdom and clarity of mind in knowing when to ""let go."" This is what makes the words of acquiescense sovern. 	 	 	The words of the sovereign king inspire the people: never give up! Never surrender! Okay...maybe it wasn´t a king. 	 	On-Yomi: テイ、タイ   Kun-Yomi: あき.らめる、あきら.める、つまびらか、まこと  	Examples: 諦める (あきら.める)"
elucidate	"elucidate 	 	詮   	   	Lesson: 15   Frame: 360   Strokes: 13   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT:    	Constituents: elucidate, say, words, keitai, mouth, whole, umbrella, king, jewel, ball 	 	Think of elucidating as presenting something in whole words, as distinct from broken fragmented sentences. 	 	 	Words that tell you the results of the whole story really elucidate. 	 	On-Yomi: セン   Kun-Yomi: せん.ずる、かい、あき.らか"
countenance	"countenance 	 	貌   	   	Lesson: 53   Frame: 2125   Strokes: 14   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT:    	Constituents: countenance, skunk, badger, white, dove, human legs 	 	Skunk . . . white . . . human legs. 	 	 	Anyone who watched a looney tunes cartoon know those kind of scene : pepe embraces a poor kitty mistaken for a SKUNK and the smell of pepe make the unfortunate girl loose all countenance : she turns WHITE then runs as fast as her LEGS can carry her . So much for cat s dignity and countenance. 	 	On-Yomi: ボウ、バク   Kun-Yomi: かたち、かたどる"
post a bill	"post a bill 	 	貼   	   	Lesson: 4   Frame: 60   Strokes: 12   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT:    	Constituents: affix, shellfish, clam, oyster, eye, animal legs, eight, fortune-telling, magic wand, augury, mouth 	 	The key word in this frame has do with posting bills to a billboard. In this case, the billboard is standing at the exit to a Chinese restaurant displaying the latest alternative to the tradition fortune-telling cookies. Look closely and you will see rows of leftover shells of clams with little slips of paper sticking out of them posted to the billboard. 	 	 	Fortune teller writes your fortune on a piece of paper and tells you to affix it to a shell and throw into the ocean for it to come true. Picture licking the back of the shell like a stamp and affixing it to the fortune. 	 	On-Yomi: テン、チョウ   Kun-Yomi: は.る、つ.く  	Examples: 貼る (は.る)"
graft	"graft 	 	賂   	   	Lesson: 14   Frame: 313   Strokes: 13   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT:    	Constituents: graft, shellfish, clam, oyster, eye, animal legs, eight, each, walking legs, mouth 	 	To those who believe in the inevitability of graft in government, everything has a price - or as this character has it, to each office its outlay of shells. 	 	 	It might sound simple to bribe someone, but then you have to graft the guy above him and the guy below him, and soon you´re just giving shells to each and everyone! 	 	On-Yomi: ロ   Kun-Yomi: まいな.い、まいな.う"
kick	"kick 	 	蹴   	   	Lesson: 53   Frame: 2122   Strokes: 19   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT:    	Constituents: kick, wooden leg, mouth, stop, footprint, concerning, capital, tall, top hat, mouth, small, little, understandably, chihuahua with one human leg, mouth2 	 	Wooden leg . . . concerning. hooch	"hooch 	 	酎   	   	Lesson: 38   Frame: 1537   Strokes: 10   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT:    	Constituents: hooch, whiskey bottle, glue 	 	This kanji is used for thick, low-grade saké made from various kinds of grains. Its primitives are: whisky bottle . . . glue. 	 	 	While the keyword is ""hooch"", this usually means 焼酎. It has similar effect as whiskey and sniffing glue has: you get intoxicated. 	 	On-Yomi: チュウ、チュ   Kun-Yomi: かも.す"

On awakening the first thing I notice is a (nearly empty) whiskey bottle by my bed. Then I see the stars are still shining. “I think I’ll go back to sleep and try awakening again later.”. about that time	"about that time 	 	頃   	   	Lesson: 18   Frame: 479   Strokes: 11   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT:    	Constituents: about that time, spoon, sitting on the ground, head, page, one, ceiling, drop, shellfish, clam, oyster, eye, animal legs, eight 	 	When Uncle Bob starts his comic routine of sticking spoons on his head, you know it is about that time to come up with a reason to excuse yourself. 	 	 	An alarm clock with a unique design: You set it for, say, 7:00 am, and at about that time the clock reaches out with a spoon and hits you on the head. 	 	On-Yomi: ケイ、キョウ   Kun-Yomi: ころ、ごろ、しばら.く  	Examples: 頃 (ころ)"

Your cheeks contain your jawbones, which are known as the ""scissors of the head."". 	 	On-Yomi: キョウ   Kun-Yomi: ほお、ほほ  	Examples: 頬 (ほお)"

Your chin is the part of your head under your nostrils that forms the double snare that is your jaw. 	 	On-Yomi: ガク   Kun-Yomi: あご、あぎと  	Examples: 顎 (あご)"
feed	"feed 	 	餌   	   	Lesson: 38   Frame: 1588   Strokes: 14   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT:    	Constituents: feed, eat, food, umbrella, good, halo, drop, silver, ear 	 	Food . . . ear. mochi	"mochi 	 	餅   	   	Lesson: 38   Frame: 1590   Strokes: 14   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT:    	Constituents: mochi, eat, food, umbrella, good, halo, drop, silver, puzzle, horns, two hands 	 	Mochi is the glutinous rice the Japanese pound into cakes. Its primitives are: food . . . puzzle. 	 	 	Call your friend and he answers the phone ""Mochi, mochi!"" whatever he is eating sure is making it hard to understand. I will puzzle over the content of our conversation for some time to come. 	 	On-Yomi: ヘイ、ヒョウ   Kun-Yomi: もち、もちい  	Examples: 餅 (もち)"
foot of a mountain	"foot of a mountain 	 	麓   	   	Lesson: 54   Frame: 2155   Strokes: 19   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT:    	Constituents: foot of a mountain, grove, tree, wood, deer, cave, antlers, compare, spoon, sitting on the ground, spoon2, sitting on the ground2 	 	Grove . . . deer. 	 	 	Many deer can be found in the grove at the foot of a mountain. 	 	On-Yomi: ロク   Kun-Yomi: ふもと  	Examples: 麓 (ふもと)"
Hades	"Hades 	 	冥   	   	Lesson: 14   Frame: 322   Strokes: 10   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT:    	Constituents: hades, crown, sun, day, six 	 	The key word in this frame refers to the underworld, the world of the dead. By way of the classic Greek association, it is also used for the ""dwarf planet"" Pluto. Since no one knows precisely when this part of the cosmos was finished, we may imagine it as the crowning deed of day six of the creation. 	 	 	The beast of hades one day will wear a crown, and the number of the beast is 666. 	 	On-Yomi: メイ、ミョウ   Kun-Yomi: くら.い"
sprain	"sprain 	 	挫   	   	Lesson: 27   Frame: 1101   Strokes: 10   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT:    	Constituents: sprain, finger, fingers, sitting in meditation, assembly line, person, soil, dirt, ground, person2 	 	Fingers . . . assembly line . . . soil. 	 	 	I sprained my fingers when I sat in meditation (by sitting in a strange position). 	 	On-Yomi: ザ、サ   Kun-Yomi: くじ.く、くじ.ける"
go upstream	"go upstream 	 	遡   	   	Lesson: 53   Frame: 2111   Strokes: 13   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT:    	Constituents: go upstream, first day of the month, mountain goat, horns, mountain, moon, month, flesh, part of the body, road 	 	Mountain goat . . . moon . . . road. 	 	 	You decide to go salmon fishing, so you ride a mountain goat to the top of the road. Under the light of the moon, as it's illegal, you catch the salmon going upstream. 	 	On-Yomi: ソ、サク   Kun-Yomi: さかのぼ.る  	Examples: 遡る (さかのぼ.る)"
bracing	"bracing 	 	爽   	   	Lesson: 39   Frame: 1608   Strokes: 11   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: bracing, large, St. Bernard, sheaf, sheaf4 	 	The sense of the key word is of something refreshing and invigorating. It is made up of the St. Bernard and a pair of sheaves on each side. 	 	 	The St Bernard is bracing itself for an operation requiring four stitches. 	 	On-Yomi: ソウ   Kun-Yomi: あき.らか、さわ.やか、たがう  	Examples: 爽やか (さわ.やか)"
uprising	"uprising 	 	勃   	   	Lesson: 25   Frame: 930   Strokes: 9   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT:    	Constituents: erection, bishop, cross, ten, needle, crown, child, power, muscle, arnold 	 	If you think of the ten as a little ""cross"" sitting atop the root of a house where we are used to seeing the ""chimney"" (drop), then you have the image of a chapel. (This combination will appear once more in this book: Frame 1465.) To complete the picture for uprising, add: child . . . muscles. 	 	 	An erection can shoot like a needle from its crown and has the power to make a child. 	 	On-Yomi: ボツ、ホツ   Kun-Yomi: おこ.る、にわかに"
remains	"remains 	 	骸   	   	Lesson: 39   Frame: 1641   Strokes: 16   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT:    	Constituents: remains, skeleton, joint, moon, month, flesh, part of the body, sign of the hog, acorn, top hat 	 	Skeleton . . . acorn. 	 	 	The remains consisted of a skeleton which had the remains of some acorns in its stomach area. Whether it died from eating the acorns remains to be seen. 	 	On-Yomi: ガイ、カイ   Kun-Yomi: むくろ"
relatives	"relatives 	 	戚   	   	Lesson: 17   Frame: 385   Strokes: 11   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT:    	Constituents: relatives, half-uncle, above, small, little, parade 	 	If you think of a parade of particularly disagreeable relatives, it should not be hard to imagine them as large bodies with little pea-brains above. 	 	 	Your half-uncle is leading a parade of your relatives. (Note: 上 + 小 makes up part of ""uncle"" 叔, so I´ve called it ""half-uncle"".). 	 	On-Yomi: ソク、セキ   Kun-Yomi: いた.む、うれ.える、みうち"
donburi	"donburi 	 	丼   	   	Lesson: 48 &nbsp; Frame: 1947 &nbsp; Strokes: 5 &nbsp; &mdash; &nbsp; Jouyou Grade: JH &nbsp; JLPT:    	Constituents: domburi, well, drop 	 	Donburi is a bowl of rice with eel or meat on it. The character is a pictograph, perhaps designed by someone who felt that the portion of meat he was served with his bowl of rice looked to be no more than a tiny drop in the well. 	 	 	A little one is eating a domburi while standing over, looking down into, a WELL. He drops it, and it falls down & down until it looks like nothing more than a DROP, landing at the bottom of the well! 	 	On-Yomi: トン、タン、ショウ、セイ &nbsp; Kun-Yomi: どんぶり  	Examples: 丼 (どんぶりどん)"
capital suburbs	"capital suburbs 	 	畿   	   	Lesson: 36   Frame: 1483   Strokes: 15   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT:    	Constituents: capital suburbs, cocoon, rice field, brains, fiesta, cocoon2 	 	Two cocoons . . . field . . . fiesta. 	 	 	People aside, I wonder how many rice fields there are in the capital suburbs. 	 	On-Yomi: キ   Kun-Yomi: みやこ"
fist	"fist 	 	拳   	   	Lesson: 32   Frame: 1290   Strokes: 10   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: fist, quarter, hand 	 	Quarter . . . hand. Be careful to keep this key word distinct from the primitive element of the same meaning we met back in Frame 741. 	 	 	1) I hold a roll of quarters in my hand when I make a fist. 2) I hold a quarter in my hand as I prepare to play the Iron Fist Tournament: 鉄拳 （てっけん） at the arcade. 	 	On-Yomi: ケン、ゲン   Kun-Yomi: こぶし  	Examples: 拳 (こぶし)"
large hill	"large hill 	 	阜   	   	Lesson: 34   Frame: 1360   Strokes: 8   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT:    	Constituents: large hill, maestro, ten, needle 	 	Maestro . . . needle. 	 	 	The maestro lives on top of a large hill so that he can play music at over ten decibels without anyone giving a damn. 	 	On-Yomi: フ、フウ   Kun-Yomi:"
interrogative	"interrogative 	 	那   	   	Lesson: 49   Frame: 1992   Strokes: 7   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT: 1   	Constituents: interrogative, sword, dagger, two, city walls 	 	Sword . . . two . . . city walls. Used classically to indicate an interrogative part of speech, this character is used chiefly now for its sound. 	 	 	If you arrive with two swords at the city walls, expect some interrogatives before they´ll let you in. 	 	On-Yomi: ナ、ダ   Kun-Yomi: なに、なんぞ、いかん"
stationery	"stationery 	 	箋・䇳   	   	Lesson: 26   Frame: 1011   Strokes: 12   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT:    	Constituents: stationery, bamboo, float, fiesta, float*, fiesta2 	 	Bamboo . . . float. Note that the drawing of the primitive for float uses the abbreviated form that has become standard in the general-use kanji and as we met it earlier (Frames 393-95). Until such time as typesetting fonts make the adjustment, only the older form has been approved. Here we have opted for the simpler, avant garde drawing. 	 	 	Note: the spelling should be stationery (= paper, office supplies), not stationary (= not moving). The error is in the original book. 	 	On-Yomi: セン   Kun-Yomi: ふだ"
glossary	"glossary 	 	彙   	   	Lesson: 31   Frame: 1237   Strokes: 13   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT:    	Constituents: glossary, broken broom, mutual, crown, fruit, rice field, brains, tree, wood, broom* 	 	The top primitive of this character is actually an old form of broom. The remaining elements are: crown . . . fruit. 	 	 	People who read the glossary are mutually exclusive (exclude the top line of mutually (#757) ) from those who eat crowned fruit イ はりねずみ same kind 語彙. 	 	On-Yomi: イ   Kun-Yomi: はりねずみ"
sniff	"sniff 	 	嗅   	   	Lesson: 7   Frame: 129   Strokes: 12   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT:    	Constituents:  	 	You have seen those scratch'n'sniff advertisements for perfumes. This one is for a mouthwash that replaces one stinking oder with another. 	 	 	Your mouth stinks: you need to sniff your breath. 	 	On-Yomi: キュウ   Kun-Yomi: か.ぐ"
metaphor	"metaphor 	 	喩・喻   	   	Lesson: 13   Frame: 308   Strokes: 12   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT:    	Constituents:  	 	People who try to sound literary often end up butchering the language. Here we see a meeting of butchers whose mouths are producing the metaphors. 	 	 	Metaphorically speaking, all the equipment in your mouth is basically just a meeting of butchers, designed to pulverize whatever meat you put in there. 	 	On-Yomi: ユ   Kun-Yomi: さと.す、 たと.える"
obituary	"obituary 	 	訃   	   	Lesson: 15   Frame: 363   Strokes: 9   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT:    	Constituents:  	 	The words of this obituary work like a magic wand, conjuring up the desceased. 	 	 	Obituary. As a famous man lay dying, the media were already preparing the words of his obituary until a magician, with a wave of his wand, restored the man back to health. 	 	On-Yomi: フ   Kun-Yomi: しらせ"
block letters	"block letters 	 	楷   	   	Lesson: 18   Frame: 485   Strokes: 13   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT:    	Constituents:  	 	The key word refers to kanji that are written in full, squared form, as opposed to cursive writing which is more flowing andabbreviates some of the strokes. Here block letters are pictured as tidy rows of trees that are all the same size and can be read easily by all, whatever calligraphic skills they possess. 	 	 	Block letters (as opposed to cursive) are rigid and lifeless like wood; they're all the same size so that all can read them. 	 	On-Yomi: カイ   Kun-Yomi:"
orderliness	"orderliness 	 	諧   	   	Lesson: 18   Frame: 486   Strokes: 16   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT:    	Constituents:  	 	The harmoney of ""a place for everything and everything in its place"" is applied here to the orderliness of all the words one speaks. 	 	 	To have orderliness, your words must be in all the right places. 	 	On-Yomi: カイ   Kun-Yomi: かな.う、 やわ.らぐ"
weld	"weld 	 	錮   	   	Lesson: 22   Frame: 623   Strokes: 16   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT:    	Constituents:  	 	Metal . . . harden. 	 	 	You weld metal in the knowledge that it will harden again. 	 	On-Yomi: コ   Kun-Yomi: ふさ.ぐ"
selfish	"selfish 	 	恣   	   	Lesson: 22   Frame: 641   Strokes: 10   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT:    	Constituents:  	 	Second . . . heart. 	 	 	A selfish person doesn't care about the next person's heart, only their own. 	 	On-Yomi: シ   Kun-Yomi: ほしいまま"
disquieting	"disquieting 	 	惧   	   	Lesson: 22   Frame: 680   Strokes: 11   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT:    	Constituents:  	 	State of mind . . . tool. 	 	 	My mind found the tool disquieting. 	 	On-Yomi: ク   Kun-Yomi: おそ.れる"
hanker	"hanker 	 	憬   	   	Lesson: 22   Frame: 682   Strokes: 15   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT:    	Constituents:  	 	State of mind . . . scenery. 	 	 	My mind hankers for sunrise over the capital. 	 	On-Yomi: ケイ   Kun-Yomi: あこが.れる"
yank	"yank 	 	拉   	   	Lesson: 23   Frame: 696   Strokes: 8   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT:    	Constituents:  	 	The sense of this key word is to pull or jerk, as in opening a door or making ""ramen"" noodles. Its elements: fingers . . . vase. 	 	 	He quickly yanked his fingers out of the vase. Maybe no one noticed the attempt to steal the cookies... 	 	On-Yomi: ラ、 ラツ、 ロウ   Kun-Yomi: くだ.く、 ひし.ぐ、 らっ.する"
arrogance	"arrogance 	 	傲   	   	Lesson: 27   Frame: 1054   Strokes: 13   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT:    	Constituents:  	 	Person . . . soil . . . compass . . . taskmaster. You may, of course, take the character for emulate from the previous frame as the basis for this kanji, adding to it only the element for soil. 	 	 	He showed his arrogance as he poured dirt on those who tried to emulate him. 	 	On-Yomi: ゴウ   Kun-Yomi: あなど.る、 おご.る"
trail	"trail 	 	踪   	   	Lesson: 34   Frame: 1382   Strokes: 15   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT:    	Constituents:  	 	Wooden leg . . . religion. The key word refers to a trail of footprints or tracks left behind. 	 	 	A trail of destruction is left by pirates and religion invaders. 	 	On-Yomi: ショウ、 ソウ   Kun-Yomi: あと"
fine	"fine 	 	緻   	   	Lesson: 36   Frame: 1437   Strokes: 16   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT:    	Constituents:  	 	The key word should be taken to mean minute, detailed, or nuanced. Its primitive elements are: thread . . . doth. 	 	 	THREAD, DOTH. fine THREADS DOTH make fine cloth. Think of a Shakespearean character stating this to someone else. Picture fine threads on one side of the picture and an aftershot of a fine cloth. 	 	On-Yomi: チ   Kun-Yomi: こまか.い"
holed gem	"holed gem 	 	璧   	   	Lesson: 39   Frame: 1617   Strokes: 18   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT:    	Constituents:  	 	The holed gem to which this kanji refers is a flat, circular object of about a foot in length, made of stone or glass and having a large hole in the middle. It's elements: ketchup . . . ball. 	 	 	Even more valuable and perfect (完璧) than a holed gem is a delicious meatball (ball = たま = 玉) with ketchup. Yum! 	 	On-Yomi: ヘキ   Kun-Yomi: たま"
clasp	"clasp 	 	摯   	   	Lesson: 39   Frame: 1624   Strokes: 15   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT:    	Constituents:  	 	Of the many and widely different meanings of this kanji, we select the verbal meaning of clasp, which fits in well with its primitive elements: tenacious . . . hand. 	 	 	When you clasp something you tenaciously 執 hold on to it with your hand 手, te. 真摯、しんし, sincerity, earnestness. 	 	On-Yomi: シ   Kun-Yomi: いた.る"
covet	"covet 	 	貪   	   	Lesson: 41   Frame: 1713   Strokes: 11   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT:    	Constituents:  	 	Clock . . . shellfish. 	 	 	Whatever you covet at the moment (now), can be bought with money. Well, _almost_ anything.... 	 	On-Yomi: タン、 トン   Kun-Yomi: むさぼ.る"
shudder	"shudder 	 	慄   	   	Lesson: 41   Frame: 1736   Strokes: 13   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT:    	Constituents:  	 	State of mind . . . chestnut. 	 	 	Shudder. If chestnut trees were sentient, shudder would be their state of mind as the tree shaker approaches. Note: Tree shakers are used commercially to harvest nuts and cider apples. A tree shaker makes a tree shudder causing all the ripe chestnuts to fall. 	 	On-Yomi: リツ   Kun-Yomi: おそ.れる、 おのの.く、 ふる.える"
bitter	"bitter 	 	辣   	   	Lesson: 43   Frame: 1798   Strokes: 14   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT:    	Constituents:  	 	Spicy . . . bundle. 	 	 	The bitter taste was so awful that I put whole bundle of spice in my mouth to get rid of it. 	 	On-Yomi: ラツ   Kun-Yomi: から.い"
carbuncle	"carbuncle 	 	瘍   	   	Lesson: 44   Frame: 1817   Strokes: 14   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT:    	Constituents:  	 	Sickness . . . piggy bank. 	 	 	His sickness caused numerous carbuncles, which when emptied by the doctors also emptied his piggy bank. 	 	On-Yomi: ヨウ   Kun-Yomi: かさ"
suckle	"suckle 	 	哺   	   	Lesson: 49   Frame: 1979   Strokes: 10   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT:    	Constituents:  	 	Mouth . . . dog tag. 	 	 	The scaredy-cat soldier puts his dog tags in his mouth and suckles them nervously. It sounds like he's a suckling infant. 	 	On-Yomi: ホ   Kun-Yomi: はぐく.む、 ふく.む"
gloom	"gloom 	 	鬱   	   	Lesson: 53   Frame: 2120   Strokes: 29   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT:    	Constituents:  	 	Learning this character will take a little doing. Before we start, it is a good idea to keep the key word distinct from melancholy (Frame 663), with which it combines to create the psychological condition of depression (a metaphor based on the hollow or sinking of the material depression we met in Frame 1421). The picture of gloom begins with a small grove of trees, under which we see a crown made out of used tin cans. Next (the lower half of the kanji) we find a combination that appears only a few times in modern characters and only once in those treated in the volumes of Remembering the Kanji. It is composed of a shovel with a sheaf dotted with small drops on all sides. Think of it as a large scoop shovel attached to the front of a bulldozer, whose driver is singing: ♪ ""Bulldozing in the sheaves, bulldozing in the sheaves..."" ♪ The drops represent the chaff flying about as the sheaves are tossed about by the heavy machinery. There is someone sitting on the ground alongside, watching as the machinery makes its way around the neighboring farmland - and it's you, wearing your tin-can crown. You feel overwhelmed by the impending doom as the invasion of agro-business draws closer and closer to the grove, the only patch of woods that remains of what once was a vast forest. The whole scene represents a re-shaping of the natural environment that brings the heavy weight of gloom down upon you. A bit much, perhaps, but there are enough elements to allow for any number of other combinations. 	 	 	The pixie, wearing a tin can crown, watches from the middle of the grove, the sparkling villain approach. She sits down in gloom wondering if she belongs amongst the trees, for she has never seen such a beautiful shape. 	 	On-Yomi: ウツ   Kun-Yomi: うっ.する、 しげ.る、 ふさ.ぐ"
humiliate	"humiliate 	 	羞   	   	Lesson: 56   Frame: 2198   Strokes: 11   —   Jouyou Grade: JH   JLPT:    	Constituents:  	 	Wool . . sign of the cow. 	 	 	The sheep had his coat shaven in the winter and a sign of th cow branded on him. How humiliating. 	 	On-Yomi: シュウ   Kun-Yomi: すすめ.る、 はじ.る、 は.ずかしい"
